children.name: Paragraph_1
children.value: OLIVER MINGLES WITH NEW ASSOCIATES.  GOING TO A FUNERAL FOR THE FIRST TIME, HE FORMS AN UNFAVOURABLE NOTION OF HIS MASTER'S BUSINESS
children.prevalue: OLIVER MINGLES WITH NEW ASSOCIATES GOING TO A FUNERAL FOR THE FIRST TIME HE FORMS AN UNFAVOURABLE NOTION OF HIS MASTER S BUSINESS

children.name: Paragraph_2
children.value: Oliver, being left to himself in the undertaker's shop, set the lamp down on a workman's bench, and gazed timidly about him with a feeling of awe and dread, which many people a good deal older than he will be at no loss to understand.  An unfinished coffin on black tressels, which stood in the middle of the shop, looked so gloomy and death-like that a cold tremble came over him, every time his eyes wandered in the direction of the dismal object: from which he almost expected to see some frightful form slowly rear its head, to drive him mad with terror. Against the wall were ranged, in regular array, a long row of elm boards cut in the same shape: looking in the dim light, like high-shouldered ghosts with their hands in their breeches pockets. Coffin-plates, elm-chips, bright-headed nails, and shreds of black cloth, lay scattered on the floor; and the wall behind the counter was ornamented with a lively representation of two mutes in very stiff neckcloths, on duty at a large private door, with a hearse drawn by four black steeds, approaching in the distance. The shop was close and hot.  The atmosphere seemed tainted with the smell of coffins.  The recess beneath the counter in which his flock mattress was thrust, looked like a grave.
children.prevalue: Oliver being left to himself in the undertaker s shop set the lamp down on a workman s bench and gazed timidly about him with a feeling of awe and dread which many people a good deal older than he will be at no loss to understand An unfinished coffin on black tressels which stood in the middle of the shop looked so gloomy and death like that a cold tremble came over him every time his eyes wandered in the direction of the dismal object from which he almost expected to see some frightful form slowly rear its head to drive him mad with terror Against the wall were ranged in regular array a long row of elm boards cut in the same shape looking in the dim light like high shouldered ghosts with their hands in their breeches pockets Coffin plates elm chips bright headed nails and shreds of black cloth lay scattered on the floor and the wall behind the counter was ornamented with a lively representation of two mutes in very stiff neckcloths on duty at a large private door with a hearse drawn by four black steeds approaching in the distance The shop was close and hot The atmosphere seemed tainted with the smell of coffins The recess beneath the counter in which his flock mattress was thrust looked like a grave

children.name: Paragraph_3
children.value: Nor were these the only dismal feelings which depressed Oliver. He was alone in a strange place; and we all know how chilled and desolate the best of us will sometimes feel in such a situation. The boy had no friends to care for, or to care for him.  The regret of no recent separation was fresh in his mind; the absence of no loved and well-remembered face sank heavily into his heart.
children.prevalue: Nor were these the only dismal feelings which depressed Oliver He was alone in a strange place and we all know how chilled and desolate the best of us will sometimes feel in such a situation The boy had no friends to care for or to care for him The regret of no recent separation was fresh in his mind the absence of no loved and well remembered face sank heavily into his heart

children.name: Paragraph_4
children.value: But his heart was heavy, notwithstanding; and he wished, as he crept into his narrow bed, that that were his coffin, and that he could be lain in a calm and lasting sleep in the churchyard ground, with the tall grass waving gently above his head, and the sound of the old deep bell to soothe him in his sleep.
children.prevalue: But his heart was heavy notwithstanding and he wished as he crept into his narrow bed that that were his coffin and that he could be lain in a calm and lasting sleep in the churchyard ground with the tall grass waving gently above his head and the sound of the old deep bell to soothe him in his sleep

children.name: Paragraph_5
children.value: Oliver was awakened in the morning, by a loud kicking at the outside of the shop-door: which, before he could huddle on his clothes, was repeated, in an angry and impetuous manner, about twenty-five times. When he began to undo the chain, the legs desisted, and a voice began.
children.prevalue: Oliver was awakened in the morning by a loud kicking at the outside of the shop door which before he could huddle on his clothes was repeated in an angry and impetuous manner about twenty five times When he began to undo the chain the legs desisted and a voice began

children.name: Paragraph_6
children.value: 'Open the door, will yer?' cried the voice which belonged to the legs which had kicked at the door.
children.prevalue: Open the door will yer cried the voice which belonged to the legs which had kicked at the door

children.name: Paragraph_7
children.value: 'I will, directly, sir,' replied Oliver: undoing the chain, and turning the key.
children.prevalue: I will directly sir replied Oliver undoing the chain and turning the key

children.name: Paragraph_8
children.value: 'I suppose yer the new boy, ain't yer?' said the voice through the key-hole.
children.prevalue: I suppose yer the new boy ain t yer said the voice through the key hole

children.name: Paragraph_9
children.value: 'Yes, sir,' replied Oliver.
children.prevalue: Yes sir replied Oliver

children.name: Paragraph_10
children.value: 'How old are yer?' inquired the voice.
children.prevalue: How old are yer inquired the voice

children.name: Paragraph_11
children.value: 'Ten, sir,' replied Oliver.
children.prevalue: Ten sir replied Oliver

children.name: Paragraph_12
children.value: 'Then I'll whop yer when I get in,' said the voice; 'you just see if I don't, that's all, my work'us brat!' and having made this obliging promise, the voice began to whistle.
children.prevalue: Then I ll whop yer when I get in said the voice you just see if I don t that s all my work us brat and having made this obliging promise the voice began to whistle

children.name: Paragraph_13
children.value: Oliver had been too often subjected to the process to which the very expressive monosyllable just recorded bears reference, to entertain the smallest doubt that the owner of the voice, whoever he might be, would redeem his pledge, most honourably. He drew back the bolts with a trembling hand, and opened the door.
children.prevalue: Oliver had been too often subjected to the process to which the very expressive monosyllable just recorded bears reference to entertain the smallest doubt that the owner of the voice whoever he might be would redeem his pledge most honourably He drew back the bolts with a trembling hand and opened the door

children.name: Paragraph_14
children.value: For a second or two, Oliver glanced up the street, and down the street, and over the way: impressed with the belief that the unknown, who had addressed him through the key-hole, had walked a few paces off, to warm himself; for nobody did he see but a big charity-boy, sitting on a post in front of the house, eating a slice of bread and butter: which he cut into wedges, the size of his mouth, with a clasp-knife, and then consumed with great dexterity.
children.prevalue: For a second or two Oliver glanced up the street and down the street and over the way impressed with the belief that the unknown who had addressed him through the key hole had walked a few paces off to warm himself for nobody did he see but a big charity boy sitting on a post in front of the house eating a slice of bread and butter which he cut into wedges the size of his mouth with a clasp knife and then consumed with great dexterity

children.name: Paragraph_15
children.value: 'I beg your pardon, sir,' said Oliver at length: seeing that no other visitor made his appearance; 'did you knock?'
children.prevalue: I beg your pardon sir said Oliver at length seeing that no other visitor made his appearance did you knock

children.name: Paragraph_16
children.value: 'I kicked,' replied the charity-boy.
children.prevalue: I kicked replied the charity boy

children.name: Paragraph_17
children.value: 'Did you want a coffin, sir?' inquired Oliver, innocently.
children.prevalue: Did you want a coffin sir inquired Oliver innocently

children.name: Paragraph_18
children.value: At this, the charity-boy looked monstrous fierce; and said that Oliver would want one before long, if he cut jokes with his superiors in that way.
children.prevalue: At this the charity boy looked monstrous fierce and said that Oliver would want one before long if he cut jokes with his superiors in that way

children.name: Paragraph_19
children.value: 'Yer don't know who I am, I suppose, Work'us?' said the charity-boy, in continuation: descending from the top of the post, meanwhile, with edifying gravity.
children.prevalue: Yer don t know who I am I suppose Work us said the charity boy in continuation descending from the top of the post meanwhile with edifying gravity

children.name: Paragraph_20
children.value: 'No, sir,' rejoined Oliver.
children.prevalue: No sir rejoined Oliver

children.name: Paragraph_21
children.value: 'I'm Mister Noah Claypole,' said the charity-boy, 'and you're under me. Take down the shutters, yer idle young ruffian!' With this, Mr. Claypole administered a kick to Oliver, and entered the shop with a dignified air, which did him great credit.  It is difficult for a large-headed, small-eyed youth, of lumbering make and heavy countenance, to look dignified under any circumstances; but it is more especially so, when superadded to these personal attractions are a red nose and yellow smalls.
children.prevalue: I m Mister Noah Claypole said the charity boy and you re under me Take down the shutters yer idle young ruffian With this Mr Claypole administered a kick to Oliver and entered the shop with a dignified air which did him great credit It is difficult for a large headed small eyed youth of lumbering make and heavy countenance to look dignified under any circumstances but it is more especially so when superadded to these personal attractions are a red nose and yellow smalls

children.name: Paragraph_22
children.value: Oliver, having taken down the shutters, and broken a pane of glass in his effort to stagger away beneath the weight of the first one to a small court at the side of the house in which they were kept during the day, was graciously assisted by Noah: who having consoled him with the assurance that 'he'd catch it,' condescended to help him.  Mr. Sowerberry came down soon after. Shortly afterwards, Mrs. Sowerberry appeared.  Oliver having 'caught it,' in fulfilment of Noah's prediction, followed that young gentleman down the stairs to breakfast.
children.prevalue: Oliver having taken down the shutters and broken a pane of glass in his effort to stagger away beneath the weight of the first one to a small court at the side of the house in which they were kept during the day was graciously assisted by Noah who having consoled him with the assurance that he d catch it condescended to help him Mr Sowerberry came down soon after Shortly afterwards Mrs Sowerberry appeared Oliver having caught it in fulfilment of Noah s prediction followed that young gentleman down the stairs to breakfast

children.name: Paragraph_23
children.value: 'Come near the fire, Noah,' said Charlotte.  'I saved a nice little bit of bacon for you from master's breakfast.  Oliver, shut that door at Mister Noah's back, and take them bits that I've put out on the cover of the bread-pan.  There's your tea; take it away to that box, and drink it there, and make haste, for they'll want you to mind the shop. D'ye hear?'
children.prevalue: Come near the fire Noah said Charlotte I saved a nice little bit of bacon for you from master s breakfast Oliver shut that door at Mister Noah s back and take them bits that I ve put out on the cover of the bread pan There s your tea take it away to that box and drink it there and make haste for they ll want you to mind the shop D ye hear

children.name: Paragraph_24
children.value: 'D'ye hear, Work'us?' said Noah Claypole.
children.prevalue: D ye hear Work us said Noah Claypole

children.name: Paragraph_25
children.value: 'Lor, Noah!' said Charlotte, 'what a rum creature you are!  Why don't you let the boy alone?'
children.prevalue: Lor Noah said Charlotte what a rum creature you are Why don t you let the boy alone

children.name: Paragraph_26
children.value: 'Let him alone!' said Noah.  'Why everybody lets him alone enough, for the matter of that.  Neither his father nor his mother will ever interfere with him.  All his relations let him have his own way pretty well.  Eh, Charlotte?  He! he! he!'
children.prevalue: Let him alone said Noah Why everybody lets him alone enough for the matter of that Neither his father nor his mother will ever interfere with him All his relations let him have his own way pretty well Eh Charlotte He he he

children.name: Paragraph_27
children.value: 'Oh, you queer soul!' said Charlotte, bursting into a hearty laugh, in which she was joined by Noah; after which they both looked scornfully at poor Oliver Twist, as he sat shivering on the box in the coldest corner of the room, and ate the stale pieces which had been specially reserved for him.
children.prevalue: Oh you queer soul said Charlotte bursting into a hearty laugh in which she was joined by Noah after which they both looked scornfully at poor Oliver Twist as he sat shivering on the box in the coldest corner of the room and ate the stale pieces which had been specially reserved for him

children.name: Paragraph_28
children.value: Noah was a charity-boy, but not a workhouse orphan.  No chance-child was he, for he could trace his genealogy all the way back to his parents, who lived hard by; his mother being a washerwoman, and his father a drunken soldier, discharged with a wooden leg, and a diurnal pension of twopence-halfpenny and an unstateable fraction.  The shop-boys in the neighbourhood had long been in the habit of branding Noah in the public streets, with the ignominious epithets of 'leathers,' 'charity,' and the like; and Noah had bourne them without reply.  But, now that fortune had cast in his way a nameless orphan, at whom even the meanest could point the finger of scorn, he retorted on him with interest.  This affords charming food for contemplation.  It shows us what a beautiful thing human nature may be made to be; and how impartially the same amiable qualities are developed in the finest lord and the dirtiest charity-boy.
children.prevalue: Noah was a charity boy but not a workhouse orphan No chance child was he for he could trace his genealogy all the way back to his parents who lived hard by his mother being a washerwoman and his father a drunken soldier discharged with a wooden leg and a diurnal pension of twopence halfpenny and an unstateable fraction The shop boys in the neighbourhood had long been in the habit of branding Noah in the public streets with the ignominious epithets of leathers charity and the like and Noah had bourne them without reply But now that fortune had cast in his way a nameless orphan at whom even the meanest could point the finger of scorn he retorted on him with interest This affords charming food for contemplation It shows us what a beautiful thing human nature may be made to be and how impartially the same amiable qualities are developed in the finest lord and the dirtiest charity boy

children.name: Paragraph_29
children.value: Oliver had been sojourning at the undertaker's some three weeks or a month.  Mr. and Mrs. Sowerberry--the shop being shut up--were taking their supper in the little back-parlour, when Mr. Sowerberry, after several deferential glances at his wife, said,
children.prevalue: Oliver had been sojourning at the undertaker s some three weeks or a month Mr and Mrs Sowerberry the shop being shut up were taking their supper in the little back parlour when Mr Sowerberry after several deferential glances at his wife said

children.name: Paragraph_30
children.value: 'My dear--'  He was going to say more; but, Mrs. Sowerberry looking up, with a peculiarly unpropitious aspect, he stopped short.
children.prevalue: My dear He was going to say more but Mrs Sowerberry looking up with a peculiarly unpropitious aspect he stopped short

children.name: Paragraph_31
children.value: 'Well,' said Mrs. Sowerberry, sharply.
children.prevalue: Well said Mrs Sowerberry sharply

children.name: Paragraph_32
children.value: 'Nothing, my dear, nothing,' said Mr. Sowerberry.
children.prevalue: Nothing my dear nothing said Mr Sowerberry

children.name: Paragraph_33
children.value: 'Ugh, you brute!' said Mrs. Sowerberry.
children.prevalue: Ugh you brute said Mrs Sowerberry

children.name: Paragraph_34
children.value: 'Not at all, my dear,' said Mr. Sowerberry humbly.  'I thought you didn't want to hear, my dear.  I was only going to say--'
children.prevalue: Not at all my dear said Mr Sowerberry humbly I thought you didn t want to hear my dear I was only going to say

children.name: Paragraph_35
children.value: 'Oh, don't tell me what you were going to say,' interposed Mrs. Sowerberry.  'I am nobody; don't consult me, pray.  I don't want to intrude upon your secrets.'  As Mrs. Sowerberry said this, she gave an hysterical laugh, which threatened violent consequences.
children.prevalue: Oh don t tell me what you were going to say interposed Mrs Sowerberry I am nobody don t consult me pray I don t want to intrude upon your secrets As Mrs Sowerberry said this she gave an hysterical laugh which threatened violent consequences

children.name: Paragraph_36
children.value: 'But, my dear,' said Sowerberry, 'I want to ask your advice.'
children.prevalue: But my dear said Sowerberry I want to ask your advice

children.name: Paragraph_37
children.value: 'No, no, don't ask mine,' replied Mrs. Sowerberry, in an affecting manner: 'ask somebody else's.'  Here, there was another hysterical laugh, which frightened Mr. Sowerberry very much.  This is a very common and much-approved matrimonial course of treatment, which is often very effective. It at once reduced Mr. Sowerberry to begging, as a special favour, to be allowed to say what Mrs. Sowerberry was most curious to hear.  After a short duration, the permission was most graciously conceded.
children.prevalue: No no don t ask mine replied Mrs Sowerberry in an affecting manner ask somebody else s Here there was another hysterical laugh which frightened Mr Sowerberry very much This is a very common and much approved matrimonial course of treatment which is often very effective It at once reduced Mr Sowerberry to begging as a special favour to be allowed to say what Mrs Sowerberry was most curious to hear After a short duration the permission was most graciously conceded

children.name: Paragraph_38
children.value: 'It's only about young Twist, my dear,' said Mr. Sowerberry. 'A very good-looking boy, that, my dear.'
children.prevalue: It s only about young Twist my dear said Mr Sowerberry A very good looking boy that my dear

children.name: Paragraph_39
children.value: 'He need be, for he eats enough,' observed the lady.
children.prevalue: He need be for he eats enough observed the lady

children.name: Paragraph_40
children.value: 'There's an expression of melancholy in his face, my dear,' resumed Mr. Sowerberry, 'which is very interesting.  He would make a delightful mute, my love.'
children.prevalue: There s an expression of melancholy in his face my dear resumed Mr Sowerberry which is very interesting He would make a delightful mute my love

children.name: Paragraph_41
children.value: Mrs. Sowerberry looked up with an expression of considerable wonderment.  Mr. Sowerberry remarked it and, without allowing time for any observation on the good lady's part, proceeded.
children.prevalue: Mrs Sowerberry looked up with an expression of considerable wonderment Mr Sowerberry remarked it and without allowing time for any observation on the good lady s part proceeded

children.name: Paragraph_42
children.value: 'I don't mean a regular mute to attend grown-up people, my dear, but only for children's practice.  It would be very new to have a mute in proportion, my dear.  You may depend upon it, it would have a superb effect.'
children.prevalue: I don t mean a regular mute to attend grown up people my dear but only for children s practice It would be very new to have a mute in proportion my dear You may depend upon it it would have a superb effect

children.name: Paragraph_43
children.value: Mrs. Sowerberry, who had a good deal of taste in the undertaking way, was much struck by the novelty of this idea; but, as it would have been compromising her dignity to have said so, under existing circumstances, she merely inquired, with much sharpness, why such an obvious suggestion had not presented itself to her husband's mind before?  Mr. Sowerberry rightly construed this, as an acquiescence in his proposition; it was speedily determined, therefore, that Oliver should be at once initiated into the mysteries of the trade; and, with this view, that he should accompany his master on the very next occasion of his services being required.
children.prevalue: Mrs Sowerberry who had a good deal of taste in the undertaking way was much struck by the novelty of this idea but as it would have been compromising her dignity to have said so under existing circumstances she merely inquired with much sharpness why such an obvious suggestion had not presented itself to her husband s mind before Mr Sowerberry rightly construed this as an acquiescence in his proposition it was speedily determined therefore that Oliver should be at once initiated into the mysteries of the trade and with this view that he should accompany his master on the very next occasion of his services being required

children.name: Paragraph_44
children.value: The occasion was not long in coming.  Half an hour after breakfast next morning, Mr. Bumble entered the shop; and supporting his cane against the counter, drew forth his large leathern pocket-book: from which he selected a small scrap of paper, which he handed over to Sowerberry.
children.prevalue: The occasion was not long in coming Half an hour after breakfast next morning Mr Bumble entered the shop and supporting his cane against the counter drew forth his large leathern pocket book from which he selected a small scrap of paper which he handed over to Sowerberry

children.name: Paragraph_45
children.value: 'Aha!' said the undertaker, glancing over it with a lively countenance; 'an order for a coffin, eh?'
children.prevalue: Aha said the undertaker glancing over it with a lively countenance an order for a coffin eh

children.name: Paragraph_46
children.value: 'For a coffin first, and a porochial funeral afterwards,' replied Mr. Bumble, fastening the strap of the leathern pocket-book: which, like himself, was very corpulent.
children.prevalue: For a coffin first and a porochial funeral afterwards replied Mr Bumble fastening the strap of the leathern pocket book which like himself was very corpulent

children.name: Paragraph_47
children.value: 'Bayton,' said the undertaker, looking from the scrap of paper to Mr. Bumble.  'I never heard the name before.'
children.prevalue: Bayton said the undertaker looking from the scrap of paper to Mr Bumble I never heard the name before

children.name: Paragraph_48
children.value: Bumble shook his head, as he replied, 'Obstinate people, Mr. Sowerberry; very obstinate.  Proud, too, I'm afraid, sir.'
children.prevalue: Bumble shook his head as he replied Obstinate people Mr Sowerberry very obstinate Proud too I m afraid sir

children.name: Paragraph_49
children.value: 'Proud, eh?' exclaimed Mr. Sowerberry with a sneer.  'Come, that's too much.'
children.prevalue: Proud eh exclaimed Mr Sowerberry with a sneer Come that s too much

children.name: Paragraph_50
children.value: 'Oh, it's sickening,' replied the beadle.  'Antimonial, Mr. Sowerberry!'
children.prevalue: Oh it s sickening replied the beadle Antimonial Mr Sowerberry

children.name: Paragraph_51
children.value: 'So it is,' acquiesced the undertaker.
children.prevalue: So it is acquiesced the undertaker

children.name: Paragraph_52
children.value: 'We only heard of the family the night before last,' said the beadle; 'and we shouldn't have known anything about them, then, only a woman who lodges in the same house made an application to the porochial committee for them to send the porochial surgeon to see a woman as was very bad.  He had gone out to dinner; but his 'prentice (which is a very clever lad) sent 'em some medicine in a blacking-bottle, offhand.'
children.prevalue: We only heard of the family the night before last said the beadle and we shouldn t have known anything about them then only a woman who lodges in the same house made an application to the porochial committee for them to send the porochial surgeon to see a woman as was very bad He had gone out to dinner but his prentice which is a very clever lad sent em some medicine in a blacking bottle offhand

children.name: Paragraph_53
children.value: 'Ah, there's promptness,' said the undertaker.
children.prevalue: Ah there s promptness said the undertaker

children.name: Paragraph_54
children.value: 'Promptness, indeed!' replied the beadle.  'But what's the consequence; what's the ungrateful behaviour of these rebels, sir?  Why, the husband sends back word that the medicine won't suit his wife's complaint, and so she shan't take it--says she shan't take it, sir!  Good, strong, wholesome medicine, as was given with great success to two Irish labourers and a coal-heaver, only a week before--sent 'em for nothing, with a blackin'-bottle in,--and he sends back word that she shan't take it, sir!'
children.prevalue: Promptness indeed replied the beadle But what s the consequence what s the ungrateful behaviour of these rebels sir Why the husband sends back word that the medicine won t suit his wife s complaint and so she shan t take it says she shan t take it sir Good strong wholesome medicine as was given with great success to two Irish labourers and a coal heaver only a week before sent em for nothing with a blackin bottle in and he sends back word that she shan t take it sir

children.name: Paragraph_55
children.value: As the atrocity presented itself to Mr. Bumble's mind in full force, he struck the counter sharply with his cane, and became flushed with indignation.
children.prevalue: As the atrocity presented itself to Mr Bumble s mind in full force he struck the counter sharply with his cane and became flushed with indignation

children.name: Paragraph_56
children.value: 'Well,' said the undertaker, 'I ne--ver--did--'
children.prevalue: Well said the undertaker I ne ver did

children.name: Paragraph_57
children.value: 'Never did, sir!' ejaculated the beadle.  'No, nor nobody never did; but now she's dead, we've got to bury her; and that's the direction; and the sooner it's done, the better.'
children.prevalue: Never did sir ejaculated the beadle No nor nobody never did but now she s dead we ve got to bury her and that s the direction and the sooner it s done the better

children.name: Paragraph_58
children.value: Thus saying, Mr. Bumble put on his cocked hat wrong side first, in a fever of parochial excitement; and flounced out of the shop.
children.prevalue: Thus saying Mr Bumble put on his cocked hat wrong side first in a fever of parochial excitement and flounced out of the shop

children.name: Paragraph_59
children.value: 'Why, he was so angry, Oliver, that he forgot even to ask after you!' said Mr. Sowerberry, looking after the beadle as he strode down the street.
children.prevalue: Why he was so angry Oliver that he forgot even to ask after you said Mr Sowerberry looking after the beadle as he strode down the street

children.name: Paragraph_60
children.value: 'Yes, sir,' replied Oliver, who had carefully kept himself out of sight, during the interview; and who was shaking from head to foot at the mere recollection of the sound of Mr. Bumble's voice.
children.prevalue: Yes sir replied Oliver who had carefully kept himself out of sight during the interview and who was shaking from head to foot at the mere recollection of the sound of Mr Bumble s voice

children.name: Paragraph_61
children.value: He needn't haven taken the trouble to shrink from Mr. Bumble's glance, however; for that functionary, on whom the prediction of the gentleman in the white waistcoat had made a very strong impression, thought that now the undertaker had got Oliver upon trial the subject was better avoided, until such time as he should be firmly bound for seven years, and all danger of his being returned upon the hands of the parish should be thus effectually and legally overcome.
children.prevalue: He needn t haven taken the trouble to shrink from Mr Bumble s glance however for that functionary on whom the prediction of the gentleman in the white waistcoat had made a very strong impression thought that now the undertaker had got Oliver upon trial the subject was better avoided until such time as he should be firmly bound for seven years and all danger of his being returned upon the hands of the parish should be thus effectually and legally overcome

children.name: Paragraph_62
children.value: 'Well,' said Mr. Sowerberry, taking up his hat, 'the sooner this job is done, the better.  Noah, look after the shop. Oliver, put on your cap, and come with me.'  Oliver obeyed, and followed his master on his professional mission.
children.prevalue: Well said Mr Sowerberry taking up his hat the sooner this job is done the better Noah look after the shop Oliver put on your cap and come with me Oliver obeyed and followed his master on his professional mission

children.name: Paragraph_63
children.value: They walked on, for some time, through the most crowded and densely inhabited part of the town; and then, striking down a narrow street more dirty and miserable than any they had yet passed through, paused to look for the house which was the object of their search.  The houses on either side were high and large, but very old, and tenanted by people of the poorest class: as their neglected appearance would have sufficiently denoted, without the concurrent testimony afforded by the squalid looks of the few men and women who, with folded arms and bodies half doubled, occasionally skulked along.  A great many of the tenements had shop-fronts; but these were fast closed, and mouldering away; only the upper rooms being inhabited.  Some houses which had become insecure from age and decay, were prevented from falling into the street, by huge beams of wood reared against the walls, and firmly planted in the road; but even these crazy dens seemed to have been selected as the nightly haunts of some houseless wretches, for many of the rough boards which supplied the place of door and window, were wrenched from their positions, to afford an aperture wide enough for the passage of a human body.  The kennel was stagnant and filthy. The very rats, which here and there lay putrefying in its rottenness, were hideous with famine.

children.name: Paragraph_64
children.value: There was neither knocker nor bell-handle at the open door where Oliver and his master stopped; so, groping his way cautiously through the dark passage, and bidding Oliver keep close to him and not be afraid the undertaker mounted to the top of the first flight of stairs.  Stumbling against a door on the landing, he rapped at it with his knuckles.
children.prevalue: There was neither knocker nor bell handle at the open door where Oliver and his master stopped so groping his way cautiously through the dark passage and bidding Oliver keep close to him and not be afraid the undertaker mounted to the top of the first flight of stairs Stumbling against a door on the landing he rapped at it with his knuckles

children.name: Paragraph_65
children.value: It was opened by a young girl of thirteen or fourteen.  The undertaker at once saw enough of what the room contained, to know it was the apartment to which he had been directed.  He stepped in; Oliver followed him.
children.prevalue: It was opened by a young girl of thirteen or fourteen The undertaker at once saw enough of what the room contained to know it was the apartment to which he had been directed He stepped in Oliver followed him

children.name: Paragraph_66
children.value: There was no fire in the room; but a man was crouching, mechanically, over the empty stove.  An old woman, too, had drawn a low stool to the cold hearth, and was sitting beside him. There were some ragged children in another corner; and in a small recess, opposite the door, there lay upon the ground, something covered with an old blanket. Oliver shuddered as he cast his eyes toward the place, and crept involuntarily closer to his master; for though it was covered up, the boy felt that it was a corpse.
children.prevalue: There was no fire in the room but a man was crouching mechanically over the empty stove An old woman too had drawn a low stool to the cold hearth and was sitting beside him There were some ragged children in another corner and in a small recess opposite the door there lay upon the ground something covered with an old blanket Oliver shuddered as he cast his eyes toward the place and crept involuntarily closer to his master for though it was covered up the boy felt that it was a corpse

children.name: Paragraph_67
children.value: The man's face was thin and very pale; his hair and beard were grizzly; his eyes were bloodshot.  The old woman's face was wrinkled; her two remaining teeth protruded over her under lip; and her eyes were bright and piercing.  Oliver was afraid to look at either her or the man. They seemed so like the rats he had seen outside.
children.prevalue: The man s face was thin and very pale his hair and beard were grizzly his eyes were bloodshot The old woman s face was wrinkled her two remaining teeth protruded over her under lip and her eyes were bright and piercing Oliver was afraid to look at either her or the man They seemed so like the rats he had seen outside

children.name: Paragraph_68
children.value: 'Nobody shall go near her,' said the man, starting fiercely up, as the undertaker approached the recess. 'Keep back! Damn you, keep back, if you've a life to lose!'
children.prevalue: Nobody shall go near her said the man starting fiercely up as the undertaker approached the recess Keep back Damn you keep back if you ve a life to lose

children.name: Paragraph_69
children.value: 'Nonsense, my good man,' said the undertaker, who was pretty well used to misery in all its shapes.  'Nonsense!'
children.prevalue: Nonsense my good man said the undertaker who was pretty well used to misery in all its shapes Nonsense

children.name: Paragraph_70
children.value: 'I tell you,' said the man:  clenching his hands, and stamping furiously on the floor,--'I tell you I won't have her put into the ground.  She couldn't rest there.  The worms would worry her--not eat her--she is so worn away.'
children.prevalue: I tell you said the man clenching his hands and stamping furiously on the floor I tell you I won t have her put into the ground She couldn t rest there The worms would worry her not eat her she is so worn away

children.name: Paragraph_71
children.value: The undertaker offered no reply to this raving; but producing a tape from his pocket, knelt down for a moment by the side of the body.
children.prevalue: The undertaker offered no reply to this raving but producing a tape from his pocket knelt down for a moment by the side of the body

children.name: Paragraph_72
children.value: 'Ah!' said the man: bursting into tears, and sinking on his knees at the feet of the dead woman; 'kneel down, kneel down--kneel round her, every one of you, and mark my words!  I say she was starved to death. I never knew how bad she was, till the fever came upon her; and then her bones were starting through the skin.  There was neither fire nor candle; she died in the dark--in the dark!  She couldn't even see her children's faces, though we heard her gasping out their names. I begged for her in the streets: and they sent me to prison. When I came back, she was dying; and all the blood in my heart has dried up, for they starved her to death.  I swear it before the God that saw it! They starved her!'  He twined his hands in his hair; and, with a loud scream, rolled grovelling upon the floor: his eyes fixed, and the foam covering his lips.
children.prevalue: Ah said the man bursting into tears and sinking on his knees at the feet of the dead woman kneel down kneel down kneel round her every one of you and mark my words I say she was starved to death I never knew how bad she was till the fever came upon her and then her bones were starting through the skin There was neither fire nor candle she died in the dark in the dark She couldn t even see her children s faces though we heard her gasping out their names I begged for her in the streets and they sent me to prison When I came back she was dying and all the blood in my heart has dried up for they starved her to death I swear it before the God that saw it They starved her He twined his hands in his hair and with a loud scream rolled grovelling upon the floor his eyes fixed and the foam covering his lips

children.name: Paragraph_73
children.value: The terrified children cried bitterly; but the old woman, who had hitherto remained as quiet as if she had been wholly deaf to all that passed, menaced them into silence.  Having unloosened the cravat of the man who still remained extended on the ground, she tottered towards the undertaker.
children.prevalue: The terrified children cried bitterly but the old woman who had hitherto remained as quiet as if she had been wholly deaf to all that passed menaced them into silence Having unloosened the cravat of the man who still remained extended on the ground she tottered towards the undertaker

children.name: Paragraph_74
children.value: 'She was my daughter,' said the old woman, nodding her head in the direction of the corpse; and speaking with an idiotic leer, more ghastly than even the presence of death in such a place. 'Lord, Lord! Well, it is strange that I who gave birth to her, and was a woman then, should be alive and merry now, and she lying there: so cold and stiff!  Lord, Lord!--to think of it; it's as good as a play--as good as a play!'
children.prevalue: She was my daughter said the old woman nodding her head in the direction of the corpse and speaking with an idiotic leer more ghastly than even the presence of death in such a place Lord Lord Well it is strange that I who gave birth to her and was a woman then should be alive and merry now and she lying there so cold and stiff Lord Lord to think of it it s as good as a play as good as a play

children.name: Paragraph_75
children.value: As the wretched creature mumbled and chuckled in her hideous merriment, the undertaker turned to go away.
children.prevalue: As the wretched creature mumbled and chuckled in her hideous merriment the undertaker turned to go away

children.name: Paragraph_76
children.value: 'Stop, stop!' said the old woman in a loud whisper.  'Will she be buried to-morrow, or next day, or to-night?  I laid her out; and I must walk, you know.  Send me a large cloak: a good warm one: for it is bitter cold.  We should have cake and wine, too, before we go!  Never mind; send some bread--only a loaf of bread and a cup of water.  Shall we have some bread, dear?' she said eagerly: catching at the undertaker's coat, as he once more moved towards the door.
children.prevalue: Stop stop said the old woman in a loud whisper Will she be buried to morrow or next day or to night I laid her out and I must walk you know Send me a large cloak a good warm one for it is bitter cold We should have cake and wine too before we go Never mind send some bread only a loaf of bread and a cup of water Shall we have some bread dear she said eagerly catching at the undertaker s coat as he once more moved towards the door

children.name: Paragraph_77
children.value: 'Yes, yes,' said the undertaker,'of course.  Anything you like!' He disengaged himself from the old woman's grasp; and, drawing Oliver after him, hurried away.
children.prevalue: Yes yes said the undertaker of course Anything you like He disengaged himself from the old woman s grasp and drawing Oliver after him hurried away

children.name: Paragraph_78
children.value: The next day, (the family having been meanwhile relieved with a half-quartern loaf and a piece of cheese, left with them by Mr. Bumble himself,) Oliver and his master returned to the miserable abode; where Mr. Bumble had already arrived, accompanied by four men from the workhouse, who were to act as bearers.  An old black cloak had been thrown over the rags of the old woman and the man; and the bare coffin having been screwed down, was hoisted on the shoulders of the bearers, and carried into the street.
children.prevalue: The next day the family having been meanwhile relieved with a half quartern loaf and a piece of cheese left with them by Mr Bumble himself Oliver and his master returned to the miserable abode where Mr Bumble had already arrived accompanied by four men from the workhouse who were to act as bearers An old black cloak had been thrown over the rags of the old woman and the man and the bare coffin having been screwed down was hoisted on the shoulders of the bearers and carried into the street

children.name: Paragraph_79
children.value: 'Now, you must put your best leg foremost, old lady!' whispered Sowerberry in the old woman's ear; 'we are rather late; and it won't do, to keep the clergyman waiting.  Move on, my men,--as quick as you like!'
children.prevalue: Now you must put your best leg foremost old lady whispered Sowerberry in the old woman s ear we are rather late and it won t do to keep the clergyman waiting Move on my men as quick as you like

children.name: Paragraph_80
children.value: Thus directed, the bearers trotted on under their light burden; and the two mourners kept as near them, as they could.  Mr. Bumble and Sowerberry walked at a good smart pace in front; and Oliver, whose legs were not so long as his master's, ran by the side.
children.prevalue: Thus directed the bearers trotted on under their light burden and the two mourners kept as near them as they could Mr Bumble and Sowerberry walked at a good smart pace in front and Oliver whose legs were not so long as his master s ran by the side

children.name: Paragraph_81
children.value: There was not so great a necessity for hurrying as Mr. Sowerberry had anticipated, however; for when they reached the obscure corner of the churchyard in which the nettles grew, and where the parish graves were made, the clergyman had not arrived; and the clerk, who was sitting by the vestry-room fire, seemed to think it by no means improbable that it might be an hour or so, before he came.  So, they put the bier on the brink of the grave; and the two mourners waited patiently in the damp clay, with a cold rain drizzling down, while the ragged boys whom the spectacle had attracted into the churchyard played a noisy game at hide-and-seek among the tombstones, or varied their amusements by jumping backwards and forwards over the coffin.  Mr. Sowerberry and Bumble, being personal friends of the clerk, sat by the fire with him, and read the paper.
children.prevalue: There was not so great a necessity for hurrying as Mr Sowerberry had anticipated however for when they reached the obscure corner of the churchyard in which the nettles grew and where the parish graves were made the clergyman had not arrived and the clerk who was sitting by the vestry room fire seemed to think it by no means improbable that it might be an hour or so before he came So they put the bier on the brink of the grave and the two mourners waited patiently in the damp clay with a cold rain drizzling down while the ragged boys whom the spectacle had attracted into the churchyard played a noisy game at hide and seek among the tombstones or varied their amusements by jumping backwards and forwards over the coffin Mr Sowerberry and Bumble being personal friends of the clerk sat by the fire with him and read the paper

children.name: Paragraph_82
children.value: At length, after a lapse of something more than an hour, Mr. Bumble, and Sowerberry, and the clerk, were seen running towards the grave. Immediately afterwards, the clergyman appeared: putting on his surplice as he came along.  Mr. Bumble then thrashed a boy or two, to keep up appearances; and the reverend gentleman, having read as much of the burial service as could be compressed into four minutes, gave his surplice to the clerk, and walked away again.
children.prevalue: At length after a lapse of something more than an hour Mr Bumble and Sowerberry and the clerk were seen running towards the grave Immediately afterwards the clergyman appeared putting on his surplice as he came along Mr Bumble then thrashed a boy or two to keep up appearances and the reverend gentleman having read as much of the burial service as could be compressed into four minutes gave his surplice to the clerk and walked away again

children.name: Paragraph_83
children.value: 'Now, Bill!' said Sowerberry to the grave-digger. 'Fill up!'
children.prevalue: Now Bill said Sowerberry to the grave digger Fill up

children.name: Paragraph_84
children.value: It was no very difficult task, for the grave was so full, that the uppermost coffin was within a few feet of the surface.  The grave-digger shovelled in the earth; stamped it loosely down with his feet: shouldered his spade; and walked off, followed by the boys, who murmured very loud complaints at the fun being over so soon.
children.prevalue: It was no very difficult task for the grave was so full that the uppermost coffin was within a few feet of the surface The grave digger shovelled in the earth stamped it loosely down with his feet shouldered his spade and walked off followed by the boys who murmured very loud complaints at the fun being over so soon

children.name: Paragraph_85
children.value: 'Come, my good fellow!' said Bumble, tapping the man on the back. 'They want to shut up the yard.'
children.prevalue: Come my good fellow said Bumble tapping the man on the back They want to shut up the yard

children.name: Paragraph_86
children.value: The man who had never once moved, since he had taken his station by the grave side, started, raised his head, stared at the person who had addressed him, walked forward for a few paces; and fell down in a swoon.  The crazy old woman was too much occupied in bewailing the loss of her cloak (which the undertaker had taken off), to pay him any attention; so they threw a can of cold water over him; and when he came to, saw him safely out of the churchyard, locked the gate, and departed on their different ways.
children.prevalue: The man who had never once moved since he had taken his station by the grave side started raised his head stared at the person who had addressed him walked forward for a few paces and fell down in a swoon The crazy old woman was too much occupied in bewailing the loss of her cloak which the undertaker had taken off to pay him any attention so they threw a can of cold water over him and when he came to saw him safely out of the churchyard locked the gate and departed on their different ways

children.name: Paragraph_87
children.value: 'Well, Oliver,' said Sowerberry, as they walked home, 'how do you like it?'
children.prevalue: Well Oliver said Sowerberry as they walked home how do you like it

children.name: Paragraph_88
children.value: 'Pretty well, thank you, sir' replied Oliver, with considerable hesitation.  'Not very much, sir.'
children.prevalue: Pretty well thank you sir replied Oliver with considerable hesitation Not very much sir

children.name: Paragraph_89
children.value: 'Ah, you'll get used to it in time, Oliver,' said Sowerberry. 'Nothing when you are used to it, my boy.'
children.prevalue: Ah you ll get used to it in time Oliver said Sowerberry Nothing when you are used to it my boy

children.name: Paragraph_90
children.value: Oliver wondered, in his own mind, whether it had taken a very long time to get Mr. Sowerberry used to it.  But he thought it better not to ask the question; and walked back to the shop: thinking over all he had seen and heard.
children.prevalue: Oliver wondered in his own mind whether it had taken a very long time to get Mr Sowerberry used to it But he thought it better not to ask the question and walked back to the shop thinking over all he had seen and heard

children.name: Paragraph_1
children.value: OLIVER, BEING GOADED BY THE TAUNTS OF NOAH, ROUSES INTO ACTION, AND RATHER ASTONISHES HIM
children.prevalue: OLIVER BEING GOADED BY THE TAUNTS OF NOAH ROUSES INTO ACTION AND RATHER ASTONISHES HIM

children.name: Paragraph_2
children.value: The month's trial over, Oliver was formally apprenticed.  It was a nice sickly season just at this time.  In commercial phrase, coffins were looking up; and, in the course of a few weeks, Oliver acquired a great deal of experience.  The success of Mr. Sowerberry's ingenious speculation, exceeded even his most sanguine hopes.  The oldest inhabitants recollected no period at which measles had been so prevalent, or so fatal to infant existence; and many were the mournful processions which little Oliver headed, in a hat-band reaching down to his knees, to the indescribable admiration and emotion of all the mothers in the town.  As Oliver accompanied his master in most of his adult expeditions too, in order that he might acquire that equanimity of demeanour and full command of nerve which was essential to a finished undertaker, he had many opportunities of observing the beautiful resignation and fortitude with which some strong-minded people bear their trials and losses.
children.prevalue: The month s trial over Oliver was formally apprenticed It was a nice sickly season just at this time In commercial phrase coffins were looking up and in the course of a few weeks Oliver acquired a great deal of experience The success of Mr Sowerberry s ingenious speculation exceeded even his most sanguine hopes The oldest inhabitants recollected no period at which measles had been so prevalent or so fatal to infant existence and many were the mournful processions which little Oliver headed in a hat band reaching down to his knees to the indescribable admiration and emotion of all the mothers in the town As Oliver accompanied his master in most of his adult expeditions too in order that he might acquire that equanimity of demeanour and full command of nerve which was essential to a finished undertaker he had many opportunities of observing the beautiful resignation and fortitude with which some strong minded people bear their trials and losses

children.name: Paragraph_3
children.value: For instance; when Sowerberry had an order for the burial of some rich old lady or gentleman, who was surrounded by a great number of nephews and nieces, who had been perfectly inconsolable during the previous illness, and whose grief had been wholly irrepressible even on the most public occasions, they would be as happy among themselves as need be--quite cheerful and contented--conversing together with as much freedom and gaiety, as if nothing whatever had happened to disturb them.  Husbands, too, bore the loss of their wives with the most heroic calmness. Wives, again, put on weeds for their husbands, as if, so far from grieving in the garb of sorrow, they had made up their minds to render it as becoming and attractive as possible.  It was observable, too, that ladies and gentlemen who were in passions of anguish during the ceremony of interment, recovered almost as soon as they reached home, and became quite composed before the tea-drinking was over.  All this was very pleasant and improving to see; and Oliver beheld it with great admiration.
children.prevalue: For instance when Sowerberry had an order for the burial of some rich old lady or gentleman who was surrounded by a great number of nephews and nieces who had been perfectly inconsolable during the previous illness and whose grief had been wholly irrepressible even on the most public occasions they would be as happy among themselves as need be quite cheerful and contented conversing together with as much freedom and gaiety as if nothing whatever had happened to disturb them Husbands too bore the loss of their wives with the most heroic calmness Wives again put on weeds for their husbands as if so far from grieving in the garb of sorrow they had made up their minds to render it as becoming and attractive as possible It was observable too that ladies and gentlemen who were in passions of anguish during the ceremony of interment recovered almost as soon as they reached home and became quite composed before the tea drinking was over All this was very pleasant and improving to see and Oliver beheld it with great admiration

children.name: Paragraph_4
children.value: That Oliver Twist was moved to resignation by the example of these good people, I cannot, although I am his biographer, undertake to affirm with any degree of confidence; but I can most distinctly say, that for many months he continued meekly to submit to the domination and ill-treatment of Noah Claypole: who used him far worse than before, now that his jealousy was roused by seeing the new boy promoted to the black stick and hatband, while he, the old one, remained stationary in the muffin-cap and leathers.  Charlotte treated him ill, because Noah did; and Mrs. Sowerberry was his decided enemy, because Mr. Sowerberry was disposed to be his friend; so, between these three on one side, and a glut of funerals on the other, Oliver was not altogether as comfortable as the hungry pig was, when he was shut up, by mistake, in the grain department of a brewery.
children.prevalue: That Oliver Twist was moved to resignation by the example of these good people I cannot although I am his biographer undertake to affirm with any degree of confidence but I can most distinctly say that for many months he continued meekly to submit to the domination and ill treatment of Noah Claypole who used him far worse than before now that his jealousy was roused by seeing the new boy promoted to the black stick and hatband while he the old one remained stationary in the muffin cap and leathers Charlotte treated him ill because Noah did and Mrs Sowerberry was his decided enemy because Mr Sowerberry was disposed to be his friend so between these three on one side and a glut of funerals on the other Oliver was not altogether as comfortable as the hungry pig was when he was shut up by mistake in the grain department of a brewery

children.name: Paragraph_5
children.value: And now, I come to a very important passage in Oliver's history; for I have to record an act, slight and unimportant perhaps in appearance, but which indirectly produced a material change in all his future prospects and proceedings.
children.prevalue: And now I come to a very important passage in Oliver s history for I have to record an act slight and unimportant perhaps in appearance but which indirectly produced a material change in all his future prospects and proceedings

children.name: Paragraph_6
children.value: One day, Oliver and Noah had descended into the kitchen at the usual dinner-hour, to banquet upon a small joint of mutton--a pound and a half of the worst end of the neck--when Charlotte being called out of the way, there ensued a brief interval of time, which Noah Claypole, being hungry and vicious, considered he could not possibly devote to a worthier purpose than aggravating and tantalising young Oliver Twist.
children.prevalue: One day Oliver and Noah had descended into the kitchen at the usual dinner hour to banquet upon a small joint of mutton a pound and a half of the worst end of the neck when Charlotte being called out of the way there ensued a brief interval of time which Noah Claypole being hungry and vicious considered he could not possibly devote to a worthier purpose than aggravating and tantalising young Oliver Twist

children.name: Paragraph_7
children.value: Intent upon this innocent amusement, Noah put his feet on the table-cloth; and pulled Oliver's hair; and twitched his ears; and expressed his opinion that he was a 'sneak'; and furthermore announced his intention of coming to see him hanged, whenever that desirable event should take place; and entered upon various topics of petty annoyance, like a malicious and ill-conditioned charity-boy as he was. But, making Oliver cry, Noah attempted to be more facetious still; and in his attempt, did what many sometimes do to this day, when they want to be funny.  He got rather personal.
children.prevalue: Intent upon this innocent amusement Noah put his feet on the table cloth and pulled Oliver s hair and twitched his ears and expressed his opinion that he was a sneak and furthermore announced his intention of coming to see him hanged whenever that desirable event should take place and entered upon various topics of petty annoyance like a malicious and ill conditioned charity boy as he was But making Oliver cry Noah attempted to be more facetious still and in his attempt did what many sometimes do to this day when they want to be funny He got rather personal

children.name: Paragraph_8
children.value: 'Work'us,' said Noah, 'how's your mother?'
children.prevalue: Work us said Noah how s your mother

children.name: Paragraph_9
children.value: 'She's dead,' replied Oliver; 'don't you say anything about her to me!'
children.prevalue: She s dead replied Oliver don t you say anything about her to me

children.name: Paragraph_10
children.value: Oliver's colour rose as he said this; he breathed quickly; and there was a curious working of the mouth and nostrils, which Mr. Claypole thought must be the immediate precursor of a violent fit of crying. Under this impression he returned to the charge.
children.prevalue: Oliver s colour rose as he said this he breathed quickly and there was a curious working of the mouth and nostrils which Mr Claypole thought must be the immediate precursor of a violent fit of crying Under this impression he returned to the charge

children.name: Paragraph_11
children.value: 'What did she die of, Work'us?' said Noah.
children.prevalue: What did she die of Work us said Noah

children.name: Paragraph_12
children.value: 'Of a broken heart, some of our old nurses told me,' replied Oliver: more as if he were talking to himself, than answering Noah. 'I think I know what it must be to die of that!'
children.prevalue: Of a broken heart some of our old nurses told me replied Oliver more as if he were talking to himself than answering Noah I think I know what it must be to die of that

children.name: Paragraph_13
children.value: 'Tol de rol lol lol, right fol lairy, Work'us,' said Noah, as a tear rolled down Oliver's cheek.  'What's set you a snivelling now?'
children.prevalue: Tol de rol lol lol right fol lairy Work us said Noah as a tear rolled down Oliver s cheek What s set you a snivelling now

children.name: Paragraph_14
children.value: 'Not you,' replied Oliver, sharply. 'There; that's enough. Don't say anything more to me about her; you'd better not!'
children.prevalue: Not you replied Oliver sharply There that s enough Don t say anything more to me about her you d better not

children.name: Paragraph_15
children.value: 'Better not!' exclaimed Noah. 'Well!  Better not!  Work'us, don't be impudent.  Your mother, too!  She was a nice 'un she was.  Oh, Lor!' And here, Noah nodded his head expressively; and curled up as much of his small red nose as muscular action could collect together, for the occasion.
children.prevalue: Better not exclaimed Noah Well Better not Work us don t be impudent Your mother too She was a nice un she was Oh Lor And here Noah nodded his head expressively and curled up as much of his small red nose as muscular action could collect together for the occasion

children.name: Paragraph_16
children.value: 'Yer know, Work'us,' continued Noah, emboldened by Oliver's silence, and speaking in a jeering tone of affected pity: of all tones the most annoying: 'Yer know, Work'us, it can't be helped now; and of course yer couldn't help it then; and I am very sorry for it; and I'm sure we all are, and pity yer very much.  But yer must know, Work'us, yer mother was a regular right-down bad 'un.'
children.prevalue: Yer know Work us continued Noah emboldened by Oliver s silence and speaking in a jeering tone of affected pity of all tones the most annoying Yer know Work us it can t be helped now and of course yer couldn t help it then and I am very sorry for it and I m sure we all are and pity yer very much But yer must know Work us yer mother was a regular right down bad un

children.name: Paragraph_17
children.value: 'What did you say?' inquired Oliver, looking up very quickly.
children.prevalue: What did you say inquired Oliver looking up very quickly

children.name: Paragraph_18
children.value: 'A regular right-down bad 'un, Work'us,' replied Noah, coolly. 'And it's a great deal better, Work'us, that she died when she did, or else she'd have been hard labouring in Bridewell, or transported, or hung; which is more likely than either, isn't it?'
children.prevalue: A regular right down bad un Work us replied Noah coolly And it s a great deal better Work us that she died when she did or else she d have been hard labouring in Bridewell or transported or hung which is more likely than either isn t it

children.name: Paragraph_19
children.value: Crimson with fury, Oliver started up; overthrew the chair and table; seized Noah by the throat; shook him, in the violence of his rage, till his teeth chattered in his head; and collecting his whole force into one heavy blow, felled him to the ground.
children.prevalue: Crimson with fury Oliver started up overthrew the chair and table seized Noah by the throat shook him in the violence of his rage till his teeth chattered in his head and collecting his whole force into one heavy blow felled him to the ground

children.name: Paragraph_20
children.value: A minute ago, the boy had looked the quiet child, mild, dejected creature that harsh treatment had made him.  But his spirit was roused at last; the cruel insult to his dead mother had set his blood on fire. His breast heaved; his attitude was erect; his eye bright and vivid; his whole person changed, as he stood glaring over the cowardly tormentor who now lay crouching at his feet; and defied him with an energy he had never known before.
children.prevalue: A minute ago the boy had looked the quiet child mild dejected creature that harsh treatment had made him But his spirit was roused at last the cruel insult to his dead mother had set his blood on fire His breast heaved his attitude was erect his eye bright and vivid his whole person changed as he stood glaring over the cowardly tormentor who now lay crouching at his feet and defied him with an energy he had never known before

children.name: Paragraph_21
children.value: 'He'll murder me!' blubbered Noah.  'Charlotte!  missis!  Here's the new boy a murdering of me!  Help! help!  Oliver's gone mad! Char--lotte!'
children.prevalue: He ll murder me blubbered Noah Charlotte missis Here s the new boy a murdering of me Help help Oliver s gone mad Char lotte

children.name: Paragraph_22
children.value: Noah's shouts were responded to, by a loud scream from Charlotte, and a louder from Mrs. Sowerberry; the former of whom rushed into the kitchen by a side-door, while the latter paused on the staircase till she was quite certain that it was consistent with the preservation of human life, to come further down.
children.prevalue: Noah s shouts were responded to by a loud scream from Charlotte and a louder from Mrs Sowerberry the former of whom rushed into the kitchen by a side door while the latter paused on the staircase till she was quite certain that it was consistent with the preservation of human life to come further down

children.name: Paragraph_23
children.value: 'Oh, you little wretch!' screamed Charlotte: seizing Oliver with her utmost force, which was about equal to that of a moderately strong man in particularly good training.  'Oh, you little un-grate-ful, mur-de-rous, hor-rid villain!'  And between every syllable, Charlotte gave Oliver a blow with all her might: accompanying it with a scream, for the benefit of society.
children.prevalue: Oh you little wretch screamed Charlotte seizing Oliver with her utmost force which was about equal to that of a moderately strong man in particularly good training Oh you little un grate ful mur de rous hor rid villain And between every syllable Charlotte gave Oliver a blow with all her might accompanying it with a scream for the benefit of society

children.name: Paragraph_24
children.value: Charlotte's fist was by no means a light one; but, lest it should not be effectual in calming Oliver's wrath, Mrs. Sowerberry plunged into the kitchen, and assisted to hold him with one hand, while she scratched his face with the other. In this favourable position of affairs, Noah rose from the ground, and pommelled him behind.
children.prevalue: Charlotte s fist was by no means a light one but lest it should not be effectual in calming Oliver s wrath Mrs Sowerberry plunged into the kitchen and assisted to hold him with one hand while she scratched his face with the other In this favourable position of affairs Noah rose from the ground and pommelled him behind

children.name: Paragraph_25
children.value: This was rather too violent exercise to last long.  When they were all wearied out, and could tear and beat no longer, they dragged Oliver, struggling and shouting, but nothing daunted, into the dust-cellar, and there locked him up.  This being done, Mrs. Sowerberry sunk into a chair, and burst into tears.
children.prevalue: This was rather too violent exercise to last long When they were all wearied out and could tear and beat no longer they dragged Oliver struggling and shouting but nothing daunted into the dust cellar and there locked him up This being done Mrs Sowerberry sunk into a chair and burst into tears

children.name: Paragraph_26
children.value: 'Bless her, she's going off!' said Charlotte.  'A glass of water, Noah, dear.  Make haste!'
children.prevalue: Bless her she s going off said Charlotte A glass of water Noah dear Make haste

children.name: Paragraph_27
children.value: 'Oh!  Charlotte,' said Mrs. Sowerberry:  speaking as well as she could, through a deficiency of breath, and a sufficiency of cold water, which Noah had poured over her head and shoulders.  'Oh! Charlotte, what a mercy we have not all been murdered in our beds!'
children.prevalue: Oh Charlotte said Mrs Sowerberry speaking as well as she could through a deficiency of breath and a sufficiency of cold water which Noah had poured over her head and shoulders Oh Charlotte what a mercy we have not all been murdered in our beds

children.name: Paragraph_28
children.value: 'Ah! mercy indeed, ma'am,' was the reply.  I only hope this'll teach master not to have any more of these dreadful creatures, that are born to be murderers and robbers from their very cradle. Poor Noah!  He was all but killed, ma'am, when I come in.'
children.prevalue: Ah mercy indeed ma am was the reply I only hope this ll teach master not to have any more of these dreadful creatures that are born to be murderers and robbers from their very cradle Poor Noah He was all but killed ma am when I come in

children.name: Paragraph_29
children.value: 'Poor fellow!' said Mrs. Sowerberry: looking piteously on the charity-boy.
children.prevalue: Poor fellow said Mrs Sowerberry looking piteously on the charity boy

children.name: Paragraph_30
children.value: Noah, whose top waistcoat-button might have been somewhere on a level with the crown of Oliver's head, rubbed his eyes with the inside of his wrists while this commiseration was bestowed upon him, and performed some affecting tears and sniffs.
children.prevalue: Noah whose top waistcoat button might have been somewhere on a level with the crown of Oliver s head rubbed his eyes with the inside of his wrists while this commiseration was bestowed upon him and performed some affecting tears and sniffs

children.name: Paragraph_31
children.value: 'What's to be done!' exclaimed Mrs. Sowerberry.  'Your master's not at home; there's not a man in the house, and he'll kick that door down in ten minutes.'  Oliver's vigorous plunges against the bit of timber in question, rendered this occurance highly probable.
children.prevalue: What s to be done exclaimed Mrs Sowerberry Your master s not at home there s not a man in the house and he ll kick that door down in ten minutes Oliver s vigorous plunges against the bit of timber in question rendered this occurance highly probable

children.name: Paragraph_32
children.value: 'Dear, dear!  I don't know, ma'am,' said Charlotte, 'unless we send for the police-officers.'
children.prevalue: Dear dear I don t know ma am said Charlotte unless we send for the police officers

children.name: Paragraph_33
children.value: 'Or the millingtary,' suggested Mr. Claypole.
children.prevalue: Or the millingtary suggested Mr Claypole

children.name: Paragraph_34
children.value: 'No, no,' said Mrs. Sowerberry: bethinking herself of Oliver's old friend.  'Run to Mr. Bumble, Noah, and tell him to come here directly, and not to lose a minute; never mind your cap!  Make haste!  You can hold a knife to that black eye, as you run along. It'll keep the swelling down.'
children.prevalue: No no said Mrs Sowerberry bethinking herself of Oliver s old friend Run to Mr Bumble Noah and tell him to come here directly and not to lose a minute never mind your cap Make haste You can hold a knife to that black eye as you run along It ll keep the swelling down

children.name: Paragraph_35
children.value: Noah stopped to make no reply, but started off at his fullest speed; and very much it astonished the people who were out walking, to see a charity-boy tearing through the streets pell-mell, with no cap on his head, and a clasp-knife at his eye.
children.prevalue: Noah stopped to make no reply but started off at his fullest speed and very much it astonished the people who were out walking to see a charity boy tearing through the streets pell mell with no cap on his head and a clasp knife at his eye

children.name: Paragraph_1
children.value: OLIVER CONTINUES REFRACTORY
children.prevalue: OLIVER CONTINUES REFRACTORY

children.name: Paragraph_2
children.value: Noah Claypole ran along the streets at his swiftest pace, and paused not once for breath, until he reached the workhouse-gate. Having rested here, for a minute or so, to collect a good burst of sobs and an imposing show of tears and terror, he knocked loudly at the wicket; and presented such a rueful face to the aged pauper who opened it, that even he, who saw nothing but rueful faces about him at the best of times, started back in astonishment.
children.prevalue: Noah Claypole ran along the streets at his swiftest pace and paused not once for breath until he reached the workhouse gate Having rested here for a minute or so to collect a good burst of sobs and an imposing show of tears and terror he knocked loudly at the wicket and presented such a rueful face to the aged pauper who opened it that even he who saw nothing but rueful faces about him at the best of times started back in astonishment

children.name: Paragraph_3
children.value: 'Why, what's the matter with the boy!' said the old pauper.
children.prevalue: Why what s the matter with the boy said the old pauper

children.name: Paragraph_4
children.value: 'Mr. Bumble!  Mr. Bumble!' cried Noah, with well-affected dismay: and in tones so loud and agitated, that they not only caught the ear of Mr. Bumble himself, who happened to be hard by, but alarmed him so much that he rushed into the yard without his cocked hat,--which is a very curious and remarkable circumstance: as showing that even a beadle, acted upon a sudden and powerful impulse, may be afflicted with a momentary visitation of loss of self-possession, and forgetfulness of personal dignity.
children.prevalue: Mr Bumble Mr Bumble cried Noah with well affected dismay and in tones so loud and agitated that they not only caught the ear of Mr Bumble himself who happened to be hard by but alarmed him so much that he rushed into the yard without his cocked hat which is a very curious and remarkable circumstance as showing that even a beadle acted upon a sudden and powerful impulse may be afflicted with a momentary visitation of loss of self possession and forgetfulness of personal dignity

children.name: Paragraph_5
children.value: 'Oh, Mr. Bumble, sir!' said Noah:  'Oliver, sir,--Oliver has--'
children.prevalue: Oh Mr Bumble sir said Noah Oliver sir Oliver has

children.name: Paragraph_6
children.value: 'What?  What?' interposed Mr. Bumble: with a gleam of pleasure in his metallic eyes. 'Not run away; he hasn't run away, has he, Noah?'
children.prevalue: What What interposed Mr Bumble with a gleam of pleasure in his metallic eyes Not run away he hasn t run away has he Noah

children.name: Paragraph_7
children.value: 'No, sir, no.  Not run away, sir, but he's turned wicious,' replied Noah. 'He tried to murder me, sir; and then he tried to murder Charlotte; and then missis.  Oh! what dreadful pain it is!
children.prevalue: No sir no Not run away sir but he s turned wicious replied Noah He tried to murder me sir and then he tried to murder Charlotte and then missis Oh what dreadful pain it is

children.name: Paragraph_8
children.value: Such agony, please, sir!'  And here, Noah writhed and twisted his body into an extensive variety of eel-like positions; thereby giving Mr. Bumble to understand that, from the violent and sanguinary onset of Oliver Twist, he had sustained severe internal injury and damage, from which he was at that moment suffering the acutest torture.
children.prevalue: Such agony please sir And here Noah writhed and twisted his body into an extensive variety of eel like positions thereby giving Mr Bumble to understand that from the violent and sanguinary onset of Oliver Twist he had sustained severe internal injury and damage from which he was at that moment suffering the acutest torture

children.name: Paragraph_9
children.value: When Noah saw that the intelligence he communicated perfectly paralysed Mr. Bumble, he imparted additional effect thereunto, by bewailing his dreadful wounds ten times louder than before; and when he observed a gentleman in a white waistcoat crossing the yard, he was more tragic in his lamentations than ever: rightly conceiving it highly expedient to attract the notice, and rouse the indignation, of the gentleman aforesaid.
children.prevalue: When Noah saw that the intelligence he communicated perfectly paralysed Mr Bumble he imparted additional effect thereunto by bewailing his dreadful wounds ten times louder than before and when he observed a gentleman in a white waistcoat crossing the yard he was more tragic in his lamentations than ever rightly conceiving it highly expedient to attract the notice and rouse the indignation of the gentleman aforesaid

children.name: Paragraph_10
children.value: The gentleman's notice was very soon attracted; for he had not walked three paces, when he turned angrily round, and inquired what that young cur was howling for, and why Mr. Bumble did not favour him with something which would render the series of vocular exclamations so designated, an involuntary process?
children.prevalue: The gentleman s notice was very soon attracted for he had not walked three paces when he turned angrily round and inquired what that young cur was howling for and why Mr Bumble did not favour him with something which would render the series of vocular exclamations so designated an involuntary process

children.name: Paragraph_11
children.value: 'It's a poor boy from the free-school, sir,' replied Mr. Bumble, 'who has been nearly murdered--all but murdered, sir,--by young Twist.'
children.prevalue: It s a poor boy from the free school sir replied Mr Bumble who has been nearly murdered all but murdered sir by young Twist

children.name: Paragraph_12
children.value: 'By Jove!' exclaimed the gentleman in the white waistcoat, stopping short.  'I knew it!  I felt a strange presentiment from the very first, that that audacious young savage would come to be hung!'
children.prevalue: By Jove exclaimed the gentleman in the white waistcoat stopping short I knew it I felt a strange presentiment from the very first that that audacious young savage would come to be hung

children.name: Paragraph_13
children.value: 'He has likewise attempted, sir, to murder the female servant,' said Mr. Bumble, with a face of ashy paleness.
children.prevalue: He has likewise attempted sir to murder the female servant said Mr Bumble with a face of ashy paleness

children.name: Paragraph_14
children.value: 'And his missis,' interposed Mr. Claypole.
children.prevalue: And his missis interposed Mr Claypole

children.name: Paragraph_15
children.value: 'And his master, too, I think you said, Noah?' added Mr. Bumble.
children.prevalue: And his master too I think you said Noah added Mr Bumble

children.name: Paragraph_16
children.value: 'No! he's out, or he would have murdered him,' replied Noah. 'He said he wanted to.'
children.prevalue: No he s out or he would have murdered him replied Noah He said he wanted to

children.name: Paragraph_17
children.value: 'Ah!  Said he wanted to, did he, my boy?' inquired the gentleman in the white waistcoat.
children.prevalue: Ah Said he wanted to did he my boy inquired the gentleman in the white waistcoat

children.name: Paragraph_18
children.value: 'Yes, sir,' replied Noah.  'And please, sir, missis wants to know whether Mr. Bumble can spare time to step up there, directly, and flog him--'cause master's out.'
children.prevalue: Yes sir replied Noah And please sir missis wants to know whether Mr Bumble can spare time to step up there directly and flog him cause master s out

children.name: Paragraph_19
children.value: 'Certainly, my boy; certainly,' said the gentleman in the white waistcoat: smiling benignly, and patting Noah's head, which was about three inches higher than his own.  'You're a good boy--a very good boy. Here's a penny for you.  Bumble, just step up to Sowerberry's with your cane, and see what's best to be done. Don't spare him, Bumble.'
children.prevalue: Certainly my boy certainly said the gentleman in the white waistcoat smiling benignly and patting Noah s head which was about three inches higher than his own You re a good boy a very good boy Here s a penny for you Bumble just step up to Sowerberry s with your cane and see what s best to be done Don t spare him Bumble

children.name: Paragraph_20
children.value: 'No, I will not, sir,' replied the beadle.  And the cocked hat and cane having been, by this time, adjusted to their owner's satisfaction, Mr. Bumble and Noah Claypole betook themselves with all speed to the undertaker's shop.
