children.prevalue: No I will not sir replied the beadle And the cocked hat and cane having been by this time adjusted to their owner s satisfaction Mr Bumble and Noah Claypole betook themselves with all speed to the undertaker s shop

children.name: Paragraph_21
children.value: Here the position of affairs had not at all improved.  Sowerberry had not yet returned, and Oliver continued to kick, with undiminished vigour, at the cellar-door.  The accounts of his ferocity as related by Mrs. Sowerberry and Charlotte, were of so startling a nature, that Mr. Bumble judged it prudent to parley, before opening the door.  With this view he gave a kick at the outside, by way of prelude; and, then, applying his mouth to the keyhole, said, in a deep and impressive tone:
children.prevalue: Here the position of affairs had not at all improved Sowerberry had not yet returned and Oliver continued to kick with undiminished vigour at the cellar door The accounts of his ferocity as related by Mrs Sowerberry and Charlotte were of so startling a nature that Mr Bumble judged it prudent to parley before opening the door With this view he gave a kick at the outside by way of prelude and then applying his mouth to the keyhole said in a deep and impressive tone

children.name: Paragraph_22
children.value: 'Oliver!'
children.prevalue: Oliver

children.name: Paragraph_23
children.value: 'Come; you let me out!' replied Oliver, from the inside.
children.prevalue: Come you let me out replied Oliver from the inside

children.name: Paragraph_24
children.value: 'Do you know this here voice, Oliver?' said Mr. Bumble.
children.prevalue: Do you know this here voice Oliver said Mr Bumble

children.name: Paragraph_25
children.value: 'Yes,' replied Oliver.
children.prevalue: Yes replied Oliver

children.name: Paragraph_26
children.value: 'Ain't you afraid of it, sir?  Ain't you a-trembling while I speak, sir?' said Mr. Bumble.
children.prevalue: Ain t you afraid of it sir Ain t you a trembling while I speak sir said Mr Bumble

children.name: Paragraph_27
children.value: 'No!' replied Oliver, boldly.
children.prevalue: No replied Oliver boldly

children.name: Paragraph_28
children.value: An answer so different from the one he had expected to elicit, and was in the habit of receiving, staggered Mr. Bumble not a little.  He stepped back from the keyhole; drew himself up to his full height; and looked from one to another of the three bystanders, in mute astonishment.
children.prevalue: An answer so different from the one he had expected to elicit and was in the habit of receiving staggered Mr Bumble not a little He stepped back from the keyhole drew himself up to his full height and looked from one to another of the three bystanders in mute astonishment

children.name: Paragraph_29
children.value: 'Oh, you know, Mr. Bumble, he must be mad,' said Mrs. Sowerberry.
children.prevalue: Oh you know Mr Bumble he must be mad said Mrs Sowerberry

children.name: Paragraph_30
children.value: 'No boy in half his senses could venture to speak so to you.'
children.prevalue: No boy in half his senses could venture to speak so to you

children.name: Paragraph_31
children.value: 'It's not Madness, ma'am,' replied Mr. Bumble, after a few moments of deep meditation.  'It's Meat.'
children.prevalue: It s not Madness ma am replied Mr Bumble after a few moments of deep meditation It s Meat

children.name: Paragraph_32
children.value: 'What?' exclaimed Mrs. Sowerberry.
children.prevalue: What exclaimed Mrs Sowerberry

children.name: Paragraph_33
children.value: 'Meat, ma'am, meat,' replied Bumble, with stern emphasis. 'You've over-fed him, ma'am.  You've raised a artificial soul and spirit in him, ma'am unbecoming a person of his condition: as the board, Mrs. Sowerberry, who are practical philosophers, will tell you.  What have paupers to do with soul or spirit?  It's quite enough that we let 'em have live bodies.  If you had kept the boy on gruel, ma'am, this would never have happened.'
children.prevalue: Meat ma am meat replied Bumble with stern emphasis You ve over fed him ma am You ve raised a artificial soul and spirit in him ma am unbecoming a person of his condition as the board Mrs Sowerberry who are practical philosophers will tell you What have paupers to do with soul or spirit It s quite enough that we let em have live bodies If you had kept the boy on gruel ma am this would never have happened

children.name: Paragraph_34
children.value: 'Dear, dear!' ejaculated Mrs. Sowerberry, piously raising her eyes to the kitchen ceiling: 'this comes of being liberal!'
children.prevalue: Dear dear ejaculated Mrs Sowerberry piously raising her eyes to the kitchen ceiling this comes of being liberal

children.name: Paragraph_35
children.value: The liberality of Mrs. Sowerberry to Oliver, had consisted of a profuse bestowal upon him of all the dirty odds and ends which nobody else would eat; so there was a great deal of meekness and self-devotion in her voluntarily remaining under Mr. Bumble's heavy accusation.  Of which, to do her justice, she was wholly innocent, in thought, word, or deed.
children.prevalue: The liberality of Mrs Sowerberry to Oliver had consisted of a profuse bestowal upon him of all the dirty odds and ends which nobody else would eat so there was a great deal of meekness and self devotion in her voluntarily remaining under Mr Bumble s heavy accusation Of which to do her justice she was wholly innocent in thought word or deed

children.name: Paragraph_36
children.value: 'Ah!' said Mr. Bumble, when the lady brought her eyes down to earth again; 'the only thing that can be done now, that I know of, is to leave him in the cellar for a day or so, till he's a little starved down; and then to take him out, and keep him on gruel all through the apprenticeship.  He comes of a bad family. Excitable natures, Mrs. Sowerberry!  Both the nurse and doctor said, that that mother of his made her way here, against difficulties and pain that would have killed any well-disposed woman, weeks before.'
children.prevalue: Ah said Mr Bumble when the lady brought her eyes down to earth again the only thing that can be done now that I know of is to leave him in the cellar for a day or so till he s a little starved down and then to take him out and keep him on gruel all through the apprenticeship He comes of a bad family Excitable natures Mrs Sowerberry Both the nurse and doctor said that that mother of his made her way here against difficulties and pain that would have killed any well disposed woman weeks before

children.name: Paragraph_37
children.value: At this point of Mr. Bumble's discourse, Oliver, just hearing enough to know that some allusion was being made to his mother, recommenced kicking, with a violence that rendered every other sound inaudible. Sowerberry returned at this juncture.  Oliver's offence having been explained to him, with such exaggerations as the ladies thought best calculated to rouse his ire, he unlocked the cellar-door in a twinkling, and dragged his rebellious apprentice out, by the collar.
children.prevalue: At this point of Mr Bumble s discourse Oliver just hearing enough to know that some allusion was being made to his mother recommenced kicking with a violence that rendered every other sound inaudible Sowerberry returned at this juncture Oliver s offence having been explained to him with such exaggerations as the ladies thought best calculated to rouse his ire he unlocked the cellar door in a twinkling and dragged his rebellious apprentice out by the collar

children.name: Paragraph_38
children.value: Oliver's clothes had been torn in the beating he had received; his face was bruised and scratched; and his hair scattered over his forehead. The angry flush had not disappeared, however; and when he was pulled out of his prison, he scowled boldly on Noah, and looked quite undismayed.
children.prevalue: Oliver s clothes had been torn in the beating he had received his face was bruised and scratched and his hair scattered over his forehead The angry flush had not disappeared however and when he was pulled out of his prison he scowled boldly on Noah and looked quite undismayed

children.name: Paragraph_39
children.value: 'Now, you are a nice young fellow, ain't you?' said Sowerberry; giving Oliver a shake, and a box on the ear.
children.prevalue: Now you are a nice young fellow ain t you said Sowerberry giving Oliver a shake and a box on the ear

children.name: Paragraph_40
children.value: 'He called my mother names,' replied Oliver.
children.prevalue: He called my mother names replied Oliver

children.name: Paragraph_41
children.value: 'Well, and what if he did, you little ungrateful wretch?' said Mrs. Sowerberry.  'She deserved what he said, and worse.'
children.prevalue: Well and what if he did you little ungrateful wretch said Mrs Sowerberry She deserved what he said and worse

children.name: Paragraph_42
children.value: 'She didn't' said Oliver.
children.prevalue: She didn t said Oliver

children.name: Paragraph_43
children.value: 'She did,' said Mrs. Sowerberry.
children.prevalue: She did said Mrs Sowerberry

children.name: Paragraph_44
children.value: 'It's a lie!' said Oliver.
children.prevalue: It s a lie said Oliver

children.name: Paragraph_45
children.value: Mrs. Sowerberry burst into a flood of tears.
children.prevalue: Mrs Sowerberry burst into a flood of tears

children.name: Paragraph_46
children.value: This flood of tears left Mr. Sowerberry no alternative.  If he had hesitated for one instant to punish Oliver most severely, it must be quite clear to every experienced reader that he would have been, according to all precedents in disputes of matrimony established, a brute, an unnatural husband, an insulting creature, a base imitation of a man, and various other agreeable characters too numerous for recital within the limits of this chapter.  To do him justice, he was, as far as his power went--it was not very extensive--kindly disposed towards the boy; perhaps, because it was his interest to be so; perhaps, because his wife disliked him. The flood of tears, however, left him no resource; so he at once gave him a drubbing, which satisfied even Mrs. Sowerberry herself, and rendered Mr. Bumble's subsequent application of the parochial cane, rather unnecessary.  For the rest of the day, he was shut up in the back kitchen, in company with a pump and a slice of bread; and at night, Mrs. Sowerberry, after making various remarks outside the door, by no means complimentary to the memory of his mother, looked into the room, and, amidst the jeers and pointings of Noah and Charlotte, ordered him upstairs to his dismal bed.
children.prevalue: This flood of tears left Mr Sowerberry no alternative If he had hesitated for one instant to punish Oliver most severely it must be quite clear to every experienced reader that he would have been according to all precedents in disputes of matrimony established a brute an unnatural husband an insulting creature a base imitation of a man and various other agreeable characters too numerous for recital within the limits of this chapter To do him justice he was as far as his power went it was not very extensive kindly disposed towards the boy perhaps because it was his interest to be so perhaps because his wife disliked him The flood of tears however left him no resource so he at once gave him a drubbing which satisfied even Mrs Sowerberry herself and rendered Mr Bumble s subsequent application of the parochial cane rather unnecessary For the rest of the day he was shut up in the back kitchen in company with a pump and a slice of bread and at night Mrs Sowerberry after making various remarks outside the door by no means complimentary to the memory of his mother looked into the room and amidst the jeers and pointings of Noah and Charlotte ordered him upstairs to his dismal bed

children.name: Paragraph_47
children.value: It was not until he was left alone in the silence and stillness of the gloomy workshop of the undertaker, that Oliver gave way to the feelings which the day's treatment may be supposed likely to have awakened in a mere child.  He had listened to their taunts with a look of contempt; he had borne the lash without a cry: for he felt that pride swelling in his heart which would have kept down a shriek to the last, though they had roasted him alive.  But now, when there were none to see or hear him, he fell upon his knees on the floor; and, hiding his face in his hands, wept such tears as, God send for the credit of our nature, few so young may ever have cause to pour out before him!
children.prevalue: It was not until he was left alone in the silence and stillness of the gloomy workshop of the undertaker that Oliver gave way to the feelings which the day s treatment may be supposed likely to have awakened in a mere child He had listened to their taunts with a look of contempt he had borne the lash without a cry for he felt that pride swelling in his heart which would have kept down a shriek to the last though they had roasted him alive But now when there were none to see or hear him he fell upon his knees on the floor and hiding his face in his hands wept such tears as God send for the credit of our nature few so young may ever have cause to pour out before him

children.name: Paragraph_48
children.value: For a long time, Oliver remained motionless in this attitude. The candle was burning low in the socket when he rose to his feet. Having gazed cautiously round him, and listened intently, he gently undid the fastenings of the door, and looked abroad.
children.prevalue: For a long time Oliver remained motionless in this attitude The candle was burning low in the socket when he rose to his feet Having gazed cautiously round him and listened intently he gently undid the fastenings of the door and looked abroad

children.name: Paragraph_49
children.value: It was a cold, dark night.  The stars seemed, to the boy's eyes, farther from the earth than he had ever seen them before; there was no wind; and the sombre shadows thrown by the trees upon the ground, looked sepulchral and death-like, from being so still. He softly reclosed the door.  Having availed himself of the expiring light of the candle to tie up in a handkerchief the few articles of wearing apparel he had, sat himself down upon a bench, to wait for morning.
children.prevalue: It was a cold dark night The stars seemed to the boy s eyes farther from the earth than he had ever seen them before there was no wind and the sombre shadows thrown by the trees upon the ground looked sepulchral and death like from being so still He softly reclosed the door Having availed himself of the expiring light of the candle to tie up in a handkerchief the few articles of wearing apparel he had sat himself down upon a bench to wait for morning

children.name: Paragraph_50
children.value: With the first ray of light that struggled through the crevices in the shutters, Oliver arose, and again unbarred the door.  One timid look around--one moment's pause of hesitation--he had closed it behind him, and was in the open street.
children.prevalue: With the first ray of light that struggled through the crevices in the shutters Oliver arose and again unbarred the door One timid look around one moment s pause of hesitation he had closed it behind him and was in the open street

children.name: Paragraph_51
children.value: He looked to the right and to the left, uncertain whither to fly.
children.prevalue: He looked to the right and to the left uncertain whither to fly

children.name: Paragraph_52
children.value: He remembered to have seen the waggons, as they went out, toiling up the hill.  He took the same route; and arriving at a footpath across the fields: which he knew, after some distance, led out again into the road; struck into it, and walked quickly on.
children.prevalue: He remembered to have seen the waggons as they went out toiling up the hill He took the same route and arriving at a footpath across the fields which he knew after some distance led out again into the road struck into it and walked quickly on

children.name: Paragraph_53
children.value: Along this same footpath, Oliver well-remembered he had trotted beside Mr. Bumble, when he first carried him to the workhouse from the farm. His way lay directly in front of the cottage. His heart beat quickly when he bethought himself of this; and he half resolved to turn back. He had come a long way though, and should lose a great deal of time by doing so.  Besides, it was so early that there was very little fear of his being seen; so he walked on.
children.prevalue: Along this same footpath Oliver well remembered he had trotted beside Mr Bumble when he first carried him to the workhouse from the farm His way lay directly in front of the cottage His heart beat quickly when he bethought himself of this and he half resolved to turn back He had come a long way though and should lose a great deal of time by doing so Besides it was so early that there was very little fear of his being seen so he walked on

children.name: Paragraph_54
children.value: He reached the house.  There was no appearance of its inmates stirring at that early hour.  Oliver stopped, and peeped into the garden.  A child was weeding one of the little beds; as he stopped, he raised his pale face and disclosed the features of one of his former companions. Oliver felt glad to see him, before he went; for, though younger than himself, he had been his little friend and playmate.  They had been beaten, and starved, and shut up together, many and many a time.
children.prevalue: He reached the house There was no appearance of its inmates stirring at that early hour Oliver stopped and peeped into the garden A child was weeding one of the little beds as he stopped he raised his pale face and disclosed the features of one of his former companions Oliver felt glad to see him before he went for though younger than himself he had been his little friend and playmate They had been beaten and starved and shut up together many and many a time

children.name: Paragraph_55
children.value: 'Hush, Dick!' said Oliver, as the boy ran to the gate, and thrust his thin arm between the rails to greet him.  'Is any one up?'
children.prevalue: Hush Dick said Oliver as the boy ran to the gate and thrust his thin arm between the rails to greet him Is any one up

children.name: Paragraph_56
children.value: 'Nobody but me,' replied the child.
children.prevalue: Nobody but me replied the child

children.name: Paragraph_57
children.value: 'You musn't say you saw me, Dick,' said Oliver.  'I am running away. They beat and ill-use me, Dick; and I am going to seek my fortune, some long way off.  I don't know where.  How pale you are!'
children.prevalue: You musn t say you saw me Dick said Oliver I am running away They beat and ill use me Dick and I am going to seek my fortune some long way off I don t know where How pale you are

children.name: Paragraph_58
children.value: 'I heard the doctor tell them I was dying,' replied the child with a faint smile.  'I am very glad to see you, dear; but don't stop, don't stop!'
children.prevalue: I heard the doctor tell them I was dying replied the child with a faint smile I am very glad to see you dear but don t stop don t stop

children.name: Paragraph_59
children.value: 'Yes, yes, I will, to say good-b'ye to you,' replied Oliver. 'I shall see you again, Dick.  I know I shall!  You will be well and happy!'
children.prevalue: Yes yes I will to say good b ye to you replied Oliver I shall see you again Dick I know I shall You will be well and happy

children.name: Paragraph_60
children.value: 'I hope so,' replied the child.  'After I am dead, but not before.  I know the doctor must be right, Oliver, because I dream so much of Heaven, and Angels, and kind faces that I never see when I am awake. Kiss me,' said the child,  climbing up the low gate, and flinging his little arms round Oliver's neck. 'Good-b'ye, dear!  God bless you!'
children.prevalue: I hope so replied the child After I am dead but not before I know the doctor must be right Oliver because I dream so much of Heaven and Angels and kind faces that I never see when I am awake Kiss me said the child climbing up the low gate and flinging his little arms round Oliver s neck Good b ye dear God bless you

children.name: Paragraph_61
children.value: The blessing was from a young child's lips, but it was the first that Oliver had ever heard invoked upon his head; and through the struggles and sufferings, and troubles and changes, of his after life, he never once forgot it.
children.prevalue: The blessing was from a young child s lips but it was the first that Oliver had ever heard invoked upon his head and through the struggles and sufferings and troubles and changes of his after life he never once forgot it

children.name: Paragraph_1
children.value: OLIVER WALKS TO LONDON.  HE ENCOUNTERS ON THE ROAD A STRANGE SORT OF YOUNG GENTLEMAN
children.prevalue: OLIVER WALKS TO LONDON HE ENCOUNTERS ON THE ROAD A STRANGE SORT OF YOUNG GENTLEMAN

children.name: Paragraph_2
children.value: Oliver reached the stile at which the by-path terminated; and once more gained the high-road.  It was eight o'clock now. Though he was nearly five miles away from the town, he ran, and hid behind the hedges, by turns, till noon: fearing that he might be pursued and overtaken.  Then he sat down to rest by the side of the milestone, and began to think, for the first time, where he had better go and try to live.
children.prevalue: Oliver reached the stile at which the by path terminated and once more gained the high road It was eight o clock now Though he was nearly five miles away from the town he ran and hid behind the hedges by turns till noon fearing that he might be pursued and overtaken Then he sat down to rest by the side of the milestone and began to think for the first time where he had better go and try to live

children.name: Paragraph_3
children.value: The stone by which he was seated, bore, in large characters, an intimation that it was just seventy miles from that spot to London. The name awakened a new train of ideas in the boy's mind.
children.prevalue: The stone by which he was seated bore in large characters an intimation that it was just seventy miles from that spot to London The name awakened a new train of ideas in the boy s mind

children.name: Paragraph_4
children.value: London!--that great place!--nobody--not even Mr. Bumble--could ever find him there!  He had often heard the old men in the workhouse, too, say that no lad of spirit need want in London; and that there were ways of living in that vast city, which those who had been bred up in country parts had no idea of.  It was the very place for a homeless boy, who must die in the streets unless some one helped him. As these things passed through his thoughts, he jumped upon his feet, and again walked forward.
children.prevalue: London that great place nobody not even Mr Bumble could ever find him there He had often heard the old men in the workhouse too say that no lad of spirit need want in London and that there were ways of living in that vast city which those who had been bred up in country parts had no idea of It was the very place for a homeless boy who must die in the streets unless some one helped him As these things passed through his thoughts he jumped upon his feet and again walked forward

children.name: Paragraph_5
children.value: He had diminished the distance between himself and London by full four miles more, before he recollected how much he must undergo ere he could hope to reach his place of destination. As this consideration forced itself upon him, he slackened his pace a little, and meditated upon his means of getting there.  He had a crust of bread, a coarse shirt, and two pairs of stockings, in his bundle.  He had a penny too--a gift of Sowerberry's after some funeral in which he had acquitted himself more than ordinarily well--in his pocket. 'A clean shirt,' thought Oliver, 'is a very comfortable thing; and so are two pairs of darned stockings; and so is a penny; but they are small helps to a sixty-five miles' walk in winter time.'  But Oliver's thoughts, like those of most other people, although they were extremely ready and active to point out his difficulties, were wholly at a loss to suggest any feasible mode of surmounting them; so, after a good deal of thinking to no particular purpose, he changed his little bundle over to the other shoulder, and trudged on.
children.prevalue: He had diminished the distance between himself and London by full four miles more before he recollected how much he must undergo ere he could hope to reach his place of destination As this consideration forced itself upon him he slackened his pace a little and meditated upon his means of getting there He had a crust of bread a coarse shirt and two pairs of stockings in his bundle He had a penny too a gift of Sowerberry s after some funeral in which he had acquitted himself more than ordinarily well in his pocket A clean shirt thought Oliver is a very comfortable thing and so are two pairs of darned stockings and so is a penny but they are small helps to a sixty five miles walk in winter time But Oliver s thoughts like those of most other people although they were extremely ready and active to point out his difficulties were wholly at a loss to suggest any feasible mode of surmounting them so after a good deal of thinking to no particular purpose he changed his little bundle over to the other shoulder and trudged on

children.name: Paragraph_6
children.value: Oliver walked twenty miles that day; and all that time tasted nothing but the crust of dry bread, and a few draughts of water, which he begged at the cottage-doors by the road-side.  When the night came, he turned into a meadow; and, creeping close under a hay-rick, determined to lie there, till morning.  He felt frightened at first, for the wind moaned dismally over the empty fields: and he was cold and hungry, and more alone than he had ever felt before.  Being very tired with his walk, however, he soon fell asleep and forgot his troubles.
children.prevalue: Oliver walked twenty miles that day and all that time tasted nothing but the crust of dry bread and a few draughts of water which he begged at the cottage doors by the road side When the night came he turned into a meadow and creeping close under a hay rick determined to lie there till morning He felt frightened at first for the wind moaned dismally over the empty fields and he was cold and hungry and more alone than he had ever felt before Being very tired with his walk however he soon fell asleep and forgot his troubles

children.name: Paragraph_7
children.value: He felt cold and stiff, when he got up next morning, and so hungry that he was obliged to exchange the penny for a small loaf, in the very first village through which he passed.  He had walked no more than twelve miles, when night closed in again. His feet were sore, and his legs so weak that they trembled beneath him.  Another night passed in the bleak damp air, made him worse; when he set forward on his journey next morning he could hardly crawl along.
children.prevalue: He felt cold and stiff when he got up next morning and so hungry that he was obliged to exchange the penny for a small loaf in the very first village through which he passed He had walked no more than twelve miles when night closed in again His feet were sore and his legs so weak that they trembled beneath him Another night passed in the bleak damp air made him worse when he set forward on his journey next morning he could hardly crawl along

children.name: Paragraph_8
children.value: He waited at the bottom of a steep hill till a stage-coach came up, and then begged of the outside passengers; but there were very few who took any notice of him: and even those told him to wait till they got to the top of the hill, and then let them see how far he could run for a halfpenny.  Poor Oliver tried to keep up with the coach a little way, but was unable to do it, by reason of his fatigue and sore feet.  When the outsides saw this, they put their halfpence back into their pockets again, declaring that he was an idle young dog, and didn't deserve anything; and the coach rattled away and left only a cloud of dust behind.
children.prevalue: He waited at the bottom of a steep hill till a stage coach came up and then begged of the outside passengers but there were very few who took any notice of him and even those told him to wait till they got to the top of the hill and then let them see how far he could run for a halfpenny Poor Oliver tried to keep up with the coach a little way but was unable to do it by reason of his fatigue and sore feet When the outsides saw this they put their halfpence back into their pockets again declaring that he was an idle young dog and didn t deserve anything and the coach rattled away and left only a cloud of dust behind

children.name: Paragraph_9
children.value: In some villages, large painted boards were fixed up: warning all persons who begged within the district, that they would be sent to jail.  This frightened Oliver very much, and made him glad to get out of those villages with all possible expedition.  In others, he would stand about the inn-yards, and look mournfully at every one who passed: a proceeding which generally terminated in the landlady's ordering one of the post-boys who were lounging about, to drive that strange boy out of the place, for she was sure he had come to steal something.  If he begged at a farmer's house, ten to one but they threatened to set the dog on him; and when he showed his nose in a shop, they talked about the beadle--which brought Oliver's heart into his mouth,--very often the only thing he had there, for many hours together.
children.prevalue: In some villages large painted boards were fixed up warning all persons who begged within the district that they would be sent to jail This frightened Oliver very much and made him glad to get out of those villages with all possible expedition In others he would stand about the inn yards and look mournfully at every one who passed a proceeding which generally terminated in the landlady s ordering one of the post boys who were lounging about to drive that strange boy out of the place for she was sure he had come to steal something If he begged at a farmer s house ten to one but they threatened to set the dog on him and when he showed his nose in a shop they talked about the beadle which brought Oliver s heart into his mouth very often the only thing he had there for many hours together

children.name: Paragraph_10
children.value: In fact, if it had not been for a good-hearted turnpike-man, and a benevolent old lady, Oliver's troubles would have been shortened by the very same process which had put an end to his mother's; in other words, he would most assuredly have fallen dead upon the king's highway.  But the turnpike-man gave him a meal of bread and cheese; and the old lady, who had a shipwrecked grandson wandering barefoot in some distant part of the earth, took pity upon the poor orphan, and gave him what little she could afford--and more--with such kind and gentle words, and such tears of sympathy and compassion, that they sank deeper into Oliver's soul, than all the sufferings he had ever undergone.
children.prevalue: In fact if it had not been for a good hearted turnpike man and a benevolent old lady Oliver s troubles would have been shortened by the very same process which had put an end to his mother s in other words he would most assuredly have fallen dead upon the king s highway But the turnpike man gave him a meal of bread and cheese and the old lady who had a shipwrecked grandson wandering barefoot in some distant part of the earth took pity upon the poor orphan and gave him what little she could afford and more with such kind and gentle words and such tears of sympathy and compassion that they sank deeper into Oliver s soul than all the sufferings he had ever undergone

children.name: Paragraph_11
children.value: Early on the seventh morning after he had left his native place, Oliver limped slowly into the little town of Barnet. The window-shutters were closed; the street was empty; not a soul had awakened to the business of the day.  The sun was rising in all its splendid beauty; but the light only served to show the boy his own lonesomeness and desolation, as he sat, with bleeding feet and covered with dust, upon a door-step.
children.prevalue: Early on the seventh morning after he had left his native place Oliver limped slowly into the little town of Barnet The window shutters were closed the street was empty not a soul had awakened to the business of the day The sun was rising in all its splendid beauty but the light only served to show the boy his own lonesomeness and desolation as he sat with bleeding feet and covered with dust upon a door step

children.name: Paragraph_12
children.value: By degrees, the shutters were opened; the window-blinds were drawn up; and people began passing to and fro.  Some few stopped to gaze at Oliver for a moment or two, or turned round to stare at him as they hurried by; but none relieved him, or troubled themselves to inquire how he came there. He had no heart to beg. And there he sat.
children.prevalue: By degrees the shutters were opened the window blinds were drawn up and people began passing to and fro Some few stopped to gaze at Oliver for a moment or two or turned round to stare at him as they hurried by but none relieved him or troubled themselves to inquire how he came there He had no heart to beg And there he sat

children.name: Paragraph_13
children.value: He had been crouching on the step for some time: wondering at the great number of public-houses (every other house in Barnet was a tavern, large or small), gazing listlessly at the coaches as they passed through, and thinking how strange it seemed that they could do, with ease, in a few hours, what it had taken him a whole week of courage and determination beyond his years to accomplish: when he was roused by observing that a boy, who had passed him carelessly some minutes before, had returned, and was now surveying him most earnestly from the opposite side of the way.  He took little heed of this at first; but the boy remained in the same attitude of close observation so long, that Oliver raised his head, and returned his steady look.  Upon this, the boy crossed over; and walking close up to Oliver, said,
children.prevalue: He had been crouching on the step for some time wondering at the great number of public houses every other house in Barnet was a tavern large or small gazing listlessly at the coaches as they passed through and thinking how strange it seemed that they could do with ease in a few hours what it had taken him a whole week of courage and determination beyond his years to accomplish when he was roused by observing that a boy who had passed him carelessly some minutes before had returned and was now surveying him most earnestly from the opposite side of the way He took little heed of this at first but the boy remained in the same attitude of close observation so long that Oliver raised his head and returned his steady look Upon this the boy crossed over and walking close up to Oliver said

children.name: Paragraph_14
children.value: 'Hullo, my covey!  What's the row?'
children.prevalue: Hullo my covey What s the row

children.name: Paragraph_15
children.value: The boy who addressed this inquiry to the young wayfarer, was about his own age: but one of the queerest looking boys that Oliver had even seen.  He was a snub-nosed, flat-browed, common-faced boy enough; and as dirty a juvenile as one would wish to see; but he had about him all the airs and manners of a man.  He was short of his age: with rather bow-legs, and little, sharp, ugly eyes.  His hat was stuck on the top of his head so lightly, that it threatened to fall off every moment--and would have done so, very often, if the wearer had not had a knack of every now and then giving his head a sudden twitch, which brought it back to its old place again.  He wore a man's coat, which reached nearly to his heels.  He had turned the cuffs back, half-way up his arm, to get his hands out of the sleeves: apparently with the ultimate view of thrusting them into the pockets of his corduroy trousers; for there he kept them.  He was, altogether, as roystering and swaggering a young gentleman as ever stood four feet six, or something less, in the bluchers.
children.prevalue: The boy who addressed this inquiry to the young wayfarer was about his own age but one of the queerest looking boys that Oliver had even seen He was a snub nosed flat browed common faced boy enough and as dirty a juvenile as one would wish to see but he had about him all the airs and manners of a man He was short of his age with rather bow legs and little sharp ugly eyes His hat was stuck on the top of his head so lightly that it threatened to fall off every moment and would have done so very often if the wearer had not had a knack of every now and then giving his head a sudden twitch which brought it back to its old place again He wore a man s coat which reached nearly to his heels He had turned the cuffs back half way up his arm to get his hands out of the sleeves apparently with the ultimate view of thrusting them into the pockets of his corduroy trousers for there he kept them He was altogether as roystering and swaggering a young gentleman as ever stood four feet six or something less in the bluchers

children.name: Paragraph_16
children.value: 'Hullo, my covey!  What's the row?' said this strange young gentleman to Oliver.
children.prevalue: Hullo my covey What s the row said this strange young gentleman to Oliver

children.name: Paragraph_17
children.value: 'I am very hungry and tired,' replied Oliver: the tears standing in his eyes as he spoke. 'I have walked a long way.  I have been walking these seven days.'
children.prevalue: I am very hungry and tired replied Oliver the tears standing in his eyes as he spoke I have walked a long way I have been walking these seven days

children.name: Paragraph_18
children.value: 'Walking for sivin days!' said the young gentleman.  'Oh, I see. Beak's order, eh?  But,' he added, noticing Oliver's look of surprise, 'I suppose you don't know what a beak is, my flash com-pan-i-on.'
children.prevalue: Walking for sivin days said the young gentleman Oh I see Beak s order eh But he added noticing Oliver s look of surprise I suppose you don t know what a beak is my flash com pan i on

children.name: Paragraph_19
children.value: Oliver mildly replied, that he had always heard a bird's mouth described by the term in question.
children.prevalue: Oliver mildly replied that he had always heard a bird s mouth described by the term in question

children.name: Paragraph_20
children.value: 'My eyes, how green!' exclaimed the young gentleman. 'Why, a beak's a madgst'rate; and when you walk by a beak's order, it's not straight forerd, but always agoing up, and niver a coming down agin.  Was you never on the mill?'
children.prevalue: My eyes how green exclaimed the young gentleman Why a beak s a madgst rate and when you walk by a beak s order it s not straight forerd but always agoing up and niver a coming down agin Was you never on the mill

children.name: Paragraph_21
children.value: 'What mill?' inquired Oliver.
children.prevalue: What mill inquired Oliver

children.name: Paragraph_22
children.value: 'What mill!  Why, the mill--the mill as takes up so little room that it'll work inside a Stone Jug; and always goes better when the wind's low with people, than when it's high; acos then they can't get workmen. But come,' said the young gentleman; 'you want grub, and you shall have it.  I'm at low-water-mark myself--only one bob and a magpie; but, as far as it goes, I'll fork out and stump.  Up with you on your pins. There!  Now then! 'Morrice!'
children.prevalue: What mill Why the mill the mill as takes up so little room that it ll work inside a Stone Jug and always goes better when the wind s low with people than when it s high acos then they can t get workmen But come said the young gentleman you want grub and you shall have it I m at low water mark myself only one bob and a magpie but as far as it goes I ll fork out and stump Up with you on your pins There Now then Morrice

children.name: Paragraph_23
children.value: Assisting Oliver to rise, the young gentleman took him to an adjacent chandler's shop, where he purchased a sufficiency of ready-dressed ham and a half-quartern loaf, or, as he himself expressed it, 'a fourpenny bran!' the ham being kept clean and preserved from dust, by the ingenious expedient of making a hole in the loaf by pulling out a portion of the crumb, and stuffing it therein.  Taking the bread under his arm, the young gentlman turned into a small public-house, and led the way to a tap-room in the rear of the premises. Here, a pot of beer was brought in, by direction of the mysterious youth; and Oliver, falling to, at his new friend's bidding, made a long and hearty meal, during the progress of which the strange boy eyed him from time to time with great attention.
children.prevalue: Assisting Oliver to rise the young gentleman took him to an adjacent chandler s shop where he purchased a sufficiency of ready dressed ham and a half quartern loaf or as he himself expressed it a fourpenny bran the ham being kept clean and preserved from dust by the ingenious expedient of making a hole in the loaf by pulling out a portion of the crumb and stuffing it therein Taking the bread under his arm the young gentlman turned into a small public house and led the way to a tap room in the rear of the premises Here a pot of beer was brought in by direction of the mysterious youth and Oliver falling to at his new friend s bidding made a long and hearty meal during the progress of which the strange boy eyed him from time to time with great attention

children.name: Paragraph_24
children.value: 'Going to London?' said the strange boy, when Oliver had at length concluded.
children.prevalue: Going to London said the strange boy when Oliver had at length concluded

children.name: Paragraph_25
children.value: 'Yes.'
children.prevalue: Yes

children.name: Paragraph_26
children.value: 'Got any lodgings?'
children.prevalue: Got any lodgings

children.name: Paragraph_27
children.value: 'No.'
children.prevalue: No

children.name: Paragraph_28
children.value: 'Money?'
children.prevalue: Money

children.name: Paragraph_29
children.value: 'No.'
children.prevalue: No

children.name: Paragraph_30
children.value: The strange boy whistled; and put his arms into his pockets, as far as the big coat-sleeves would let them go.
children.prevalue: The strange boy whistled and put his arms into his pockets as far as the big coat sleeves would let them go

children.name: Paragraph_31
children.value: 'Do you live in London?' inquired Oliver.
children.prevalue: Do you live in London inquired Oliver

children.name: Paragraph_32
children.value: 'Yes. I do, when I'm at home,' replied the boy. 'I suppose you want some place to sleep in to-night, don't you?'
children.prevalue: Yes I do when I m at home replied the boy I suppose you want some place to sleep in to night don t you

children.name: Paragraph_33
children.value: 'I do, indeed,' answered Oliver. 'I have not slept under a roof since I left the country.'
children.prevalue: I do indeed answered Oliver I have not slept under a roof since I left the country

children.name: Paragraph_34
children.value: 'Don't fret your eyelids on that score,' said the young gentleman. 'I've got to be in London to-night; and I know a 'spectable old gentleman as lives there, wot'll give you lodgings for nothink, and never ask for the change--that is, if any genelman he knows interduces you. And don't he know me?  Oh, no! Not in the least!  By no means. Certainly not!'
children.prevalue: Don t fret your eyelids on that score said the young gentleman I ve got to be in London to night and I know a spectable old gentleman as lives there wot ll give you lodgings for nothink and never ask for the change that is if any genelman he knows interduces you And don t he know me Oh no Not in the least By no means Certainly not

children.name: Paragraph_35
children.value: The young gentleman smiled, as if to intimate that the latter fragments of discourse were playfully ironical; and finished the beer as he did so.
children.prevalue: The young gentleman smiled as if to intimate that the latter fragments of discourse were playfully ironical and finished the beer as he did so

children.name: Paragraph_36
children.value: This unexpected offer of shelter was too tempting to be resisted; especially as it was immediately followed up, by the assurance that the old gentleman referred to, would doubtless provide Oliver with a comfortable place, without loss of time.  This led to a more friendly and confidential dialogue; from which Oliver discovered that his friend's name was Jack Dawkins, and that he was a peculiar pet and protege of the elderly gentleman before mentioned.
children.prevalue: This unexpected offer of shelter was too tempting to be resisted especially as it was immediately followed up by the assurance that the old gentleman referred to would doubtless provide Oliver with a comfortable place without loss of time This led to a more friendly and confidential dialogue from which Oliver discovered that his friend s name was Jack Dawkins and that he was a peculiar pet and protege of the elderly gentleman before mentioned

children.name: Paragraph_37
children.value: Mr. Dawkin's appearance did not say a vast deal in favour of the comforts which his patron's interest obtained for those whom he took under his protection; but, as he had a rather flightly and dissolute mode of conversing, and furthermore avowed that among his intimate friends he was better known by the sobriquet of 'The Artful Dodger,' Oliver concluded that, being of a dissipated and careless turn, the moral precepts of his benefactor had hitherto been thrown away upon him.  Under this impression, he secretly resolved to cultivate the good opinion of the old gentleman as quickly as possible; and, if he found the Dodger incorrigible, as he more than half suspected he should, to decline the honour of his farther acquaintance.
children.prevalue: Mr Dawkin s appearance did not say a vast deal in favour of the comforts which his patron s interest obtained for those whom he took under his protection but as he had a rather flightly and dissolute mode of conversing and furthermore avowed that among his intimate friends he was better known by the sobriquet of The Artful Dodger Oliver concluded that being of a dissipated and careless turn the moral precepts of his benefactor had hitherto been thrown away upon him Under this impression he secretly resolved to cultivate the good opinion of the old gentleman as quickly as possible and if he found the Dodger incorrigible as he more than half suspected he should to decline the honour of his farther acquaintance

children.name: Paragraph_38
children.value: As John Dawkins objected to their entering London before nightfall, it was nearly eleven o'clock when they reached the turnpike at Islington. They crossed from the Angel into St. John's Road; struck down the small street which terminates at Sadler's Wells Theatre; through Exmouth Street and Coppice Row; down the little court by the side of the workhouse; across the classic ground which once bore the name of Hockley-in-the-Hole; thence into Little Saffron Hill; and so into Saffron Hill the Great: along which the Dodger scudded at a rapid pace, directing Oliver to follow close at his heels.

children.name: Paragraph_39
children.value: Although Oliver had enough to occupy his attention in keeping sight of his leader, he could not help bestowing a few hasty glances on either side of the way, as he passed along.  A dirtier or more wretched place he had never seen.  The street was very narrow and muddy, and the air was impregnated with filthy odours.
children.prevalue: Although Oliver had enough to occupy his attention in keeping sight of his leader he could not help bestowing a few hasty glances on either side of the way as he passed along A dirtier or more wretched place he had never seen The street was very narrow and muddy and the air was impregnated with filthy odours

children.name: Paragraph_40
children.value: There were a good many small shops; but the only stock in trade appeared to be heaps of children, who, even at that time of night, were crawling in and out at the doors, or screaming from the inside.  The sole places that seemed to prosper amid the general blight of the place, were the public-houses; and in them, the lowest orders of Irish were wrangling with might and main. Covered ways and yards, which here and there diverged from the main street, disclosed little knots of houses, where drunken men and women were positively wallowing in filth; and from several of the door-ways, great ill-looking fellows were cautiously emerging, bound, to all appearance, on no very well-disposed or harmless errands.
children.prevalue: There were a good many small shops but the only stock in trade appeared to be heaps of children who even at that time of night were crawling in and out at the doors or screaming from the inside The sole places that seemed to prosper amid the general blight of the place were the public houses and in them the lowest orders of Irish were wrangling with might and main Covered ways and yards which here and there diverged from the main street disclosed little knots of houses where drunken men and women were positively wallowing in filth and from several of the door ways great ill looking fellows were cautiously emerging bound to all appearance on no very well disposed or harmless errands

children.name: Paragraph_41
children.value: Oliver was just considering whether he hadn't better run away, when they reached the bottom of the hill.  His conductor, catching him by the arm, pushed open the door of a house near Field Lane; and drawing him into the passage, closed it behind them.
children.prevalue: Oliver was just considering whether he hadn t better run away when they reached the bottom of the hill His conductor catching him by the arm pushed open the door of a house near Field Lane and drawing him into the passage closed it behind them

children.name: Paragraph_42
children.value: 'Now, then!' cried a voice from below, in reply to a whistle from the Dodger.
children.prevalue: Now then cried a voice from below in reply to a whistle from the Dodger

children.name: Paragraph_43
children.value: 'Plummy and slam!' was the reply.
children.prevalue: Plummy and slam was the reply

children.name: Paragraph_44
children.value: This seemed to be some watchword or signal that all was right; for the light of a feeble candle gleamed on the wall at the remote end of the passage; and a man's face peeped out, from where a balustrade of the old kitchen staircase had been broken away.
children.prevalue: This seemed to be some watchword or signal that all was right for the light of a feeble candle gleamed on the wall at the remote end of the passage and a man s face peeped out from where a balustrade of the old kitchen staircase had been broken away

children.name: Paragraph_45
children.value: 'There's two on you,' said the man, thrusting the candle farther out, and shielding his eyes with his hand.  'Who's the t'other one?'
children.prevalue: There s two on you said the man thrusting the candle farther out and shielding his eyes with his hand Who s the t other one

children.name: Paragraph_46
children.value: 'A new pal,' replied Jack Dawkins, pulling Oliver forward.
children.prevalue: A new pal replied Jack Dawkins pulling Oliver forward

children.name: Paragraph_47
children.value: 'Where did he come from?'
children.prevalue: Where did he come from

children.name: Paragraph_48
children.value: 'Greenland. Is Fagin upstairs?'
children.prevalue: Greenland Is Fagin upstairs

children.name: Paragraph_49
children.value: 'Yes, he's a sortin' the wipes.  Up with you!'  The candle was drawn back, and the face disappeared.
children.prevalue: Yes he s a sortin the wipes Up with you The candle was drawn back and the face disappeared

children.name: Paragraph_50
children.value: Oliver, groping his way with one hand, and having the other firmly grasped by his companion, ascended with much difficulty the dark and broken stairs: which his conductor mounted with an ease and expedition that showed he was well acquainted with them.
children.prevalue: Oliver groping his way with one hand and having the other firmly grasped by his companion ascended with much difficulty the dark and broken stairs which his conductor mounted with an ease and expedition that showed he was well acquainted with them

children.name: Paragraph_51
children.value: He threw open the door of a back-room, and drew Oliver in after him.
children.prevalue: He threw open the door of a back room and drew Oliver in after him

children.name: Paragraph_52
children.value: The walls and ceiling of the room were perfectly black with age and dirt.  There was a deal table before the fire: upon which were a candle, stuck in a ginger-beer bottle, two or three pewter pots, a loaf and butter, and a plate.  In a frying-pan, which was on the fire, and which was secured to the mantelshelf by a string, some sausages were cooking; and standing over them, with a toasting-fork in his hand, was a very old shrivelled Jew, whose villainous-looking and repulsive face was obscured by a quantity of matted red hair. He was dressed in a greasy flannel gown, with his throat bare; and seemed to be dividing his attention between the frying-pan and the clothes-horse, over which a great number of silk handkerchiefs were hanging.  Several rough beds made of old sacks, were huddled side by side on the floor. Seated round the table were four or five boys, none older than the Dodger, smoking long clay pipes, and drinking spirits with the air of middle-aged men. These all crowded about their associate as he whispered a few words to the Jew; and then turned round and grinned at Oliver.  So did the Jew himself, toasting-fork in hand.
children.prevalue: The walls and ceiling of the room were perfectly black with age and dirt There was a deal table before the fire upon which were a candle stuck in a ginger beer bottle two or three pewter pots a loaf and butter and a plate In a frying pan which was on the fire and which was secured to the mantelshelf by a string some sausages were cooking and standing over them with a toasting fork in his hand was a very old shrivelled Jew whose villainous looking and repulsive face was obscured by a quantity of matted red hair He was dressed in a greasy flannel gown with his throat bare and seemed to be dividing his attention between the frying pan and the clothes horse over which a great number of silk handkerchiefs were hanging Several rough beds made of old sacks were huddled side by side on the floor Seated round the table were four or five boys none older than the Dodger smoking long clay pipes and drinking spirits with the air of middle aged men These all crowded about their associate as he whispered a few words to the Jew and then turned round and grinned at Oliver So did the Jew himself toasting fork in hand

children.name: Paragraph_53
children.value: 'This is him, Fagin,' said Jack Dawkins;'my friend Oliver Twist.'
children.prevalue: This is him Fagin said Jack Dawkins my friend Oliver Twist

children.name: Paragraph_54
children.value: The Jew grinned; and, making a low obeisance to Oliver, took him by the hand, and hoped he should have the honour of his intimate acquaintance. Upon this, the young gentleman with the pipes came round him, and shook both his hands very hard--especially the one in which he held his little bundle.  One young gentleman was very anxious to hang up his cap for him; and another was so obliging as to put his hands in his pockets, in order that, as he was very tired, he might not have the trouble of emptying them, himself, when he went to bed.  These civilities would probably be extended much farther, but for a liberal exercise of the Jew's toasting-fork on the heads and shoulders of the affectionate youths who offered them.
children.prevalue: The Jew grinned and making a low obeisance to Oliver took him by the hand and hoped he should have the honour of his intimate acquaintance Upon this the young gentleman with the pipes came round him and shook both his hands very hard especially the one in which he held his little bundle One young gentleman was very anxious to hang up his cap for him and another was so obliging as to put his hands in his pockets in order that as he was very tired he might not have the trouble of emptying them himself when he went to bed These civilities would probably be extended much farther but for a liberal exercise of the Jew s toasting fork on the heads and shoulders of the affectionate youths who offered them

children.name: Paragraph_55
children.value: 'We are very glad to see you, Oliver, very,' said the Jew. 'Dodger, take off the sausages; and draw a tub near the fire for Oliver.  Ah, you're a-staring at the pocket-handkerchiefs! eh, my dear. There are a good many of 'em, ain't there? We've just looked 'em out, ready for the wash; that's all, Oliver; that's all. Ha! ha! ha!'
children.prevalue: We are very glad to see you Oliver very said the Jew Dodger take off the sausages and draw a tub near the fire for Oliver Ah you re a staring at the pocket handkerchiefs eh my dear There are a good many of em ain t there We ve just looked em out ready for the wash that s all Oliver that s all Ha ha ha

children.name: Paragraph_56
children.value: The latter part of this speech, was hailed by a boisterous shout from all the hopeful pupils of the merry old gentleman. In the midst of which they went to supper.
children.prevalue: The latter part of this speech was hailed by a boisterous shout from all the hopeful pupils of the merry old gentleman In the midst of which they went to supper

children.name: Paragraph_57
children.value: Oliver ate his share, and the Jew then mixed him a glass of hot gin-and-water: telling him he must drink it off directly, because another gentleman wanted the tumbler. Oliver did as he was desired. Immediately afterwards he felt himself gently lifted on to one of the sacks; and then he sunk into a deep sleep.
children.prevalue: Oliver ate his share and the Jew then mixed him a glass of hot gin and water telling him he must drink it off directly because another gentleman wanted the tumbler Oliver did as he was desired Immediately afterwards he felt himself gently lifted on to one of the sacks and then he sunk into a deep sleep

children.name: Paragraph_1
children.value: CONTAINING FURTHER PARTICULARS CONCERNING THE PLEASANT OLD GENTLEMAN, AND HIS HOPEFUL PUPILS
children.prevalue: CONTAINING FURTHER PARTICULARS CONCERNING THE PLEASANT OLD GENTLEMAN AND HIS HOPEFUL PUPILS

children.name: Paragraph_2
children.value: It was late next morning when Oliver awoke, from a sound, long sleep. There was no other person in the room but the old Jew, who was boiling some coffee in a saucepan for breakfast, and whistling softly to himself as he stirred it round and round, with an iron spoon. He would stop every now and then to listen when there was the least noise below: and when he had satisfied himself, he would go on whistling and stirring again, as before.
children.prevalue: It was late next morning when Oliver awoke from a sound long sleep There was no other person in the room but the old Jew who was boiling some coffee in a saucepan for breakfast and whistling softly to himself as he stirred it round and round with an iron spoon He would stop every now and then to listen when there was the least noise below and when he had satisfied himself he would go on whistling and stirring again as before

children.name: Paragraph_3
children.value: Although Oliver had roused himself from sleep, he was not thoroughly awake. There is a drowsy state, between sleeping and waking, when you dream more in five minutes with your eyes half open, and yourself half conscious of everything that is passing around you, than you would in five nights with your eyes fast closed, and your senses wrapt in perfect unconsciousness. At such time, a mortal knows just enough of what his mind is doing, to form some glimmering conception of its mighty powers, its bounding from earth and spurning time and space, when freed from the restraint of its corporeal associate.
children.prevalue: Although Oliver had roused himself from sleep he was not thoroughly awake There is a drowsy state between sleeping and waking when you dream more in five minutes with your eyes half open and yourself half conscious of everything that is passing around you than you would in five nights with your eyes fast closed and your senses wrapt in perfect unconsciousness At such time a mortal knows just enough of what his mind is doing to form some glimmering conception of its mighty powers its bounding from earth and spurning time and space when freed from the restraint of its corporeal associate

children.name: Paragraph_4
children.value: Oliver was precisely in this condition. He saw the Jew with his half-closed eyes; heard his low whistling; and recognised the sound of the spoon grating against the saucepan's sides: and yet the self-same senses were mentally engaged, at the same time, in busy action with almost everybody he had ever known.
children.prevalue: Oliver was precisely in this condition He saw the Jew with his half closed eyes heard his low whistling and recognised the sound of the spoon grating against the saucepan s sides and yet the self same senses were mentally engaged at the same time in busy action with almost everybody he had ever known

children.name: Paragraph_5
children.value: When the coffee was done, the Jew drew the saucepan to the hob. Standing, then in an irresolute attitude for a few minutes, as if he did not well know how to employ himself, he turned round and looked at Oliver, and called him by his name. He did not answer, and was to all appearances asleep.
children.prevalue: When the coffee was done the Jew drew the saucepan to the hob Standing then in an irresolute attitude for a few minutes as if he did not well know how to employ himself he turned round and looked at Oliver and called him by his name He did not answer and was to all appearances asleep

children.name: Paragraph_6
children.value: After satisfying himself upon this head, the Jew stepped gently to the door: which he fastened. He then drew forth: as it seemed to Oliver, from some trap in the floor: a small box, which he placed carefully on the table. His eyes glistened as he raised the lid, and looked in. Dragging an old chair to the table, he sat down; and took from it a magnificent gold watch, sparkling with jewels.
children.prevalue: After satisfying himself upon this head the Jew stepped gently to the door which he fastened He then drew forth as it seemed to Oliver from some trap in the floor a small box which he placed carefully on the table His eyes glistened as he raised the lid and looked in Dragging an old chair to the table he sat down and took from it a magnificent gold watch sparkling with jewels

children.name: Paragraph_7
children.value: 'Aha!' said the Jew, shrugging up his shoulders, and distorting every feature with a hideous grin. 'Clever dogs! Clever dogs! Staunch to the last! Never told the old parson where they were. Never poached upon old Fagin! And why should they? It wouldn't have loosened the knot, or kept the drop up, a minute longer. No, no, no! Fine fellows! Fine fellows!'
children.prevalue: Aha said the Jew shrugging up his shoulders and distorting every feature with a hideous grin Clever dogs Clever dogs Staunch to the last Never told the old parson where they were Never poached upon old Fagin And why should they It wouldn t have loosened the knot or kept the drop up a minute longer No no no Fine fellows Fine fellows

children.name: Paragraph_8
children.value: With these, and other muttered reflections of the like nature, the Jew once more deposited the watch in its place of safety. At least half a dozen more were severally drawn forth from the same box, and surveyed with equal pleasure; besides rings, brooches, bracelets, and other articles of jewellery, of such magnificent materials, and costly workmanship, that Oliver had no idea, even of their names.
children.prevalue: With these and other muttered reflections of the like nature the Jew once more deposited the watch in its place of safety At least half a dozen more were severally drawn forth from the same box and surveyed with equal pleasure besides rings brooches bracelets and other articles of jewellery of such magnificent materials and costly workmanship that Oliver had no idea even of their names

children.name: Paragraph_9
children.value: Having replaced these trinkets, the Jew took out another: so small that it lay in the palm of his hand. There seemed to be some very minute inscription on it; for the Jew laid it flat upon the table, and shading it with his hand, pored over it, long and earnestly. At length he put it down, as if despairing of success; and, leaning back in his chair, muttered:
children.prevalue: Having replaced these trinkets the Jew took out another so small that it lay in the palm of his hand There seemed to be some very minute inscription on it for the Jew laid it flat upon the table and shading it with his hand pored over it long and earnestly At length he put it down as if despairing of success and leaning back in his chair muttered

children.name: Paragraph_10
children.value: 'What a fine thing capital punishment is! Dead men never repent; dead men never bring awkward stories to light. Ah, it's a fine thing for the trade! Five of 'em strung up in a row, and none left to play booty, or turn white-livered!'
children.prevalue: What a fine thing capital punishment is Dead men never repent dead men never bring awkward stories to light Ah it s a fine thing for the trade Five of em strung up in a row and none left to play booty or turn white livered

children.name: Paragraph_11
children.value: As the Jew uttered these words, his bright dark eyes, which had been staring vacantly before him, fell on Oliver's face; the boy's eyes were fixed on his in mute curiousity; and although the recognition was only for an instant--for the briefest space of time that can possibly be conceived--it was enough to show the old man that he had been observed.
children.prevalue: As the Jew uttered these words his bright dark eyes which had been staring vacantly before him fell on Oliver s face the boy s eyes were fixed on his in mute curiousity and although the recognition was only for an instant for the briefest space of time that can possibly be conceived it was enough to show the old man that he had been observed

children.name: Paragraph_12
children.value: He closed the lid of the box with a loud crash; and, laying his hand on a bread knife which was on the table, started furiously up. He trembled very much though; for, even in his terror, Oliver could see that the knife quivered in the air.
children.prevalue: He closed the lid of the box with a loud crash and laying his hand on a bread knife which was on the table started furiously up He trembled very much though for even in his terror Oliver could see that the knife quivered in the air

children.name: Paragraph_13
children.value: 'What's that?' said the Jew. 'What do you watch me for? Why are you awake? What have you seen? Speak out, boy! Quick--quick! for your life.
children.prevalue: What s that said the Jew What do you watch me for Why are you awake What have you seen Speak out boy Quick quick for your life

children.name: Paragraph_14
children.value: 'I wasn't able to sleep any longer, sir,' replied Oliver, meekly. 'I am very sorry if I have disturbed you, sir.'
children.prevalue: I wasn t able to sleep any longer sir replied Oliver meekly I am very sorry if I have disturbed you sir

children.name: Paragraph_15
children.value: 'You were not awake an hour ago?' said the Jew, scowling fiercely on the boy.
children.prevalue: You were not awake an hour ago said the Jew scowling fiercely on the boy

children.name: Paragraph_16
children.value: 'No! No, indeed!' replied Oliver.
children.prevalue: No No indeed replied Oliver

children.name: Paragraph_17
children.value: 'Are you sure?' cried the Jew: with a still fiercer look than before: and a threatening attitude.
children.prevalue: Are you sure cried the Jew with a still fiercer look than before and a threatening attitude

children.name: Paragraph_18
children.value: 'Upon my word I was not, sir,' replied Oliver, earnestly. 'I was not, indeed, sir.'
children.prevalue: Upon my word I was not sir replied Oliver earnestly I was not indeed sir

children.name: Paragraph_19
children.value: 'Tush, tush, my dear!' said the Jew, abruptly resuming his old manner, and playing with the knife a little, before he laid it down; as if to induce the belief that he had caught it up, in mere sport. 'Of course I know that, my dear. I only tried to frighten you. You're a brave boy. Ha! ha! you're a brave boy, Oliver.' The Jew rubbed his hands with a chuckle, but glanced uneasily at the box, notwithstanding.
children.prevalue: Tush tush my dear said the Jew abruptly resuming his old manner and playing with the knife a little before he laid it down as if to induce the belief that he had caught it up in mere sport Of course I know that my dear I only tried to frighten you You re a brave boy Ha ha you re a brave boy Oliver The Jew rubbed his hands with a chuckle but glanced uneasily at the box notwithstanding

children.name: Paragraph_20
children.value: 'Did you see any of these pretty things, my dear?' said the Jew, laying his hand upon it after a short pause.
children.prevalue: Did you see any of these pretty things my dear said the Jew laying his hand upon it after a short pause

children.name: Paragraph_21
children.value: 'Yes, sir,' replied Oliver.
children.prevalue: Yes sir replied Oliver

children.name: Paragraph_22
children.value: 'Ah!' said the Jew, turning rather pale. 'They--they're mine, Oliver; my little property. All I have to live upon, in my old age. The folks call me a miser, my dear. Only a miser; that's all.'
children.prevalue: Ah said the Jew turning rather pale They they re mine Oliver my little property All I have to live upon in my old age The folks call me a miser my dear Only a miser that s all

children.name: Paragraph_23
children.value: Oliver thought the old gentleman must be a decided miser to live in such a dirty place, with so many watches; but, thinking that perhaps his fondness for the Dodger and the other boys, cost him a good deal of money, he only cast a deferential look at the Jew, and asked if he might get up.
children.prevalue: Oliver thought the old gentleman must be a decided miser to live in such a dirty place with so many watches but thinking that perhaps his fondness for the Dodger and the other boys cost him a good deal of money he only cast a deferential look at the Jew and asked if he might get up

children.name: Paragraph_24
children.value: 'Certainly, my dear, certainly,' replied the old gentleman. 'Stay. There's a pitcher of water in the corner by the door. Bring it here; and I'll give you a basin to wash in, my dear.'
children.prevalue: Certainly my dear certainly replied the old gentleman Stay There s a pitcher of water in the corner by the door Bring it here and I ll give you a basin to wash in my dear

children.name: Paragraph_25
children.value: Oliver got up; walked across the room; and stooped for an instant to raise the pitcher.  When he turned his head, the box was gone.
children.prevalue: Oliver got up walked across the room and stooped for an instant to raise the pitcher When he turned his head the box was gone

children.name: Paragraph_26
children.value: He had scarcely washed himself, and made everything tidy, by emptying the basin out of the window, agreeably to the Jew's directions, when the Dodger returned: accompanied by a very sprightly young friend, whom Oliver had seen smoking on the previous night, and who was now formally introduced to him as Charley Bates. The four sat down, to breakfast, on the coffee, and some hot rolls and ham which the Dodger had brought home in the crown of his hat.
children.prevalue: He had scarcely washed himself and made everything tidy by emptying the basin out of the window agreeably to the Jew s directions when the Dodger returned accompanied by a very sprightly young friend whom Oliver had seen smoking on the previous night and who was now formally introduced to him as Charley Bates The four sat down to breakfast on the coffee and some hot rolls and ham which the Dodger had brought home in the crown of his hat

children.name: Paragraph_27
children.value: 'Well,' said the Jew, glancing slyly at Oliver, and addressing himself to the Dodger, 'I hope you've been at work this morning, my dears?'
children.prevalue: Well said the Jew glancing slyly at Oliver and addressing himself to the Dodger I hope you ve been at work this morning my dears

children.name: Paragraph_28
children.value: 'Hard,' replied the Dodger.
children.prevalue: Hard replied the Dodger

children.name: Paragraph_29
children.value: 'As nails,' added Charley Bates.
children.prevalue: As nails added Charley Bates

children.name: Paragraph_30
children.value: 'Good boys, good boys!' said the Jew. 'What have you got, Dodger?'
children.prevalue: Good boys good boys said the Jew What have you got Dodger

children.name: Paragraph_31
children.value: 'A couple of pocket-books,' replied that young gentlman.
children.prevalue: A couple of pocket books replied that young gentlman

children.name: Paragraph_32
children.value: 'Lined?' inquired the Jew, with eagerness.
children.prevalue: Lined inquired the Jew with eagerness

children.name: Paragraph_33
children.value: 'Pretty well,' replied the Dodger, producing two pocket-books; one green, and the other red.
children.prevalue: Pretty well replied the Dodger producing two pocket books one green and the other red

children.name: Paragraph_34
children.value: 'Not so heavy as they might be,' said the Jew, after looking at the insides carefully; 'but very neat and nicely made.  Ingenious workman, ain't he, Oliver?'
children.prevalue: Not so heavy as they might be said the Jew after looking at the insides carefully but very neat and nicely made Ingenious workman ain t he Oliver

children.name: Paragraph_35
children.value: 'Very indeed, sir,' said Oliver. At which Mr. Charles Bates laughed uproariously; very much to the amazement of Oliver, who saw nothing to laugh at, in anything that had passed.
children.prevalue: Very indeed sir said Oliver At which Mr Charles Bates laughed uproariously very much to the amazement of Oliver who saw nothing to laugh at in anything that had passed

children.name: Paragraph_36
children.value: 'And what have you got, my dear?' said Fagin to Charley Bates.
children.prevalue: And what have you got my dear said Fagin to Charley Bates

children.name: Paragraph_37
children.value: 'Wipes,' replied Master Bates; at the same time producing four pocket-handkerchiefs.
children.prevalue: Wipes replied Master Bates at the same time producing four pocket handkerchiefs

children.name: Paragraph_38
children.value: 'Well,' said the Jew, inspecting them closely; 'they're very good ones, very. You haven't marked them well, though, Charley; so the marks shall be picked out with a needle, and we'll teach Oliver how to do it. Shall us, Oliver, eh? Ha! ha! ha!'
children.prevalue: Well said the Jew inspecting them closely they re very good ones very You haven t marked them well though Charley so the marks shall be picked out with a needle and we ll teach Oliver how to do it Shall us Oliver eh Ha ha ha

children.name: Paragraph_39
children.value: 'If you please, sir,' said Oliver.
children.prevalue: If you please sir said Oliver

children.name: Paragraph_40
children.value: 'You'd like to be able to make pocket-handkerchiefs as easy as Charley Bates, wouldn't you, my dear?' said the Jew.
children.prevalue: You d like to be able to make pocket handkerchiefs as easy as Charley Bates wouldn t you my dear said the Jew

children.name: Paragraph_41
children.value: 'Very much, indeed, if you'll teach me, sir,' replied Oliver.
children.prevalue: Very much indeed if you ll teach me sir replied Oliver

children.name: Paragraph_42
children.value: Master Bates saw something so exquisitely ludicrous in this reply, that he burst into another laugh; which laugh, meeting the coffee he was drinking, and carrying it down some wrong channel, very nearly terminated in his premature suffocation.
children.prevalue: Master Bates saw something so exquisitely ludicrous in this reply that he burst into another laugh which laugh meeting the coffee he was drinking and carrying it down some wrong channel very nearly terminated in his premature suffocation

children.name: Paragraph_43
children.value: 'He is so jolly green!' said Charley when he recovered, as an apology to the company for his unpolite behaviour.
children.prevalue: He is so jolly green said Charley when he recovered as an apology to the company for his unpolite behaviour

children.name: Paragraph_44
children.value: The Dodger said nothing, but he smoothed Oliver's hair over his eyes, and said he'd know better, by and by; upon which the old gentleman, observing Oliver's colour mounting, changed the subject by asking whether there had been much of a crowd at the execution that morning? This made him wonder more and more; for it was plain from the replies of the two boys that they had both been there; and Oliver naturally wondered how they could possibly have found time to be so very industrious.
children.prevalue: The Dodger said nothing but he smoothed Oliver s hair over his eyes and said he d know better by and by upon which the old gentleman observing Oliver s colour mounting changed the subject by asking whether there had been much of a crowd at the execution that morning This made him wonder more and more for it was plain from the replies of the two boys that they had both been there and Oliver naturally wondered how they could possibly have found time to be so very industrious

children.name: Paragraph_45
children.value: When the breakfast was cleared away; the merry old gentlman and the two boys played at a very curious and uncommon game, which was performed in this way. The merry old gentleman, placing a snuff-box in one pocket of his trousers, a note-case in the other, and a watch in his waistcoat pocket, with a guard-chain round his neck, and sticking a mock diamond pin in his shirt: buttoned his coat tight round him, and putting his spectacle-case and handkerchief in his pockets, trotted up and down the room with a stick, in imitation of the manner in which old gentlemen walk about the streets any hour in the day.  Sometimes he stopped at the fire-place, and sometimes at the door, making believe that he was staring with all his might into shop-windows.  At such times, he would look constantly round him, for fear of thieves, and would keep slapping all his pockets in turn, to see that he hadn't lost anything, in such a very funny and natural manner, that Oliver laughed till the tears ran down his face.
