children.value: Having disposed of these evil-minded persons for the night, Mr. Bumble sat himself down in the house at which the coach stopped; and took a temperate dinner of steaks, oyster sauce, and porter. Putting a glass of hot gin-and-water on the chimney-piece, he drew his chair to the fire; and, with sundry moral reflections on the too-prevalent sin of discontent and complaining, composed himself to read the paper.

children.name: Paragraph_64
children.value: 'Whereas a young boy, named Oliver Twist, absconded, or was enticed, on Thursday evening last, from his home, at Pentonville; and has not since been heard of.  The above reward will be paid to any person who will give such information as will lead to the discovery of the said Oliver Twist, or tend to throw any light upon his previous history, in which the advertiser is, for many reasons, warmly interested.'

children.name: Paragraph_81
children.value: Mr. Brownlow gently shook his head to impose silence on his friend, and resumed:
children.prevalue: Mr Brownlow gently shook his head to impose silence on his friend and resumed

children.name: Paragraph_82
children.value: 'Do you know where this poor boy is now?'
children.prevalue: Do you know where this poor boy is now

children.name: Paragraph_83
children.value: 'No more than nobody,' replied Mr. Bumble.
children.prevalue: No more than nobody replied Mr Bumble

children.name: Paragraph_84
children.value: 'Well, what DO you know of him?' inquired the old gentleman. 'Speak out, my friend, if you have anything to say.  What DO you know of him?'
children.prevalue: Well what DO you know of him inquired the old gentleman Speak out my friend if you have anything to say What DO you know of him

children.name: Paragraph_85
children.value: 'You don't happen to know any good of him, do you?' said Mr. Grimwig, caustically; after an attentive perusal of Mr. Bumble's features.
children.prevalue: You don t happen to know any good of him do you said Mr Grimwig caustically after an attentive perusal of Mr Bumble s features

children.name: Paragraph_86
children.value: Mr. Bumble, catching at the inquiry very quickly, shook his head with portentous solemnity.
children.prevalue: Mr Bumble catching at the inquiry very quickly shook his head with portentous solemnity

children.name: Paragraph_87
children.value: 'You see?' said Mr. Grimwig, looking triumphantly at Mr. Brownlow.
children.prevalue: You see said Mr Grimwig looking triumphantly at Mr Brownlow

children.name: Paragraph_88
children.value: Mr. Brownlow looked apprehensively at Mr. Bumble's pursed-up countenance; and requested him to communicate what he knew regarding Oliver, in as few words as possible.
children.prevalue: Mr Brownlow looked apprehensively at Mr Bumble s pursed up countenance and requested him to communicate what he knew regarding Oliver in as few words as possible

children.name: Paragraph_89
children.value: Mr. Bumble put down his hat; unbuttoned his coat; folded his arms; inclined his head in a retrospective manner; and, after a few moments' reflection, commenced his story.
children.prevalue: Mr Bumble put down his hat unbuttoned his coat folded his arms inclined his head in a retrospective manner and after a few moments reflection commenced his story

children.name: Paragraph_90
children.value: It would be tedious if given in the beadle's words:  occupying, as it did, some twenty minutes in the telling; but the sum and substance of it was, that Oliver was a foundling, born of low and vicious parents. That he had, from his birth, displayed no better qualities than treachery, ingratitude, and malice.  That he had terminated his brief career in the place of his birth, by making a sanguinary and cowardly attack on an unoffending lad, and running away in the night-time from his master's house.  In proof of his really being the person he represented himself, Mr. Bumble laid upon the table the papers he had brought to town. Folding his arms again, he then awaited Mr. Brownlow's observations.
children.prevalue: It would be tedious if given in the beadle s words occupying as it did some twenty minutes in the telling but the sum and substance of it was that Oliver was a foundling born of low and vicious parents That he had from his birth displayed no better qualities than treachery ingratitude and malice That he had terminated his brief career in the place of his birth by making a sanguinary and cowardly attack on an unoffending lad and running away in the night time from his master s house In proof of his really being the person he represented himself Mr Bumble laid upon the table the papers he had brought to town Folding his arms again he then awaited Mr Brownlow s observations

children.name: Paragraph_91
children.value: 'I fear it is all too true,' said the old gentleman sorrowfully, after looking over the papers.  'This is not much for your intelligence; but I would gladly have given you treble the money, if it had been favourable to the boy.'
children.prevalue: I fear it is all too true said the old gentleman sorrowfully after looking over the papers This is not much for your intelligence but I would gladly have given you treble the money if it had been favourable to the boy

children.name: Paragraph_92
children.value: It is not improbable that if Mr. Bumble had been possessed of this information at an earlier period of the interview, he might have imparted a very different colouring to his little history. It was too late to do it now, however; so he shook his head gravely, and, pocketing the five guineas, withdrew.
children.prevalue: It is not improbable that if Mr Bumble had been possessed of this information at an earlier period of the interview he might have imparted a very different colouring to his little history It was too late to do it now however so he shook his head gravely and pocketing the five guineas withdrew

children.name: Paragraph_93
children.value: Mr. Brownlow paced the room to and fro for some minutes; evidently so much disturbed by the beadle's tale, that even Mr. Grimwig forbore to vex him further.
children.prevalue: Mr Brownlow paced the room to and fro for some minutes evidently so much disturbed by the beadle s tale that even Mr Grimwig forbore to vex him further

children.name: Paragraph_94
children.value: At length he stopped, and rang the bell violently.
children.prevalue: At length he stopped and rang the bell violently

children.name: Paragraph_95
children.value: 'Mrs. Bedwin,' said Mr. Brownlow, when the housekeeper appeared; 'that boy, Oliver, is an imposter.'
children.prevalue: Mrs Bedwin said Mr Brownlow when the housekeeper appeared that boy Oliver is an imposter

children.name: Paragraph_96
children.value: 'It can't be, sir.  It cannot be,' said the old lady energetically.
children.prevalue: It can t be sir It cannot be said the old lady energetically

children.name: Paragraph_97
children.value: 'I tell you he is,' retorted the old gentleman.  'What do you mean by can't be?  We have just heard a full account of him from his birth; and he has been a thorough-paced little villain, all his life.'
children.prevalue: I tell you he is retorted the old gentleman What do you mean by can t be We have just heard a full account of him from his birth and he has been a thorough paced little villain all his life

children.name: Paragraph_98
children.value: 'I never will believe it, sir,' replied the old lady, firmly. 'Never!'
children.prevalue: I never will believe it sir replied the old lady firmly Never

children.name: Paragraph_99
children.value: 'You old women never believe anything but quack-doctors, and lying story-books,' growled Mr. Grimwig.  'I knew it all along. Why didn't you take my advise in the beginning; you would if he hadn't had a fever, I suppose, eh?  He was interesting, wasn't he?  Interesting! Bah!'  And Mr. Grimwig poked the fire with a flourish.
children.prevalue: You old women never believe anything but quack doctors and lying story books growled Mr Grimwig I knew it all along Why didn t you take my advise in the beginning you would if he hadn t had a fever I suppose eh He was interesting wasn t he Interesting Bah And Mr Grimwig poked the fire with a flourish

children.name: Paragraph_100
children.value: 'He was a dear, grateful, gentle child, sir,' retorted Mrs. Bedwin, indignantly.  'I know what children are, sir; and have done these forty years; and people who can't say the same, shouldn't say anything about them.  That's my opinion!'
children.prevalue: He was a dear grateful gentle child sir retorted Mrs Bedwin indignantly I know what children are sir and have done these forty years and people who can t say the same shouldn t say anything about them That s my opinion

children.name: Paragraph_101
children.value: This was a hard hit at Mr. Grimwig, who was a bachelor.  As it extorted nothing from that gentleman but a smile, the old lady tossed her head, and smoothed down her apron preparatory to another speech, when she was stopped by Mr. Brownlow.
children.prevalue: This was a hard hit at Mr Grimwig who was a bachelor As it extorted nothing from that gentleman but a smile the old lady tossed her head and smoothed down her apron preparatory to another speech when she was stopped by Mr Brownlow

children.name: Paragraph_102
children.value: 'Silence!' said the old gentleman, feigning an anger he was far from feeling.  'Never let me hear the boy's name again.  I rang to tell you that.  Never.  Never, on any pretence, mind!  You may leave the room, Mrs. Bedwin.  Remember!  I am in earnest.'
children.prevalue: Silence said the old gentleman feigning an anger he was far from feeling Never let me hear the boy s name again I rang to tell you that Never Never on any pretence mind You may leave the room Mrs Bedwin Remember I am in earnest

children.name: Paragraph_103
children.value: There were sad hearts at Mr. Brownlow's that night.
children.prevalue: There were sad hearts at Mr Brownlow s that night

children.name: Paragraph_104
children.value: Oliver's heart sank within him, when he thought of his good friends; it was well for him that he could not know what they had heard, or it might have broken outright.
children.prevalue: Oliver s heart sank within him when he thought of his good friends it was well for him that he could not know what they had heard or it might have broken outright

children.name: Paragraph_1
children.value: HOW OLIVER PASSED HIS TIME IN THE IMPROVING SOCIETY OF HIS REPUTABLE FRIENDS
children.prevalue: HOW OLIVER PASSED HIS TIME IN THE IMPROVING SOCIETY OF HIS REPUTABLE FRIENDS

children.name: Paragraph_2
children.value: About noon next day, when the Dodger and Master Bates had gone out to pursue their customary avocations, Mr. Fagin took the opportunity of reading Oliver a long lecture on the crying sin of ingratitude; of which he clearly demonstrated he had been guilty, to no ordinary extent, in wilfully absenting himself from the society of his anxious friends; and, still more, in endeavouring to escape from them after so much trouble and expense had been incurred in his recovery. Mr. Fagin laid great stress on the fact of his having taken Oliver in, and cherished him, when, without his timely aid, he might have perished with hunger; and he related the dismal and affecting history of a young lad whom, in his philanthropy, he had succoured under parallel circumstances, but who, proving unworthy of his confidence and evincing a desire to communicate with the police, had unfortunately come to be hanged at the Old Bailey one morning.  Mr. Fagin did not seek to conceal his share in the catastrophe, but lamented with tears in his eyes that the wrong-headed and treacherous behaviour of the young person in question, had rendered it necessary that he should become the victim of certain evidence for the crown: which, if it were not precisely true, was indispensably necessary for the safety of him (Mr. Fagin) and a few select friends.  Mr. Fagin concluded by drawing a rather disagreeable picture of the discomforts of hanging; and, with great friendliness and politeness of manner, expressed his anxious hopes that he might never be obliged to submit Oliver Twist to that unpleasant operation.
children.prevalue: About noon next day when the Dodger and Master Bates had gone out to pursue their customary avocations Mr Fagin took the opportunity of reading Oliver a long lecture on the crying sin of ingratitude of which he clearly demonstrated he had been guilty to no ordinary extent in wilfully absenting himself from the society of his anxious friends and still more in endeavouring to escape from them after so much trouble and expense had been incurred in his recovery Mr Fagin laid great stress on the fact of his having taken Oliver in and cherished him when without his timely aid he might have perished with hunger and he related the dismal and affecting history of a young lad whom in his philanthropy he had succoured under parallel circumstances but who proving unworthy of his confidence and evincing a desire to communicate with the police had unfortunately come to be hanged at the Old Bailey one morning Mr Fagin did not seek to conceal his share in the catastrophe but lamented with tears in his eyes that the wrong headed and treacherous behaviour of the young person in question had rendered it necessary that he should become the victim of certain evidence for the crown which if it were not precisely true was indispensably necessary for the safety of him Mr Fagin and a few select friends Mr Fagin concluded by drawing a rather disagreeable picture of the discomforts of hanging and with great friendliness and politeness of manner expressed his anxious hopes that he might never be obliged to submit Oliver Twist to that unpleasant operation

children.name: Paragraph_3
children.value: Little Oliver's blood ran cold, as he listened to the Jew's words, and imperfectly comprehended the dark threats conveyed in them.  That it was possible even for justice itself to confound the innocent with the guilty when they were in accidental companionship, he knew already; and that deeply-laid plans for the destruction of inconveniently knowing or over-communicative persons, had been really devised and carried out by the Jew on more occasions than one, he thought by no means unlikely, when he recollected the general nature of the altercations between that gentleman and Mr. Sikes: which seemed to bear reference to some foregone conspiracy of the kind.  As he glanced timidly up, and met the Jew's searching look, he felt that his pale face and trembling limbs were neither unnoticed nor unrelished by that wary old gentleman.
children.prevalue: Little Oliver s blood ran cold as he listened to the Jew s words and imperfectly comprehended the dark threats conveyed in them That it was possible even for justice itself to confound the innocent with the guilty when they were in accidental companionship he knew already and that deeply laid plans for the destruction of inconveniently knowing or over communicative persons had been really devised and carried out by the Jew on more occasions than one he thought by no means unlikely when he recollected the general nature of the altercations between that gentleman and Mr Sikes which seemed to bear reference to some foregone conspiracy of the kind As he glanced timidly up and met the Jew s searching look he felt that his pale face and trembling limbs were neither unnoticed nor unrelished by that wary old gentleman

children.name: Paragraph_4
children.value: The Jew, smiling hideously, patted Oliver on the head, and said, that if he kept himself quiet, and applied himself to business, he saw they would be very good friends yet.  Then, taking his hat, and covering himself with an old patched great-coat, he went out, and locked the room-door behind him.
children.prevalue: The Jew smiling hideously patted Oliver on the head and said that if he kept himself quiet and applied himself to business he saw they would be very good friends yet Then taking his hat and covering himself with an old patched great coat he went out and locked the room door behind him

children.name: Paragraph_5
children.value: And so Oliver remained all that day, and for the greater part of many subsequent days, seeing nobody, between early morning and midnight, and left during the long hours to commune with his own thoughts.  Which, never failing to revert to his kind friends, and the opinion they must long ago have formed of him, were sad indeed.
children.prevalue: And so Oliver remained all that day and for the greater part of many subsequent days seeing nobody between early morning and midnight and left during the long hours to commune with his own thoughts Which never failing to revert to his kind friends and the opinion they must long ago have formed of him were sad indeed

children.name: Paragraph_6
children.value: After the lapse of a week or so, the Jew left the room-door unlocked; and he was at liberty to wander about the house.
children.prevalue: After the lapse of a week or so the Jew left the room door unlocked and he was at liberty to wander about the house

children.name: Paragraph_7
children.value: It was a very dirty place.  The rooms upstairs had great high wooden chimney-pieces and large doors, with panelled walls and cornices to the ceiling; which, although they were black with neglect and dust, were ornamented in various ways.  From all of these tokens Oliver concluded that a long time ago, before the old Jew was born, it had belonged to better people, and had perhaps been quite gay and handsome:  dismal and dreary as it looked now.
children.prevalue: It was a very dirty place The rooms upstairs had great high wooden chimney pieces and large doors with panelled walls and cornices to the ceiling which although they were black with neglect and dust were ornamented in various ways From all of these tokens Oliver concluded that a long time ago before the old Jew was born it had belonged to better people and had perhaps been quite gay and handsome dismal and dreary as it looked now

children.name: Paragraph_8
children.value: Spiders had built their webs in the angles of the walls and ceilings; and sometimes, when Oliver walked softly into a room, the mice would scamper across the floor, and run back terrified to their holes.  With these exceptions, there was neither sight nor sound of any living thing; and often, when it grew dark, and he was tired of wandering from room to room, he would crouch in the corner of the passage by the street-door, to be as near living people as he could; and would remain there, listening and counting the hours, until the Jew or the boys returned.
children.prevalue: Spiders had built their webs in the angles of the walls and ceilings and sometimes when Oliver walked softly into a room the mice would scamper across the floor and run back terrified to their holes With these exceptions there was neither sight nor sound of any living thing and often when it grew dark and he was tired of wandering from room to room he would crouch in the corner of the passage by the street door to be as near living people as he could and would remain there listening and counting the hours until the Jew or the boys returned

children.name: Paragraph_9
children.value: In all the rooms, the mouldering shutters were fast closed:  the bars which held them were screwed tight into the wood; the only light which was admitted, stealing its way through round holes at the top: which made the rooms more gloomy, and filled them with strange shadows. There was a back-garret window with rusty bars outside, which had no shutter; and out of this, Oliver often gazed with a melancholy face for hours together; but nothing was to be descried from it but a confused and crowded mass of housetops, blackened chimneys, and gable-ends. Sometimes, indeed, a grizzly head might be seen, peering over the parapet-wall of a distant house; but it was quickly withdrawn again; and as the window of Oliver's observatory was nailed down, and dimmed with the rain and smoke of years, it was as much as he could do to make out the forms of the different objects beyond, without making any attempt to be seen or heard,--which he had as much chance of being, as if he had lived inside the ball of St. Paul's Cathedral.
children.prevalue: In all the rooms the mouldering shutters were fast closed the bars which held them were screwed tight into the wood the only light which was admitted stealing its way through round holes at the top which made the rooms more gloomy and filled them with strange shadows There was a back garret window with rusty bars outside which had no shutter and out of this Oliver often gazed with a melancholy face for hours together but nothing was to be descried from it but a confused and crowded mass of housetops blackened chimneys and gable ends Sometimes indeed a grizzly head might be seen peering over the parapet wall of a distant house but it was quickly withdrawn again and as the window of Oliver s observatory was nailed down and dimmed with the rain and smoke of years it was as much as he could do to make out the forms of the different objects beyond without making any attempt to be seen or heard which he had as much chance of being as if he had lived inside the ball of St Paul s Cathedral

children.name: Paragraph_10
children.value: One afternoon, the Dodger and Master Bates being engaged out that evening, the first-named young gentleman took it into his head to evince some anxiety regarding the decoration of his person (to do him justice, this was by no means an habitual weakness with him); and, with this end and aim, he condescendingly commanded Oliver to assist him in his toilet, straightway.
children.prevalue: One afternoon the Dodger and Master Bates being engaged out that evening the first named young gentleman took it into his head to evince some anxiety regarding the decoration of his person to do him justice this was by no means an habitual weakness with him and with this end and aim he condescendingly commanded Oliver to assist him in his toilet straightway

children.name: Paragraph_11
children.value: Oliver was but too glad to make himself useful; too happy to have some faces, however bad, to look upon; too desirous to conciliate those about him when he could honestly do so; to throw any objection in the way of this proposal.  So he at once expressed his readiness; and, kneeling on the floor, while the Dodger sat upon the table so that he could take his foot in his laps, he applied himself to a process which Mr. Dawkins designated as 'japanning his trotter-cases.'  The phrase, rendered into plain English, signifieth, cleaning his boots.
children.prevalue: Oliver was but too glad to make himself useful too happy to have some faces however bad to look upon too desirous to conciliate those about him when he could honestly do so to throw any objection in the way of this proposal So he at once expressed his readiness and kneeling on the floor while the Dodger sat upon the table so that he could take his foot in his laps he applied himself to a process which Mr Dawkins designated as japanning his trotter cases The phrase rendered into plain English signifieth cleaning his boots

children.name: Paragraph_12
children.value: Whether it was the sense of freedom and independence which a rational animal may be supposed to feel when he sits on a table in an easy attitude smoking a pipe, swinging one leg carelessly to and fro, and having his boots cleaned all the time, without even the past trouble of having taken them off, or the prospective misery of putting them on, to disturb his reflections; or whether it was the goodness of the tobacco that soothed the feelings of the Dodger, or the mildness of the beer that mollified his thoughts; he was evidently tinctured, for the nonce, with a spice of romance and enthusiasm, foreign to his general nature. He looked down on Oliver, with a thoughtful countenance, for a brief space; and then, raising his head, and heaving a gentle sign, said, half in abstraction, and half to Master Bates:
children.prevalue: Whether it was the sense of freedom and independence which a rational animal may be supposed to feel when he sits on a table in an easy attitude smoking a pipe swinging one leg carelessly to and fro and having his boots cleaned all the time without even the past trouble of having taken them off or the prospective misery of putting them on to disturb his reflections or whether it was the goodness of the tobacco that soothed the feelings of the Dodger or the mildness of the beer that mollified his thoughts he was evidently tinctured for the nonce with a spice of romance and enthusiasm foreign to his general nature He looked down on Oliver with a thoughtful countenance for a brief space and then raising his head and heaving a gentle sign said half in abstraction and half to Master Bates

children.name: Paragraph_13
children.value: 'What a pity it is he isn't a prig!'
children.prevalue: What a pity it is he isn t a prig

children.name: Paragraph_14
children.value: 'Ah!' said Master Charles Bates; 'he don't know what's good for him.'
children.prevalue: Ah said Master Charles Bates he don t know what s good for him

children.name: Paragraph_15
children.value: The Dodger sighed again, and resumed his pipe: as did Charley Bates. They both smoked, for some seconds, in silence.
children.prevalue: The Dodger sighed again and resumed his pipe as did Charley Bates They both smoked for some seconds in silence

children.name: Paragraph_16
children.value: 'I suppose you don't even know what a prig is?' said the Dodger mournfully.
children.prevalue: I suppose you don t even know what a prig is said the Dodger mournfully

children.name: Paragraph_17
children.value: 'I think I know that,' replied Oliver, looking up.  'It's a the--; you're one, are you not?' inquired Oliver, checking himself.
children.prevalue: I think I know that replied Oliver looking up It s a the you re one are you not inquired Oliver checking himself

children.name: Paragraph_18
children.value: 'I am,' replied the Dodger.  'I'd scorn to be anything else.'  Mr. Dawkins gave his hat a ferocious cock, after delivering this sentiment, and looked at Master Bates, as if to denote that he would feel obliged by his saying anything to the contrary.
children.prevalue: I am replied the Dodger I d scorn to be anything else Mr Dawkins gave his hat a ferocious cock after delivering this sentiment and looked at Master Bates as if to denote that he would feel obliged by his saying anything to the contrary

children.name: Paragraph_19
children.value: 'I am,' repeated the Dodger.  'So's Charley.  So's Fagin. So's Sikes. So's Nancy.  So's Bet.  So we all are, down to the dog. And he's the downiest one of the lot!'
children.prevalue: I am repeated the Dodger So s Charley So s Fagin So s Sikes So s Nancy So s Bet So we all are down to the dog And he s the downiest one of the lot

children.name: Paragraph_20
children.value: 'And the least given to peaching,' added Charley Bates.
children.prevalue: And the least given to peaching added Charley Bates

children.name: Paragraph_21
children.value: 'He wouldn't so much as bark in a witness-box, for fear of committing himself; no, not if you tied him up in one, and left him there without wittles for a fortnight,' said the Dodger.
children.prevalue: He wouldn t so much as bark in a witness box for fear of committing himself no not if you tied him up in one and left him there without wittles for a fortnight said the Dodger

children.name: Paragraph_22
children.value: 'Not a bit of it,' observed Charley.
children.prevalue: Not a bit of it observed Charley

children.name: Paragraph_23
children.value: 'He's a rum dog.  Don't he look fierce at any strange cove that laughs or sings when he's in company!' pursued the Dodger. 'Won't he growl at all, when he hears a fiddle playing!  And don't he hate other dogs as ain't of his breed!  Oh, no!'
children.prevalue: He s a rum dog Don t he look fierce at any strange cove that laughs or sings when he s in company pursued the Dodger Won t he growl at all when he hears a fiddle playing And don t he hate other dogs as ain t of his breed Oh no

children.name: Paragraph_24
children.value: 'He's an out-and-out Christian,' said Charley.
children.prevalue: He s an out and out Christian said Charley

children.name: Paragraph_25
children.value: This was merely intended as a tribute to the animal's abilities, but it was an appropriate remark in another sense, if Master Bates had only known it; for there are a good many ladies and gentlemen, claiming to be out-and-out Christians, between whom, and Mr. Sikes' dog, there exist strong and singular points of resemblance.
children.prevalue: This was merely intended as a tribute to the animal s abilities but it was an appropriate remark in another sense if Master Bates had only known it for there are a good many ladies and gentlemen claiming to be out and out Christians between whom and Mr Sikes dog there exist strong and singular points of resemblance

children.name: Paragraph_26
children.value: 'Well, well,' said the Dodger, recurring to the point from which they had strayed: with that mindfulness of his profession which influenced all his proceedings.  'This hasn't go anything to do with young Green here.'
children.prevalue: Well well said the Dodger recurring to the point from which they had strayed with that mindfulness of his profession which influenced all his proceedings This hasn t go anything to do with young Green here

children.name: Paragraph_27
children.value: 'No more it has,' said Charley.  'Why don't you put yourself under Fagin, Oliver?'
children.prevalue: No more it has said Charley Why don t you put yourself under Fagin Oliver

children.name: Paragraph_28
children.value: 'And make your fortun' out of hand?' added the Dodger, with a grin.
children.prevalue: And make your fortun out of hand added the Dodger with a grin

children.name: Paragraph_29
children.value: 'And so be able to retire on your property, and do the gen-teel: as I mean to, in the very next leap-year but four that ever comes, and the forty-second Tuesday in Trinity-week,' said Charley Bates.
children.prevalue: And so be able to retire on your property and do the gen teel as I mean to in the very next leap year but four that ever comes and the forty second Tuesday in Trinity week said Charley Bates

children.prevalue: I don t like it rejoined Oliver timidly I wish they would let me go I I would rather go

children.name: Paragraph_31
children.value: 'And Fagin would RATHER not!' rejoined Charley.
children.prevalue: And Fagin would RATHER not rejoined Charley

children.name: Paragraph_32
children.value: Oliver knew this too well; but thinking it might be dangerous to express his feelings more openly, he only sighed, and went on with his boot-cleaning.
children.prevalue: Oliver knew this too well but thinking it might be dangerous to express his feelings more openly he only sighed and went on with his boot cleaning

children.name: Paragraph_33
children.value: 'Go!' exclaimed the Dodger.  'Why, where's your spirit?' Don't you take any pride out of yourself?  Would you go and be dependent on your friends?'
children.prevalue: Go exclaimed the Dodger Why where s your spirit Don t you take any pride out of yourself Would you go and be dependent on your friends

children.prevalue: Oh blow that said Master Bates drawing two or three silk handkerchiefs from his pocket and tossing them into a cupboard that s too mean that is

children.name: Paragraph_36

children.value: 'That,' rejoined the Dodger, with a wave of his pipe, 'That was all out of consideration for Fagin, 'cause the traps know that we work together, and he might have got into trouble if we hadn't made our lucky; that was the move, wasn't it, Charley?'

children.value: Master Bates nodded assent, and would have spoken, but the recollection of Oliver's flight came so suddenly upon him, that the smoke he was inhaling got entangled with a laugh, and went up into his head, and down into his throat: and brought on a fit of coughing and stamping, about five minutes long.

children.name: Paragraph_39
children.value: 'Look here!' said the Dodger, drawing forth a handful of shillings and halfpence. 'Here's a jolly life!  What's the odds where it comes from? Here, catch hold; there's plenty more where they were took from.  You won't, won't you?  Oh, you precious flat!'

children.prevalue: I don t know what that means replied Oliver

children.name: Paragraph_42
children.value: 'Something in this way, old feller,' said Charly.  As he said it, Master Bates caught up an end of his neckerchief; and, holding it erect in the air, dropped his head on his shoulder, and jerked a curious sound through his teeth; thereby indicating, by a lively pantomimic representation, that scragging and hanging were one and the same thing.
children.prevalue: Something in this way old feller said Charly As he said it Master Bates caught up an end of his neckerchief and holding it erect in the air dropped his head on his shoulder and jerked a curious sound through his teeth thereby indicating by a lively pantomimic representation that scragging and hanging were one and the same thing

children.name: Paragraph_43
children.value: 'That's what it means,' said Charley.  'Look how he stares, Jack!
children.prevalue: That s what it means said Charley Look how he stares Jack

children.name: Paragraph_44
children.value: I never did see such prime company as that 'ere boy; he'll be the death of me, I know he will.'  Master Charley Bates, having laughed heartily again, resumed his pipe with tears in his eyes.
children.prevalue: I never did see such prime company as that ere boy he ll be the death of me I know he will Master Charley Bates having laughed heartily again resumed his pipe with tears in his eyes

children.name: Paragraph_45
children.value: 'You've been brought up bad,' said the Dodger, surveying his boots with much satisfaction when Oliver had polished them. 'Fagin will make something of you, though, or you'll be the first he ever had that turned out unprofitable.  You'd better begin at once; for you'll come to the trade long before you think of it; and you're only losing time, Oliver.'
children.prevalue: You ve been brought up bad said the Dodger surveying his boots with much satisfaction when Oliver had polished them Fagin will make something of you though or you ll be the first he ever had that turned out unprofitable You d better begin at once for you ll come to the trade long before you think of it and you re only losing time Oliver

children.name: Paragraph_46
children.value: Master Bates backed this advice with sundry moral admonitions of his own:  which, being exhausted, he and his friend Mr. Dawkins launched into a glowing description of the numerous pleasures incidental to the life they led, interspersed with a variety of hints to Oliver that the best thing he could do, would be to secure Fagin's favour without more delay, by the means which they themselves had employed to gain it.
children.prevalue: Master Bates backed this advice with sundry moral admonitions of his own which being exhausted he and his friend Mr Dawkins launched into a glowing description of the numerous pleasures incidental to the life they led interspersed with a variety of hints to Oliver that the best thing he could do would be to secure Fagin s favour without more delay by the means which they themselves had employed to gain it

children.name: Paragraph_47
children.value: 'And always put this in your pipe, Nolly,' said the Dodger, as the Jew was heard unlocking the door above, 'if you don't take fogels and tickers--'
children.prevalue: And always put this in your pipe Nolly said the Dodger as the Jew was heard unlocking the door above if you don t take fogels and tickers

children.name: Paragraph_48
children.value: 'What's the good of talking in that way?' interposed Master Bates; 'he don't know what you mean.'
children.prevalue: What s the good of talking in that way interposed Master Bates he don t know what you mean

children.name: Paragraph_49
children.value: 'If you don't take pocket-handkechers and watches,' said the Dodger, reducing his conversation to the level of Oliver's capacity, 'some other cove will; so that the coves that lose 'em will be all the worse, and you'll be all the worse, too, and nobody half a ha'p'orth the better, except the chaps wot gets them--and you've just as good a right to them as they have.'
children.prevalue: If you don t take pocket handkechers and watches said the Dodger reducing his conversation to the level of Oliver s capacity some other cove will so that the coves that lose em will be all the worse and you ll be all the worse too and nobody half a ha p orth the better except the chaps wot gets them and you ve just as good a right to them as they have

children.name: Paragraph_50
children.value: 'To be sure, to be sure!' said the Jew, who had entered unseen by Oliver.  'It all lies in a nutshell my dear; in a nutshell, take the Dodger's word for it.  Ha! ha! ha!  He understands the catechism of his trade.'
children.prevalue: To be sure to be sure said the Jew who had entered unseen by Oliver It all lies in a nutshell my dear in a nutshell take the Dodger s word for it Ha ha ha He understands the catechism of his trade

children.name: Paragraph_51
children.value: The old man rubbed his hands gleefully together, as he corroborated the Dodger's reasoning in these terms; and chuckled with delight at his pupil's proficiency.
children.prevalue: The old man rubbed his hands gleefully together as he corroborated the Dodger s reasoning in these terms and chuckled with delight at his pupil s proficiency

children.name: Paragraph_52
children.value: The conversation proceeded no farther at this time, for the Jew had returned home accompanied by Miss Betsy, and a gentleman whom Oliver had never seen before, but who was accosted by the Dodger as Tom Chitling; and who, having lingered on the stairs to exchange a few gallantries with the lady, now made his appearance.
children.prevalue: The conversation proceeded no farther at this time for the Jew had returned home accompanied by Miss Betsy and a gentleman whom Oliver had never seen before but who was accosted by the Dodger as Tom Chitling and who having lingered on the stairs to exchange a few gallantries with the lady now made his appearance

children.name: Paragraph_53
children.value: Mr. Chitling was older in years than the Dodger: having perhaps numbered eighteen winters; but there was a degree of deference in his deportment towards that young gentleman which seemed to indicate that he felt himself conscious of a slight inferiority in point of genius and professional aquirements.  He had small twinkling eyes, and a pock-marked face; wore a fur cap, a dark corduroy jacket, greasy fustian trousers, and an apron.  His wardrobe was, in truth, rather out of repair; but he excused himself to the company by stating that his 'time' was only out an hour before; and that, in consequence of having worn the regimentals for six weeks past, he had not been able to bestow any attention on his private clothes.  Mr. Chitling added, with strong marks of irritation, that the new way of fumigating clothes up yonder was infernal unconstitutional, for it burnt holes in them, and there was no remedy against the County.  The same remark he considered to apply to the regulation mode of cutting the hair: which he held to be decidedly unlawful.  Mr. Chitling wound up his observations by stating that he had not touched a drop of anything for forty-two moral long hard-working days; and that he 'wished he might be busted if he warn't as dry as a lime-basket.'
children.prevalue: Mr Chitling was older in years than the Dodger having perhaps numbered eighteen winters but there was a degree of deference in his deportment towards that young gentleman which seemed to indicate that he felt himself conscious of a slight inferiority in point of genius and professional aquirements He had small twinkling eyes and a pock marked face wore a fur cap a dark corduroy jacket greasy fustian trousers and an apron His wardrobe was in truth rather out of repair but he excused himself to the company by stating that his time was only out an hour before and that in consequence of having worn the regimentals for six weeks past he had not been able to bestow any attention on his private clothes Mr Chitling added with strong marks of irritation that the new way of fumigating clothes up yonder was infernal unconstitutional for it burnt holes in them and there was no remedy against the County The same remark he considered to apply to the regulation mode of cutting the hair which he held to be decidedly unlawful Mr Chitling wound up his observations by stating that he had not touched a drop of anything for forty two moral long hard working days and that he wished he might be busted if he warn t as dry as a lime basket

children.name: Paragraph_54
children.value: 'Where do you think the gentleman has come from, Oliver?' inquired the Jew, with a grin, as the other boys put a bottle of spirits on the table.
children.prevalue: Where do you think the gentleman has come from Oliver inquired the Jew with a grin as the other boys put a bottle of spirits on the table

children.name: Paragraph_55
children.value: 'I--I--don't know, sir,' replied Oliver.
children.prevalue: I I don t know sir replied Oliver

children.name: Paragraph_56
children.value: 'Who's that?' inquired Tom Chitling, casting a contemptuous look at Oliver.
children.prevalue: Who s that inquired Tom Chitling casting a contemptuous look at Oliver

children.name: Paragraph_57
children.value: 'A young friend of mine, my dear,' replied the Jew.
children.prevalue: A young friend of mine my dear replied the Jew

children.name: Paragraph_58
children.value: 'He's in luck, then,' said the young man, with a meaning look at Fagin. 'Never mind where I came from, young 'un; you'll find your way there, soon enough, I'll bet a crown!'
children.prevalue: He s in luck then said the young man with a meaning look at Fagin Never mind where I came from young un you ll find your way there soon enough I ll bet a crown

children.name: Paragraph_59
children.value: At this sally, the boys laughed.  After some more jokes on the same subject, they exchanged a few short whispers with Fagin; and withdrew.
children.prevalue: At this sally the boys laughed After some more jokes on the same subject they exchanged a few short whispers with Fagin and withdrew

children.name: Paragraph_60
children.value: After some words apart between the last comer and Fagin, they drew their chairs towards the fire; and the Jew, telling Oliver to come and sit by him, led the conversation to the topics most calculated to interest his hearers.  These were, the great advantages of the trade, the proficiency of the Dodger, the amiability of Charley Bates, and the liberality of the Jew himself.  At length these subjects displayed signs of being thoroughly exhausted; and Mr. Chitling did the same: for the house of correction becomes fatiguing after a week or two. Miss Betsy accordingly withdrew; and left the party to their repose.
children.prevalue: After some words apart between the last comer and Fagin they drew their chairs towards the fire and the Jew telling Oliver to come and sit by him led the conversation to the topics most calculated to interest his hearers These were the great advantages of the trade the proficiency of the Dodger the amiability of Charley Bates and the liberality of the Jew himself At length these subjects displayed signs of being thoroughly exhausted and Mr Chitling did the same for the house of correction becomes fatiguing after a week or two Miss Betsy accordingly withdrew and left the party to their repose

children.name: Paragraph_61
children.value: From this day, Oliver was seldom left alone; but was placed in almost constant communication with the two boys, who played the old game with the Jew every day: whether for their own improvement or Oliver's, Mr. Fagin best knew.  At other times the old man would tell them stories of robberies he had committed in his younger days:  mixed up with so much that was droll and curious, that Oliver could not help laughing heartily, and showing that he was amused in spite of all his better feelings.
children.prevalue: From this day Oliver was seldom left alone but was placed in almost constant communication with the two boys who played the old game with the Jew every day whether for their own improvement or Oliver s Mr Fagin best knew At other times the old man would tell them stories of robberies he had committed in his younger days mixed up with so much that was droll and curious that Oliver could not help laughing heartily and showing that he was amused in spite of all his better feelings

children.name: Paragraph_62
children.value: In short, the wily old Jew had the boy in his toils.  Having prepared his mind, by solitude and gloom, to prefer any society to the companionship of his own sad thoughts in such a dreary place, he was now slowly instilling into his soul the poison which he hoped would blacken it, and change its hue for ever.
children.prevalue: In short the wily old Jew had the boy in his toils Having prepared his mind by solitude and gloom to prefer any society to the companionship of his own sad thoughts in such a dreary place he was now slowly instilling into his soul the poison which he hoped would blacken it and change its hue for ever

children.name: Paragraph_1
children.value: IN WHICH A NOTABLE PLAN IS DISCUSSED AND DETERMINED ON
children.prevalue: IN WHICH A NOTABLE PLAN IS DISCUSSED AND DETERMINED ON

children.name: Paragraph_2
children.value: It was a chill, damp, windy night, when the Jew: buttoning his great-coat tight round his shrivelled body, and pulling the collar up over his ears so as completely to obscure the lower part of his face: emerged from his den.  He paused on the step as the door was locked and chained behind him; and having listened while the boys made all secure, and until their retreating footsteps were no longer audible, slunk down the street as quickly as he could.
children.prevalue: It was a chill damp windy night when the Jew buttoning his great coat tight round his shrivelled body and pulling the collar up over his ears so as completely to obscure the lower part of his face emerged from his den He paused on the step as the door was locked and chained behind him and having listened while the boys made all secure and until their retreating footsteps were no longer audible slunk down the street as quickly as he could

children.name: Paragraph_3
children.value: The house to which Oliver had been conveyed, was in the neighborhood of Whitechapel.  The Jew stopped for an instant at the corner of the street; and, glancing suspiciously round, crossed the road, and struck off in the direction of the Spitalfields.
children.prevalue: The house to which Oliver had been conveyed was in the neighborhood of Whitechapel The Jew stopped for an instant at the corner of the street and glancing suspiciously round crossed the road and struck off in the direction of the Spitalfields

children.name: Paragraph_4
children.value: The mud lay thick upon the stones, and a black mist hung over the streets; the rain fell sluggishly down, and everything felt cold and clammy to the touch.  It seemed just the night when it befitted such a being as the Jew to be abroad.  As he glided stealthily along, creeping beneath the shelter of the walls and doorways, the hideous old man seemed like some loathsome reptile, engendered in the slime and darkness through which he moved: crawling forth, by night, in search of some rich offal for a meal.
children.prevalue: The mud lay thick upon the stones and a black mist hung over the streets the rain fell sluggishly down and everything felt cold and clammy to the touch It seemed just the night when it befitted such a being as the Jew to be abroad As he glided stealthily along creeping beneath the shelter of the walls and doorways the hideous old man seemed like some loathsome reptile engendered in the slime and darkness through which he moved crawling forth by night in search of some rich offal for a meal

children.name: Paragraph_5
children.value: He kept on his course, through many winding and narrow ways, until he reached Bethnal Green; then, turning suddenly off to the left, he soon became involved in a maze of the mean and dirty streets which abound in that close and densely-populated quarter.
children.prevalue: He kept on his course through many winding and narrow ways until he reached Bethnal Green then turning suddenly off to the left he soon became involved in a maze of the mean and dirty streets which abound in that close and densely populated quarter

children.name: Paragraph_6
children.value: The Jew was evidently too familiar with the ground he traversed to be at all bewildered, either by the darkness of the night, or the intricacies of the way.  He hurried through several alleys and streets, and at length turned into one, lighted only by a single lamp at the farther end.  At the door of a house in this street, he knocked; having exchanged a few muttered words with the person who opened it, he walked upstairs.
children.prevalue: The Jew was evidently too familiar with the ground he traversed to be at all bewildered either by the darkness of the night or the intricacies of the way He hurried through several alleys and streets and at length turned into one lighted only by a single lamp at the farther end At the door of a house in this street he knocked having exchanged a few muttered words with the person who opened it he walked upstairs

children.name: Paragraph_7
children.value: A dog growled as he touched the handle of a room-door; and a man's voice demanded who was there.
children.prevalue: A dog growled as he touched the handle of a room door and a man s voice demanded who was there

children.name: Paragraph_8
children.value: 'Only me, Bill; only me, my dear,' said the Jew looking in.
children.prevalue: Only me Bill only me my dear said the Jew looking in

children.name: Paragraph_9
children.value: 'Bring in your body then,' said Sikes.  'Lie down, you stupid brute! Don't you know the devil when he's got a great-coat on?'
children.prevalue: Bring in your body then said Sikes Lie down you stupid brute Don t you know the devil when he s got a great coat on

children.name: Paragraph_10
children.value: Apparently, the dog had been somewhat deceived by Mr. Fagin's outer garment; for as the Jew unbuttoned it, and threw it over the back of a chair, he retired to the corner from which he had risen:  wagging his tail as he went, to show that he was as well satisfied as it was in his nature to be.
children.prevalue: Apparently the dog had been somewhat deceived by Mr Fagin s outer garment for as the Jew unbuttoned it and threw it over the back of a chair he retired to the corner from which he had risen wagging his tail as he went to show that he was as well satisfied as it was in his nature to be

children.name: Paragraph_11
children.value: 'Well!' said Sikes.
children.prevalue: Well said Sikes

children.name: Paragraph_12
children.value: 'Well, my dear,' replied the Jew.--'Ah! Nancy.'
children.prevalue: Well my dear replied the Jew Ah Nancy

children.name: Paragraph_13
children.value: The latter recognition was uttered with just enough of embarrassment to imply a doubt of its reception; for Mr. Fagin and his young friend had not met, since she had interfered in behalf of Oliver.  All doubts upon the subject, if he had any, were speedily removed by the young lady's behaviour.  She took her feet off the fender, pushed back her chair, and bade Fagin draw up his, without saying more about it:  for it was a cold night, and no mistake.
children.prevalue: The latter recognition was uttered with just enough of embarrassment to imply a doubt of its reception for Mr Fagin and his young friend had not met since she had interfered in behalf of Oliver All doubts upon the subject if he had any were speedily removed by the young lady s behaviour She took her feet off the fender pushed back her chair and bade Fagin draw up his without saying more about it for it was a cold night and no mistake

children.name: Paragraph_14
children.value: 'It is cold, Nancy dear,' said the Jew, as he warmed his skinny hands over the fire.  'It seems to go right through one,' added the old man, touching his side.
children.prevalue: It is cold Nancy dear said the Jew as he warmed his skinny hands over the fire It seems to go right through one added the old man touching his side

children.name: Paragraph_15
children.value: 'It must be a piercer, if it finds its way through your heart,' said Mr. Sikes.  'Give him something to drink, Nancy.  Burn my body, make haste!  It's enough to turn a man ill, to see his lean old carcase shivering in that way, like a ugly ghost just rose from the grave.'
children.prevalue: It must be a piercer if it finds its way through your heart said Mr Sikes Give him something to drink Nancy Burn my body make haste It s enough to turn a man ill to see his lean old carcase shivering in that way like a ugly ghost just rose from the grave

children.name: Paragraph_16
children.value: Nancy quickly brought a bottle from a cupboard, in which there were many:  which, to judge from the diversity of their appearance, were filled with several kinds of liquids.  Sikes pouring out a glass of brandy, bade the Jew drink it off.
children.prevalue: Nancy quickly brought a bottle from a cupboard in which there were many which to judge from the diversity of their appearance were filled with several kinds of liquids Sikes pouring out a glass of brandy bade the Jew drink it off

children.name: Paragraph_17
children.value: 'Quite enough, quite, thankye, Bill,' replied the Jew, putting down the glass after just setting his lips to it.
children.prevalue: Quite enough quite thankye Bill replied the Jew putting down the glass after just setting his lips to it

children.name: Paragraph_18
children.value: 'What!  You're afraid of our getting the better of you, are you?' inquired Sikes, fixing his eyes on the Jew.  'Ugh!'
children.prevalue: What You re afraid of our getting the better of you are you inquired Sikes fixing his eyes on the Jew Ugh

children.name: Paragraph_19
children.value: With a hoarse grunt of contempt, Mr. Sikes seized the glass, and threw the remainder of its contents into the ashes: as a preparatory ceremony to filling it again for himself:  which he did at once.
children.prevalue: With a hoarse grunt of contempt Mr Sikes seized the glass and threw the remainder of its contents into the ashes as a preparatory ceremony to filling it again for himself which he did at once

children.name: Paragraph_20
children.value: The Jew glanced round the room, as his companion tossed down the second glassful; not in curiousity, for he had seen it often before; but in a restless and suspicious manner habitual to him. It was a meanly furnished apartment, with nothing but the contents of the closet to induce the belief that its occupier was anything but a working man; and with no more suspicious articles displayed to view than two or three heavy bludgeons which stood in a corner, and a 'life-preserver' that hung over the chimney-piece.
children.prevalue: The Jew glanced round the room as his companion tossed down the second glassful not in curiousity for he had seen it often before but in a restless and suspicious manner habitual to him It was a meanly furnished apartment with nothing but the contents of the closet to induce the belief that its occupier was anything but a working man and with no more suspicious articles displayed to view than two or three heavy bludgeons which stood in a corner and a life preserver that hung over the chimney piece

children.name: Paragraph_21
children.value: 'There,' said Sikes, smacking his lips. 'Now I'm ready.'
children.prevalue: There said Sikes smacking his lips Now I m ready

children.name: Paragraph_22
children.value: 'For business?' inquired the Jew.
children.prevalue: For business inquired the Jew

children.name: Paragraph_23
children.value: 'For business,' replied Sikes; 'so say what you've got to say.'
children.prevalue: For business replied Sikes so say what you ve got to say

children.name: Paragraph_24
children.value: 'About the crib at Chertsey, Bill?' said the Jew, drawing his chair forward, and speaking in a very low voice.
children.prevalue: About the crib at Chertsey Bill said the Jew drawing his chair forward and speaking in a very low voice

children.name: Paragraph_25
children.value: 'Yes.  Wot about it?' inquired Sikes.
children.prevalue: Yes Wot about it inquired Sikes

children.name: Paragraph_26
children.value: 'Ah! you know what I mean, my dear,' said the Jew.  'He knows what I mean, Nancy; don't he?'
children.prevalue: Ah you know what I mean my dear said the Jew He knows what I mean Nancy don t he

children.name: Paragraph_27
children.value: 'No, he don't,' sneered Mr. Sikes.  'Or he won't, and that's the same thing.  Speak out, and call things by their right names; don't sit there, winking and blinking, and talking to me in hints, as if you warn't the very first that thought about the robbery.  Wot d'ye mean?'
children.prevalue: No he don t sneered Mr Sikes Or he won t and that s the same thing Speak out and call things by their right names don t sit there winking and blinking and talking to me in hints as if you warn t the very first that thought about the robbery Wot d ye mean

children.name: Paragraph_28
children.value: 'Hush, Bill, hush!' said the Jew, who had in vain attempted to stop this burst of indignation; 'somebody will hear us, my dear. Somebody will hear us.'
children.prevalue: Hush Bill hush said the Jew who had in vain attempted to stop this burst of indignation somebody will hear us my dear Somebody will hear us

children.name: Paragraph_29
children.value: 'Let 'em hear!' said Sikes; 'I don't care.'  But as Mr. Sikes DID care, on reflection, he dropped his voice as he said the words, and grew calmer.
children.prevalue: Let em hear said Sikes I don t care But as Mr Sikes DID care on reflection he dropped his voice as he said the words and grew calmer

children.name: Paragraph_30
children.value: 'There, there,' said the Jew, coaxingly.  'It was only my caution, nothing more.  Now, my dear, about that crib at Chertsey; when is it to be done, Bill, eh?  When is it to be done?  Such plate, my dear, such plate!' said the Jew:  rubbing his hands, and elevating his eyebrows in a rapture of anticipation.
children.prevalue: There there said the Jew coaxingly It was only my caution nothing more Now my dear about that crib at Chertsey when is it to be done Bill eh When is it to be done Such plate my dear such plate said the Jew rubbing his hands and elevating his eyebrows in a rapture of anticipation

children.name: Paragraph_31
children.value: 'Not at all,' replied Sikes coldly.
children.prevalue: Not at all replied Sikes coldly

children.name: Paragraph_32
children.value: 'Not to be done at all!' echoed the Jew, leaning back in his chair.
children.prevalue: Not to be done at all echoed the Jew leaning back in his chair

children.name: Paragraph_33
children.value: 'No, not at all,' rejoined Sikes.  'At least it can't be a put-up job, as we expected.'
children.prevalue: No not at all rejoined Sikes At least it can t be a put up job as we expected

children.name: Paragraph_34
children.value: 'Then it hasn't been properly gone about,' said the Jew, turning pale with anger.  'Don't tell me!'
children.prevalue: Then it hasn t been properly gone about said the Jew turning pale with anger Don t tell me

children.name: Paragraph_35
children.value: 'But I will tell you,' retorted Sikes.  'Who are you that's not to be told?  I tell you that Toby Crackit has been hanging about the place for a fortnight, and he can't get one of the servants in line.'
children.prevalue: But I will tell you retorted Sikes Who are you that s not to be told I tell you that Toby Crackit has been hanging about the place for a fortnight and he can t get one of the servants in line

children.name: Paragraph_36
children.value: 'Do you mean to tell me, Bill,' said the Jew: softening as the other grew heated:  'that neither of the two men in the house can be got over?'
children.prevalue: Do you mean to tell me Bill said the Jew softening as the other grew heated that neither of the two men in the house can be got over

children.name: Paragraph_37
children.value: 'Yes, I do mean to tell you so,' replied Sikes.  'The old lady has had 'em these twenty years; and if you were to give 'em five hundred pound, they wouldn't be in it.'
children.prevalue: Yes I do mean to tell you so replied Sikes The old lady has had em these twenty years and if you were to give em five hundred pound they wouldn t be in it

children.name: Paragraph_38
children.value: 'But do you mean to say, my dear,' remonstrated the Jew, 'that the women can't be got over?'
children.prevalue: But do you mean to say my dear remonstrated the Jew that the women can t be got over

children.name: Paragraph_39
children.value: 'Not a bit of it,' replied Sikes.
children.prevalue: Not a bit of it replied Sikes

children.name: Paragraph_40
children.value: 'Not by flash Toby Crackit?' said the Jew incredulously. 'Think what women are, Bill,'
children.prevalue: Not by flash Toby Crackit said the Jew incredulously Think what women are Bill

children.name: Paragraph_41
children.value: 'No; not even by flash Toby Crackit,' replied Sikes.  'He says he's worn sham whiskers, and a canary waistcoat, the whole blessed time he's been loitering down there, and it's all of no use.'
children.prevalue: No not even by flash Toby Crackit replied Sikes He says he s worn sham whiskers and a canary waistcoat the whole blessed time he s been loitering down there and it s all of no use

children.name: Paragraph_42
children.value: 'He should have tried mustachios and a pair of military trousers, my dear,' said the Jew.
children.prevalue: He should have tried mustachios and a pair of military trousers my dear said the Jew

children.name: Paragraph_43
children.value: 'So he did,' rejoined Sikes, 'and they warn't of no more use than the other plant.'
children.prevalue: So he did rejoined Sikes and they warn t of no more use than the other plant

children.name: Paragraph_44
children.value: The Jew looked blank at this information.  After ruminating for some minutes with his chin sunk on his breast, he raised his head and said, with a deep sigh, that if flash Toby Crackit reported aright, he feared the game was up.
children.prevalue: The Jew looked blank at this information After ruminating for some minutes with his chin sunk on his breast he raised his head and said with a deep sigh that if flash Toby Crackit reported aright he feared the game was up

children.name: Paragraph_45
children.value: 'And yet,' said the old man, dropping his hands on his knees, 'it's a sad thing, my dear, to lose so much when we had set our hearts upon it.'
children.prevalue: And yet said the old man dropping his hands on his knees it s a sad thing my dear to lose so much when we had set our hearts upon it

children.name: Paragraph_46
children.value: 'So it is,' said Mr. Sikes.  'Worse luck!'
children.prevalue: So it is said Mr Sikes Worse luck

children.name: Paragraph_47
children.value: A long silence ensued; during which the Jew was plunged in deep thought, with his face wrinkled into an expression of villainy perfectly demoniacal.  Sikes eyed him furtively from time to time. Nancy, apparently fearful of irritating the housebreaker, sat with her eyes fixed upon the fire, as if she had been deaf to all that passed.
children.prevalue: A long silence ensued during which the Jew was plunged in deep thought with his face wrinkled into an expression of villainy perfectly demoniacal Sikes eyed him furtively from time to time Nancy apparently fearful of irritating the housebreaker sat with her eyes fixed upon the fire as if she had been deaf to all that passed

children.name: Paragraph_48
children.value: 'Fagin,' said Sikes, abruptly breaking the stillness that prevailed; 'is it worth fifty shiners extra, if it's safely done from the outside?'
children.prevalue: Fagin said Sikes abruptly breaking the stillness that prevailed is it worth fifty shiners extra if it s safely done from the outside

children.name: Paragraph_49
children.value: 'Yes,' said the Jew, as suddenly rousing himself.
children.prevalue: Yes said the Jew as suddenly rousing himself

children.name: Paragraph_50
children.value: 'Is it a bargain?' inquired Sikes.

children.name: Paragraph_51

The crib's barred up at night like a jail; but there's one part we can crack, safe and softly.'

children.name: Paragraph_60
children.value: 'Never mind wot it is!' replied Sikes.  'I want a boy, and he musn't be a big 'un.  Lord!' said Mr. Sikes, reflectively, 'if I'd only got that young boy of Ned, the chimbley-sweeper's!  He kept him small on purpose, and let him out by the job.  But the father gets lagged; and then the Juvenile Delinquent Society comes, and takes the boy away from a trade where he was earning money, teaches him to read and write, and in time makes a 'prentice of him.  And so they go on,' said Mr. Sikes, his wrath rising with the recollection of his wrongs, 'so they go on; and, if they'd got money enough (which it's a Providence they haven't,) we shouldn't have half a dozen boys left in the whole trade, in a year or two.'

The old man crossed his arms upon his breast; and, drawing his head and shoulders into a heap, literally hugged himself for joy.

children.name: Paragraph_87
children.value: 'And wot,' said Sikes, scowling fiercely on his agreeable friend, 'wot makes you take so much pains about one chalk-faced kid, when you know there are fifty boys snoozing about Common Garden every night, as you might pick and choose from?'
children.prevalue: And wot said Sikes scowling fiercely on his agreeable friend wot makes you take so much pains about one chalk faced kid when you know there are fifty boys snoozing about Common Garden every night as you might pick and choose from

children.name: Paragraph_88
children.value: 'Because they're of no use to me, my dear,' replied the Jew, with some confusion, 'not worth the taking.  Their looks convict 'em when they get into trouble, and I lose 'em all.  With this boy, properly managed, my dears, I could do what I couldn't with twenty of them.  Besides,' said the Jew, recovering his self-possession, 'he has us now if he could only give us leg-bail again; and he must be in the same boat with us.  Never mind how he came there; it's quite enough for my power over him that he was in a robbery; that's all I want.  Now, how much better this is, than being obliged to put the poor leetle boy out of the way--which would be dangerous, and we should lose by it besides.'

children.name: Paragraph_98
children.value: After some discussion, in which all three took an active part, it was decided that Nancy should repair to the Jew's next evening when the night had set in, and bring Oliver away with her; Fagin craftily observing, that, if he evinced any disinclination to the task, he would be more willing to accompany the girl who had so recently interfered in his behalf, than anybody else.  It was also solemnly arranged that poor Oliver should, for the purposes of the contemplated expedition, be unreservedly consigned to the care and custody of Mr. William Sikes; and further, that the said Sikes should deal with him as he thought fit; and should not be held responsible by the Jew for any mischance or evil that might be necessary to visit him: it being understood that, to render the compact in this respect binding, any representations made by Mr. Sikes on his return should be required to be confirmed and corroborated, in all important particulars, by the testimony of flash Toby Crackit.

children.name: Paragraph_99
children.value: These preliminaries adjusted, Mr. Sikes proceeded to drink brandy at a furious rate, and to flourish the crowbar in an alarming manner; yelling forth, at the same time, most unmusical snatches of song, mingled with wild execrations.  At length, in a fit of professional enthusiasm, he insisted upon producing his box of housebreaking tools: which he had no sooner stumbled in with, and opened for the purpose of explaining the nature and properties of the various implements it contained, and the peculiar beauties of their construction, than he fell over the box upon the floor, and went to sleep where he fell.

children.name: Paragraph_108
children.value: The boy was lying, fast asleep, on a rude bed upon the floor; so pale with anxiety, and sadness, and the closeness of his prison, that he looked like death; not death as it shows in shroud and coffin, but in the guise it wears when life has just departed; when a young and gentle spirit has, but an instant, fled to Heaven, and the gross air of the world has not had time to breathe upon the changing dust it hallowed.

children.name: Paragraph_1
children.value: WHEREIN OLIVER IS DELIVERED OVER TO MR. WILLIAM SIKES
children.prevalue: WHEREIN OLIVER IS DELIVERED OVER TO MR WILLIAM SIKES

children.name: Paragraph_2
children.value: When Oliver awoke in the morning, he was a good deal surprised to find that a new pair of shoes, with strong thick soles, had been placed at his bedside; and that his old shoes had been removed. At first, he was pleased with the discovery: hoping that it might be the forerunner of his release; but such thoughts were quickly dispelled, on his sitting down to breakfast along with the Jew, who told him, in a tone and manner which increased his alarm, that he was to be taken to the residence of Bill Sikes that night.
children.prevalue: When Oliver awoke in the morning he was a good deal surprised to find that a new pair of shoes with strong thick soles had been placed at his bedside and that his old shoes had been removed At first he was pleased with the discovery hoping that it might be the forerunner of his release but such thoughts were quickly dispelled on his sitting down to breakfast along with the Jew who told him in a tone and manner which increased his alarm that he was to be taken to the residence of Bill Sikes that night

children.name: Paragraph_4

children.prevalue: No no my dear Not to stop there replied the Jew We shouldn t like to lose you Don t be afraid Oliver you shall come back to us again Ha ha ha We won t be so cruel as to send you away my dear Oh no no

children.prevalue: The old man who was stooping over the fire toasting a piece of bread looked round as he bantered Oliver thus and chuckled as if to show that he knew he would still be very glad to get away if he could

He had no other opportunity:  for the Jew remained very surly and silent till night:  when he prepared to go abroad.

children.value: Oliver looked up; the Jew, pointing to the candle, motioned him to light it.  He did so; and, as he placed the candlestick upon the table, saw that the Jew was gazing fixedly at him, with lowering and contracted brows, from the dark end of the room.

children.name: Paragraph_16
children.value: 'Take heed, Oliver! take heed!' said the old man, shaking his right hand before him in a warning manner.  'He's a rough man, and thinks nothing of blood when his own is up. Whatever falls out, say nothing; and do what he bids you.  Mind!'  Placing a strong emphasis on the last word, he suffered his features gradually to resolve themselves into a ghastly grin, and, nodding his head, left the room.

children.name: Paragraph_17
children.value: Oliver leaned his head upon his hand when the old man disappeared, and pondered, with a trembling heart, on the words he had just heard.  The more he thought of the Jew's admonition, the more he was at a loss to divine its real purpose and meaning.
children.prevalue: Oliver leaned his head upon his hand when the old man disappeared and pondered with a trembling heart on the words he had just heard The more he thought of the Jew s admonition the more he was at a loss to divine its real purpose and meaning

children.name: Paragraph_18
children.value: He could think of no bad object to be attained by sending him to Sikes, which would not be equally well answered by his remaining with Fagin; and after meditating for a long time, concluded that he had been selected to perform some ordinary menial offices for the housebreaker, until another boy, better suited for his purpose could be engaged.  He was too well accustomed to suffering, and had suffered too much where he was, to bewail the prospect of change very severely.  He remained lost in thought for some minutes; and then, with a heavy sigh, snuffed the candle, and, taking up the book which the Jew had left with him, began to read.
children.prevalue: He could think of no bad object to be attained by sending him to Sikes which would not be equally well answered by his remaining with Fagin and after meditating for a long time concluded that he had been selected to perform some ordinary menial offices for the housebreaker until another boy better suited for his purpose could be engaged He was too well accustomed to suffering and had suffered too much where he was to bewail the prospect of change very severely He remained lost in thought for some minutes and then with a heavy sigh snuffed the candle and taking up the book which the Jew had left with him began to read

children.name: Paragraph_19
children.value: He turned over the leaves.  Carelessly at first; but, lighting on a passage which attracted his attention, he soon became intent upon the volume.  It was a history of the lives and trials of great criminals; and the pages were soiled and thumbed with use. Here, he read of dreadful crimes that made the blood run cold; of secret murders that had been committed by the lonely wayside; of bodies hidden from the eye of man in deep pits and wells: which would not keep them down, deep as they were, but had yielded them up at last, after many years, and so maddened the murderers with the sight, that in their horror they had confessed their guilt, and yelled for the gibbet to end their agony. Here, too, he read of men who, lying in their beds at dead of night, had been tempted (so they said) and led on, by their own bad thoughts, to such dreadful bloodshed as it made the flesh creep, and the limbs quail, to think of.  The terrible descriptions were so real and vivid, that the sallow pages seemed to turn red with gore; and the words upon them, to be sounded in his ears, as if they were whispered, in hollow murmurs, by the spirits of the dead.
children.prevalue: He turned over the leaves Carelessly at first but lighting on a passage which attracted his attention he soon became intent upon the volume It was a history of the lives and trials of great criminals and the pages were soiled and thumbed with use Here he read of dreadful crimes that made the blood run cold of secret murders that had been committed by the lonely wayside of bodies hidden from the eye of man in deep pits and wells which would not keep them down deep as they were but had yielded them up at last after many years and so maddened the murderers with the sight that in their horror they had confessed their guilt and yelled for the gibbet to end their agony Here too he read of men who lying in their beds at dead of night had been tempted so they said and led on by their own bad thoughts to such dreadful bloodshed as it made the flesh creep and the limbs quail to think of The terrible descriptions were so real and vivid that the sallow pages seemed to turn red with gore and the words upon them to be sounded in his ears as if they were whispered in hollow murmurs by the spirits of the dead

children.name: Paragraph_20
children.value: In a paroxysm of fear, the boy closed the book, and thrust it from him. Then, falling upon his knees, he prayed Heaven to spare him from such deeds; and rather to will that he should die at once, than be reserved for crimes, so fearful and appalling. By degrees, he grew more calm, and besought, in a low and broken voice, that he might be rescued from his present dangers; and that if any aid were to be raised up for a poor outcast boy who had never known the love of friends or kindred, it might come to him now, when, desolate and deserted, he stood alone in the midst of wickedness and guilt.
children.prevalue: In a paroxysm of fear the boy closed the book and thrust it from him Then falling upon his knees he prayed Heaven to spare him from such deeds and rather to will that he should die at once than be reserved for crimes so fearful and appalling By degrees he grew more calm and besought in a low and broken voice that he might be rescued from his present dangers and that if any aid were to be raised up for a poor outcast boy who had never known the love of friends or kindred it might come to him now when desolate and deserted he stood alone in the midst of wickedness and guilt

children.name: Paragraph_21
children.value: He had concluded his prayer, but still remained with his head buried in his hands, when a rustling noise aroused him.
children.prevalue: He had concluded his prayer but still remained with his head buried in his hands when a rustling noise aroused him

children.name: Paragraph_22
children.value: 'What's that!' he cried, starting up, and catching sight of a figure standing by the door.  'Who's there?'
children.prevalue: What s that he cried starting up and catching sight of a figure standing by the door Who s there

children.name: Paragraph_23
children.value: 'Me.  Only me,' replied a tremulous voice.
children.prevalue: Me Only me replied a tremulous voice

children.name: Paragraph_24
children.value: Oliver raised the candle above his head: and looked towards the door. It was Nancy.
children.prevalue: Oliver raised the candle above his head and looked towards the door It was Nancy

children.name: Paragraph_25
children.value: 'Put down the light,' said the girl, turning away her head. 'It hurts my eyes.'
children.prevalue: Put down the light said the girl turning away her head It hurts my eyes

children.name: Paragraph_26
children.value: Oliver saw that she was very pale, and gently inquired if she were ill. The girl threw herself into a chair, with her back towards him:  and wrung her hands; but made no reply.
children.prevalue: Oliver saw that she was very pale and gently inquired if she were ill The girl threw herself into a chair with her back towards him and wrung her hands but made no reply

children.name: Paragraph_27
children.value: 'God forgive me!' she cried after a while, 'I never thought of this.'
children.prevalue: God forgive me she cried after a while I never thought of this

children.name: Paragraph_28
children.value: 'Has anything happened?' asked Oliver.  'Can I help you?  I will if I can.  I will, indeed.'
children.prevalue: Has anything happened asked Oliver Can I help you I will if I can I will indeed

children.name: Paragraph_29
children.value: She rocked herself to and fro; caught her throat; and, uttering a gurgling sound, gasped for breath.
children.prevalue: She rocked herself to and fro caught her throat and uttering a gurgling sound gasped for breath

children.name: Paragraph_30
children.value: 'Nancy!' cried Oliver, 'What is it?'
children.prevalue: Nancy cried Oliver What is it

children.name: Paragraph_31
