children.value: The girl beat her hands upon her knees, and her feet upon the ground; and, suddenly stopping, drew her shawl close round her: and shivered with cold.
children.prevalue: The girl beat her hands upon her knees and her feet upon the ground and suddenly stopping drew her shawl close round her and shivered with cold

children.name: Paragraph_32
children.value: Oliver stirred the fire.  Drawing her chair close to it, she sat there, for a little time, without speaking; but at length she raised her head, and looked round.
children.prevalue: Oliver stirred the fire Drawing her chair close to it she sat there for a little time without speaking but at length she raised her head and looked round

children.name: Paragraph_33
children.value: 'I don't know what comes over me sometimes,' said she, affecting to busy herself in arranging her dress; 'it's this damp dirty room, I think.  Now, Nolly, dear, are you ready?'
children.prevalue: I don t know what comes over me sometimes said she affecting to busy herself in arranging her dress it s this damp dirty room I think Now Nolly dear are you ready

children.name: Paragraph_34
children.value: 'Am I to go with you?' asked Oliver.
children.prevalue: Am I to go with you asked Oliver

children.name: Paragraph_35
children.value: 'Yes.  I have come from Bill,' replied the girl.  'You are to go with me.'
children.prevalue: Yes I have come from Bill replied the girl You are to go with me

children.name: Paragraph_36
children.value: 'What for?' asked Oliver, recoiling.
children.prevalue: What for asked Oliver recoiling

children.name: Paragraph_37
children.value: 'What for?' echoed the girl, raising her eyes, and averting them again, the moment they encountered the boy's face.  'Oh!  For no harm.'
children.prevalue: What for echoed the girl raising her eyes and averting them again the moment they encountered the boy s face Oh For no harm

children.name: Paragraph_38
children.value: 'I don't believe it,' said Oliver:  who had watched her closely.
children.prevalue: I don t believe it said Oliver who had watched her closely

children.name: Paragraph_39
children.value: 'Have it your own way,' rejoined the girl, affecting to laugh. 'For no good, then.'
children.prevalue: Have it your own way rejoined the girl affecting to laugh For no good then

children.name: Paragraph_40
children.value: Oliver could see that he had some power over the girl's better feelings, and, for an instant, thought of appealing to her compassion for his helpless state.  But, then, the thought darted across his mind that it was barely eleven o'clock; and that many people were still in the streets:  of whom surely some might be found to give credence to his tale.  As the reflection occured to him, he stepped forward:  and said, somewhat hastily, that he was ready.
children.prevalue: Oliver could see that he had some power over the girl s better feelings and for an instant thought of appealing to her compassion for his helpless state But then the thought darted across his mind that it was barely eleven o clock and that many people were still in the streets of whom surely some might be found to give credence to his tale As the reflection occured to him he stepped forward and said somewhat hastily that he was ready

children.name: Paragraph_41
children.value: Neither his brief consideration, nor its purport, was lost on his companion.  She eyed him narrowly, while he spoke; and cast upon him a look of intelligence which sufficiently showed that she guessed what had been passing in his thoughts.
children.prevalue: Neither his brief consideration nor its purport was lost on his companion She eyed him narrowly while he spoke and cast upon him a look of intelligence which sufficiently showed that she guessed what had been passing in his thoughts

children.name: Paragraph_42
children.value: 'Hush!' said the girl, stooping over him, and pointing to the door as she looked cautiously round.  'You can't help yourself. I have tried hard for you, but all to no purpose.  You are hedged round and round. If ever you are to get loose from here, this is not the time.'
children.prevalue: Hush said the girl stooping over him and pointing to the door as she looked cautiously round You can t help yourself I have tried hard for you but all to no purpose You are hedged round and round If ever you are to get loose from here this is not the time

children.name: Paragraph_43
children.value: Struck by the energy of her manner, Oliver looked up in her face with great surprise.  She seemed to speak the truth; her countenance was white and agitated; and she trembled with very earnestness.
children.prevalue: Struck by the energy of her manner Oliver looked up in her face with great surprise She seemed to speak the truth her countenance was white and agitated and she trembled with very earnestness

children.name: Paragraph_44
children.value: 'I have saved you from being ill-used once, and I will again, and I do now,' continued the girl aloud; 'for those who would have fetched you, if I had not, would have been far more rough than me.  I have promised for your being quiet and silent; if you are not, you will only do harm to yourself and me too, and perhaps be my death.  See here!  I have borne all this for you already, as true as God sees me show it.'
children.prevalue: I have saved you from being ill used once and I will again and I do now continued the girl aloud for those who would have fetched you if I had not would have been far more rough than me I have promised for your being quiet and silent if you are not you will only do harm to yourself and me too and perhaps be my death See here I have borne all this for you already as true as God sees me show it

children.name: Paragraph_45
children.value: She pointed, hastily, to some livid bruises on her neck and arms; and continued, with great rapidity:
children.prevalue: She pointed hastily to some livid bruises on her neck and arms and continued with great rapidity

children.name: Paragraph_46
children.value: 'Remember this!  And don't let me suffer more for you, just now. If I could help you, I would; but I have not the power.  They don't mean to harm you; whatever they make you do, is no fault of yours.  Hush! Every word from you is a blow for me.  Give me your hand.  Make haste! Your hand!'
children.prevalue: Remember this And don t let me suffer more for you just now If I could help you I would but I have not the power They don t mean to harm you whatever they make you do is no fault of yours Hush Every word from you is a blow for me Give me your hand Make haste Your hand

children.name: Paragraph_47
children.value: She caught the hand which Oliver instinctively placed in hers, and, blowing out the light, drew him after her up the stairs. The door was opened, quickly, by some one shrouded in the darkness, and was as quickly closed, when they had passed out.  A hackney-cabriolet was in waiting; with the same vehemence which she had exhibited in addressing Oliver, the girl pulled him in with her, and drew the curtains close. The driver wanted no directions, but lashed his horse into full speed, without the delay of an instant.
children.prevalue: She caught the hand which Oliver instinctively placed in hers and blowing out the light drew him after her up the stairs The door was opened quickly by some one shrouded in the darkness and was as quickly closed when they had passed out A hackney cabriolet was in waiting with the same vehemence which she had exhibited in addressing Oliver the girl pulled him in with her and drew the curtains close The driver wanted no directions but lashed his horse into full speed without the delay of an instant

children.name: Paragraph_48
children.value: The girl still held Oliver fast by the hand, and continued to pour into his ear, the warnings and assurances she had already imparted.  All was so quick and hurried, that he had scarcely time to recollect where he was, or how he came there, when the carriage stopped at the house to which the Jew's steps had been directed on the previous evening.
children.prevalue: The girl still held Oliver fast by the hand and continued to pour into his ear the warnings and assurances she had already imparted All was so quick and hurried that he had scarcely time to recollect where he was or how he came there when the carriage stopped at the house to which the Jew s steps had been directed on the previous evening

children.name: Paragraph_49
children.value: For one brief moment, Oliver cast a hurried glance along the empty street, and a cry for help hung upon his lips.  But the girl's voice was in his ear, beseeching him in such tones of agony to remember her, that he had not the heart to utter it. While he hesitated, the opportunity was gone; he was already in the house, and the door was shut.
children.prevalue: For one brief moment Oliver cast a hurried glance along the empty street and a cry for help hung upon his lips But the girl s voice was in his ear beseeching him in such tones of agony to remember her that he had not the heart to utter it While he hesitated the opportunity was gone he was already in the house and the door was shut

children.name: Paragraph_50
children.value: 'This way,' said the girl, releasing her hold for the first time. 'Bill!'
children.prevalue: This way said the girl releasing her hold for the first time Bill

children.name: Paragraph_51
children.value: 'Hallo!' replied Sikes: appearing at the head of the stairs, with a candle.  'Oh!  That's the time of day.  Come on!'
children.prevalue: Hallo replied Sikes appearing at the head of the stairs with a candle Oh That s the time of day Come on

children.name: Paragraph_52
children.value: This was a very strong expression of approbation, an uncommonly hearty welcome, from a person of Mr. Sikes' temperament.  Nancy, appearing much gratified thereby, saluted him cordially.
children.prevalue: This was a very strong expression of approbation an uncommonly hearty welcome from a person of Mr Sikes temperament Nancy appearing much gratified thereby saluted him cordially

children.name: Paragraph_53
children.value: 'Bull's-eye's gone home with Tom,' observed Sikes, as he lighted them up.  'He'd have been in the way.'
children.prevalue: Bull s eye s gone home with Tom observed Sikes as he lighted them up He d have been in the way

children.name: Paragraph_54
children.value: 'That's right,' rejoined Nancy.
children.prevalue: That s right rejoined Nancy

children.name: Paragraph_55
children.value: 'So you've got the kid,' said Sikes when they had all reached the room: closing the door as he spoke.
children.prevalue: So you ve got the kid said Sikes when they had all reached the room closing the door as he spoke

children.name: Paragraph_56
children.value: 'Yes, here he is,' replied Nancy.
children.prevalue: Yes here he is replied Nancy

children.name: Paragraph_57
children.value: 'Did he come quiet?' inquired Sikes.
children.prevalue: Did he come quiet inquired Sikes

children.name: Paragraph_58
children.value: 'Like a lamb,' rejoined Nancy.
children.prevalue: Like a lamb rejoined Nancy

children.name: Paragraph_59
children.value: 'I'm glad to hear it,' said Sikes, looking grimly at Oliver; 'for the sake of his young carcase:  as would otherways have suffered for it. Come here, young 'un; and let me read you a lectur', which is as well got over at once.'
children.prevalue: I m glad to hear it said Sikes looking grimly at Oliver for the sake of his young carcase as would otherways have suffered for it Come here young un and let me read you a lectur which is as well got over at once

children.name: Paragraph_60
children.value: Thus addressing his new pupil, Mr. Sikes pulled off Oliver's cap and threw it into a corner; and then, taking him by the shoulder, sat himself down by the table, and stood the boy in front of him.
children.prevalue: Thus addressing his new pupil Mr Sikes pulled off Oliver s cap and threw it into a corner and then taking him by the shoulder sat himself down by the table and stood the boy in front of him

children.name: Paragraph_61
children.value: 'Now, first:  do you know wot this is?' inquired Sikes, taking up a pocket-pistol which lay on the table.
children.prevalue: Now first do you know wot this is inquired Sikes taking up a pocket pistol which lay on the table

children.name: Paragraph_62
children.value: Oliver replied in the affirmative.
children.prevalue: Oliver replied in the affirmative

children.name: Paragraph_63
children.value: 'Well, then, look here,' continued Sikes.  'This is powder; that 'ere's a bullet; and this is a little bit of a old hat for waddin'.'
children.prevalue: Well then look here continued Sikes This is powder that ere s a bullet and this is a little bit of a old hat for waddin

children.name: Paragraph_64
children.value: Oliver murmured his comprehension of the different bodies referred to; and Mr. Sikes proceeded to load the pistol, with great nicety and deliberation.
children.prevalue: Oliver murmured his comprehension of the different bodies referred to and Mr Sikes proceeded to load the pistol with great nicety and deliberation

children.name: Paragraph_65
children.value: 'Now it's loaded,' said Mr. Sikes, when he had finished.
children.prevalue: Now it s loaded said Mr Sikes when he had finished

children.name: Paragraph_66
children.value: 'Yes, I see it is, sir,' replied Oliver.
children.prevalue: Yes I see it is sir replied Oliver

children.name: Paragraph_67
children.value: 'Well,' said the robber, grasping Oliver's wrist, and putting the barrel so close to his temple that they touched; at which moment the boy could not repress a start; 'if you speak a word when you're out o'doors with me, except when I speak to you, that loading will be in your head without notice.  So, if you do make up your mind to speak without leave, say your prayers first.'
children.prevalue: Well said the robber grasping Oliver s wrist and putting the barrel so close to his temple that they touched at which moment the boy could not repress a start if you speak a word when you re out o doors with me except when I speak to you that loading will be in your head without notice So if you do make up your mind to speak without leave say your prayers first

children.name: Paragraph_68
children.value: Having bestowed a scowl upon the object of this warning, to increase its effect, Mr. Sikes continued.
children.prevalue: Having bestowed a scowl upon the object of this warning to increase its effect Mr Sikes continued

children.name: Paragraph_69
children.value: 'As near as I know, there isn't anybody as would be asking very partickler arter you, if you was disposed of; so I needn't take this devil-and-all of trouble to explain matters to you, if it warn't for your own good.  D'ye hear me?'
children.prevalue: As near as I know there isn t anybody as would be asking very partickler arter you if you was disposed of so I needn t take this devil and all of trouble to explain matters to you if it warn t for your own good D ye hear me

children.name: Paragraph_70
children.value: 'The short and the long of what you mean,' said Nancy:  speaking very emphatically, and slightly frowning at Oliver as if to bespeak his serious attention to her words:  'is, that if you're crossed by him in this job you have on hand, you'll prevent his ever telling tales afterwards, by shooting him through the head, and will take your chance of swinging for it, as you do for a great many other things in the way of business, every month of your life.'
children.prevalue: The short and the long of what you mean said Nancy speaking very emphatically and slightly frowning at Oliver as if to bespeak his serious attention to her words is that if you re crossed by him in this job you have on hand you ll prevent his ever telling tales afterwards by shooting him through the head and will take your chance of swinging for it as you do for a great many other things in the way of business every month of your life

children.name: Paragraph_71
children.value: 'That's it!' observed Mr. Sikes, approvingly; 'women can always put things in fewest words.--Except when it's blowing up; and then they lengthens it out.  And now that he's thoroughly up to it, let's have some supper, and get a snooze before starting.'
children.prevalue: That s it observed Mr Sikes approvingly women can always put things in fewest words Except when it s blowing up and then they lengthens it out And now that he s thoroughly up to it let s have some supper and get a snooze before starting

children.name: Paragraph_72
children.value: In pursuance of this request, Nancy quickly laid the cloth; disappearing for a few minutes, she presently returned with a pot of porter and a dish of sheep's heads: which gave occasion to several pleasant witticisms on the part of Mr. Sikes, founded upon the singular coincidence of 'jemmies' being a can name, common to them, and also to an ingenious implement much used in his profession.  Indeed, the worthy gentleman, stimulated perhaps by the immediate prospect of being on active service, was in great spirits and good humour; in proof whereof, it may be here remarked, that he humourously drank all the beer at a draught, and did not utter, on a rough calculation, more than four-score oaths during the whole progress of the meal.
children.prevalue: In pursuance of this request Nancy quickly laid the cloth disappearing for a few minutes she presently returned with a pot of porter and a dish of sheep s heads which gave occasion to several pleasant witticisms on the part of Mr Sikes founded upon the singular coincidence of jemmies being a can name common to them and also to an ingenious implement much used in his profession Indeed the worthy gentleman stimulated perhaps by the immediate prospect of being on active service was in great spirits and good humour in proof whereof it may be here remarked that he humourously drank all the beer at a draught and did not utter on a rough calculation more than four score oaths during the whole progress of the meal

children.name: Paragraph_73
children.value: Supper being ended--it may be easily conceived that Oliver had no great appetite for it--Mr. Sikes disposed of a couple of glasses of spirits and water, and threw himself on the bed; ordering Nancy, with many imprecations in case of failure, to call him at five precisely.  Oliver stretched himself in his clothes, by command of the same authority, on a mattress upon the floor; and the girl, mending the fire, sat before it, in readiness to rouse them at the appointed time.
children.prevalue: Supper being ended it may be easily conceived that Oliver had no great appetite for it Mr Sikes disposed of a couple of glasses of spirits and water and threw himself on the bed ordering Nancy with many imprecations in case of failure to call him at five precisely Oliver stretched himself in his clothes by command of the same authority on a mattress upon the floor and the girl mending the fire sat before it in readiness to rouse them at the appointed time

children.name: Paragraph_74
children.value: For a long time Oliver lay awake, thinking it not impossible that Nancy might seek that opportunity of whispering some further advice; but the girl sat brooding over the fire, without moving, save now and then to trim the light.  Weary with watching and anxiety, he at length fell asleep.
children.prevalue: For a long time Oliver lay awake thinking it not impossible that Nancy might seek that opportunity of whispering some further advice but the girl sat brooding over the fire without moving save now and then to trim the light Weary with watching and anxiety he at length fell asleep

children.name: Paragraph_75
children.value: When he awoke, the table was covered with tea-things, and Sikes was thrusting various articles into the pockets of his great-coat, which hung over the back of a chair.  Nancy was busily engaged in preparing breakfast.  It was not yet daylight; for the candle was still burning, and it was quite dark outside. A sharp rain, too, was beating against the window-panes; and the sky looked black and cloudy.
children.prevalue: When he awoke the table was covered with tea things and Sikes was thrusting various articles into the pockets of his great coat which hung over the back of a chair Nancy was busily engaged in preparing breakfast It was not yet daylight for the candle was still burning and it was quite dark outside A sharp rain too was beating against the window panes and the sky looked black and cloudy

children.name: Paragraph_76
children.value: 'Now, then!' growled Sikes, as Oliver started up; 'half-past five! Look sharp, or you'll get no breakfast; for it's late as it is.'
children.prevalue: Now then growled Sikes as Oliver started up half past five Look sharp or you ll get no breakfast for it s late as it is

children.name: Paragraph_77
children.value: Oliver was not long in making his toilet; having taken some breakfast, he replied to a surly inquiry from Sikes, by saying that he was quite ready.
children.prevalue: Oliver was not long in making his toilet having taken some breakfast he replied to a surly inquiry from Sikes by saying that he was quite ready

children.name: Paragraph_78
children.value: Nancy, scarcely looking at the boy, threw him a handkerchief to tie round his throat; Sikes gave him a large rough cape to button over his shoulders.  Thus attired, he gave his hand to the robber, who, merely pausing to show him with a menacing gesture that he had that same pistol in a side-pocket of his great-coat, clasped it firmly in his, and, exchanging a farewell with Nancy, led him away.
children.prevalue: Nancy scarcely looking at the boy threw him a handkerchief to tie round his throat Sikes gave him a large rough cape to button over his shoulders Thus attired he gave his hand to the robber who merely pausing to show him with a menacing gesture that he had that same pistol in a side pocket of his great coat clasped it firmly in his and exchanging a farewell with Nancy led him away

children.name: Paragraph_79
children.value: Oliver turned, for an instant, when they reached the door, in the hope of meeting a look from the girl.  But she had resumed her old seat in front of the fire, and sat, perfectly motionless before it.
children.prevalue: Oliver turned for an instant when they reached the door in the hope of meeting a look from the girl But she had resumed her old seat in front of the fire and sat perfectly motionless before it

children.name: Paragraph_1
children.value: THE EXPEDITION
children.prevalue: THE EXPEDITION

children.name: Paragraph_2
children.value: It was a cheerless morning when they got into the street; blowing and raining hard; and the clouds looking dull and stormy.  The night had been very wet: large pools of water had collected in the road: and the kennels were overflowing.  There was a faint glimmering of the coming day in the sky; but it rather aggravated than relieved the gloom of the scene:  the sombre light only serving to pale that which the street lamps afforded, without shedding any warmer or brighter tints upon the wet house-tops, and dreary streets.  There appeared to be nobody stirring in that quarter of the town; the windows of the houses were all closely shut; and the streets through which they passed, were noiseless and empty.
children.prevalue: It was a cheerless morning when they got into the street blowing and raining hard and the clouds looking dull and stormy The night had been very wet large pools of water had collected in the road and the kennels were overflowing There was a faint glimmering of the coming day in the sky but it rather aggravated than relieved the gloom of the scene the sombre light only serving to pale that which the street lamps afforded without shedding any warmer or brighter tints upon the wet house tops and dreary streets There appeared to be nobody stirring in that quarter of the town the windows of the houses were all closely shut and the streets through which they passed were noiseless and empty

children.name: Paragraph_3
children.value: By the time they had turned into the Bethnal Green Road, the day had fairly begun to break.  Many of the lamps were already extinguished; a few country waggons were slowly toiling on, towards London; now and then, a stage-coach, covered with mud, rattled briskly by: the driver bestowing, as he passed, an admonitory lash upon the heavy waggoner who, by keeping on the wrong side of the road, had endangered his arriving at the office, a quarter of a minute after his time.  The public-houses, with gas-lights burning inside, were already open.  By degrees, other shops began to be unclosed, and a few scattered people were met with.  Then, came straggling groups of labourers going to their work; then, men and women with fish-baskets on their heads; donkey-carts laden with vegetables; chaise-carts filled with live-stock or whole carcasses of meat; milk-women with pails; an unbroken concourse of people, trudging out with various supplies to the eastern suburbs of the town.  As they approached the City, the noise and traffic gradually increased; when they threaded the streets between Shoreditch and Smithfield, it had swelled into a roar of sound and bustle.  It was as light as it was likely to be, till night came on again, and the busy morning of half the London population had begun.
children.prevalue: By the time they had turned into the Bethnal Green Road the day had fairly begun to break Many of the lamps were already extinguished a few country waggons were slowly toiling on towards London now and then a stage coach covered with mud rattled briskly by the driver bestowing as he passed an admonitory lash upon the heavy waggoner who by keeping on the wrong side of the road had endangered his arriving at the office a quarter of a minute after his time The public houses with gas lights burning inside were already open By degrees other shops began to be unclosed and a few scattered people were met with Then came straggling groups of labourers going to their work then men and women with fish baskets on their heads donkey carts laden with vegetables chaise carts filled with live stock or whole carcasses of meat milk women with pails an unbroken concourse of people trudging out with various supplies to the eastern suburbs of the town As they approached the City the noise and traffic gradually increased when they threaded the streets between Shoreditch and Smithfield it had swelled into a roar of sound and bustle It was as light as it was likely to be till night came on again and the busy morning of half the London population had begun

children.name: Paragraph_4
children.value: Turning down Sun Street and Crown Street, and crossing Finsbury square, Mr. Sikes struck, by way of Chiswell Street, into Barbican: thence into Long Lane, and so into Smithfield; from which latter place arose a tumult of discordant sounds that filled Oliver Twist with amazement.
children.prevalue: Turning down Sun Street and Crown Street and crossing Finsbury square Mr Sikes struck by way of Chiswell Street into Barbican thence into Long Lane and so into Smithfield from which latter place arose a tumult of discordant sounds that filled Oliver Twist with amazement

children.name: Paragraph_5
children.value: It was market-morning.  The ground was covered, nearly ankle-deep, with filth and mire; a thick steam, perpetually rising from the reeking bodies of the cattle, and mingling with the fog, which seemed to rest upon the chimney-tops, hung heavily above.  All the pens in the centre of the large area, and as many temporary pens as could be crowded into the vacant space, were filled with sheep; tied up to posts by the gutter side were long lines of beasts and oxen, three or four deep. Countrymen, butchers, drovers, hawkers, boys, thieves, idlers, and vagabonds of every low grade, were mingled together in a mass; the whistling of drovers, the barking dogs, the bellowing and plunging of the oxen, the bleating of sheep, the grunting and squeaking of pigs, the cries of hawkers, the shouts, oaths, and quarrelling on all sides; the ringing of bells and roar of voices, that issued from every public-house; the crowding, pushing, driving, beating, whooping and yelling; the hideous and discordant dim that resounded from every corner of the market; and the unwashed, unshaven, squalid, and dirty figures constantly running to and fro, and bursting in and out of the throng; rendered it a stunning and bewildering scene, which quite confounded the senses.
children.prevalue: It was market morning The ground was covered nearly ankle deep with filth and mire a thick steam perpetually rising from the reeking bodies of the cattle and mingling with the fog which seemed to rest upon the chimney tops hung heavily above All the pens in the centre of the large area and as many temporary pens as could be crowded into the vacant space were filled with sheep tied up to posts by the gutter side were long lines of beasts and oxen three or four deep Countrymen butchers drovers hawkers boys thieves idlers and vagabonds of every low grade were mingled together in a mass the whistling of drovers the barking dogs the bellowing and plunging of the oxen the bleating of sheep the grunting and squeaking of pigs the cries of hawkers the shouts oaths and quarrelling on all sides the ringing of bells and roar of voices that issued from every public house the crowding pushing driving beating whooping and yelling the hideous and discordant dim that resounded from every corner of the market and the unwashed unshaven squalid and dirty figures constantly running to and fro and bursting in and out of the throng rendered it a stunning and bewildering scene which quite confounded the senses

children.name: Paragraph_6
children.value: Mr. Sikes, dragging Oliver after him, elbowed his way through the thickest of the crowd, and bestowed very little attention on the numerous sights and sounds, which so astonished the boy.  He nodded, twice or thrice, to a passing friend; and, resisting as many invitations to take a morning dram, pressed steadily onward, until they were clear of the turmoil, and had made their way through Hosier Lane into Holborn.
children.prevalue: Mr Sikes dragging Oliver after him elbowed his way through the thickest of the crowd and bestowed very little attention on the numerous sights and sounds which so astonished the boy He nodded twice or thrice to a passing friend and resisting as many invitations to take a morning dram pressed steadily onward until they were clear of the turmoil and had made their way through Hosier Lane into Holborn

children.name: Paragraph_7
children.value: 'Now, young 'un!' said Sikes, looking up at the clock of St. Andrew's Church, 'hard upon seven! you must step out.  Come, don't lag behind already, Lazy-legs!'
children.prevalue: Now young un said Sikes looking up at the clock of St Andrew s Church hard upon seven you must step out Come don t lag behind already Lazy legs

children.name: Paragraph_8
children.value: Mr. Sikes accompanied this speech with a jerk at his little companion's wrist; Oliver, quickening his pace into a kind of trot between a fast walk and a run, kept up with the rapid strides of the house-breaker as well as he could.
children.prevalue: Mr Sikes accompanied this speech with a jerk at his little companion s wrist Oliver quickening his pace into a kind of trot between a fast walk and a run kept up with the rapid strides of the house breaker as well as he could

children.name: Paragraph_9
children.value: They held their course at this rate, until they had passed Hyde Park corner, and were on their way to Kensington:  when Sikes relaxed his pace, until an empty cart which was at some little distance behind, came up.  Seeing 'Hounslow' written on it, he asked the driver with as much civility as he could assume, if he would give them a lift as far as Isleworth.
children.prevalue: They held their course at this rate until they had passed Hyde Park corner and were on their way to Kensington when Sikes relaxed his pace until an empty cart which was at some little distance behind came up Seeing Hounslow written on it he asked the driver with as much civility as he could assume if he would give them a lift as far as Isleworth

children.name: Paragraph_10
children.value: 'Jump up,' said the man.  'Is that your boy?'
children.prevalue: Jump up said the man Is that your boy

children.name: Paragraph_11
children.value: 'Yes; he's my boy,' replied Sikes, looking hard at Oliver, and putting his hand abstractedly into the pocket where the pistol was.
children.prevalue: Yes he s my boy replied Sikes looking hard at Oliver and putting his hand abstractedly into the pocket where the pistol was

children.name: Paragraph_12
children.value: 'Your father walks rather too quick for you, don't he, my man?' inquired the driver: seeing that Oliver was out of breath.
children.prevalue: Your father walks rather too quick for you don t he my man inquired the driver seeing that Oliver was out of breath

children.name: Paragraph_13
children.value: 'Not a bit of it,' replied Sikes, interposing.  'He's used to it.
children.prevalue: Not a bit of it replied Sikes interposing He s used to it

children.name: Paragraph_14
children.value: Here, take hold of my hand, Ned.  In with you!'
children.prevalue: Here take hold of my hand Ned In with you

children.name: Paragraph_15
children.value: Thus addressing Oliver, he helped him into the cart; and the driver, pointing to a heap of sacks, told him to lie down there, and rest himself.
children.prevalue: Thus addressing Oliver he helped him into the cart and the driver pointing to a heap of sacks told him to lie down there and rest himself

children.name: Paragraph_16
children.value: As they passed the different mile-stones, Oliver wondered, more and more, where his companion meant to take him.  Kensington, Hammersmith, Chiswick, Kew Bridge, Brentford, were all passed; and yet they went on as steadily as if they had only just begun their journey.  At length, they came to a public-house called the Coach and Horses; a little way beyond which, another road appeared to run off.  And here, the cart stopped.
children.prevalue: As they passed the different mile stones Oliver wondered more and more where his companion meant to take him Kensington Hammersmith Chiswick Kew Bridge Brentford were all passed and yet they went on as steadily as if they had only just begun their journey At length they came to a public house called the Coach and Horses a little way beyond which another road appeared to run off And here the cart stopped

children.name: Paragraph_17
children.value: Sikes dismounted with great precipitation, holding Oliver by the hand all the while; and lifting him down directly, bestowed a furious look upon him, and rapped the side-pocket with his fist, in a significant manner.
children.prevalue: Sikes dismounted with great precipitation holding Oliver by the hand all the while and lifting him down directly bestowed a furious look upon him and rapped the side pocket with his fist in a significant manner

children.name: Paragraph_18
children.value: 'Good-bye, boy,' said the man.
children.prevalue: Good bye boy said the man

children.name: Paragraph_19
children.value: 'He's sulky,' replied Sikes, giving him a shake; 'he's sulky.  A young dog!  Don't mind him.'
children.prevalue: He s sulky replied Sikes giving him a shake he s sulky A young dog Don t mind him

children.name: Paragraph_20
children.value: 'Not I!' rejoined the other, getting into his cart.  'It's a fine day, after all.'  And he drove away.
children.prevalue: Not I rejoined the other getting into his cart It s a fine day after all And he drove away

children.name: Paragraph_21
children.value: Sikes waited until he had fairly gone; and then, telling Oliver he might look about him if he wanted, once again led him onward on his journey.
children.prevalue: Sikes waited until he had fairly gone and then telling Oliver he might look about him if he wanted once again led him onward on his journey

children.name: Paragraph_22
children.value: They turned round to the left, a short way past the public-house; and then, taking a right-hand road, walked on for a long time: passing many large gardens and gentlemen's houses on both sides of the way, and stopping for nothing but a little beer, until they reached a town. Here against the wall of a house, Oliver saw written up in pretty large letters, 'Hampton.'  They lingered about, in the fields, for some hours.  At length they came back into the town; and, turning into an old public-house with a defaced sign-board, ordered some dinner by the kitchen fire.
children.prevalue: They turned round to the left a short way past the public house and then taking a right hand road walked on for a long time passing many large gardens and gentlemen s houses on both sides of the way and stopping for nothing but a little beer until they reached a town Here against the wall of a house Oliver saw written up in pretty large letters Hampton They lingered about in the fields for some hours At length they came back into the town and turning into an old public house with a defaced sign board ordered some dinner by the kitchen fire

children.name: Paragraph_23
children.value: The kitchen was an old, low-roofed room; with a great beam across the middle of the ceiling, and benches, with high backs to them, by the fire; on which were seated several rough men in smock-frocks, drinking and smoking.  They took no notice of Oliver; and very little of Sikes; and, as Sikes took very little notice of them, he and his young comrade sat in a corner by themselves, without being much troubled by their company.
children.prevalue: The kitchen was an old low roofed room with a great beam across the middle of the ceiling and benches with high backs to them by the fire on which were seated several rough men in smock frocks drinking and smoking They took no notice of Oliver and very little of Sikes and as Sikes took very little notice of them he and his young comrade sat in a corner by themselves without being much troubled by their company

children.name: Paragraph_24
children.value: They had some cold meat for dinner, and sat so long after it, while Mr. Sikes indulged himself with three or four pipes, that Oliver began to feel quite certain they were not going any further.  Being much tired with the walk, and getting up so early, he dozed a little at first; then, quite overpowered by fatigue and the fumes of the tobacco, fell asleep.
children.prevalue: They had some cold meat for dinner and sat so long after it while Mr Sikes indulged himself with three or four pipes that Oliver began to feel quite certain they were not going any further Being much tired with the walk and getting up so early he dozed a little at first then quite overpowered by fatigue and the fumes of the tobacco fell asleep

children.name: Paragraph_25
children.value: It was quite dark when he was awakened by a push from Sikes. Rousing himself sufficiently to sit up and look about him, he found that worthy in close fellowship and communication with a labouring man, over a pint of ale.
children.prevalue: It was quite dark when he was awakened by a push from Sikes Rousing himself sufficiently to sit up and look about him he found that worthy in close fellowship and communication with a labouring man over a pint of ale

children.name: Paragraph_26
children.value: 'So, you're going on to Lower Halliford, are you?' inquired Sikes.
children.prevalue: So you re going on to Lower Halliford are you inquired Sikes

children.name: Paragraph_27
children.value: 'Yes, I am,' replied the man, who seemed a little the worse--or better, as the case might be--for drinking; 'and not slow about it neither.  My horse hasn't got a load behind him going back, as he had coming up in the mornin'; and he won't be long a-doing of it.  Here's luck to him. Ecod! he's a good 'un!'
children.prevalue: Yes I am replied the man who seemed a little the worse or better as the case might be for drinking and not slow about it neither My horse hasn t got a load behind him going back as he had coming up in the mornin and he won t be long a doing of it Here s luck to him Ecod he s a good un

children.name: Paragraph_28
children.value: 'Could you give my boy and me a lift as far as there?' demanded Sikes, pushing the ale towards his new friend.
children.prevalue: Could you give my boy and me a lift as far as there demanded Sikes pushing the ale towards his new friend

children.name: Paragraph_29
children.value: 'If you're going directly, I can,' replied the man, looking out of the pot.  'Are you going to Halliford?'
children.prevalue: If you re going directly I can replied the man looking out of the pot Are you going to Halliford

children.name: Paragraph_30
children.value: 'Going on to Shepperton,' replied Sikes.
children.prevalue: Going on to Shepperton replied Sikes

children.name: Paragraph_31
children.value: 'I'm your man, as far as I go,' replied the other.  'Is all paid, Becky?'
children.prevalue: I m your man as far as I go replied the other Is all paid Becky

children.name: Paragraph_32
children.value: 'Yes, the other gentleman's paid,' replied the girl.
children.prevalue: Yes the other gentleman s paid replied the girl

children.name: Paragraph_33
children.value: 'I say!' said the man, with tipsy gravity; 'that won't do, you know.'
children.prevalue: I say said the man with tipsy gravity that won t do you know

children.name: Paragraph_34
children.value: 'Why not?' rejoined Sikes.  'You're a-going to accommodate us, and wot's to prevent my standing treat for a pint or so, in return?'
children.prevalue: Why not rejoined Sikes You re a going to accommodate us and wot s to prevent my standing treat for a pint or so in return

children.name: Paragraph_35
children.value: The stranger reflected upon this argument, with a very profound face; having done so, he seized Sikes by the hand:  and declared he was a real good fellow.  To which Mr. Sikes replied, he was joking; as, if he had been sober, there would have been strong reason to suppose he was.
children.prevalue: The stranger reflected upon this argument with a very profound face having done so he seized Sikes by the hand and declared he was a real good fellow To which Mr Sikes replied he was joking as if he had been sober there would have been strong reason to suppose he was

children.name: Paragraph_36
children.value: After the exchange of a few more compliments, they bade the company good-night, and went out; the girl gathering up the pots and glasses as they did so, and lounging out to the door, with her hands full, to see the party start.
children.prevalue: After the exchange of a few more compliments they bade the company good night and went out the girl gathering up the pots and glasses as they did so and lounging out to the door with her hands full to see the party start

children.name: Paragraph_37
children.value: The horse, whose health had been drunk in his absence, was standing outside:  ready harnessed to the cart.  Oliver and Sikes got in without any further ceremony; and the man to whom he belonged, having lingered for a minute or two 'to bear him up,' and to defy the hostler and the world to produce his equal, mounted also.  Then, the hostler was told to give the horse his head; and, his head being given him, he made a very unpleasant use of it:  tossing it into the air with great disdain, and running into the parlour windows over the way; after performing those feats, and supporting himself for a short time on his hind-legs, he started off at great speed, and rattled out of the town right gallantly.
children.prevalue: The horse whose health had been drunk in his absence was standing outside ready harnessed to the cart Oliver and Sikes got in without any further ceremony and the man to whom he belonged having lingered for a minute or two to bear him up and to defy the hostler and the world to produce his equal mounted also Then the hostler was told to give the horse his head and his head being given him he made a very unpleasant use of it tossing it into the air with great disdain and running into the parlour windows over the way after performing those feats and supporting himself for a short time on his hind legs he started off at great speed and rattled out of the town right gallantly

children.name: Paragraph_38
children.value: The night was very dark.  A damp mist rose from the river, and the marshy ground about; and spread itself over the dreary fields.  It was piercing cold, too; all was gloomy and black. Not a word was spoken; for the driver had grown sleepy; and Sikes was in no mood to lead him into conversation.  Oliver sat huddled together, in a corner of the cart; bewildered with alarm and apprehension; and figuring strange objects in the gaunt trees, whose branches waved grimly to and fro, as if in some fantastic joy at the desolation of the scene.
children.prevalue: The night was very dark A damp mist rose from the river and the marshy ground about and spread itself over the dreary fields It was piercing cold too all was gloomy and black Not a word was spoken for the driver had grown sleepy and Sikes was in no mood to lead him into conversation Oliver sat huddled together in a corner of the cart bewildered with alarm and apprehension and figuring strange objects in the gaunt trees whose branches waved grimly to and fro as if in some fantastic joy at the desolation of the scene

children.name: Paragraph_39
children.value: As they passed Sunbury Church, the clock struck seven.  There was a light in the ferry-house window opposite:  which streamed across the road, and threw into more sombre shadow a dark yew-tree with graves beneath it.  There was a dull sound of falling water not far off; and the leaves of the old tree stirred gently in the night wind.  It seemed like quiet music for the repose of the dead.
children.prevalue: As they passed Sunbury Church the clock struck seven There was a light in the ferry house window opposite which streamed across the road and threw into more sombre shadow a dark yew tree with graves beneath it There was a dull sound of falling water not far off and the leaves of the old tree stirred gently in the night wind It seemed like quiet music for the repose of the dead

children.name: Paragraph_40
children.value: Sunbury was passed through, and they came again into the lonely road. Two or three miles more, and the cart stopped.  Sikes alighted, took Oliver by the hand, and they once again walked on.
children.prevalue: Sunbury was passed through and they came again into the lonely road Two or three miles more and the cart stopped Sikes alighted took Oliver by the hand and they once again walked on

children.name: Paragraph_41
children.value: They turned into no house at Shepperton, as the weary boy had expected; but still kept walking on, in mud and darkness, through gloomy lanes and over cold open wastes, until they came within sight of the lights of a town at no great distance.  On looking intently forward, Oliver saw that the water was just below them, and that they were coming to the foot of a bridge.
children.prevalue: They turned into no house at Shepperton as the weary boy had expected but still kept walking on in mud and darkness through gloomy lanes and over cold open wastes until they came within sight of the lights of a town at no great distance On looking intently forward Oliver saw that the water was just below them and that they were coming to the foot of a bridge

children.name: Paragraph_42
children.value: Sikes kept straight on, until they were close upon the bridge; then turned suddenly down a bank upon the left.
children.prevalue: Sikes kept straight on until they were close upon the bridge then turned suddenly down a bank upon the left

children.name: Paragraph_43
children.value: 'The water!' thought Oliver, turning sick with fear.  'He has brought me to this lonely place to murder me!'
children.prevalue: The water thought Oliver turning sick with fear He has brought me to this lonely place to murder me

children.name: Paragraph_44
children.value: He was about to throw himself on the ground, and make one struggle for his young life, when he saw that they stood before a solitary house: all ruinous and decayed.  There was a window on each side of the dilapidated entrance; and one story above; but no light was visible. The house was dark, dismantled: and the all appearance, uninhabited.
children.prevalue: He was about to throw himself on the ground and make one struggle for his young life when he saw that they stood before a solitary house all ruinous and decayed There was a window on each side of the dilapidated entrance and one story above but no light was visible The house was dark dismantled and the all appearance uninhabited

children.name: Paragraph_45
children.value: Sikes, with Oliver's hand still in his, softly approached the low porch, and raised the latch.  The door yielded to the pressure, and they passed in together.
children.prevalue: Sikes with Oliver s hand still in his softly approached the low porch and raised the latch The door yielded to the pressure and they passed in together

children.name: Paragraph_1
children.value: THE BURGLARY
children.prevalue: THE BURGLARY

children.name: Paragraph_2
children.value: 'Hallo!' cried a loud, hoarse voice, as soon as they set foot in the passage.
children.prevalue: Hallo cried a loud hoarse voice as soon as they set foot in the passage

children.name: Paragraph_3
children.value: 'Don't make such a row,' said Sikes, bolting the door.  'Show a glim, Toby.'
children.prevalue: Don t make such a row said Sikes bolting the door Show a glim Toby

children.name: Paragraph_4
children.value: 'Aha! my pal!' cried the same voice.  'A glim, Barney, a glim! Show the gentleman in, Barney; wake up first, if convenient.'
children.prevalue: Aha my pal cried the same voice A glim Barney a glim Show the gentleman in Barney wake up first if convenient

children.name: Paragraph_5
children.value: The speaker appeared to throw a boot-jack, or some such article, at the person he addressed, to rouse him from his slumbers:  for the noise of a wooden body, falling violently, was heard; and then an indistinct muttering, as of a man between sleep and awake.
children.prevalue: The speaker appeared to throw a boot jack or some such article at the person he addressed to rouse him from his slumbers for the noise of a wooden body falling violently was heard and then an indistinct muttering as of a man between sleep and awake

children.name: Paragraph_6
children.value: 'Do you hear?' cried the same voice.  'There's Bill Sikes in the passage with nobody to do the civil to him; and you sleeping there, as if you took laudanum with your meals, and nothing stronger.  Are you any fresher now, or do you want the iron candlestick to wake you thoroughly?'
children.prevalue: Do you hear cried the same voice There s Bill Sikes in the passage with nobody to do the civil to him and you sleeping there as if you took laudanum with your meals and nothing stronger Are you any fresher now or do you want the iron candlestick to wake you thoroughly

children.name: Paragraph_7
children.value: A pair of slipshod feet shuffled, hastily, across the bare floor of the room, as this interrogatory was put; and there issued, from a door on the right hand; first, a feeble candle:  and next, the form of the same individual who has been heretofore described as labouring under the infirmity of speaking through his nose, and officiating as waiter at the public-house on Saffron Hill.
children.prevalue: A pair of slipshod feet shuffled hastily across the bare floor of the room as this interrogatory was put and there issued from a door on the right hand first a feeble candle and next the form of the same individual who has been heretofore described as labouring under the infirmity of speaking through his nose and officiating as waiter at the public house on Saffron Hill

children.name: Paragraph_8
children.value: 'Bister Sikes!' exclaimed Barney, with real or counterfeit joy; 'cub id, sir; cub id.'
children.prevalue: Bister Sikes exclaimed Barney with real or counterfeit joy cub id sir cub id

children.name: Paragraph_9
children.value: 'Here! you get on first,' said Sikes, putting Oliver in front of him. 'Quicker! or I shall tread upon your heels.'
children.prevalue: Here you get on first said Sikes putting Oliver in front of him Quicker or I shall tread upon your heels

children.name: Paragraph_10
children.value: Muttering a curse upon his tardiness, Sikes pushed Oliver before him; and they entered a low dark room with a smoky fire, two or three broken chairs, a table, and a very old couch:  on which, with his legs much higher than his head, a man was reposing at full length, smoking a long clay pipe.  He was dressed in a smartly-cut snuff-coloured coat, with large brass buttons; an orange neckerchief; a coarse, staring, shawl-pattern waistcoat; and drab breeches.  Mr. Crackit (for he it was) had no very great quantity of hair, either upon his head or face; but what he had, was of a reddish dye, and tortured into long corkscrew curls, through which he occasionally thrust some very dirty fingers, ornamented with large common rings.  He was a trifle above the middle size, and apparently rather weak in the legs; but this circumstance by no means detracted from his own admiration of his top-boots, which he contemplated, in their elevated situation, with lively satisfaction.
children.prevalue: Muttering a curse upon his tardiness Sikes pushed Oliver before him and they entered a low dark room with a smoky fire two or three broken chairs a table and a very old couch on which with his legs much higher than his head a man was reposing at full length smoking a long clay pipe He was dressed in a smartly cut snuff coloured coat with large brass buttons an orange neckerchief a coarse staring shawl pattern waistcoat and drab breeches Mr Crackit for he it was had no very great quantity of hair either upon his head or face but what he had was of a reddish dye and tortured into long corkscrew curls through which he occasionally thrust some very dirty fingers ornamented with large common rings He was a trifle above the middle size and apparently rather weak in the legs but this circumstance by no means detracted from his own admiration of his top boots which he contemplated in their elevated situation with lively satisfaction

children.name: Paragraph_11
children.value: 'Bill, my boy!' said this figure, turning his head towards the door, 'I'm glad to see you.  I was almost afraid you'd given it up:  in which case I should have made a personal wentur.  Hallo!'
children.prevalue: Bill my boy said this figure turning his head towards the door I m glad to see you I was almost afraid you d given it up in which case I should have made a personal wentur Hallo

children.name: Paragraph_12
children.value: Uttering this exclamation in a tone of great surprise, as his eyes rested on Oliver, Mr. Toby Crackit brought himself into a sitting posture, and demanded who that was.
children.prevalue: Uttering this exclamation in a tone of great surprise as his eyes rested on Oliver Mr Toby Crackit brought himself into a sitting posture and demanded who that was

children.name: Paragraph_13
children.value: 'The boy.  Only the boy!' replied Sikes, drawing a chair towards the fire.
children.prevalue: The boy Only the boy replied Sikes drawing a chair towards the fire

children.name: Paragraph_14
children.value: 'Wud of Bister Fagid's lads,' exclaimed Barney, with a grin.
children.prevalue: Wud of Bister Fagid s lads exclaimed Barney with a grin

children.name: Paragraph_15
children.value: 'Fagin's, eh!' exclaimed Toby, looking at Oliver.  'Wot an inwalable boy that'll make, for the old ladies' pockets in chapels!  His mug is a fortin' to him.'
children.prevalue: Fagin s eh exclaimed Toby looking at Oliver Wot an inwalable boy that ll make for the old ladies pockets in chapels His mug is a fortin to him

children.name: Paragraph_16
children.value: 'There--there's enough of that,' interposed Sikes, impatiently; and stooping over his recumbant friend, he whispered a few words in his ear:  at which Mr. Crackit laughed immensely, and honoured Oliver with a long stare of astonishment.
children.prevalue: There there s enough of that interposed Sikes impatiently and stooping over his recumbant friend he whispered a few words in his ear at which Mr Crackit laughed immensely and honoured Oliver with a long stare of astonishment

children.name: Paragraph_17
children.value: 'Now,' said Sikes, as he resumed his seat, 'if you'll give us something to eat and drink while we're waiting, you'll put some heart in us; or in me, at all events.  Sit down by the fire, younker, and rest yourself; for you'll have to go out with us again to-night, though not very far off.'
children.prevalue: Now said Sikes as he resumed his seat if you ll give us something to eat and drink while we re waiting you ll put some heart in us or in me at all events Sit down by the fire younker and rest yourself for you ll have to go out with us again to night though not very far off

children.name: Paragraph_18
children.value: Oliver looked at Sikes, in mute and timid wonder; and drawing a stool to the fire, sat with his aching head upon his hands, scarecely knowing where he was, or what was passing around him.
children.prevalue: Oliver looked at Sikes in mute and timid wonder and drawing a stool to the fire sat with his aching head upon his hands scarecely knowing where he was or what was passing around him

children.name: Paragraph_19
children.value: 'Here,' said Toby, as the young Jew placed some fragments of food, and a bottle upon the table,  'Success to the crack!'  He rose to honour the toast; and, carefully depositing his empty pipe in a corner, advanced to the table, filled a glass with spirits, and drank off its contents.  Mr. Sikes did the same.
children.prevalue: Here said Toby as the young Jew placed some fragments of food and a bottle upon the table Success to the crack He rose to honour the toast and carefully depositing his empty pipe in a corner advanced to the table filled a glass with spirits and drank off its contents Mr Sikes did the same

children.name: Paragraph_20
children.value: 'A drain for the boy,' said Toby, half-filling a wine-glass. 'Down with it, innocence.'
children.prevalue: A drain for the boy said Toby half filling a wine glass Down with it innocence

children.name: Paragraph_21
children.value: 'Indeed,' said Oliver, looking piteously up into the man's face; 'indeed, I--'
children.prevalue: Indeed said Oliver looking piteously up into the man s face indeed I

children.name: Paragraph_22
children.value: 'Down with it!' echoed Toby.  'Do you think I don't know what's good for you?  Tell him to drink it, Bill.'
children.prevalue: Down with it echoed Toby Do you think I don t know what s good for you Tell him to drink it Bill

children.name: Paragraph_23
children.value: 'He had better!' said Sikes clapping his hand upon his pocket. 'Burn my body, if he isn't more trouble than a whole family of Dodgers.  Drink it, you perwerse imp; drink it!'
children.prevalue: He had better said Sikes clapping his hand upon his pocket Burn my body if he isn t more trouble than a whole family of Dodgers Drink it you perwerse imp drink it

children.name: Paragraph_24
children.value: Frightened by the menacing gestures of the two men, Oliver hastily swallowed the contents of the glass, and immediately fell into a violent fit of coughing:  which delighted Toby Crackit and Barney, and even drew a smile from the surly Mr. Sikes.
children.prevalue: Frightened by the menacing gestures of the two men Oliver hastily swallowed the contents of the glass and immediately fell into a violent fit of coughing which delighted Toby Crackit and Barney and even drew a smile from the surly Mr Sikes

children.name: Paragraph_25
children.value: This done, and Sikes having satisfied his appetite (Oliver could eat nothing but a small crust of bread which they made him swallow), the two men laid themselves down on chairs for a short nap.  Oliver retained his stool by the fire; Barney wrapped in a blanket, stretched himself on the floor:  close outside the fender.
children.prevalue: This done and Sikes having satisfied his appetite Oliver could eat nothing but a small crust of bread which they made him swallow the two men laid themselves down on chairs for a short nap Oliver retained his stool by the fire Barney wrapped in a blanket stretched himself on the floor close outside the fender

children.name: Paragraph_26
children.value: They slept, or appeared to sleep, for some time; nobody stirring but Barney, who rose once or twice to throw coals on the fire. Oliver fell into a heavy doze:  imagining himself straying along the gloomy lanes, or wandering about the dark churchyard, or retracing some one or other of the scenes of the past day:  when he was roused by Toby Crackit jumping up and declaring it was half-past one.
children.prevalue: They slept or appeared to sleep for some time nobody stirring but Barney who rose once or twice to throw coals on the fire Oliver fell into a heavy doze imagining himself straying along the gloomy lanes or wandering about the dark churchyard or retracing some one or other of the scenes of the past day when he was roused by Toby Crackit jumping up and declaring it was half past one

children.name: Paragraph_27
children.value: In an instant, the other two were on their legs, and all were actively engaged in busy preparation.  Sikes and his companion enveloped their necks and chins in large dark shawls, and drew on their great-coats; Barney, opening a cupboard, brought forth several articles, which he hastily crammed into the pockets.
children.prevalue: In an instant the other two were on their legs and all were actively engaged in busy preparation Sikes and his companion enveloped their necks and chins in large dark shawls and drew on their great coats Barney opening a cupboard brought forth several articles which he hastily crammed into the pockets

children.name: Paragraph_28
children.value: 'Barkers for me, Barney,' said Toby Crackit.
children.prevalue: Barkers for me Barney said Toby Crackit

children.name: Paragraph_29
children.value: 'Here they are,' replied Barney, producing a pair of pistols. 'You loaded them yourself.'
children.prevalue: Here they are replied Barney producing a pair of pistols You loaded them yourself

children.name: Paragraph_30
children.value: 'All right!' replied Toby, stowing them away.  'The persuaders?'
children.prevalue: All right replied Toby stowing them away The persuaders

children.name: Paragraph_31
children.value: 'I've got 'em,' replied Sikes.
children.prevalue: I ve got em replied Sikes

children.name: Paragraph_32
children.value: 'Crape, keys, centre-bits, darkies--nothing forgotten?' inquired Toby: fastening a small crowbar to a loop inside the skirt of his coat.
children.prevalue: Crape keys centre bits darkies nothing forgotten inquired Toby fastening a small crowbar to a loop inside the skirt of his coat

children.name: Paragraph_33
children.value: 'All right,' rejoined his companion.  'Bring them bits of timber, Barney.  That's the time of day.'
children.prevalue: All right rejoined his companion Bring them bits of timber Barney That s the time of day

children.name: Paragraph_34
children.value: With these words, he took a thick stick from Barney's hands, who, having delivered another to Toby, busied himself in fastening on Oliver's cape.
children.prevalue: With these words he took a thick stick from Barney s hands who having delivered another to Toby busied himself in fastening on Oliver s cape

children.name: Paragraph_35
children.value: 'Now then!' said Sikes, holding out his hand.
children.prevalue: Now then said Sikes holding out his hand

children.name: Paragraph_36
children.value: Oliver:  who was completely stupified by the unwonted exercise, and the air, and the drink which had been forced upon him:  put his hand mechanically into that which Sikes extended for the purpose.
children.prevalue: Oliver who was completely stupified by the unwonted exercise and the air and the drink which had been forced upon him put his hand mechanically into that which Sikes extended for the purpose

children.name: Paragraph_37
children.value: 'Take his other hand, Toby,' said Sikes.  'Look out, Barney.'
children.prevalue: Take his other hand Toby said Sikes Look out Barney

children.name: Paragraph_38
children.value: The man went to the door, and returned to announce that all was quiet. The two robbers issued forth with Oliver between them. Barney, having made all fast, rolled himself up as before, and was soon asleep again.
children.prevalue: The man went to the door and returned to announce that all was quiet The two robbers issued forth with Oliver between them Barney having made all fast rolled himself up as before and was soon asleep again

children.name: Paragraph_39
children.value: It was now intensely dark.  The fog was much heavier than it had been in the early part of the night; and the atmosphere was so damp, that, although no rain fell, Oliver's hair and eyebrows, within a few minutes after leaving the house, had become stiff with the half-frozen moisture that was floating about.  They crossed the bridge, and kept on towards the lights which he had seen before.  They were at no great distance off; and, as they walked pretty briskly, they soon arrived at Chertsey.
children.prevalue: It was now intensely dark The fog was much heavier than it had been in the early part of the night and the atmosphere was so damp that although no rain fell Oliver s hair and eyebrows within a few minutes after leaving the house had become stiff with the half frozen moisture that was floating about They crossed the bridge and kept on towards the lights which he had seen before They were at no great distance off and as they walked pretty briskly they soon arrived at Chertsey

children.name: Paragraph_40
children.value: 'Slap through the town,' whispered Sikes; 'there'll be nobody in the way, to-night, to see us.'
children.prevalue: Slap through the town whispered Sikes there ll be nobody in the way to night to see us

children.name: Paragraph_41
children.value: Toby acquiesced; and they hurried through the main street of the little town, which at that late hour was wholly deserted.  A dim light shone at intervals from some bed-room window; and the hoarse barking of dogs occasionally broke the silence of the night.  But there was nobody abroad.  They had cleared the town, as the church-bell struck two.
children.prevalue: Toby acquiesced and they hurried through the main street of the little town which at that late hour was wholly deserted A dim light shone at intervals from some bed room window and the hoarse barking of dogs occasionally broke the silence of the night But there was nobody abroad They had cleared the town as the church bell struck two

children.name: Paragraph_42
children.value: Quickening their pace, they turned up a road upon the left hand. After walking about a quarter of a mile, they stopped before a detached house surrounded by a wall:  to the top of which, Toby Crackit, scarcely pausing to take breath, climbed in a twinkling.
children.prevalue: Quickening their pace they turned up a road upon the left hand After walking about a quarter of a mile they stopped before a detached house surrounded by a wall to the top of which Toby Crackit scarcely pausing to take breath climbed in a twinkling

children.name: Paragraph_43
children.value: 'The boy next,' said Toby.  'Hoist him up; I'll catch hold of him.'
children.prevalue: The boy next said Toby Hoist him up I ll catch hold of him

children.name: Paragraph_44
children.value: Before Oliver had time to look round, Sikes had caught him under the arms; and in three or four seconds he and Toby were lying on the grass on the other side.  Sikes followed directly.  And they stole cautiously towards the house.
children.prevalue: Before Oliver had time to look round Sikes had caught him under the arms and in three or four seconds he and Toby were lying on the grass on the other side Sikes followed directly And they stole cautiously towards the house

children.name: Paragraph_45
children.value: And now, for the first time, Oliver, well-nigh mad with grief and terror, saw that housebreaking and robbery, if not murder, were the objects of the expedition.  He clasped his hands together, and involuntarily uttered a subdued exclamation of horror.  A mist came before his eyes; the cold sweat stood upon his ashy face; his limbs failed him; and he sank upon his knees.
children.prevalue: And now for the first time Oliver well nigh mad with grief and terror saw that housebreaking and robbery if not murder were the objects of the expedition He clasped his hands together and involuntarily uttered a subdued exclamation of horror A mist came before his eyes the cold sweat stood upon his ashy face his limbs failed him and he sank upon his knees

children.name: Paragraph_46
children.value: 'Get up!' murmured Sikes, trembling with rage, and drawing the pistol from his pocket; 'Get up, or I'll strew your brains upon the grass.'
children.prevalue: Get up murmured Sikes trembling with rage and drawing the pistol from his pocket Get up or I ll strew your brains upon the grass

children.name: Paragraph_47
children.value: 'Oh! for God's sake let me go!' cried Oliver; 'let me run away and die in the fields.  I will never come near London; never, never!  Oh! pray have mercy on me, and do not make me steal.  For the love of all the bright Angels that rest in Heaven, have mercy upon me!'
children.prevalue: Oh for God s sake let me go cried Oliver let me run away and die in the fields I will never come near London never never Oh pray have mercy on me and do not make me steal For the love of all the bright Angels that rest in Heaven have mercy upon me

children.name: Paragraph_48
children.value: The man to whom this appeal was made, swore a dreadful oath, and had cocked the pistol, when Toby, striking it from his grasp, placed his hand upon the boy's mouth, and dragged him to the house.
children.prevalue: The man to whom this appeal was made swore a dreadful oath and had cocked the pistol when Toby striking it from his grasp placed his hand upon the boy s mouth and dragged him to the house

children.name: Paragraph_49
children.value: 'Hush!' cried the man; 'it won't answer here.  Say another word, and I'll do your business myself with a crack on the head.  That makes no noise, and is quite as certain, and more genteel.  Here, Bill, wrench the shutter open.  He's game enough now, I'll engage.  I've seen older hands of his age took the same way, for a minute or two, on a cold night.'
children.prevalue: Hush cried the man it won t answer here Say another word and I ll do your business myself with a crack on the head That makes no noise and is quite as certain and more genteel Here Bill wrench the shutter open He s game enough now I ll engage I ve seen older hands of his age took the same way for a minute or two on a cold night

children.name: Paragraph_50
children.value: Sikes, invoking terrific imprecations upon Fagin's head for sending Oliver on such an errand, plied the crowbar vigorously, but with little noise.  After some delay, and some assistance from Toby, the shutter to which he had referred, swung open on its hinges.
children.prevalue: Sikes invoking terrific imprecations upon Fagin s head for sending Oliver on such an errand plied the crowbar vigorously but with little noise After some delay and some assistance from Toby the shutter to which he had referred swung open on its hinges

children.name: Paragraph_51
children.value: It was a little lattice window, about five feet and a half above the ground, at the back of the house:  which belonged to a scullery, or small brewing-place, at the end of the passage.  The aperture was so small, that the inmates had probably not thought it worth while to defend it more securely; but it was large enough to admit a boy of Oliver's size, nevertheless.  A very brief exercise of Mr. Sike's art, sufficed to overcome the fastening of the lattice; and it soon stood wide open also.
children.prevalue: It was a little lattice window about five feet and a half above the ground at the back of the house which belonged to a scullery or small brewing place at the end of the passage The aperture was so small that the inmates had probably not thought it worth while to defend it more securely but it was large enough to admit a boy of Oliver s size nevertheless A very brief exercise of Mr Sike s art sufficed to overcome the fastening of the lattice and it soon stood wide open also

children.name: Paragraph_52
children.value: 'Now listen, you young limb,' whispered Sikes, drawing a dark lantern from his pocket, and throwing the glare full on Oliver's face; 'I'm a going to put you through there.  Take this light; go softly up the steps straight afore you, and along the little hall, to the street door; unfasten it, and let us in.'
children.prevalue: Now listen you young limb whispered Sikes drawing a dark lantern from his pocket and throwing the glare full on Oliver s face I m a going to put you through there Take this light go softly up the steps straight afore you and along the little hall to the street door unfasten it and let us in

children.name: Paragraph_53
children.value: 'There's a bolt at the top, you won't be able to reach,' interposed Toby. 'Stand upon one of the hall chairs.  There are three there, Bill, with a jolly large blue unicorn and gold pitchfork on 'em:  which is the old lady's arms.'
children.prevalue: There s a bolt at the top you won t be able to reach interposed Toby Stand upon one of the hall chairs There are three there Bill with a jolly large blue unicorn and gold pitchfork on em which is the old lady s arms

children.name: Paragraph_54
children.value: 'Keep quiet, can't you?' replied Sikes, with a threatening look. 'The room-door is open, is it?'
children.prevalue: Keep quiet can t you replied Sikes with a threatening look The room door is open is it

children.name: Paragraph_55
children.value: 'Wide,' replied Toby, after peeping in to satisfy himself. 'The game of that is, that they always leave it open with a catch, so that the dog, who's got a bed in here, may walk up and down the passage when he feels wakeful.  Ha! ha! Barney 'ticed him away to-night.  So neat!'
children.prevalue: Wide replied Toby after peeping in to satisfy himself The game of that is that they always leave it open with a catch so that the dog who s got a bed in here may walk up and down the passage when he feels wakeful Ha ha Barney ticed him away to night So neat

children.name: Paragraph_56
children.value: Although Mr. Crackit spoke in a scarcely audible whisper, and laughed without noise, Sikes imperiously commanded him to be silent, and to get to work.  Toby complied, by first producing his lantern, and placing it on the ground; then by planting himself firmly with his head against the wall beneath the window, and his hands upon his knees, so as to make a step of his back. This was no sooner done, than Sikes, mounting upon him, put Oliver gently through the window with his feet first; and, without leaving hold of his collar, planted him safely on the floor inside.
children.prevalue: Although Mr Crackit spoke in a scarcely audible whisper and laughed without noise Sikes imperiously commanded him to be silent and to get to work Toby complied by first producing his lantern and placing it on the ground then by planting himself firmly with his head against the wall beneath the window and his hands upon his knees so as to make a step of his back This was no sooner done than Sikes mounting upon him put Oliver gently through the window with his feet first and without leaving hold of his collar planted him safely on the floor inside

children.name: Paragraph_57
children.value: 'Take this lantern,' said Sikes, looking into the room.  'You see the stairs afore you?'
children.prevalue: Take this lantern said Sikes looking into the room You see the stairs afore you

children.name: Paragraph_58
children.value: Oliver, more dead than alive, gasped out, 'Yes.'  Sikes, pointing to the street-door with the pistol-barrel, briefly advised him to take notice that he was within shot all the way; and that if he faltered, he would fall dead that instant.
children.prevalue: Oliver more dead than alive gasped out Yes Sikes pointing to the street door with the pistol barrel briefly advised him to take notice that he was within shot all the way and that if he faltered he would fall dead that instant

children.name: Paragraph_59
children.value: 'It's done in a minute,' said Sikes, in the same low whisper. 'Directly I leave go of you, do your work.  Hark!'
children.prevalue: It s done in a minute said Sikes in the same low whisper Directly I leave go of you do your work Hark

children.name: Paragraph_60
children.value: 'What's that?' whispered the other man.
children.prevalue: What s that whispered the other man

children.name: Paragraph_61
children.value: They listened intently.
children.prevalue: They listened intently

children.name: Paragraph_62
children.value: 'Nothing,' said Sikes, releasing his hold of Oliver.  'Now!'
children.prevalue: Nothing said Sikes releasing his hold of Oliver Now

children.name: Paragraph_63
children.value: In the short time he had had to collect his senses, the boy had firmly resolved that, whether he died in the attempt or not, he would make one effort to dart upstairs from the hall, and alarm the family.  Filled with this idea, he advanced at once, but stealthily.
children.prevalue: In the short time he had had to collect his senses the boy had firmly resolved that whether he died in the attempt or not he would make one effort to dart upstairs from the hall and alarm the family Filled with this idea he advanced at once but stealthily

children.name: Paragraph_64
children.value: 'Come back!' suddenly cried Sikes aloud.  'Back! back!'
children.prevalue: Come back suddenly cried Sikes aloud Back back

children.name: Paragraph_65
children.value: Scared by the sudden breaking of the dead stillness of the place, and by a loud cry which followed it, Oliver let his lantern fall, and knew not whether to advance or fly.
children.prevalue: Scared by the sudden breaking of the dead stillness of the place and by a loud cry which followed it Oliver let his lantern fall and knew not whether to advance or fly

children.name: Paragraph_66
children.value: The cry was repeated--a light appeared--a vision of two terrified half-dressed men at the top of the stairs swam before his eyes--a flash--a loud noise--a smoke--a crash somewhere, but where he knew not,--and he staggered back.
children.prevalue: The cry was repeated a light appeared a vision of two terrified half dressed men at the top of the stairs swam before his eyes a flash a loud noise a smoke a crash somewhere but where he knew not and he staggered back

children.name: Paragraph_67
children.value: Sikes had disappeared for an instant; but he was up again, and had him by the collar before the smoke had cleared away.  He fired his own pistol after the men, who were already retreating; and dragged the boy up.
