children.prevalue: Sikes had disappeared for an instant but he was up again and had him by the collar before the smoke had cleared away He fired his own pistol after the men who were already retreating and dragged the boy up

children.name: Paragraph_68
children.value: 'Clasp your arm tighter,' said Sikes, as he drew him through the window.  'Give me a shawl here.  They've hit him.  Quick!  How the boy bleeds!'
children.prevalue: Clasp your arm tighter said Sikes as he drew him through the window Give me a shawl here They ve hit him Quick How the boy bleeds

children.name: Paragraph_69
children.value: Then came the loud ringing of a bell, mingled with the noise of fire-arms, and the shouts of men, and the sensation of being carried over uneven ground at a rapid pace.  And then, the noises grew confused in the distance; and a cold deadly feeling crept over the boy's heart; and he saw or heard no more.

children.name: Paragraph_1
children.value: WHICH CONTAINS THE SUBSTANCE OF A PLEASANT CONVERSATION BETWEEN MR. BUMBLE AND A LADY; AND SHOWS THAT EVEN A BEADLE MAY BE SUSCEPTIBLE ON SOME POINTS
children.prevalue: WHICH CONTAINS THE SUBSTANCE OF A PLEASANT CONVERSATION BETWEEN MR BUMBLE AND A LADY AND SHOWS THAT EVEN A BEADLE MAY BE SUSCEPTIBLE ON SOME POINTS

children.name: Paragraph_2
children.value: The night was bitter cold.  The snow lay on the ground, frozen into a hard thick crust, so that only the heaps that had drifted into byways and corners were affected by the sharp wind that howled abroad:  which, as if expending increased fury on such prey as it found, caught it savagely up in clouds, and, whirling it into a thousand misty eddies, scattered it in air.  Bleak, dark, and piercing cold, it was a night for the well-housed and fed to draw round the bright fire and thank God they were at home; and for the homeless, starving wretch to lay him down and die.  Many hunger-worn outcasts close their eyes in our bare streets, at such times, who, let their crimes have been what they may, can hardly open them in a more bitter world.
children.prevalue: The night was bitter cold The snow lay on the ground frozen into a hard thick crust so that only the heaps that had drifted into byways and corners were affected by the sharp wind that howled abroad which as if expending increased fury on such prey as it found caught it savagely up in clouds and whirling it into a thousand misty eddies scattered it in air Bleak dark and piercing cold it was a night for the well housed and fed to draw round the bright fire and thank God they were at home and for the homeless starving wretch to lay him down and die Many hunger worn outcasts close their eyes in our bare streets at such times who let their crimes have been what they may can hardly open them in a more bitter world

children.name: Paragraph_3
children.value: Such was the aspect of out-of-doors affairs, when Mrs. Corney, the matron of the workhouse to which our readers have been already introduced as the birthplace of Oliver Twist, sat herself down before a cheerful fire in her own little room, and glanced, with no small degree of complacency, at a small round table:  on which stood a tray of corresponding size, furnished with all necessary materials for the most grateful meal that matrons enjoy.  In fact, Mrs. Corney was about to solace herself with a cup of tea. As she glanced from the table to the fireplace, where the smallest of all possible kettles was singing a small song in a small voice, her inward satisfaction evidently increased,--so much so, indeed, that Mrs. Corney smiled.
children.prevalue: Such was the aspect of out of doors affairs when Mrs Corney the matron of the workhouse to which our readers have been already introduced as the birthplace of Oliver Twist sat herself down before a cheerful fire in her own little room and glanced with no small degree of complacency at a small round table on which stood a tray of corresponding size furnished with all necessary materials for the most grateful meal that matrons enjoy In fact Mrs Corney was about to solace herself with a cup of tea As she glanced from the table to the fireplace where the smallest of all possible kettles was singing a small song in a small voice her inward satisfaction evidently increased so much so indeed that Mrs Corney smiled

children.name: Paragraph_4
children.value: 'Well!' said the matron, leaning her elbow on the table, and looking reflectively at the fire; 'I'm sure we have all on us a great deal to be grateful for!  A great deal, if we did but know it.  Ah!'
children.prevalue: Well said the matron leaning her elbow on the table and looking reflectively at the fire I m sure we have all on us a great deal to be grateful for A great deal if we did but know it Ah

children.name: Paragraph_5
children.value: Mrs. Corney shook her head mournfully, as if deploring the mental blindness of those paupers who did not know it; and thrusting a silver spoon (private property) into the inmost recesses of a two-ounce tin tea-caddy, proceeded to make the tea.
children.prevalue: Mrs Corney shook her head mournfully as if deploring the mental blindness of those paupers who did not know it and thrusting a silver spoon private property into the inmost recesses of a two ounce tin tea caddy proceeded to make the tea

children.name: Paragraph_6
children.value: How slight a thing will disturb the equanimity of our frail minds!  The black teapot, being very small and easily filled, ran over while Mrs. Corney was moralising; and the water slightly scalded Mrs. Corney's hand.
children.prevalue: How slight a thing will disturb the equanimity of our frail minds The black teapot being very small and easily filled ran over while Mrs Corney was moralising and the water slightly scalded Mrs Corney s hand

children.name: Paragraph_7
children.value: 'Drat the pot!' said the worthy matron, setting it down very hastily on the hob; 'a little stupid thing, that only holds a couple of cups! What use is it of, to anybody!  Except,' said Mrs. Corney, pausing, 'except to a poor desolate creature like me.  Oh dear!'
children.prevalue: Drat the pot said the worthy matron setting it down very hastily on the hob a little stupid thing that only holds a couple of cups What use is it of to anybody Except said Mrs Corney pausing except to a poor desolate creature like me Oh dear

children.name: Paragraph_8
children.value: With these words, the matron dropped into her chair, and, once more resting her elbow on the table, thought of her solitary fate.  The small teapot, and the single cup, had awakened in her mind sad recollections of Mr. Corney (who had not been dead more than five-and-twenty years); and she was overpowered.
children.prevalue: With these words the matron dropped into her chair and once more resting her elbow on the table thought of her solitary fate The small teapot and the single cup had awakened in her mind sad recollections of Mr Corney who had not been dead more than five and twenty years and she was overpowered

children.name: Paragraph_9
children.value: 'I shall never get another!' said Mrs. Corney, pettishly; 'I shall never get another--like him.'
children.prevalue: I shall never get another said Mrs Corney pettishly I shall never get another like him

children.name: Paragraph_10
children.value: Whether this remark bore reference to the husband, or the teapot, is uncertain.  It might have been the latter; for Mrs. Corney looked at it as she spoke; and took it up afterwards.  She had just tasted her first cup, when she was disturbed by a soft tap at the room-door.
children.prevalue: Whether this remark bore reference to the husband or the teapot is uncertain It might have been the latter for Mrs Corney looked at it as she spoke and took it up afterwards She had just tasted her first cup when she was disturbed by a soft tap at the room door

children.name: Paragraph_11
children.value: 'Oh, come in with you!' said Mrs. Corney, sharply.  'Some of the old women dying, I suppose.  They always die when I'm at meals. Don't stand there, letting the cold air in, don't.  What's amiss now, eh?'
children.prevalue: Oh come in with you said Mrs Corney sharply Some of the old women dying I suppose They always die when I m at meals Don t stand there letting the cold air in don t What s amiss now eh

children.name: Paragraph_12
children.value: 'Nothing, ma'am, nothing,' replied a man's voice.
children.prevalue: Nothing ma am nothing replied a man s voice

children.name: Paragraph_13
children.value: 'Dear me!' exclaimed the matron, in a much sweeter tone, 'is that Mr. Bumble?'
children.prevalue: Dear me exclaimed the matron in a much sweeter tone is that Mr Bumble

children.name: Paragraph_14
children.value: 'At your service, ma'am,' said Mr. Bumble, who had been stopping outside to rub his shoes clean, and to shake the snow off his coat; and who now made his appearance, bearing the cocked hat in one hand and a bundle in the other.  'Shall I shut the door, ma'am?'
children.prevalue: At your service ma am said Mr Bumble who had been stopping outside to rub his shoes clean and to shake the snow off his coat and who now made his appearance bearing the cocked hat in one hand and a bundle in the other Shall I shut the door ma am

children.name: Paragraph_15
children.value: The lady modestly hesitated to reply, lest there should be any impropriety in holding an interview with Mr. Bumble, with closed doors. Mr. Bumble taking advantage of the hesitation, and being very cold himself, shut it without permission.
children.prevalue: The lady modestly hesitated to reply lest there should be any impropriety in holding an interview with Mr Bumble with closed doors Mr Bumble taking advantage of the hesitation and being very cold himself shut it without permission

children.name: Paragraph_16
children.value: 'Hard weather, Mr. Bumble,' said the matron.
children.prevalue: Hard weather Mr Bumble said the matron

children.name: Paragraph_17
children.value: 'Hard, indeed, ma'am,' replied the beadle.  'Anti-porochial weather this, ma'am.  We have given away, Mrs. Corney, we have given away a matter of twenty quartern loaves and a cheese and a half, this very blessed afternoon; and yet them paupers are not contented.'
children.prevalue: Hard indeed ma am replied the beadle Anti porochial weather this ma am We have given away Mrs Corney we have given away a matter of twenty quartern loaves and a cheese and a half this very blessed afternoon and yet them paupers are not contented

children.name: Paragraph_18
children.value: 'Of course not.  When would they be, Mr. Bumble?' said the matron, sipping her tea.
children.prevalue: Of course not When would they be Mr Bumble said the matron sipping her tea

children.name: Paragraph_19
children.value: 'When, indeed, ma'am!' rejoined Mr. Bumble.  'Why here's one man that, in consideration of his wife and large family, has a quartern loaf and a good pound of cheese, full weight.  Is he grateful, ma'am?  Is he grateful?  Not a copper farthing's worth of it!  What does he do, ma'am, but ask for a few coals; if it's only a pocket handkerchief full, he says!  Coals! What would he do with coals?  Toast his cheese with 'em and then come back for more.  That's the way with these people, ma'am; give 'em a apron full of coals to-day, and they'll come back for another, the day after to-morrow, as brazen as alabaster.'
children.prevalue: When indeed ma am rejoined Mr Bumble Why here s one man that in consideration of his wife and large family has a quartern loaf and a good pound of cheese full weight Is he grateful ma am Is he grateful Not a copper farthing s worth of it What does he do ma am but ask for a few coals if it s only a pocket handkerchief full he says Coals What would he do with coals Toast his cheese with em and then come back for more That s the way with these people ma am give em a apron full of coals to day and they ll come back for another the day after to morrow as brazen as alabaster

children.name: Paragraph_20
children.value: The matron expressed her entire concurrence in this intelligible simile; and the beadle went on.
children.prevalue: The matron expressed her entire concurrence in this intelligible simile and the beadle went on

children.name: Paragraph_21
children.value: 'I never,' said Mr. Bumble, 'see anything like the pitch it's got to. The day afore yesterday, a man--you have been a married woman, ma'am, and I may mention it to you--a man, with hardly a rag upon his back (here Mrs. Corney looked at the floor), goes to our overseer's door when he has got company coming to dinner; and says, he must be relieved, Mrs. Corney.  As he wouldn't go away, and shocked the company very much, our overseer sent him out a pound of potatoes and half a pint of oatmeal.  My heart! says the ungrateful villain, what's the use of this to me?  You might as well give me a pair of iron spectacles!  Very good, says our overseer, taking 'em away again, you won't get anything else here.  Then I'll die in the streets! says the vagrant.  Oh no, you won't, says our overseer.'
children.prevalue: I never said Mr Bumble see anything like the pitch it s got to The day afore yesterday a man you have been a married woman ma am and I may mention it to you a man with hardly a rag upon his back here Mrs Corney looked at the floor goes to our overseer s door when he has got company coming to dinner and says he must be relieved Mrs Corney As he wouldn t go away and shocked the company very much our overseer sent him out a pound of potatoes and half a pint of oatmeal My heart says the ungrateful villain what s the use of this to me You might as well give me a pair of iron spectacles Very good says our overseer taking em away again you won t get anything else here Then I ll die in the streets says the vagrant Oh no you won t says our overseer

children.name: Paragraph_22
children.value: 'Ha! ha!  That was very good!  So like Mr. Grannett, wasn't it?' interposed the matron.  'Well, Mr. Bumble?'
children.prevalue: Ha ha That was very good So like Mr Grannett wasn t it interposed the matron Well Mr Bumble

children.name: Paragraph_23
children.value: 'Well, ma'am,' rejoined the beadle, 'he went away; and he did die in the streets.  There's a obstinate pauper for you!'
children.prevalue: Well ma am rejoined the beadle he went away and he did die in the streets There s a obstinate pauper for you

children.name: Paragraph_24
children.value: 'It beats anything I could have believed,' observed the matron emphatically.  'But don't you think out-of-door relief a very bad thing, any way, Mr. Bumble?  You're a gentleman of experience, and ought to know.  Come.'
children.prevalue: It beats anything I could have believed observed the matron emphatically But don t you think out of door relief a very bad thing any way Mr Bumble You re a gentleman of experience and ought to know Come

children.name: Paragraph_25
children.value: 'Mrs. Corney,' said the beadle, smiling as men smile who are conscious of superior information, 'out-of-door relief, properly managed: properly managed, ma'am: is the porochial safeguard.  The great principle of out-of-door relief is, to give the paupers exactly what they don't want; and then they get tired of coming.'
children.prevalue: Mrs Corney said the beadle smiling as men smile who are conscious of superior information out of door relief properly managed properly managed ma am is the porochial safeguard The great principle of out of door relief is to give the paupers exactly what they don t want and then they get tired of coming

children.name: Paragraph_26
children.value: 'Dear me!' exclaimed Mrs. Corney.  'Well, that is a good one, too!'
children.prevalue: Dear me exclaimed Mrs Corney Well that is a good one too

children.name: Paragraph_27
children.value: 'Yes.  Betwixt you and me, ma'am,' returned Mr. Bumble, 'that's the great principle; and that's the reason why, if you look at any cases that get into them owdacious newspapers, you'll always observe that sick families have been relieved with slices of cheese.  That's the rule now, Mrs. Corney, all over the country. But, however,' said the beadle, stopping to unpack his bundle, 'these are official secrets, ma'am; not to be spoken of; except, as I may say, among the porochial officers, such as ourselves. This is the port wine, ma'am, that the board ordered for the infirmary; real, fresh, genuine port wine; only out of the cask this forenoon; clear as a bell, and no sediment!'
children.prevalue: Yes Betwixt you and me ma am returned Mr Bumble that s the great principle and that s the reason why if you look at any cases that get into them owdacious newspapers you ll always observe that sick families have been relieved with slices of cheese That s the rule now Mrs Corney all over the country But however said the beadle stopping to unpack his bundle these are official secrets ma am not to be spoken of except as I may say among the porochial officers such as ourselves This is the port wine ma am that the board ordered for the infirmary real fresh genuine port wine only out of the cask this forenoon clear as a bell and no sediment

children.name: Paragraph_28
children.value: Having held the first bottle up to the light, and shaken it well to test its excellence, Mr. Bumble placed them both on top of a chest of drawers; folded the handkerchief in which they had been wrapped; put it carefully in his pocket; and took up his hat, as if to go.
children.prevalue: Having held the first bottle up to the light and shaken it well to test its excellence Mr Bumble placed them both on top of a chest of drawers folded the handkerchief in which they had been wrapped put it carefully in his pocket and took up his hat as if to go

children.name: Paragraph_29
children.value: 'You'll have a very cold walk, Mr. Bumble,' said the matron.
children.prevalue: You ll have a very cold walk Mr Bumble said the matron

children.name: Paragraph_30
children.value: 'It blows, ma'am,' replied Mr. Bumble, turning up his coat-collar, 'enough to cut one's ears off.'
children.prevalue: It blows ma am replied Mr Bumble turning up his coat collar enough to cut one s ears off

children.name: Paragraph_31
children.value: The matron looked, from the little kettle, to the beadle, who was moving towards the door; and as the beadle coughed, preparatory to bidding her good-night, bashfully inquired whether--whether he wouldn't take a cup of tea?
children.prevalue: The matron looked from the little kettle to the beadle who was moving towards the door and as the beadle coughed preparatory to bidding her good night bashfully inquired whether whether he wouldn t take a cup of tea

children.name: Paragraph_32
children.value: Mr. Bumble instantaneously turned back his collar again; laid his hat and stick upon a chair; and drew another chair up to the table.  As he slowly seated himself, he looked at the lady.  She fixed her eyes upon the little teapot.  Mr. Bumble coughed again, and slightly smiled.
children.prevalue: Mr Bumble instantaneously turned back his collar again laid his hat and stick upon a chair and drew another chair up to the table As he slowly seated himself he looked at the lady She fixed her eyes upon the little teapot Mr Bumble coughed again and slightly smiled

children.name: Paragraph_33
children.value: Mrs. Corney rose to get another cup and saucer from the closet. As she sat down, her eyes once again encountered those of the gallant beadle; she coloured, and applied herself to the task of making his tea.  Again Mr. Bumble coughed--louder this time than he had coughed yet.
children.prevalue: Mrs Corney rose to get another cup and saucer from the closet As she sat down her eyes once again encountered those of the gallant beadle she coloured and applied herself to the task of making his tea Again Mr Bumble coughed louder this time than he had coughed yet

children.name: Paragraph_34
children.value: 'Sweet?  Mr. Bumble?' inquired the matron, taking up the sugar-basin.
children.prevalue: Sweet Mr Bumble inquired the matron taking up the sugar basin

children.name: Paragraph_35
children.value: 'Very sweet, indeed, ma'am,' replied Mr. Bumble.  He fixed his eyes on Mrs. Corney as he said this; and if ever a beadle looked tender, Mr. Bumble was that beadle at that moment.
children.prevalue: Very sweet indeed ma am replied Mr Bumble He fixed his eyes on Mrs Corney as he said this and if ever a beadle looked tender Mr Bumble was that beadle at that moment

children.name: Paragraph_36
children.value: The tea was made, and handed in silence.  Mr. Bumble, having spread a handkerchief over his knees to prevent the crumbs from sullying the splendour of his shorts, began to eat and drink; varying these amusements, occasionally, by fetching a deep sigh; which, however, had no injurious effect upon his appetite, but, on the contrary, rather seemed to facilitate his operations in the tea and toast department.
children.prevalue: The tea was made and handed in silence Mr Bumble having spread a handkerchief over his knees to prevent the crumbs from sullying the splendour of his shorts began to eat and drink varying these amusements occasionally by fetching a deep sigh which however had no injurious effect upon his appetite but on the contrary rather seemed to facilitate his operations in the tea and toast department

children.name: Paragraph_37
children.value: 'You have a cat, ma'am, I see,' said Mr. Bumble, glancing at one who, in the centre of her family, was basking before the fire; 'and kittens too, I declare!'
children.prevalue: You have a cat ma am I see said Mr Bumble glancing at one who in the centre of her family was basking before the fire and kittens too I declare

children.name: Paragraph_38
children.value: 'I am so fond of them, Mr. Bumble, you can't think,' replied the matron.  'They're so happy, so frolicsome, and so cheerful, that they are quite companions for me.'
children.prevalue: I am so fond of them Mr Bumble you can t think replied the matron They re so happy so frolicsome and so cheerful that they are quite companions for me

children.name: Paragraph_39
children.value: 'Very nice animals, ma'am,' replied Mr. Bumble, approvingly; 'so very domestic.'
children.prevalue: Very nice animals ma am replied Mr Bumble approvingly so very domestic

children.name: Paragraph_40
children.value: 'Oh, yes!' rejoined the matron with enthusiasm; 'so fond of their home too, that it's quite a pleasure, I'm sure.'
children.prevalue: Oh yes rejoined the matron with enthusiasm so fond of their home too that it s quite a pleasure I m sure

children.name: Paragraph_41
children.value: 'Mrs. Corney, ma'am,' said Mr. Bumble, slowly, and marking the time with his teaspoon, 'I mean to say this, ma'am; that any cat, or kitten, that could live with you, ma'am, and not be fond of its home, must be a ass, ma'am.'
children.prevalue: Mrs Corney ma am said Mr Bumble slowly and marking the time with his teaspoon I mean to say this ma am that any cat or kitten that could live with you ma am and not be fond of its home must be a ass ma am

children.name: Paragraph_42
children.value: 'Oh, Mr. Bumble!' remonstrated Mrs. Corney.
children.prevalue: Oh Mr Bumble remonstrated Mrs Corney

children.name: Paragraph_43
children.value: 'It's of no use disguising facts, ma'am,' said Mr. Bumble, slowly flourishing the teaspoon with a kind of amorous dignity which made him doubly impressive; 'I would drown it myself, with pleasure.'
children.prevalue: It s of no use disguising facts ma am said Mr Bumble slowly flourishing the teaspoon with a kind of amorous dignity which made him doubly impressive I would drown it myself with pleasure

children.name: Paragraph_44
children.value: 'Then you're a cruel man,' said the matron vivaciously, as she held out her hand for the beadle's cup; 'and a very hard-hearted man besides.'
children.prevalue: Then you re a cruel man said the matron vivaciously as she held out her hand for the beadle s cup and a very hard hearted man besides

children.name: Paragraph_45
children.value: 'Hard-hearted, ma'am?' said Mr. Bumble.  'Hard?'  Mr. Bumble resigned his cup without another word; squeezed Mrs. Corney's little finger as she took it; and inflicting two open-handed slaps upon his laced waistcoat, gave a mighty sigh, and hitched his chair a very little morsel farther from the fire.
children.prevalue: Hard hearted ma am said Mr Bumble Hard Mr Bumble resigned his cup without another word squeezed Mrs Corney s little finger as she took it and inflicting two open handed slaps upon his laced waistcoat gave a mighty sigh and hitched his chair a very little morsel farther from the fire

children.name: Paragraph_46
children.value: It was a round table; and as Mrs. Corney and Mr. Bumble had been sitting opposite each other, with no great space between them, and fronting the fire, it will be seen that Mr. Bumble, in receding from the fire, and still keeping at the table, increased the distance between himself and Mrs. Corney; which proceeding, some prudent readers will doubtless be disposed to admire, and to consider an act of great heroism on Mr. Bumble's part:  he being in some sort tempted by time, place, and opportunity, to give utterance to certain soft nothings, which however well they may become the lips of the light and thoughtless, do seem immeasurably beneath the dignity of judges of the land, members of parliament, ministers of state, lord mayors, and other great public functionaries, but more particularly beneath the stateliness and gravity of a beadle:  who (as is well known) should be the sternest and most inflexible among them all.
children.prevalue: It was a round table and as Mrs Corney and Mr Bumble had been sitting opposite each other with no great space between them and fronting the fire it will be seen that Mr Bumble in receding from the fire and still keeping at the table increased the distance between himself and Mrs Corney which proceeding some prudent readers will doubtless be disposed to admire and to consider an act of great heroism on Mr Bumble s part he being in some sort tempted by time place and opportunity to give utterance to certain soft nothings which however well they may become the lips of the light and thoughtless do seem immeasurably beneath the dignity of judges of the land members of parliament ministers of state lord mayors and other great public functionaries but more particularly beneath the stateliness and gravity of a beadle who as is well known should be the sternest and most inflexible among them all

children.name: Paragraph_47
children.value: Whatever were Mr. Bumble's intentions, however (and no doubt they were of the best): it unfortunately happened, as has been twice before remarked, that the table was a round one; consequently Mr. Bumble, moving his chair by little and little, soon began to diminish the distance between himself and the matron; and, continuing to travel round the outer edge of the circle, brought his chair, in time, close to that in which the matron was seated.
children.prevalue: Whatever were Mr Bumble s intentions however and no doubt they were of the best it unfortunately happened as has been twice before remarked that the table was a round one consequently Mr Bumble moving his chair by little and little soon began to diminish the distance between himself and the matron and continuing to travel round the outer edge of the circle brought his chair in time close to that in which the matron was seated

children.name: Paragraph_48
children.value: Indeed, the two chairs touched; and when they did so, Mr. Bumble stopped.
children.prevalue: Indeed the two chairs touched and when they did so Mr Bumble stopped

children.name: Paragraph_49
children.value: Now, if the matron had moved her chair to the right, she would have been scorched by the fire; and if to the left, she must have fallen into Mr. Bumble's arms; so (being a discreet matron, and no doubt foreseeing these consequences at a glance) she remained where she was, and handed Mr. Bumble another cup of tea.
children.prevalue: Now if the matron had moved her chair to the right she would have been scorched by the fire and if to the left she must have fallen into Mr Bumble s arms so being a discreet matron and no doubt foreseeing these consequences at a glance she remained where she was and handed Mr Bumble another cup of tea

children.name: Paragraph_50
children.value: 'Hard-hearted, Mrs. Corney?' said Mr. Bumble, stirring his tea, and looking up into the matron's face; 'are you hard-hearted, Mrs. Corney?'
children.prevalue: Hard hearted Mrs Corney said Mr Bumble stirring his tea and looking up into the matron s face are you hard hearted Mrs Corney

children.name: Paragraph_51
children.value: 'Dear me!' exclaimed the matron, 'what a very curious question from a single man.  What can you want to know for, Mr. Bumble?'
children.prevalue: Dear me exclaimed the matron what a very curious question from a single man What can you want to know for Mr Bumble

children.name: Paragraph_52
children.value: The beadle drank his tea to the last drop; finished a piece of toast; whisked the crumbs off his knees; wiped his lips; and deliberately kissed the matron.
children.prevalue: The beadle drank his tea to the last drop finished a piece of toast whisked the crumbs off his knees wiped his lips and deliberately kissed the matron

children.name: Paragraph_53
children.value: 'Mr. Bumble!' cried that discreet lady in a whisper; for the fright was so great, that she had quite lost her voice, 'Mr. Bumble, I shall scream!'  Mr. Bumble made no reply; but in a slow and dignified manner, put his arm round the matron's waist.
children.prevalue: Mr Bumble cried that discreet lady in a whisper for the fright was so great that she had quite lost her voice Mr Bumble I shall scream Mr Bumble made no reply but in a slow and dignified manner put his arm round the matron s waist

children.name: Paragraph_54
children.value: As the lady had stated her intention of screaming, of course she would have screamed at this additional boldness, but that the exertion was rendered unnecessary by a hasty knocking at the door:  which was no sooner heard, than Mr. Bumble darted, with much agility, to the wine bottles, and began dusting them with great violence:  while the matron sharply demanded who was there.
children.prevalue: As the lady had stated her intention of screaming of course she would have screamed at this additional boldness but that the exertion was rendered unnecessary by a hasty knocking at the door which was no sooner heard than Mr Bumble darted with much agility to the wine bottles and began dusting them with great violence while the matron sharply demanded who was there

children.name: Paragraph_55
children.value: It is worthy of remark, as a curious physical instance of the efficacy of a sudden surprise in counteracting the effects of extreme fear, that her voice had quite recovered all its official asperity.
children.prevalue: It is worthy of remark as a curious physical instance of the efficacy of a sudden surprise in counteracting the effects of extreme fear that her voice had quite recovered all its official asperity

children.name: Paragraph_56
children.value: 'If you please, mistress,' said a withered old female pauper, hideously ugly:  putting her head in at the door, 'Old Sally is a-going fast.'
children.prevalue: If you please mistress said a withered old female pauper hideously ugly putting her head in at the door Old Sally is a going fast

children.name: Paragraph_57
children.value: 'Well, what's that to me?' angrily demanded the matron.  'I can't keep her alive, can I?'
children.prevalue: Well what s that to me angrily demanded the matron I can t keep her alive can I

children.name: Paragraph_58
children.value: 'No, no, mistress,' replied the old woman, 'nobody can; she's far beyond the reach of help.  I've seen a many people die; little babes and great strong men; and I know when death's a-coming, well enough. But she's troubled in her mind: and when the fits are not on her,--and that's not often, for she is dying very hard,--she says she has got something to tell, which you must hear.  She'll never die quiet till you come, mistress.'
children.prevalue: No no mistress replied the old woman nobody can she s far beyond the reach of help I ve seen a many people die little babes and great strong men and I know when death s a coming well enough But she s troubled in her mind and when the fits are not on her and that s not often for she is dying very hard she says she has got something to tell which you must hear She ll never die quiet till you come mistress

children.name: Paragraph_59
children.value: At this intelligence, the worthy Mrs. Corney muttered a variety of invectives against old women who couldn't even die without purposely annoying their betters; and, muffling herself in a thick shawl which she hastily caught up, briefly requested Mr. Bumble to stay till she came back, lest anything particular should occur.  Bidding the messenger walk fast, and not be all night hobbling up the stairs, she followed her from the room with a very ill grace, scolding all the way.
children.prevalue: At this intelligence the worthy Mrs Corney muttered a variety of invectives against old women who couldn t even die without purposely annoying their betters and muffling herself in a thick shawl which she hastily caught up briefly requested Mr Bumble to stay till she came back lest anything particular should occur Bidding the messenger walk fast and not be all night hobbling up the stairs she followed her from the room with a very ill grace scolding all the way

children.name: Paragraph_60
children.value: Mr. Bumble's conduct on being left to himself, was rather inexplicable. He opened the closet, counted the teaspoons, weighed the sugar-tongs, closely inspected a silver milk-pot to ascertain that it was of the genuine metal, and, having satisfied his curiosity on these points, put on his cocked hat corner-wise, and danced with much gravity four distinct times round the table.
children.prevalue: Mr Bumble s conduct on being left to himself was rather inexplicable He opened the closet counted the teaspoons weighed the sugar tongs closely inspected a silver milk pot to ascertain that it was of the genuine metal and having satisfied his curiosity on these points put on his cocked hat corner wise and danced with much gravity four distinct times round the table

children.name: Paragraph_61
children.value: Having gone through this very extraordinary performance, he took off the cocked hat again, and, spreading himself before the fire with his back towards it, seemed to be mentally engaged in taking an exact inventory of the furniture.
children.prevalue: Having gone through this very extraordinary performance he took off the cocked hat again and spreading himself before the fire with his back towards it seemed to be mentally engaged in taking an exact inventory of the furniture

children.name: Paragraph_1
children.value: TREATS ON A VERY POOR SUBJECT.  BUT IS A SHORT ONE, AND MAY BE FOUND OF IMPORTANCE IN THIS HISTORY
children.prevalue: TREATS ON A VERY POOR SUBJECT BUT IS A SHORT ONE AND MAY BE FOUND OF IMPORTANCE IN THIS HISTORY

children.name: Paragraph_2
children.value: It was no unfit messenger of death, who had disturbed the quiet of the matron's room.  Her body was bent by age; her limbs trembled with palsy; her face, distorted into a mumbling leer, resembled more the grotesque shaping of some wild pencil, than the work of Nature's hand.
children.prevalue: It was no unfit messenger of death who had disturbed the quiet of the matron s room Her body was bent by age her limbs trembled with palsy her face distorted into a mumbling leer resembled more the grotesque shaping of some wild pencil than the work of Nature s hand

children.name: Paragraph_3
children.value: Alas!  How few of Nature's faces are left alone to gladden us with their beauty!  The cares, and sorrows, and hungerings, of the world, change them as they change hearts; and it is only when those passions sleep, and have lost their hold for ever, that the troubled clouds pass off, and leave Heaven's surface clear.  It is a common thing for the countenances of the dead, even in that fixed and rigid state, to subside into the long-forgotten expression of sleeping infancy, and settle into the very look of early life; so calm, so peaceful, do they grow again, that those who knew them in their happy childhood, kneel by the coffin's side in awe, and see the Angel even upon earth.
children.prevalue: Alas How few of Nature s faces are left alone to gladden us with their beauty The cares and sorrows and hungerings of the world change them as they change hearts and it is only when those passions sleep and have lost their hold for ever that the troubled clouds pass off and leave Heaven s surface clear It is a common thing for the countenances of the dead even in that fixed and rigid state to subside into the long forgotten expression of sleeping infancy and settle into the very look of early life so calm so peaceful do they grow again that those who knew them in their happy childhood kneel by the coffin s side in awe and see the Angel even upon earth

children.name: Paragraph_4
children.value: The old crone tottered along the passages, and up the stairs, muttering some indistinct answers to the chidings of her companion; being at length compelled to pause for breath, she gave the light into her hand, and remained behind to follow as she might: while the more nimble superior made her way to the room where the sick woman lay.
children.prevalue: The old crone tottered along the passages and up the stairs muttering some indistinct answers to the chidings of her companion being at length compelled to pause for breath she gave the light into her hand and remained behind to follow as she might while the more nimble superior made her way to the room where the sick woman lay

children.name: Paragraph_5
children.value: It was a bare garret-room, with a dim light burning at the farther end. There was another old woman watching by the bed; the parish apothecary's apprentice was standing by the fire, making a toothpick out of a quill.
children.prevalue: It was a bare garret room with a dim light burning at the farther end There was another old woman watching by the bed the parish apothecary s apprentice was standing by the fire making a toothpick out of a quill

children.name: Paragraph_6
children.value: 'Cold night, Mrs. Corney,' said this young gentleman, as the matron entered.
children.prevalue: Cold night Mrs Corney said this young gentleman as the matron entered

children.name: Paragraph_7
children.value: 'Very cold, indeed, sir,' replied the mistress, in her most civil tones, and dropping a curtsey as she spoke.
children.prevalue: Very cold indeed sir replied the mistress in her most civil tones and dropping a curtsey as she spoke

children.name: Paragraph_8
children.value: 'You should get better coals out of your contractors,' said the apothecary's deputy, breaking a lump on the top of the fire with the rusty poker; 'these are not at all the sort of thing for a cold night.'
children.prevalue: You should get better coals out of your contractors said the apothecary s deputy breaking a lump on the top of the fire with the rusty poker these are not at all the sort of thing for a cold night

children.name: Paragraph_9
children.value: 'They're the board's choosing, sir,' returned the matron. 'The least they could do, would be to keep us pretty warm:  for our places are hard enough.'
children.prevalue: They re the board s choosing sir returned the matron The least they could do would be to keep us pretty warm for our places are hard enough

children.name: Paragraph_10
children.value: The conversation was here interrupted by a moan from the sick woman.
children.prevalue: The conversation was here interrupted by a moan from the sick woman

children.name: Paragraph_11
children.value: 'Oh!' said the young mag, turning his face towards the bed, as if he had previously quite forgotten the patient, 'it's all U.P. there, Mrs. Corney.'
children.prevalue: Oh said the young mag turning his face towards the bed as if he had previously quite forgotten the patient it s all U P there Mrs Corney

children.name: Paragraph_12
children.value: 'It is, is it, sir?' asked the matron.
children.prevalue: It is is it sir asked the matron

children.name: Paragraph_13
children.value: 'If she lasts a couple of hours, I shall be surprised,' said the apothecary's apprentice, intent upon the toothpick's point. 'It's a break-up of the system altogether.  Is she dozing, old lady?'
children.prevalue: If she lasts a couple of hours I shall be surprised said the apothecary s apprentice intent upon the toothpick s point It s a break up of the system altogether Is she dozing old lady

children.name: Paragraph_14
children.value: The attendant stooped over the bed, to ascertain; and nodded in the affirmative.
children.prevalue: The attendant stooped over the bed to ascertain and nodded in the affirmative

children.name: Paragraph_15
children.value: 'Then perhaps she'll go off in that way, if you don't make a row,' said the young man.  'Put the light on the floor.  She won't see it there.'
children.prevalue: Then perhaps she ll go off in that way if you don t make a row said the young man Put the light on the floor She won t see it there

children.name: Paragraph_16
children.value: The attendant did as she was told:  shaking her head meanwhile, to intimate that the woman would not die so easily; having done so, she resumed her seat by the side of the other nurse, who had by this time returned.  The mistress, with an expression of impatience, wrapped herself in her shawl, and sat at the foot of the bed.

children.name: Paragraph_17
children.value: The apothecary's apprentice, having completed the manufacture of the toothpick, planted himself in front of the fire and made good use of it for ten minutes or so:  when apparently growing rather dull, he wished Mrs. Corney joy of her job, and took himself off on tiptoe.
children.prevalue: The apothecary s apprentice having completed the manufacture of the toothpick planted himself in front of the fire and made good use of it for ten minutes or so when apparently growing rather dull he wished Mrs Corney joy of her job and took himself off on tiptoe

children.name: Paragraph_18
children.value: When they had sat in silence for some time, the two old women rose from the bed, and crouching over the fire, held out their withered hands to catch the heat.  The flame threw a ghastly light on their shrivelled faces, and made their ugliness appear terrible, as, in this position, they began to converse in a low voice.
children.prevalue: When they had sat in silence for some time the two old women rose from the bed and crouching over the fire held out their withered hands to catch the heat The flame threw a ghastly light on their shrivelled faces and made their ugliness appear terrible as in this position they began to converse in a low voice

children.name: Paragraph_19
children.value: 'Did she say any more, Anny dear, while I was gone?' inquired the messenger.
children.prevalue: Did she say any more Anny dear while I was gone inquired the messenger

children.name: Paragraph_20
children.value: 'Not a word,' replied the other.  'She plucked and tore at her arms for a little time; but I held her hands, and she soon dropped off.  She hasn't much strength in her, so I easily kept her quiet.  I ain't so weak for an old woman, although I am on parish allowance; no, no!'
children.prevalue: Not a word replied the other She plucked and tore at her arms for a little time but I held her hands and she soon dropped off She hasn t much strength in her so I easily kept her quiet I ain t so weak for an old woman although I am on parish allowance no no

children.name: Paragraph_21
children.value: 'Did she drink the hot wine the doctor said she was to have?' demanded the first.
children.prevalue: Did she drink the hot wine the doctor said she was to have demanded the first

children.name: Paragraph_22
children.value: 'I tried to get it down,' rejoined the other.  'But her teeth were tight set, and she clenched the mug so hard that it was as much as I could do to get it back again.  So I drank it; and it did me good!'
children.prevalue: I tried to get it down rejoined the other But her teeth were tight set and she clenched the mug so hard that it was as much as I could do to get it back again So I drank it and it did me good

children.name: Paragraph_23
children.value: Looking cautiously round, to ascertain that they were not overheard, the two hags cowered nearer to the fire, and chuckled heartily.
children.prevalue: Looking cautiously round to ascertain that they were not overheard the two hags cowered nearer to the fire and chuckled heartily

children.name: Paragraph_24
children.value: 'I mind the time,' said the first speaker, 'when she would have done the same, and made rare fun of it afterwards.'
children.prevalue: I mind the time said the first speaker when she would have done the same and made rare fun of it afterwards

children.name: Paragraph_25
children.value: 'Ay, that she would,' rejoined the other; 'she had a merry heart. 'A many, many, beautiful corpses she laid out, as nice and neat as waxwork.  My old eyes have seen them--ay, and those old hands touched them too; for I have helped her, scores of times.'
children.prevalue: Ay that she would rejoined the other she had a merry heart A many many beautiful corpses she laid out as nice and neat as waxwork My old eyes have seen them ay and those old hands touched them too for I have helped her scores of times

children.name: Paragraph_26
children.value: Stretching forth her trembling fingers as she spoke, the old creature shook them exultingly before her face, and fumbling in her pocket, brought out an old time-discoloured tin snuff-box, from which she shook a few grains into the outstretched palm of her companion, and a few more into her own.  While they were thus employed, the matron, who had been impatiently watching until the dying woman should awaken from her stupor, joined them by the fire, and sharply asked how long she was to wait?
children.prevalue: Stretching forth her trembling fingers as she spoke the old creature shook them exultingly before her face and fumbling in her pocket brought out an old time discoloured tin snuff box from which she shook a few grains into the outstretched palm of her companion and a few more into her own While they were thus employed the matron who had been impatiently watching until the dying woman should awaken from her stupor joined them by the fire and sharply asked how long she was to wait

children.name: Paragraph_27
children.value: 'Not long, mistress,' replied the second woman, looking up into her face.  'We have none of us long to wait for Death.  Patience, patience! He'll be here soon enough for us all.'
children.prevalue: Not long mistress replied the second woman looking up into her face We have none of us long to wait for Death Patience patience He ll be here soon enough for us all

children.name: Paragraph_28
children.value: 'Hold your tongue, you doting idiot!' said the matron sternly. 'You, Martha, tell me; has she been in this way before?'
children.prevalue: Hold your tongue you doting idiot said the matron sternly You Martha tell me has she been in this way before

children.name: Paragraph_29
children.value: 'Often,' answered the first woman.
children.prevalue: Often answered the first woman

children.name: Paragraph_30
children.value: 'But will never be again,' added the second one; 'that is, she'll never wake again but once--and mind, mistress, that won't be for long!'
children.prevalue: But will never be again added the second one that is she ll never wake again but once and mind mistress that won t be for long

children.name: Paragraph_31
children.value: 'Long or short,' said the matron, snappishly, 'she won't find me here when she does wake; take care, both of you, how you worry me again for nothing.  It's no part of my duty to see all the old women in the house die, and I won't--that's more. Mind that, you impudent old harridans. If you make a fool of me again, I'll soon cure you, I warrant you!'
children.prevalue: Long or short said the matron snappishly she won t find me here when she does wake take care both of you how you worry me again for nothing It s no part of my duty to see all the old women in the house die and I won t that s more Mind that you impudent old harridans If you make a fool of me again I ll soon cure you I warrant you

children.name: Paragraph_32
children.value: She was bouncing away, when a cry from the two women, who had turned towards the bed, caused her to look round.  The patient had raised herself upright, and was stretching her arms towards them.
children.prevalue: She was bouncing away when a cry from the two women who had turned towards the bed caused her to look round The patient had raised herself upright and was stretching her arms towards them

children.name: Paragraph_33
children.value: 'Who's that?' she cried, in a hollow voice.
children.prevalue: Who s that she cried in a hollow voice

children.name: Paragraph_34

children.name: Paragraph_36
children.value: She clutched the matron by the arm, and forcing her into a chair by the bedside, was about to speak, when looking round, she caught sight of the two old women bending forward in the attitude of eager listeners.
children.prevalue: She clutched the matron by the arm and forcing her into a chair by the bedside was about to speak when looking round she caught sight of the two old women bending forward in the attitude of eager listeners

children.name: Paragraph_37
children.value: 'Turn them away,' said the woman, drowsily; 'make haste! make haste!'
children.prevalue: Turn them away said the woman drowsily make haste make haste

children.name: Paragraph_38
children.value: The two old crones, chiming in together, began pouring out many piteous lamentations that the poor dear was too far gone to know her best friends; and were uttering sundry protestations that they would never leave her, when the superior pushed them from the room, closed the door, and returned to the bedside.  On being excluded, the old ladies changed their tone, and cried through the keyhole that old Sally was drunk; which, indeed, was not unlikely; since, in addition to a moderate dose of opium prescribed by the apothecary, she was labouring under the effects of a final taste of gin-and-water which had been privily administered, in the openness of their hearts, by the worthy old ladies themselves.
children.prevalue: The two old crones chiming in together began pouring out many piteous lamentations that the poor dear was too far gone to know her best friends and were uttering sundry protestations that they would never leave her when the superior pushed them from the room closed the door and returned to the bedside On being excluded the old ladies changed their tone and cried through the keyhole that old Sally was drunk which indeed was not unlikely since in addition to a moderate dose of opium prescribed by the apothecary she was labouring under the effects of a final taste of gin and water which had been privily administered in the openness of their hearts by the worthy old ladies themselves

children.name: Paragraph_39
children.value: 'Now listen to me,' said the dying woman aloud, as if making a great effort to revive one latent spark of energy.  'In this very room--in this very bed--I once nursed a pretty young creetur', that was brought into the house with her feet cut and bruised with walking, and all soiled with dust and blood.  She gave birth to a boy, and died.  Let me think--what was the year again!'
children.prevalue: Now listen to me said the dying woman aloud as if making a great effort to revive one latent spark of energy In this very room in this very bed I once nursed a pretty young creetur that was brought into the house with her feet cut and bruised with walking and all soiled with dust and blood She gave birth to a boy and died Let me think what was the year again

children.name: Paragraph_40
children.value: 'Never mind the year,' said the impatient auditor; 'what about her?'
children.prevalue: Never mind the year said the impatient auditor what about her

children.name: Paragraph_41
children.value: 'Ay,' murmured the sick woman, relapsing into her former drowsy state, 'what about her?--what about--I know!' she cried, jumping fiercely up: her face flushed, and her eyes starting from her head--'I robbed her, so I did!  She wasn't cold--I tell you she wasn't cold, when I stole it!'
children.prevalue: Ay murmured the sick woman relapsing into her former drowsy state what about her what about I know she cried jumping fiercely up her face flushed and her eyes starting from her head I robbed her so I did She wasn t cold I tell you she wasn t cold when I stole it

children.name: Paragraph_42
children.value: 'Stole what, for God's sake?' cried the matron, with a gesture as if she would call for help.
children.prevalue: Stole what for God s sake cried the matron with a gesture as if she would call for help

children.name: Paragraph_43
children.value: 'It!' replied the woman, laying her hand over the other's mouth. 'The only thing she had.  She wanted clothes to keep her warm, and food to eat; but she had kept it safe, and had it in her bosom.  It was gold, I tell you!  Rich gold, that might have saved her life!'
children.prevalue: It replied the woman laying her hand over the other s mouth The only thing she had She wanted clothes to keep her warm and food to eat but she had kept it safe and had it in her bosom It was gold I tell you Rich gold that might have saved her life

children.name: Paragraph_44
children.value: 'Gold!' echoed the matron, bending eagerly over the woman as she fell back.  'Go on, go on--yes--what of it?  Who was the mother? When was it?'
children.prevalue: Gold echoed the matron bending eagerly over the woman as she fell back Go on go on yes what of it Who was the mother When was it

children.name: Paragraph_45
children.value: 'She charge me to keep it safe,' replied the woman with a groan, 'and trusted me as the only woman about her.  I stole it in my heart when she first showed it me hanging round her neck; and the child's death, perhaps, is on me besides!  They would have treated him better, if they had known it all!'
children.prevalue: She charge me to keep it safe replied the woman with a groan and trusted me as the only woman about her I stole it in my heart when she first showed it me hanging round her neck and the child s death perhaps is on me besides They would have treated him better if they had known it all

children.value: 'Known what?' asked the other.  'Speak!'
children.prevalue: Known what asked the other Speak

children.name: Paragraph_47
children.value: 'The boy grew so like his mother,' said the woman, rambling on, and not heeding the question, 'that I could never forget it when I saw his face.  Poor girl! poor girl!  She was so young, too! Such a gentle lamb!  Wait; there's more to tell.  I have not told you all, have I?'
children.prevalue: The boy grew so like his mother said the woman rambling on and not heeding the question that I could never forget it when I saw his face Poor girl poor girl She was so young too Such a gentle lamb Wait there s more to tell I have not told you all have I

children.name: Paragraph_48
children.value: 'No, no,' replied the matron, inclining her head to catch the words, as they came more faintly from the dying woman.  'Be quick, or it may be too late!'
children.prevalue: No no replied the matron inclining her head to catch the words as they came more faintly from the dying woman Be quick or it may be too late

children.name: Paragraph_49
children.value: 'The mother,' said the woman, making a more violent effort than before; 'the mother, when the pains of death first came upon her, whispered in my ear that if her baby was born alive, and thrived, the day might come when it would not feel so much disgraced to hear its poor young mother named. And oh, kind Heaven! she said, folding her thin hands together, whether it be boy or girl, raise up some friends for it in this troubled world, and take pity upon a lonely desolate child, abandoned to its mercy!'

children.prevalue: The boy s name demanded the matron

children.prevalue: They called him Oliver replied the woman feebly The gold I stole was

children.name: Paragraph_52
children.value: 'Yes, yes--what?' cried the other.

children.name: Paragraph_53
children.value: She was bending eagerly over the woman to hear her reply; but drew back, instinctively, as she once again rose, slowly and stiffly, into a sitting posture; then, clutching the coverlid with both hands, muttered some indistinct sounds in her throat, and fell lifeless on the bed.
children.prevalue: She was bending eagerly over the woman to hear her reply but drew back instinctively as she once again rose slowly and stiffly into a sitting posture then clutching the coverlid with both hands muttered some indistinct sounds in her throat and fell lifeless on the bed

children.prevalue: Stone dead said one of the old women hurrying in as soon as the door was opened

children.value: 'And nothing to tell, after all,' rejoined the matron, walking carelessly away.
children.prevalue: And nothing to tell after all rejoined the matron walking carelessly away

children.name: Paragraph_1
children.value: WHEREIN THIS HISTORY REVERTS TO MR. FAGIN AND COMPANY
children.prevalue: WHEREIN THIS HISTORY REVERTS TO MR FAGIN AND COMPANY

children.name: Paragraph_2
children.value: While these things were passing in the country workhouse, Mr. Fagin sat in the old den--the same from which Oliver had been removed by the girl--brooding over a dull, smoky fire.  He held a pair of bellows upon his knee, with which he had apparently been endeavouring to rouse it into more cheerful action; but he had fallen into deep thought; and with his arms folded on them, and his chin resting on his thumbs, fixed his eyes, abstractedly, on the rusty bars.
children.prevalue: While these things were passing in the country workhouse Mr Fagin sat in the old den the same from which Oliver had been removed by the girl brooding over a dull smoky fire He held a pair of bellows upon his knee with which he had apparently been endeavouring to rouse it into more cheerful action but he had fallen into deep thought and with his arms folded on them and his chin resting on his thumbs fixed his eyes abstractedly on the rusty bars

children.name: Paragraph_3
children.value: At a table behind him sat the Artful Dodger, Master Charles Bates, and Mr. Chitling: all intent upon a game of whist; the Artful taking dummy against Master Bates and Mr. Chitling.  The countenance of the first-named gentleman, peculiarly intelligent at all times, acquired great additional interest from his close observance of the game, and his attentive perusal of Mr. Chitling's hand; upon which, from time to time, as occasion served, he bestowed a variety of earnest glances: wisely regulating his own play by the result of his observations upon his neighbour's cards.  It being a cold night, the Dodger wore his hat, as, indeed, was often his custom within doors.  He also sustained a clay pipe between his teeth, which he only removed for a brief space when he deemed it necessary to apply for refreshment to a quart pot upon the table, which stood ready filled with gin-and-water for the accommodation of the company.
children.prevalue: At a table behind him sat the Artful Dodger Master Charles Bates and Mr Chitling all intent upon a game of whist the Artful taking dummy against Master Bates and Mr Chitling The countenance of the first named gentleman peculiarly intelligent at all times acquired great additional interest from his close observance of the game and his attentive perusal of Mr Chitling s hand upon which from time to time as occasion served he bestowed a variety of earnest glances wisely regulating his own play by the result of his observations upon his neighbour s cards It being a cold night the Dodger wore his hat as indeed was often his custom within doors He also sustained a clay pipe between his teeth which he only removed for a brief space when he deemed it necessary to apply for refreshment to a quart pot upon the table which stood ready filled with gin and water for the accommodation of the company

children.name: Paragraph_4
children.value: Master Bates was also attentive to the play; but being of a more excitable nature than his accomplished friend, it was observable that he more frequently applied himself to the gin-and-water, and moreover indulged in many jests and irrelevant remarks, all highly unbecoming a scientific rubber.  Indeed, the Artful, presuming upon their close attachment, more than once took occasion to reason gravely with his companion upon these improprieties; all of which remonstrances, Master Bates received in extremely good part; merely requesting his friend to be 'blowed,' or to insert his head in a sack, or replying with some other neatly-turned witticism of a similar kind, the happy application of which, excited considerable admiration in the mind of Mr. Chitling. It was remarkable that the latter gentleman and his partner invariably lost; and that the circumstance, so far from angering Master Bates, appeared to afford him the highest amusement, inasmuch as he laughed most uproariously at the end of every deal, and protested that he had never seen such a jolly game in all his born days.
children.prevalue: Master Bates was also attentive to the play but being of a more excitable nature than his accomplished friend it was observable that he more frequently applied himself to the gin and water and moreover indulged in many jests and irrelevant remarks all highly unbecoming a scientific rubber Indeed the Artful presuming upon their close attachment more than once took occasion to reason gravely with his companion upon these improprieties all of which remonstrances Master Bates received in extremely good part merely requesting his friend to be blowed or to insert his head in a sack or replying with some other neatly turned witticism of a similar kind the happy application of which excited considerable admiration in the mind of Mr Chitling It was remarkable that the latter gentleman and his partner invariably lost and that the circumstance so far from angering Master Bates appeared to afford him the highest amusement inasmuch as he laughed most uproariously at the end of every deal and protested that he had never seen such a jolly game in all his born days

children.name: Paragraph_5
children.value: 'That's two doubles and the rub,' said Mr. Chitling, with a very long face, as he drew half-a-crown from his waistcoat-pocket.  'I never see such a feller as you, Jack; you win everything.  Even when we've good cards, Charley and I can't make nothing of 'em.'
children.prevalue: That s two doubles and the rub said Mr Chitling with a very long face as he drew half a crown from his waistcoat pocket I never see such a feller as you Jack you win everything Even when we ve good cards Charley and I can t make nothing of em

children.name: Paragraph_6
children.value: Either the master or the manner of this remark, which was made very ruefully, delighted Charley Bates so much, that his consequent shout of laughter roused the Jew from his reverie, and induced him to inquire what was the matter.
children.prevalue: Either the master or the manner of this remark which was made very ruefully delighted Charley Bates so much that his consequent shout of laughter roused the Jew from his reverie and induced him to inquire what was the matter

children.name: Paragraph_7

children.name: Paragraph_9

Nobody accepting the challenge, and his pipe being by this time smoked out, he proceeded to amuse himself by sketching a ground-plan of Newgate on the table with the piece of chalk which had served him in lieu of counters; whistling, meantime, with peculiar shrillness.

children.name: Paragraph_13
