children.name: Paragraph_74
children.value: And now that we have accompanied him so far on his road home, and have made all necessary preparations for the old woman's funeral, let us set on foot a few inquires after young Oliver Twist, and ascertain whether he be still lying in the ditch where Toby Crackit left him.
children.prevalue: And now that we have accompanied him so far on his road home and have made all necessary preparations for the old woman s funeral let us set on foot a few inquires after young Oliver Twist and ascertain whether he be still lying in the ditch where Toby Crackit left him

children.name: Paragraph_1
children.value: LOOKS AFTER OLIVER, AND PROCEEDS WITH HIS ADVENTURES
children.prevalue: LOOKS AFTER OLIVER AND PROCEEDS WITH HIS ADVENTURES

children.name: Paragraph_2
children.value: 'Wolves tear your throats!' muttered Sikes, grinding his teeth. 'I wish I was among some of you; you'd howl the hoarser for it.'
children.prevalue: Wolves tear your throats muttered Sikes grinding his teeth I wish I was among some of you you d howl the hoarser for it

children.name: Paragraph_3
children.value: As Sikes growled forth this imprecation, with the most desperate ferocity that his desperate nature was capable of, he rested the body of the wounded boy across his bended knee; and turned his head, for an instant, to look back at his pursuers.
children.prevalue: As Sikes growled forth this imprecation with the most desperate ferocity that his desperate nature was capable of he rested the body of the wounded boy across his bended knee and turned his head for an instant to look back at his pursuers

children.name: Paragraph_4
children.value: There was little to be made out, in the mist and darkness; but the loud shouting of men vibrated through the air, and the barking of the neighbouring dogs, roused by the sound of the alarm bell, resounded in every direction.
children.prevalue: There was little to be made out in the mist and darkness but the loud shouting of men vibrated through the air and the barking of the neighbouring dogs roused by the sound of the alarm bell resounded in every direction

children.name: Paragraph_5
children.value: 'Stop, you white-livered hound!' cried the robber, shouting after Toby Crackit, who, making the best use of his long legs, was already ahead. 'Stop!'
children.prevalue: Stop you white livered hound cried the robber shouting after Toby Crackit who making the best use of his long legs was already ahead Stop

children.name: Paragraph_6
children.value: The repetition of the word, brought Toby to a dead stand-still. For he was not quite satisfied that he was beyond the range of pistol-shot; and Sikes was in no mood to be played with.
children.prevalue: The repetition of the word brought Toby to a dead stand still For he was not quite satisfied that he was beyond the range of pistol shot and Sikes was in no mood to be played with

children.name: Paragraph_7
children.value: 'Bear a hand with the boy,' cried Sikes, beckoning furiously to his confederate.  'Come back!'
children.prevalue: Bear a hand with the boy cried Sikes beckoning furiously to his confederate Come back

children.name: Paragraph_8
children.value: Toby made a show of returning; but ventured, in a low voice, broken for want of breath, to intimate considerable reluctance as he came slowly along.
children.prevalue: Toby made a show of returning but ventured in a low voice broken for want of breath to intimate considerable reluctance as he came slowly along

children.name: Paragraph_9
children.value: 'Quicker!' cried Sikes, laying the boy in a dry ditch at his feet, and drawing a pistol from his pocket.  'Don't play booty with me.'
children.prevalue: Quicker cried Sikes laying the boy in a dry ditch at his feet and drawing a pistol from his pocket Don t play booty with me

children.name: Paragraph_10
children.value: At this moment the noise grew louder.  Sikes, again looking round, could discern that the men who had given chase were already climbing the gate of the field in which he stood; and that a couple of dogs were some paces in advance of them.
children.prevalue: At this moment the noise grew louder Sikes again looking round could discern that the men who had given chase were already climbing the gate of the field in which he stood and that a couple of dogs were some paces in advance of them

children.name: Paragraph_11
children.value: 'It's all up, Bill!' cried Toby; 'drop the kid, and show 'em your heels.'  With this parting advice, Mr. Crackit, preferring the chance of being shot by his friend, to the certainty of being taken by his enemies, fairly turned tail, and darted off at full speed.  Sikes clenched his teeth; took one look around; threw over the prostrate form of Oliver, the cape in which he had been hurriedly muffled; ran along the front of the hedge, as if to distract the attention of those behind, from the spot where the boy lay; paused, for a second, before another hedge which met it at right angles; and whirling his pistol high into the air, cleared it at a bound, and was gone.
children.prevalue: It s all up Bill cried Toby drop the kid and show em your heels With this parting advice Mr Crackit preferring the chance of being shot by his friend to the certainty of being taken by his enemies fairly turned tail and darted off at full speed Sikes clenched his teeth took one look around threw over the prostrate form of Oliver the cape in which he had been hurriedly muffled ran along the front of the hedge as if to distract the attention of those behind from the spot where the boy lay paused for a second before another hedge which met it at right angles and whirling his pistol high into the air cleared it at a bound and was gone

children.name: Paragraph_12
children.value: 'Ho, ho, there!' cried a tremulous voice in the rear. 'Pincher! Neptune!  Come here, come here!'
children.prevalue: Ho ho there cried a tremulous voice in the rear Pincher Neptune Come here come here

children.name: Paragraph_13
children.value: The dogs, who, in common with their masters, seemed to have no particular relish for the sport in which they were engaged, readily answered to the command.  Three men, who had by this time advanced some distance into the field, stopped to take counsel together.
children.prevalue: The dogs who in common with their masters seemed to have no particular relish for the sport in which they were engaged readily answered to the command Three men who had by this time advanced some distance into the field stopped to take counsel together

children.name: Paragraph_14
children.value: 'My advice, or, leastways, I should say, my orders, is,' said the fattest man of the party, 'that we 'mediately go home again.'
children.prevalue: My advice or leastways I should say my orders is said the fattest man of the party that we mediately go home again

children.name: Paragraph_15
children.value: 'I am agreeable to anything which is agreeable to Mr. Giles,' said a shorter man; who was by no means of a slim figure, and who was very pale in the face, and very polite: as frightened men frequently are.
children.prevalue: I am agreeable to anything which is agreeable to Mr Giles said a shorter man who was by no means of a slim figure and who was very pale in the face and very polite as frightened men frequently are

children.name: Paragraph_16

children.prevalue: I shouldn t wish to appear ill mannered gentlemen said the third who had called the dogs back Mr Giles ought to know

children.name: Paragraph_17
children.value: 'Certainly,' replied the shorter man; 'and whatever Mr. Giles says, it isn't our place to contradict him.  No, no, I know my sitiwation! Thank my stars, I know my sitiwation.'  To tell the truth, the little man did seem to know his situation, and to know perfectly well that it was by no means a desirable one; for his teeth chattered in his head as he spoke.

children.prevalue: You re a falsehood Mr Giles said Brittles

children.prevalue: You re a lie Brittles said Mr Giles

children.name: Paragraph_23
children.value: Now, these four retorts arose from Mr. Giles's taunt; and Mr. Giles's taunt had arisen from his indignation at having the responsibility of going home again, imposed upon himself under cover of a compliment. The third man brought the dispute to a close, most philosophically.
children.prevalue: Now these four retorts arose from Mr Giles s taunt and Mr Giles s taunt had arisen from his indignation at having the responsibility of going home again imposed upon himself under cover of a compliment The third man brought the dispute to a close most philosophically

children.name: Paragraph_24
children.value: 'I'll tell you what it is, gentlemen,' said he, 'we're all afraid.'
children.prevalue: I ll tell you what it is gentlemen said he we re all afraid

children.name: Paragraph_25
children.value: 'Speak for yourself, sir,' said Mr. Giles, who was the palest of the party.
children.prevalue: Speak for yourself sir said Mr Giles who was the palest of the party

children.name: Paragraph_26
children.value: 'So I do,' replied the man.  'It's natural and proper to be afraid, under such circumstances.  I am.'
children.prevalue: So I do replied the man It s natural and proper to be afraid under such circumstances I am

children.name: Paragraph_27

children.prevalue: So am I said Brittles only there s no call to tell a man he is so bounceably

children.name: Paragraph_28
children.value: These frank admissions softened Mr. Giles, who at once owned that he was afraid; upon which, they all three faced about, and ran back again with the completest unanimity, until Mr. Giles (who had the shortest wind of the party, as was encumbered with a pitchfork) most handsomely insisted on stopping, to make an apology for his hastiness of speech.
children.prevalue: These frank admissions softened Mr Giles who at once owned that he was afraid upon which they all three faced about and ran back again with the completest unanimity until Mr Giles who had the shortest wind of the party as was encumbered with a pitchfork most handsomely insisted on stopping to make an apology for his hastiness of speech

children.name: Paragraph_29
children.value: 'But it's wonderful,' said Mr. Giles, when he had explained, 'what a man will do, when his blood is up.  I should have committed murder--I know I should--if we'd caught one of them rascals.'
children.prevalue: But it s wonderful said Mr Giles when he had explained what a man will do when his blood is up I should have committed murder I know I should if we d caught one of them rascals

children.name: Paragraph_30
children.value: As the other two were impressed with a similar presentiment; and as their blood, like his, had all gone down again; some speculation ensued upon the cause of this sudden change in their temperament.
children.prevalue: As the other two were impressed with a similar presentiment and as their blood like his had all gone down again some speculation ensued upon the cause of this sudden change in their temperament

children.name: Paragraph_31
children.value: 'I know what it was,' said Mr. Giles; 'it was the gate.'
children.prevalue: I know what it was said Mr Giles it was the gate

children.name: Paragraph_32
children.value: 'I shouldn't wonder if it was,' exclaimed Brittles, catching at the idea.
children.prevalue: I shouldn t wonder if it was exclaimed Brittles catching at the idea

children.name: Paragraph_33
children.value: 'You may depend upon it,' said Giles, 'that that gate stopped the flow of the excitement.  I felt all mine suddenly going away, as I was climbing over it.'
children.prevalue: You may depend upon it said Giles that that gate stopped the flow of the excitement I felt all mine suddenly going away as I was climbing over it

children.name: Paragraph_34
children.value: By a remarkable coincidence, the other two had been visited with the same unpleasant sensation at that precise moment.  It was quite obvious, therefore, that it was the gate; especially as there was no doubt regarding the time at which the change had taken place, because all three remembered that they had come in sight of the robbers at the instant of its occurance.
children.prevalue: By a remarkable coincidence the other two had been visited with the same unpleasant sensation at that precise moment It was quite obvious therefore that it was the gate especially as there was no doubt regarding the time at which the change had taken place because all three remembered that they had come in sight of the robbers at the instant of its occurance

children.name: Paragraph_35
children.value: This dialogue was held between the two men who had surprised the burglars, and a travelling tinker who had been sleeping in an outhouse, and who had been roused, together with his two mongrel curs, to join in the pursuit.  Mr. Giles acted in the double capacity of butler and steward to the old lady of the mansion; Brittles was a lad of all-work: who, having entered her service a mere child, was treated as a promising young boy still, though he was something past thirty.
children.prevalue: This dialogue was held between the two men who had surprised the burglars and a travelling tinker who had been sleeping in an outhouse and who had been roused together with his two mongrel curs to join in the pursuit Mr Giles acted in the double capacity of butler and steward to the old lady of the mansion Brittles was a lad of all work who having entered her service a mere child was treated as a promising young boy still though he was something past thirty

children.name: Paragraph_36
children.value: Encouraging each other with such converse as this; but, keeping very close together, notwithstanding, and looking apprehensively round, whenever a fresh gust rattled through the boughs; the three men hurried back to a tree, behind which they had left their lantern, lest its light should inform the thieves in what direction to fire.  Catching up the light, they made the best of their way home, at a good round trot; and long after their dusky forms had ceased to be discernible, the light might have been seen twinkling and dancing in the distance, like some exhalation of the damp and gloomy atmosphere through which it was swiftly borne.
children.prevalue: Encouraging each other with such converse as this but keeping very close together notwithstanding and looking apprehensively round whenever a fresh gust rattled through the boughs the three men hurried back to a tree behind which they had left their lantern lest its light should inform the thieves in what direction to fire Catching up the light they made the best of their way home at a good round trot and long after their dusky forms had ceased to be discernible the light might have been seen twinkling and dancing in the distance like some exhalation of the damp and gloomy atmosphere through which it was swiftly borne

children.name: Paragraph_37
children.value: The air grew colder, as day came slowly on; and the mist rolled along the ground like a dense cloud of smoke.  The grass was wet; the pathways, and low places, were all mire and water; the damp breath of an unwholesome wind went languidly by, with a hollow moaning.  Still, Oliver lay motionless and insensible on the spot where Sikes had left him.
children.prevalue: The air grew colder as day came slowly on and the mist rolled along the ground like a dense cloud of smoke The grass was wet the pathways and low places were all mire and water the damp breath of an unwholesome wind went languidly by with a hollow moaning Still Oliver lay motionless and insensible on the spot where Sikes had left him

children.name: Paragraph_38
children.value: Morning drew on apace.  The air become more sharp and piercing, as its first dull hue--the death of night, rather than the birth of day--glimmered faintly in the sky.  The objects which had looked dim and terrible in the darkness, grew more and more defined, and gradually resolved into their familiar shapes.  The rain came down, thick and fast, and pattered noisily among the leafless bushes.  But, Oliver felt it not, as it beat against him; for he still lay stretched, helpless and unconscious, on his bed of clay.
children.prevalue: Morning drew on apace The air become more sharp and piercing as its first dull hue the death of night rather than the birth of day glimmered faintly in the sky The objects which had looked dim and terrible in the darkness grew more and more defined and gradually resolved into their familiar shapes The rain came down thick and fast and pattered noisily among the leafless bushes But Oliver felt it not as it beat against him for he still lay stretched helpless and unconscious on his bed of clay

children.name: Paragraph_39
children.value: At length, a low cry of pain broke the stillness that prevailed; and uttering it, the boy awoke.  His left arm, rudely bandaged in a shawl, hung heavy and useless at his side; the bandage was saturated with blood.  He was so weak, that he could scarcely raise himself into a sitting posture; when he had done so, he looked feebly round for help, and groaned with pain.  Trembling in every joint, from cold and exhaustion, he made an effort to stand upright; but, shuddering from head to foot, fell prostrate on the ground.
children.prevalue: At length a low cry of pain broke the stillness that prevailed and uttering it the boy awoke His left arm rudely bandaged in a shawl hung heavy and useless at his side the bandage was saturated with blood He was so weak that he could scarcely raise himself into a sitting posture when he had done so he looked feebly round for help and groaned with pain Trembling in every joint from cold and exhaustion he made an effort to stand upright but shuddering from head to foot fell prostrate on the ground

children.name: Paragraph_40
children.value: After a short return of the stupor in which he had been so long plunged, Oliver:  urged by a creeping sickness at his heart, which seemed to warn him that if he lay there, he must surely die:  got upon his feet, and essayed to walk. His head was dizzy, and he staggered to and fro like a drunken man.  But he kept up, nevertheless, and, with his head drooping languidly on his breast, went stumbling onward, he knew not whither.
children.prevalue: After a short return of the stupor in which he had been so long plunged Oliver urged by a creeping sickness at his heart which seemed to warn him that if he lay there he must surely die got upon his feet and essayed to walk His head was dizzy and he staggered to and fro like a drunken man But he kept up nevertheless and with his head drooping languidly on his breast went stumbling onward he knew not whither

children.name: Paragraph_41
children.value: And now, hosts of bewildering and confused ideas came crowding on his mind.  He seemed to be still walking between Sikes and Crackit, who were angrily disputing--for the very words they said, sounded in his ears; and when he caught his own attention, as it were, by making some violent effort to save himself from falling, he found that he was talking to them. Then, he was alone with Sikes, plodding on as on the previous day; and as shadowy people passed them, he felt the robber's grasp upon his wrist. Suddenly, he started back at the report of firearms; there rose into the air, loud cries and shouts; lights gleamed before his eyes; all was noise and tumult, as some unseen hand bore him hurriedly away.  Through all these rapid visions, there ran an undefined, uneasy consciousness of pain, which wearied and tormented him incessantly.
children.prevalue: And now hosts of bewildering and confused ideas came crowding on his mind He seemed to be still walking between Sikes and Crackit who were angrily disputing for the very words they said sounded in his ears and when he caught his own attention as it were by making some violent effort to save himself from falling he found that he was talking to them Then he was alone with Sikes plodding on as on the previous day and as shadowy people passed them he felt the robber s grasp upon his wrist Suddenly he started back at the report of firearms there rose into the air loud cries and shouts lights gleamed before his eyes all was noise and tumult as some unseen hand bore him hurriedly away Through all these rapid visions there ran an undefined uneasy consciousness of pain which wearied and tormented him incessantly

children.name: Paragraph_42
children.value: Thus he staggered on, creeping, almost mechanically, between the bars of gates, or through hedge-gaps as they came in his way, until he reached a road.  Here the rain began to fall so heavily, that it roused him.
children.prevalue: Thus he staggered on creeping almost mechanically between the bars of gates or through hedge gaps as they came in his way until he reached a road Here the rain began to fall so heavily that it roused him

children.name: Paragraph_43
children.value: He looked about, and saw that at no great distance there was a house, which perhaps he could reach.  Pitying his condition, they might have compassion on him; and if they did not, it would be better, he thought, to die near human beings, than in the lonely open fields.  He summoned up all his strength for one last trial, and bent his faltering steps towards it.
children.prevalue: He looked about and saw that at no great distance there was a house which perhaps he could reach Pitying his condition they might have compassion on him and if they did not it would be better he thought to die near human beings than in the lonely open fields He summoned up all his strength for one last trial and bent his faltering steps towards it

children.name: Paragraph_44
children.value: As he drew nearer to this house, a feeling come over him that he had seen it before.  He remembered nothing of its details; but the shape and aspect of the building seemed familiar to him.
children.prevalue: As he drew nearer to this house a feeling come over him that he had seen it before He remembered nothing of its details but the shape and aspect of the building seemed familiar to him

children.name: Paragraph_45
children.value: That garden wall!  On the grass inside, he had fallen on his knees last night, and prayed the two men's mercy.  It was the very house they had attempted to rob.
children.prevalue: That garden wall On the grass inside he had fallen on his knees last night and prayed the two men s mercy It was the very house they had attempted to rob

children.name: Paragraph_46
children.value: Oliver felt such fear come over him when he recognised the place, that, for the instant, he forgot the agony of his wound, and thought only of flight.  Flight!  He could scarcely stand:  and if he were in full possession of all the best powers of his slight and youthful frame, whither could he fly?  He pushed against the garden-gate; it was unlocked, and swung open on its hinges.  He tottered across the lawn; climbed the steps; knocked faintly at the door; and, his whole strength failing him, sunk down against one of the pillars of the little portico.
children.prevalue: Oliver felt such fear come over him when he recognised the place that for the instant he forgot the agony of his wound and thought only of flight Flight He could scarcely stand and if he were in full possession of all the best powers of his slight and youthful frame whither could he fly He pushed against the garden gate it was unlocked and swung open on its hinges He tottered across the lawn climbed the steps knocked faintly at the door and his whole strength failing him sunk down against one of the pillars of the little portico

children.name: Paragraph_47
children.value: It happened that about this time, Mr. Giles, Brittles, and the tinker, were recruiting themselves, after the fatigues and terrors of the night, with tea and sundries, in the kitchen.  Not that it was Mr. Giles's habit to admit to too great familiarity the humbler servants: towards whom it was rather his wont to deport himself with a lofty affability, which, while it gratified, could not fail to remind them of his superior position in society.  But, death, fires, and burglary, make all men equals; so Mr. Giles sat with his legs stretched out before the kitchen fender, leaning his left arm on the table, while, with his right, he illustrated a circumstantial and minute account of the robbery, to which his bearers (but especially the cook and housemaid, who were of the party) listened with breathless interest.
children.prevalue: It happened that about this time Mr Giles Brittles and the tinker were recruiting themselves after the fatigues and terrors of the night with tea and sundries in the kitchen Not that it was Mr Giles s habit to admit to too great familiarity the humbler servants towards whom it was rather his wont to deport himself with a lofty affability which while it gratified could not fail to remind them of his superior position in society But death fires and burglary make all men equals so Mr Giles sat with his legs stretched out before the kitchen fender leaning his left arm on the table while with his right he illustrated a circumstantial and minute account of the robbery to which his bearers but especially the cook and housemaid who were of the party listened with breathless interest

children.name: Paragraph_48
children.value: 'It was about half-past two,' said Mr. Giles, 'or I wouldn't swear that it mightn't have been a little nearer three, when I woke up, and, turning round in my bed, as it might be so, (here Mr. Giles turned round in his chair, and pulled the corner of the table-cloth over him to imitate bed-clothes,) I fancied I heerd a noise.'
children.prevalue: It was about half past two said Mr Giles or I wouldn t swear that it mightn t have been a little nearer three when I woke up and turning round in my bed as it might be so here Mr Giles turned round in his chair and pulled the corner of the table cloth over him to imitate bed clothes I fancied I heerd a noise

children.name: Paragraph_49
children.value: At this point of the narrative the cook turned pale, and asked the housemaid to shut the door: who asked Brittles, who asked the tinker, who pretended not to hear.
children.prevalue: At this point of the narrative the cook turned pale and asked the housemaid to shut the door who asked Brittles who asked the tinker who pretended not to hear

children.name: Paragraph_50
children.value: '--Heerd a noise,' continued Mr. Giles.  'I says, at first, This is illusion; and was composing myself off to sleep, when I heerd the noise again, distinct.'
children.prevalue: Heerd a noise continued Mr Giles I says at first This is illusion and was composing myself off to sleep when I heerd the noise again distinct

children.name: Paragraph_51
children.value: 'What sort of a noise?' asked the cook.
children.prevalue: What sort of a noise asked the cook

children.name: Paragraph_52
children.value: 'A kind of a busting noise,' replied Mr. Giles, looking round him.
children.prevalue: A kind of a busting noise replied Mr Giles looking round him

children.name: Paragraph_53
children.value: 'More like the noise of powdering a iron bar on a nutmeg-grater,' suggested Brittles.
children.prevalue: More like the noise of powdering a iron bar on a nutmeg grater suggested Brittles

children.name: Paragraph_54
children.value: 'It was, when you heerd it, sir,' rejoined Mr. Giles; 'but, at this time, it had a busting sound.  I turned down the clothes'; continued Giles, rolling back the table-cloth, 'sat up in bed; and listened.'
children.prevalue: It was when you heerd it sir rejoined Mr Giles but at this time it had a busting sound I turned down the clothes continued Giles rolling back the table cloth sat up in bed and listened

children.name: Paragraph_55
children.value: The cook and housemaid simultaneously ejaculated 'Lor!' and drew their chairs closer together.
children.prevalue: The cook and housemaid simultaneously ejaculated Lor and drew their chairs closer together

children.name: Paragraph_56
children.value: 'I heerd it now, quite apparent,' resumed Mr. Giles. 'Somebody, I says, is forcing of a door, or window; what's to be done? I'll call up that poor lad, Brittles, and save him from being murdered in his bed; or his throat, I says, may be cut from his right ear to his left, without his ever knowing it.'
children.prevalue: I heerd it now quite apparent resumed Mr Giles Somebody I says is forcing of a door or window what s to be done I ll call up that poor lad Brittles and save him from being murdered in his bed or his throat I says may be cut from his right ear to his left without his ever knowing it

children.name: Paragraph_57
children.value: Here, all eyes were turned upon Brittles, who fixed his upon the speaker, and stared at him, with his mouth wide open, and his face expressive of the most unmitigated horror.
children.prevalue: Here all eyes were turned upon Brittles who fixed his upon the speaker and stared at him with his mouth wide open and his face expressive of the most unmitigated horror

children.name: Paragraph_58
children.value: 'I tossed off the clothes,' said Giles, throwing away the table-cloth, and looking very hard at the cook and housemaid, 'got softly out of bed; drew on a pair of--'
children.prevalue: I tossed off the clothes said Giles throwing away the table cloth and looking very hard at the cook and housemaid got softly out of bed drew on a pair of

children.name: Paragraph_59
children.value: 'Ladies present, Mr. Giles,' murmured the tinker.
children.prevalue: Ladies present Mr Giles murmured the tinker

children.name: Paragraph_60
children.value: '--Of shoes, sir,' said Giles, turning upon him, and laying great emphasis on the word; 'seized the loaded pistol that always goes upstairs with the plate-basket; and walked on tiptoes to his room. Brittles, I says, when I had woke him, don't be frightened!'
children.prevalue: Of shoes sir said Giles turning upon him and laying great emphasis on the word seized the loaded pistol that always goes upstairs with the plate basket and walked on tiptoes to his room Brittles I says when I had woke him don t be frightened

children.name: Paragraph_61
children.value: 'So you did,' observed Brittles, in a low voice.
children.prevalue: So you did observed Brittles in a low voice

children.name: Paragraph_62
children.value: 'We're dead men, I think, Brittles, I says,' continued Giles; 'but don't be frightened.'
children.prevalue: We re dead men I think Brittles I says continued Giles but don t be frightened

children.name: Paragraph_63
children.value: 'Was he frightened?' asked the cook.
children.prevalue: Was he frightened asked the cook

children.name: Paragraph_64
children.value: 'Not a bit of it,' replied Mr. Giles.  'He was as firm--ah! pretty near as firm as I was.'
children.prevalue: Not a bit of it replied Mr Giles He was as firm ah pretty near as firm as I was

children.name: Paragraph_65
children.value: 'I should have died at once, I'm sure, if it had been me,' observed the housemaid.
children.prevalue: I should have died at once I m sure if it had been me observed the housemaid

children.name: Paragraph_66
children.value: 'You're a woman,' retorted Brittles, plucking up a little.
children.prevalue: You re a woman retorted Brittles plucking up a little

children.name: Paragraph_67
children.value: 'Brittles is right,' said Mr. Giles, nodding his head, approvingly; 'from a woman, nothing else was to be expected. We, being men, took a dark lantern that was standing on Brittle's hob, and groped our way downstairs in the pitch dark,--as it might be so.'
children.prevalue: Brittles is right said Mr Giles nodding his head approvingly from a woman nothing else was to be expected We being men took a dark lantern that was standing on Brittle s hob and groped our way downstairs in the pitch dark as it might be so

children.name: Paragraph_68
children.value: Mr. Giles had risen from his seat, and taken two steps with his eyes shut, to accompany his description with appropriate action, when he started violently, in common with the rest of the company, and hurried back to his chair.  The cook and housemaid screamed.
children.prevalue: Mr Giles had risen from his seat and taken two steps with his eyes shut to accompany his description with appropriate action when he started violently in common with the rest of the company and hurried back to his chair The cook and housemaid screamed

children.name: Paragraph_69
children.value: 'It was a knock,' said Mr. Giles, assuming perfect serenity. 'Open the door, somebody.'
children.prevalue: It was a knock said Mr Giles assuming perfect serenity Open the door somebody

children.name: Paragraph_70
children.value: Nobody moved.
children.prevalue: Nobody moved

children.name: Paragraph_71
children.value: 'It seems a strange sort of a thing, a knock coming at such a time in the morning,' said Mr. Giles, surveying the pale faces which surrounded him, and looking very blank himself; 'but the door must be opened.  Do you hear, somebody?'
children.prevalue: It seems a strange sort of a thing a knock coming at such a time in the morning said Mr Giles surveying the pale faces which surrounded him and looking very blank himself but the door must be opened Do you hear somebody

children.name: Paragraph_72
children.value: Mr. Giles, as he spoke, looked at Brittles; but that young man, being naturally modest, probably considered himself nobody, and so held that the inquiry could not have any application to him; at all events, he tendered no reply. Mr. Giles directed an appealing glance at the tinker; but he had suddenly fallen asleep.  The women were out of the question.
children.prevalue: Mr Giles as he spoke looked at Brittles but that young man being naturally modest probably considered himself nobody and so held that the inquiry could not have any application to him at all events he tendered no reply Mr Giles directed an appealing glance at the tinker but he had suddenly fallen asleep The women were out of the question

children.name: Paragraph_73
children.value: 'If Brittles would rather open the door, in the presence of witnesses,' said Mr. Giles, after a short silence, 'I am ready to make one.'
children.prevalue: If Brittles would rather open the door in the presence of witnesses said Mr Giles after a short silence I am ready to make one

children.name: Paragraph_74
children.value: 'So am I,' said the tinker, waking up, as suddenly as he had fallen asleep.
children.prevalue: So am I said the tinker waking up as suddenly as he had fallen asleep

children.name: Paragraph_75
children.value: Brittles capitulated on these terms; and the party being somewhat re-assured by the discovery (made on throwing open the shutters) that it was now broad day, took their way upstairs; with the dogs in front. The two women, who were afraid to stay below, brought up the rear.  By the advice of Mr. Giles, they all talked very loud, to warn any evil-disposed person outside, that they were strong in numbers; and by a master-stoke of policy, originating in the brain of the same ingenious gentleman, the dogs' tails were well pinched, in the hall, to make them bark savagely.
children.prevalue: Brittles capitulated on these terms and the party being somewhat re assured by the discovery made on throwing open the shutters that it was now broad day took their way upstairs with the dogs in front The two women who were afraid to stay below brought up the rear By the advice of Mr Giles they all talked very loud to warn any evil disposed person outside that they were strong in numbers and by a master stoke of policy originating in the brain of the same ingenious gentleman the dogs tails were well pinched in the hall to make them bark savagely

children.name: Paragraph_76
children.value: These precautions having been taken, Mr. Giles held on fast by the tinker's arm (to prevent his running away, as he pleasantly said), and gave the word of command to open the door.  Brittles obeyed; the group, peeping timorously over each other's shoulders, beheld no more formidable object than poor little Oliver Twist, speechless and exhausted, who raised his heavy eyes, and mutely solicited their compassion.
children.prevalue: These precautions having been taken Mr Giles held on fast by the tinker s arm to prevent his running away as he pleasantly said and gave the word of command to open the door Brittles obeyed the group peeping timorously over each other s shoulders beheld no more formidable object than poor little Oliver Twist speechless and exhausted who raised his heavy eyes and mutely solicited their compassion

children.name: Paragraph_77
children.value: 'A boy!' exclaimed Mr. Giles, valiantly, pushing the tinker into the background.  'What's the matter with the--eh?--Why--Brittles--look here--don't you know?'
children.prevalue: A boy exclaimed Mr Giles valiantly pushing the tinker into the background What s the matter with the eh Why Brittles look here don t you know

children.name: Paragraph_78
children.value: Brittles, who had got behind the door to open it, no sooner saw Oliver, than he uttered a loud cry.  Mr. Giles, seizing the boy by one leg and one arm (fortunately not the broken limb) lugged him straight into the hall, and deposited him at full length on the floor thereof.
children.prevalue: Brittles who had got behind the door to open it no sooner saw Oliver than he uttered a loud cry Mr Giles seizing the boy by one leg and one arm fortunately not the broken limb lugged him straight into the hall and deposited him at full length on the floor thereof

children.name: Paragraph_79
children.value: 'Here he is!' bawled Giles, calling in a state of great excitement, up the staircase; 'here's one of the thieves, ma'am! Here's a thief, miss! Wounded, miss!  I shot him, miss; and Brittles held the light.'
children.prevalue: Here he is bawled Giles calling in a state of great excitement up the staircase here s one of the thieves ma am Here s a thief miss Wounded miss I shot him miss and Brittles held the light

children.name: Paragraph_80
children.value: '--In a lantern, miss,' cried Brittles, applying one hand to the side of his mouth, so that his voice might travel the better.
children.prevalue: In a lantern miss cried Brittles applying one hand to the side of his mouth so that his voice might travel the better

children.name: Paragraph_81
children.value: The two women-servants ran upstairs to carry the intelligence that Mr. Giles had captured a robber; and the tinker busied himself in endeavouring to restore Oliver, lest he should die before he could be hanged.  In the midst of all this noise and commotion, there was heard a sweet female voice, which quelled it in an instant.
children.prevalue: The two women servants ran upstairs to carry the intelligence that Mr Giles had captured a robber and the tinker busied himself in endeavouring to restore Oliver lest he should die before he could be hanged In the midst of all this noise and commotion there was heard a sweet female voice which quelled it in an instant

children.name: Paragraph_82
children.value: 'Giles!' whispered the voice from the stair-head.
children.prevalue: Giles whispered the voice from the stair head

children.name: Paragraph_83
children.value: 'I'm here, miss,' replied Mr. Giles.  'Don't be frightened, miss; I ain't much injured.  He didn't make a very desperate resistance, miss! I was soon too many for him.'
children.prevalue: I m here miss replied Mr Giles Don t be frightened miss I ain t much injured He didn t make a very desperate resistance miss I was soon too many for him

children.name: Paragraph_84
children.value: 'Hush!' replied the young lady; 'you frighten my aunt as much as the thieves did.  Is the poor creature much hurt?'
children.prevalue: Hush replied the young lady you frighten my aunt as much as the thieves did Is the poor creature much hurt

children.name: Paragraph_85
children.value: 'Wounded desperate, miss,' replied Giles, with indescribable complacency.
children.prevalue: Wounded desperate miss replied Giles with indescribable complacency

children.name: Paragraph_86
children.value: 'He looks as if he was a-going, miss,' bawled Brittles, in the same manner as before.  'Wouldn't you like to come and look at him, miss, in case he should?'
children.prevalue: He looks as if he was a going miss bawled Brittles in the same manner as before Wouldn t you like to come and look at him miss in case he should

children.name: Paragraph_87

children.prevalue: Hush pray there s a good man rejoined the lady Wait quietly only one instant while I speak to aunt

children.name: Paragraph_88
children.value: With a footstep as soft and gentle as the voice, the speaker tripped away.  She soon returned, with the direction that the wounded person was to be carried, carefully, upstairs to Mr. Giles's room; and that Brittles was to saddle the pony and betake himself instantly to Chertsey:  from which place, he was to despatch, with all speed, a constable and doctor.
children.prevalue: With a footstep as soft and gentle as the voice the speaker tripped away She soon returned with the direction that the wounded person was to be carried carefully upstairs to Mr Giles s room and that Brittles was to saddle the pony and betake himself instantly to Chertsey from which place he was to despatch with all speed a constable and doctor

children.name: Paragraph_89
children.value: 'But won't you take one look at him, first, miss?' asked Mr. Giles, with as much pride as if Oliver were some bird of rare plumage, that he had skilfully brought down.  'Not one little peep, miss?'
children.prevalue: But won t you take one look at him first miss asked Mr Giles with as much pride as if Oliver were some bird of rare plumage that he had skilfully brought down Not one little peep miss

children.name: Paragraph_91
children.value: The old servant looked up at the speaker, as she turned away, with a glance as proud and admiring as if she had been his own child.  Then, bending over Oliver, he helped to carry him upstairs, with the care and solicitude of a woman.

children.name: Paragraph_1
children.value: HAS AN INTRODUCTORY ACCOUNT OF THE INMATES OF THE HOUSE, TO WHICH OLIVER RESORTED
children.prevalue: HAS AN INTRODUCTORY ACCOUNT OF THE INMATES OF THE HOUSE TO WHICH OLIVER RESORTED

children.name: Paragraph_2
children.value: In a handsome room:  though its furniture had rather the air of old-fashioned comfort, than of modern elegance:  there sat two ladies at a well-spread breakfast-table.  Mr. Giles, dressed with scrupulous care in a full suit of black, was in attendance upon them.  He had taken his station some half-way between the side-board and the breakfast-table; and, with his body drawn up to its full height, his head thrown back, and inclined the merest trifle on one side, his left leg advanced, and his right hand thrust into his waist-coat, while his left hung down by his side, grasping a waiter, looked like one who laboured under a very agreeable sense of his own merits and importance.
children.prevalue: In a handsome room though its furniture had rather the air of old fashioned comfort than of modern elegance there sat two ladies at a well spread breakfast table Mr Giles dressed with scrupulous care in a full suit of black was in attendance upon them He had taken his station some half way between the side board and the breakfast table and with his body drawn up to its full height his head thrown back and inclined the merest trifle on one side his left leg advanced and his right hand thrust into his waist coat while his left hung down by his side grasping a waiter looked like one who laboured under a very agreeable sense of his own merits and importance

children.name: Paragraph_3
children.value: Of the two ladies, one was well advanced in years; but the high-backed oaken chair in which she sat, was not more upright than she.  Dressed with the utmost nicety and precision, in a quaint mixture of by-gone costume, with some slight concessions to the prevailing taste, which rather served to point the old style pleasantly than to impair its effect, she sat, in a stately manner, with her hands folded on the table before her.  Her eyes (and age had dimmed but little of their brightness) were attentively upon her young companion.
children.prevalue: Of the two ladies one was well advanced in years but the high backed oaken chair in which she sat was not more upright than she Dressed with the utmost nicety and precision in a quaint mixture of by gone costume with some slight concessions to the prevailing taste which rather served to point the old style pleasantly than to impair its effect she sat in a stately manner with her hands folded on the table before her Her eyes and age had dimmed but little of their brightness were attentively upon her young companion

children.name: Paragraph_4
children.value: The younger lady was in the lovely bloom and spring-time of womanhood; at that age, when, if ever angels be for God's good purposes enthroned in mortal forms, they may be, without impiety, supposed to abide in such as hers.
children.prevalue: The younger lady was in the lovely bloom and spring time of womanhood at that age when if ever angels be for God s good purposes enthroned in mortal forms they may be without impiety supposed to abide in such as hers

children.name: Paragraph_5
children.value: She was not past seventeen.  Cast in so slight and exquisite a mould; so mild and gentle; so pure and beautiful; that earth seemed not her element, nor its rough creatures her fit companions.  The very intelligence that shone in her deep blue eye, and was stamped upon her noble head, seemed scarcely of her age, or of the world; and yet the changing expression of sweetness and good humour, the thousand lights that played about the face, and left no shadow there; above all, the smile, the cheerful, happy smile, were made for Home, and fireside peace and happiness.
children.prevalue: She was not past seventeen Cast in so slight and exquisite a mould so mild and gentle so pure and beautiful that earth seemed not her element nor its rough creatures her fit companions The very intelligence that shone in her deep blue eye and was stamped upon her noble head seemed scarcely of her age or of the world and yet the changing expression of sweetness and good humour the thousand lights that played about the face and left no shadow there above all the smile the cheerful happy smile were made for Home and fireside peace and happiness

children.name: Paragraph_6
children.value: She was busily engaged in the little offices of the table. Chancing to raise her eyes as the elder lady was regarding her, she playfully put back her hair, which was simply braided on her forehead; and threw into her beaming look, such an expression of affection and artless loveliness, that blessed spirits might have smiled to look upon her.
children.prevalue: She was busily engaged in the little offices of the table Chancing to raise her eyes as the elder lady was regarding her she playfully put back her hair which was simply braided on her forehead and threw into her beaming look such an expression of affection and artless loveliness that blessed spirits might have smiled to look upon her

children.name: Paragraph_7
children.value: 'And Brittles has been gone upwards of an hour, has he?' asked the old lady, after a pause.
children.prevalue: And Brittles has been gone upwards of an hour has he asked the old lady after a pause

children.name: Paragraph_8
children.value: 'An hour and twelve minutes, ma'am,' replied Mr. Giles, referring to a silver watch, which he drew forth by a black ribbon.
children.prevalue: An hour and twelve minutes ma am replied Mr Giles referring to a silver watch which he drew forth by a black ribbon

children.name: Paragraph_9
children.value: 'He is always slow,' remarked the old lady.
children.prevalue: He is always slow remarked the old lady

children.name: Paragraph_10
children.value: 'Brittles always was a slow boy, ma'am,' replied the attendant. And seeing, by the bye, that Brittles had been a slow boy for upwards of thirty years, there appeared no great probability of his ever being a fast one.
children.prevalue: Brittles always was a slow boy ma am replied the attendant And seeing by the bye that Brittles had been a slow boy for upwards of thirty years there appeared no great probability of his ever being a fast one

children.name: Paragraph_11
children.value: 'He gets worse instead of better, I think,' said the elder lady.
children.prevalue: He gets worse instead of better I think said the elder lady

children.name: Paragraph_12
children.value: 'It is very inexcusable in him if he stops to play with any other boys,' said the young lady, smiling.
children.prevalue: It is very inexcusable in him if he stops to play with any other boys said the young lady smiling

children.name: Paragraph_13
children.value: Mr. Giles was apparently considering the propriety of indulging in a respectful smile himself, when a gig drove up to the garden-gate: out of which there jumped a fat gentleman, who ran straight up to the door: and who, getting quickly into the house by some mysterious process, burst into the room, and nearly overturned Mr. Giles and the breakfast-table together.
children.prevalue: Mr Giles was apparently considering the propriety of indulging in a respectful smile himself when a gig drove up to the garden gate out of which there jumped a fat gentleman who ran straight up to the door and who getting quickly into the house by some mysterious process burst into the room and nearly overturned Mr Giles and the breakfast table together

children.name: Paragraph_14
children.value: 'I never heard of such a thing!' exclaimed the fat gentleman. 'My dear Mrs. Maylie--bless my soul--in the silence of the night, too--I never heard of such a thing!'
children.prevalue: I never heard of such a thing exclaimed the fat gentleman My dear Mrs Maylie bless my soul in the silence of the night too I never heard of such a thing

children.name: Paragraph_15
children.value: With these expressions of condolence, the fat gentleman shook hands with both ladies, and drawing up a chair, inquired how they found themselves.
children.prevalue: With these expressions of condolence the fat gentleman shook hands with both ladies and drawing up a chair inquired how they found themselves

children.name: Paragraph_16
children.value: 'You ought to be dead; positively dead with the fright,' said the fat gentleman.  'Why didn't you send?  Bless me, my man should have come in a minute; and so would I; and my assistant would have been delighted; or anybody, I'm sure, under such circumstances.  Dear, dear!  So unexpected!  In the silence of the night, too!'

children.name: Paragraph_17
children.value: The doctor seemed expecially troubled by the fact of the robbery having been unexpected, and attempted in the night-time; as if it were the established custom of gentlemen in the housebreaking way to transact business at noon, and to make an appointment, by post, a day or two previous.

children.name: Paragraph_18
children.value: 'And you, Miss Rose,' said the doctor, turning to the young lady, 'I--'

children.name: Paragraph_20

children.name: Paragraph_21
children.value: Mr. Giles, who had been feverishly putting the tea-cups to rights, blushed very red, and said that he had had that honour.

children.name: Paragraph_22
children.value: 'Honour, eh?' said the doctor; 'well, I don't know; perhaps it's as honourable to hit a thief in a back kitchen, as to hit your man at twelve paces.  Fancy that he fired in the air, and you've fought a duel, Giles.'
children.prevalue: Honour eh said the doctor well I don t know perhaps it s as honourable to hit a thief in a back kitchen as to hit your man at twelve paces Fancy that he fired in the air and you ve fought a duel Giles

children.name: Paragraph_23

children.name: Paragraph_25
children.value: Talking all the way, he followed Mr. Giles upstairs; and while he is going upstairs, the reader may be informed, that Mr. Losberne, a surgeon in the neighbourhood, known through a circuit of ten miles round as 'the doctor,' had grown fat, more from good-humour than from good living:  and was as kind and hearty, and withal as eccentric an old bachelor, as will be found in five times that space, by any explorer alive.

children.name: Paragraph_26
children.value: The doctor was absent, much longer than either he or the ladies had anticipated.  A large flat box was fetched out of the gig; and a bedroom bell was rung very often; and the servants ran up and down stairs perpetually; from which tokens it was justly concluded that something important was going on above.  At length he returned; and in reply to an anxious inquiry after his patient; looked very mysterious, and closed the door, carefully.

children.value: The fact was, that Mr. Giles had not, at first, been able to bring his mind to the avowal, that he had only shot a boy.  Such commendations had been bestowed upon his bravery, that he could not, for the life of him, help postponing the explanation for a few delicious minutes; during which he had flourished, in the very zenith of a brief reputation for undaunted courage.
