children.name: Paragraph_2
children.value: With many loquacious assurances that they would be agreeably surprised in the aspect of the criminal, the doctor drew the young lady's arm through one of his; and offering his disengaged hand to Mrs. Maylie, led them, with much ceremony and stateliness, upstairs.
children.prevalue: With many loquacious assurances that they would be agreeably surprised in the aspect of the criminal the doctor drew the young lady s arm through one of his and offering his disengaged hand to Mrs Maylie led them with much ceremony and stateliness upstairs

children.name: Paragraph_3
children.value: 'Now,' said the doctor, in a whisper, as he softly turned the handle of a bedroom-door, 'let us hear what you think of him.  He has not been shaved very recently, but he don't look at all ferocious notwithstanding.  Stop, though!  Let me first see that he is in visiting order.'
children.prevalue: Now said the doctor in a whisper as he softly turned the handle of a bedroom door let us hear what you think of him He has not been shaved very recently but he don t look at all ferocious notwithstanding Stop though Let me first see that he is in visiting order

children.name: Paragraph_4
children.value: Stepping before them, he looked into the room.  Motioning them to advance, he closed the door when they had entered; and gently drew back the curtains of the bed.  Upon it, in lieu of the dogged, black-visaged ruffian they had expected to behold, there lay a mere child:  worn with pain and exhaustion, and sunk into a deep sleep.  His wounded arm, bound and splintered up, was crossed upon his breast; his head reclined upon the other arm, which was half hidden by his long hair, as it streamed over the pillow.
children.prevalue: Stepping before them he looked into the room Motioning them to advance he closed the door when they had entered and gently drew back the curtains of the bed Upon it in lieu of the dogged black visaged ruffian they had expected to behold there lay a mere child worn with pain and exhaustion and sunk into a deep sleep His wounded arm bound and splintered up was crossed upon his breast his head reclined upon the other arm which was half hidden by his long hair as it streamed over the pillow

children.name: Paragraph_5
children.value: The honest gentleman held the curtain in his hand, and looked on, for a minute or so, in silence.  Whilst he was watching the patient thus, the younger lady glided softly past, and seating herself in a chair by the bedside, gathered Oliver's hair from his face.  As she stooped over him, her tears fell upon his forehead.
children.prevalue: The honest gentleman held the curtain in his hand and looked on for a minute or so in silence Whilst he was watching the patient thus the younger lady glided softly past and seating herself in a chair by the bedside gathered Oliver s hair from his face As she stooped over him her tears fell upon his forehead

children.name: Paragraph_6
children.value: The boy stirred, and smiled in his sleep, as though these marks of pity and compassion had awakened some pleasant dream of a love and affection he had never known.  Thus, a strain of gentle music, or the rippling of water in a silent place, or the odour of a flower, or the mention of a familiar word, will sometimes call up sudden dim remembrances of scenes that never were, in this life; which vanish like a breath; which some brief memory of a happier existence, long gone by, would seem to have awakened; which no voluntary exertion of the mind can ever recall.
children.prevalue: The boy stirred and smiled in his sleep as though these marks of pity and compassion had awakened some pleasant dream of a love and affection he had never known Thus a strain of gentle music or the rippling of water in a silent place or the odour of a flower or the mention of a familiar word will sometimes call up sudden dim remembrances of scenes that never were in this life which vanish like a breath which some brief memory of a happier existence long gone by would seem to have awakened which no voluntary exertion of the mind can ever recall

children.name: Paragraph_7
children.value: 'What can this mean?' exclaimed the elder lady.  'This poor child can never have been the pupil of robbers!'
children.prevalue: What can this mean exclaimed the elder lady This poor child can never have been the pupil of robbers

children.name: Paragraph_8
children.value: 'Vice,' said the surgeon, replacing the curtain, 'takes up her abode in many temples; and who can say that a fair outside shell not enshrine her?'
children.prevalue: Vice said the surgeon replacing the curtain takes up her abode in many temples and who can say that a fair outside shell not enshrine her

children.name: Paragraph_9
children.value: 'But at so early an age!' urged Rose.
children.prevalue: But at so early an age urged Rose

children.name: Paragraph_10
children.value: 'My dear young lady,' rejoined the surgeon, mournfully shaking his head; 'crime, like death, is not confined to the old and withered alone.  The youngest and fairest are too often its chosen victims.'
children.prevalue: My dear young lady rejoined the surgeon mournfully shaking his head crime like death is not confined to the old and withered alone The youngest and fairest are too often its chosen victims

children.name: Paragraph_11
children.value: 'But, can you--oh! can you really believe that this delicate boy has been the voluntary associate of the worst outcasts of society?' said Rose.
children.prevalue: But can you oh can you really believe that this delicate boy has been the voluntary associate of the worst outcasts of society said Rose

children.name: Paragraph_12
children.value: The surgeon shook his head, in a manner which intimated that he feared it was very possible; and observing that they might disturb the patient, led the way into an adjoining apartment.
children.prevalue: The surgeon shook his head in a manner which intimated that he feared it was very possible and observing that they might disturb the patient led the way into an adjoining apartment

children.name: Paragraph_13
children.value: 'But even if he has been wicked,' pursued Rose, 'think how young he is; think that he may never have known a mother's love, or the comfort of a home; that ill-usage and blows, or the want of bread, may have driven him to herd with men who have forced him to guilt.  Aunt, dear aunt, for mercy's sake, think of this, before you let them drag this sick child to a prison, which in any case must be the grave of all his chances of amendment.  Oh! as you love me, and know that I have never felt the want of parents in your goodness and affection, but that I might have done so, and might have been equally helpless and unprotected with this poor child, have pity upon him before it is too late!'
children.prevalue: But even if he has been wicked pursued Rose think how young he is think that he may never have known a mother s love or the comfort of a home that ill usage and blows or the want of bread may have driven him to herd with men who have forced him to guilt Aunt dear aunt for mercy s sake think of this before you let them drag this sick child to a prison which in any case must be the grave of all his chances of amendment Oh as you love me and know that I have never felt the want of parents in your goodness and affection but that I might have done so and might have been equally helpless and unprotected with this poor child have pity upon him before it is too late

children.name: Paragraph_14
children.value: 'My dear love,' said the elder lady, as she folded the weeping girl to her bosom, 'do you think I would harm a hair of his head?'
children.prevalue: My dear love said the elder lady as she folded the weeping girl to her bosom do you think I would harm a hair of his head

children.name: Paragraph_15
children.value: 'Oh, no!' replied Rose, eagerly.
children.prevalue: Oh no replied Rose eagerly

children.name: Paragraph_16
children.value: 'No, surely,' said the old lady; 'my days are drawing to their close: and may mercy be shown to me as I show it to others! What can I do to save him, sir?'
children.prevalue: No surely said the old lady my days are drawing to their close and may mercy be shown to me as I show it to others What can I do to save him sir

children.name: Paragraph_17
children.value: 'Let me think, ma'am,' said the doctor; 'let me think.'
children.prevalue: Let me think ma am said the doctor let me think

children.name: Paragraph_18
children.value: Mr. Losberne thrust his hands into his pockets, and took several turns up and down the room; often stopping, and balancing himself on his toes, and frowning frightfully.  After various exclamations of 'I've got it now' and 'no, I haven't,' and as many renewals of the walking and frowning, he at length made a dead halt, and spoke as follows:
children.prevalue: Mr Losberne thrust his hands into his pockets and took several turns up and down the room often stopping and balancing himself on his toes and frowning frightfully After various exclamations of I ve got it now and no I haven t and as many renewals of the walking and frowning he at length made a dead halt and spoke as follows

children.name: Paragraph_19
children.value: 'I think if you give me a full and unlimited commission to bully Giles, and that little boy, Brittles, I can manage it.  Giles is a faithful fellow and an old servant, I know; but you can make it up to him in a thousand ways, and reward him for being such a good shot besides.  You don't object to that?'
children.prevalue: I think if you give me a full and unlimited commission to bully Giles and that little boy Brittles I can manage it Giles is a faithful fellow and an old servant I know but you can make it up to him in a thousand ways and reward him for being such a good shot besides You don t object to that

children.name: Paragraph_20
children.value: 'Unless there is some other way of preserving the child,' replied Mrs. Maylie.
children.prevalue: Unless there is some other way of preserving the child replied Mrs Maylie

children.name: Paragraph_21
children.value: 'There is no other,' said the doctor.  'No other, take my word for it.'
children.prevalue: There is no other said the doctor No other take my word for it

children.name: Paragraph_22
children.value: 'Then my aunt invests you with full power,' said Rose, smiling through her tears; 'but pray don't be harder upon the poor fellows than is indispensably necessary.'
children.prevalue: Then my aunt invests you with full power said Rose smiling through her tears but pray don t be harder upon the poor fellows than is indispensably necessary

children.name: Paragraph_23
children.value: 'You seem to think,' retorted the doctor, 'that everybody is disposed to be hard-hearted to-day, except yourself, Miss Rose. I only hope, for the sake of the rising male sex generally, that you may be found in as vulnerable and soft-hearted a mood by the first eligible young fellow who appeals to your compassion; and I wish I were a young fellow, that I might avail myself, on the spot, of such a favourable opportunity for doing so, as the present.'
children.prevalue: You seem to think retorted the doctor that everybody is disposed to be hard hearted to day except yourself Miss Rose I only hope for the sake of the rising male sex generally that you may be found in as vulnerable and soft hearted a mood by the first eligible young fellow who appeals to your compassion and I wish I were a young fellow that I might avail myself on the spot of such a favourable opportunity for doing so as the present

children.name: Paragraph_24
children.value: 'You are as great a boy as poor Brittles himself,' returned Rose, blushing.
children.prevalue: You are as great a boy as poor Brittles himself returned Rose blushing

children.name: Paragraph_25
children.value: 'Well,' said the doctor, laughing heartily, 'that is no very difficult matter.  But to return to this boy.  The great point of our agreement is yet to come.  He will wake in an hour or so, I dare say; and although I have told that thick-headed constable-fellow downstairs that he musn't be moved or spoken to, on peril of his life, I think we may converse with him without danger.  Now I make this stipulation--that I shall examine him in your presence, and that, if, from what he says, we judge, and I can show to the satisfaction of your cool reason, that he is a real and thorough bad one (which is more than possible), he shall be left to his fate, without any farther interference on my part, at all events.'
children.prevalue: Well said the doctor laughing heartily that is no very difficult matter But to return to this boy The great point of our agreement is yet to come He will wake in an hour or so I dare say and although I have told that thick headed constable fellow downstairs that he musn t be moved or spoken to on peril of his life I think we may converse with him without danger Now I make this stipulation that I shall examine him in your presence and that if from what he says we judge and I can show to the satisfaction of your cool reason that he is a real and thorough bad one which is more than possible he shall be left to his fate without any farther interference on my part at all events

children.name: Paragraph_26
children.value: 'Oh no, aunt!' entreated Rose.
children.prevalue: Oh no aunt entreated Rose

children.name: Paragraph_27
children.value: 'Oh yes, aunt!' said the doctor.  'Is is a bargain?'
children.prevalue: Oh yes aunt said the doctor Is is a bargain

children.name: Paragraph_28
children.value: 'He cannot be hardened in vice,' said Rose; 'It is impossible.'
children.prevalue: He cannot be hardened in vice said Rose It is impossible

children.name: Paragraph_29
children.value: 'Very good,' retorted the doctor; 'then so much the more reason for acceding to my proposition.'
children.prevalue: Very good retorted the doctor then so much the more reason for acceding to my proposition

children.name: Paragraph_30
children.value: Finally the treaty was entered into; and the parties thereunto sat down to wait, with some impatience, until Oliver should awake.
children.prevalue: Finally the treaty was entered into and the parties thereunto sat down to wait with some impatience until Oliver should awake

children.name: Paragraph_31
children.value: The patience of the two ladies was destined to undergo a longer trial than Mr. Losberne had led them to expect; for hour after hour passed on, and still Oliver slumbered heavily.  It was evening, indeed, before the kind-hearted doctor brought them the intelligence, that he was at length sufficiently restored to be spoken to.  The boy was very ill, he said, and weak from the loss of blood; but his mind was so troubled with anxiety to disclose something, that he deemed it better to give him the opportunity, than to insist upon his remaining quiet until next morning: which he should otherwise have done.
children.prevalue: The patience of the two ladies was destined to undergo a longer trial than Mr Losberne had led them to expect for hour after hour passed on and still Oliver slumbered heavily It was evening indeed before the kind hearted doctor brought them the intelligence that he was at length sufficiently restored to be spoken to The boy was very ill he said and weak from the loss of blood but his mind was so troubled with anxiety to disclose something that he deemed it better to give him the opportunity than to insist upon his remaining quiet until next morning which he should otherwise have done

children.name: Paragraph_32
children.value: The conference was a long one.  Oliver told them all his simple history, and was often compelled to stop, by pain and want of strength. It was a solemn thing, to hear, in the darkened room, the feeble voice of the sick child recounting a weary catalogue of evils and calamities which hard men had brought upon him.  Oh! if when we oppress and grind our fellow-creatures, we bestowed but one thought on the dark evidences of human error, which, like dense and heavy clouds, are rising, slowly it is true, but not less surely, to Heaven, to pour their after-vengeance on our heads; if we heard but one instant, in imagination, the deep testimony of dead men's voices, which no power can stifle, and no pride shut out; where would be the injury and injustice, the suffering, misery, cruelty, and wrong, that each day's life brings with it!
children.prevalue: The conference was a long one Oliver told them all his simple history and was often compelled to stop by pain and want of strength It was a solemn thing to hear in the darkened room the feeble voice of the sick child recounting a weary catalogue of evils and calamities which hard men had brought upon him Oh if when we oppress and grind our fellow creatures we bestowed but one thought on the dark evidences of human error which like dense and heavy clouds are rising slowly it is true but not less surely to Heaven to pour their after vengeance on our heads if we heard but one instant in imagination the deep testimony of dead men s voices which no power can stifle and no pride shut out where would be the injury and injustice the suffering misery cruelty and wrong that each day s life brings with it

children.name: Paragraph_33
children.value: Oliver's pillow was smoothed by gentle hands that night; and loveliness and virtue watched him as he slept.  He felt calm and happy, and could have died without a murmur.
children.prevalue: Oliver s pillow was smoothed by gentle hands that night and loveliness and virtue watched him as he slept He felt calm and happy and could have died without a murmur

children.name: Paragraph_34
children.value: The momentous interview was no sooner concluded, and Oliver composed to rest again, than the doctor, after wiping his eyes, and condemning them for being weak all at once, betook himself downstairs to open upon Mr. Giles.  And finding nobody about the parlours, it occurred to him, that he could perhaps originate the proceedings with better effect in the kitchen; so into the kitchen he went.
children.prevalue: The momentous interview was no sooner concluded and Oliver composed to rest again than the doctor after wiping his eyes and condemning them for being weak all at once betook himself downstairs to open upon Mr Giles And finding nobody about the parlours it occurred to him that he could perhaps originate the proceedings with better effect in the kitchen so into the kitchen he went

children.name: Paragraph_35
children.value: There were assembled, in that lower house of the domestic parliament, the women-servants, Mr. Brittles, Mr. Giles, the tinker (who had received a special invitation to regale himself for the remainder of the day, in consideration of his services), and the constable.  The latter gentleman had a large staff, a large head, large features, and large half-boots; and he looked as if he had been taking a proportionate allowance of ale--as indeed he had.
children.prevalue: There were assembled in that lower house of the domestic parliament the women servants Mr Brittles Mr Giles the tinker who had received a special invitation to regale himself for the remainder of the day in consideration of his services and the constable The latter gentleman had a large staff a large head large features and large half boots and he looked as if he had been taking a proportionate allowance of ale as indeed he had

children.name: Paragraph_36
children.value: The adventures of the previous night were still under discussion; for Mr. Giles was expatiating upon his presence of mind, when the doctor entered; Mr. Brittles, with a mug of ale in his hand, was corroborating everything, before his superior said it.
children.prevalue: The adventures of the previous night were still under discussion for Mr Giles was expatiating upon his presence of mind when the doctor entered Mr Brittles with a mug of ale in his hand was corroborating everything before his superior said it

children.name: Paragraph_37
children.value: 'Sit still!' said the doctor, waving his hand.
children.prevalue: Sit still said the doctor waving his hand

children.name: Paragraph_38
children.value: 'Thank you, sir, said Mr. Giles.  'Misses wished some ale to be given out, sir; and as I felt no ways inclined for my own little room, sir, and was disposed for company, I am taking mine among 'em here.'
children.prevalue: Thank you sir said Mr Giles Misses wished some ale to be given out sir and as I felt no ways inclined for my own little room sir and was disposed for company I am taking mine among em here

children.name: Paragraph_39
children.value: Brittles headed a low murmur, by which the ladies and gentlemen generally were understood to express the gratification they derived from Mr. Giles's condescension.  Mr. Giles looked round with a patronising air, as much as to say that so long as they behaved properly, he would never desert them.
children.prevalue: Brittles headed a low murmur by which the ladies and gentlemen generally were understood to express the gratification they derived from Mr Giles s condescension Mr Giles looked round with a patronising air as much as to say that so long as they behaved properly he would never desert them

children.name: Paragraph_40
children.value: 'How is the patient to-night, sir?' asked Giles.
children.prevalue: How is the patient to night sir asked Giles

children.name: Paragraph_41
children.value: 'So-so'; returned the doctor.  'I am afraid you have got yourself into a scrape there, Mr. Giles.'
children.prevalue: So so returned the doctor I am afraid you have got yourself into a scrape there Mr Giles

children.name: Paragraph_42
children.value: 'I hope you don't mean to say, sir,' said Mr. Giles, trembling, 'that he's going to die.  If I thought it, I should never be happy again.  I wouldn't cut a boy off:  no, not even Brittles here; not for all the plate in the county, sir.'
children.prevalue: I hope you don t mean to say sir said Mr Giles trembling that he s going to die If I thought it I should never be happy again I wouldn t cut a boy off no not even Brittles here not for all the plate in the county sir

children.name: Paragraph_43
children.value: 'That's not the point,' said the doctor, mysteriously.  'Mr. Giles, are you a Protestant?'
children.prevalue: That s not the point said the doctor mysteriously Mr Giles are you a Protestant

children.name: Paragraph_44
children.value: 'Yes, sir, I hope so,' faltered Mr. Giles, who had turned very pale.
children.prevalue: Yes sir I hope so faltered Mr Giles who had turned very pale

children.name: Paragraph_45
children.value: 'And what are you, boy?' said the doctor, turning sharply upon Brittles.
children.prevalue: And what are you boy said the doctor turning sharply upon Brittles

children.name: Paragraph_46
children.value: 'Lord bless me, sir!' replied Brittles, starting violently; 'I'm the same as Mr. Giles, sir.'
children.prevalue: Lord bless me sir replied Brittles starting violently I m the same as Mr Giles sir

children.name: Paragraph_47
children.value: 'Then tell me this,' said the doctor, 'both of you, both of you! Are you going to take upon yourselves to swear, that that boy upstairs is the boy that was put through the little window last night?  Out with it!  Come!  We are prepared for you!'
children.prevalue: Then tell me this said the doctor both of you both of you Are you going to take upon yourselves to swear that that boy upstairs is the boy that was put through the little window last night Out with it Come We are prepared for you

children.name: Paragraph_48
children.value: The doctor, who was universally considered one of the best-tempered creatures on earth, made this demand in such a dreadful tone of anger, that Giles and Brittles, who were considerably muddled by ale and excitement, stared at each other in a state of stupefaction.
children.prevalue: The doctor who was universally considered one of the best tempered creatures on earth made this demand in such a dreadful tone of anger that Giles and Brittles who were considerably muddled by ale and excitement stared at each other in a state of stupefaction

children.name: Paragraph_49
children.value: 'Pay attention to the reply, constable, will you?' said the doctor, shaking his forefinger with great solemnity of manner, and tapping the bridge of his nose with it, to bespeak the exercise of that worthy's utmost acuteness. 'Something may come of this before long.'
children.prevalue: Pay attention to the reply constable will you said the doctor shaking his forefinger with great solemnity of manner and tapping the bridge of his nose with it to bespeak the exercise of that worthy s utmost acuteness Something may come of this before long

children.name: Paragraph_50
children.value: The constable looked as wise as he could, and took up his staff of office: which had been reclining indolently in the chimney-corner.
children.prevalue: The constable looked as wise as he could and took up his staff of office which had been reclining indolently in the chimney corner

children.name: Paragraph_51
children.value: 'It's a simple question of identity, you will observe,' said the doctor.
children.prevalue: It s a simple question of identity you will observe said the doctor

children.name: Paragraph_52
children.value: 'That's what it is, sir,' replied the constable, coughing with great violence; for he had finished his ale in a hurry, and some of it had gone the wrong way.
children.prevalue: That s what it is sir replied the constable coughing with great violence for he had finished his ale in a hurry and some of it had gone the wrong way

children.name: Paragraph_53
children.value: 'Here's the house broken into,' said the doctor, 'and a couple of men catch one moment's glimpse of a boy, in the midst of gunpowder smoke, and in all the distraction of alarm and darkness.  Here's a boy comes to that very same house, next morning, and because he happens to have his arm tied up, these men lay violent hands upon him--by doing which, they place his life in great danger--and swear he is the thief.  Now, the question is, whether these men are justified by the fact; if not, in what situation do they place themselves?'
children.prevalue: Here s the house broken into said the doctor and a couple of men catch one moment s glimpse of a boy in the midst of gunpowder smoke and in all the distraction of alarm and darkness Here s a boy comes to that very same house next morning and because he happens to have his arm tied up these men lay violent hands upon him by doing which they place his life in great danger and swear he is the thief Now the question is whether these men are justified by the fact if not in what situation do they place themselves

children.name: Paragraph_54
children.value: The constable nodded profoundly.  He said, if that wasn't law, he would be glad to know what was.
children.prevalue: The constable nodded profoundly He said if that wasn t law he would be glad to know what was

children.name: Paragraph_55
children.value: 'I ask you again,' thundered the doctor, 'are you, on your solemn oaths, able to identify that boy?'
children.prevalue: I ask you again thundered the doctor are you on your solemn oaths able to identify that boy

children.name: Paragraph_56
children.value: Brittles looked doubtfully at Mr. Giles; Mr. Giles looked doubtfully at Brittles; the constable put his hand behind his ear, to catch the reply; the two women and the tinker leaned forward to listen; the doctor glanced keenly round; when a ring was heard at the gate, and at the same moment, the sound of wheels.
children.prevalue: Brittles looked doubtfully at Mr Giles Mr Giles looked doubtfully at Brittles the constable put his hand behind his ear to catch the reply the two women and the tinker leaned forward to listen the doctor glanced keenly round when a ring was heard at the gate and at the same moment the sound of wheels

children.name: Paragraph_57
children.value: 'It's the runners!' cried Brittles, to all appearance much relieved.
children.prevalue: It s the runners cried Brittles to all appearance much relieved

children.name: Paragraph_58
children.value: 'The what?' exclaimed the doctor, aghast in his turn.
children.prevalue: The what exclaimed the doctor aghast in his turn

children.name: Paragraph_59
children.value: 'The Bow Street officers, sir,' replied Brittles, taking up a candle; 'me and Mr. Giles sent for 'em this morning.'
children.prevalue: The Bow Street officers sir replied Brittles taking up a candle me and Mr Giles sent for em this morning

children.name: Paragraph_60
children.value: 'What?' cried the doctor.
children.prevalue: What cried the doctor

children.name: Paragraph_61
children.value: 'Yes,' replied Brittles; 'I sent a message up by the coachman, and I only wonder they weren't here before, sir.'
children.prevalue: Yes replied Brittles I sent a message up by the coachman and I only wonder they weren t here before sir

children.name: Paragraph_62
children.value: 'You did, did you?  Then confound your--slow coaches down here; that's all,' said the doctor, walking away.
children.prevalue: You did did you Then confound your slow coaches down here that s all said the doctor walking away

children.name: Paragraph_1
children.value: INVOLVES A CRITICAL POSITION
children.prevalue: INVOLVES A CRITICAL POSITION

children.name: Paragraph_2
children.value: 'Who's that?' inquired Brittles, opening the door a little way, with the chain up, and peeping out, shading the candle with his hand.
children.prevalue: Who s that inquired Brittles opening the door a little way with the chain up and peeping out shading the candle with his hand

children.name: Paragraph_3
children.value: 'Open the door,' replied a man outside; 'it's the officers from Bow Street, as was sent to to-day.'
children.prevalue: Open the door replied a man outside it s the officers from Bow Street as was sent to to day

children.name: Paragraph_4
children.value: Much comforted by this assurance, Brittles opened the door to its full width, and confronted a portly man in a great-coat; who walked in, without saying anything more, and wiped his shoes on the mat, as coolly as if he lived there.
children.prevalue: Much comforted by this assurance Brittles opened the door to its full width and confronted a portly man in a great coat who walked in without saying anything more and wiped his shoes on the mat as coolly as if he lived there

children.name: Paragraph_5
children.value: 'Just send somebody out to relieve my mate, will you, young man?' said the officer; 'he's in the gig, a-minding the prad.  Have you got a coach 'us here, that you could put it up in, for five or ten minutes?'
children.prevalue: Just send somebody out to relieve my mate will you young man said the officer he s in the gig a minding the prad Have you got a coach us here that you could put it up in for five or ten minutes

children.name: Paragraph_6
children.value: Brittles replying in the affirmative, and pointing out the building, the portly man stepped back to the garden-gate, and helped his companion to put up the gig:  while Brittles lighted them, in a state of great admiration.  This done, they returned to the house, and, being shown into a parlour, took off their great-coats and hats, and showed like what they were.
children.prevalue: Brittles replying in the affirmative and pointing out the building the portly man stepped back to the garden gate and helped his companion to put up the gig while Brittles lighted them in a state of great admiration This done they returned to the house and being shown into a parlour took off their great coats and hats and showed like what they were

children.name: Paragraph_7
children.value: The man who had knocked at the door, was a stout personage of middle height, aged about fifty: with shiny black hair, cropped pretty close; half-whiskers, a round face, and sharp eyes.  The other was a red-headed, bony man, in top-boots; with a rather ill-favoured countenance, and a turned-up sinister-looking nose.

children.name: Paragraph_8
children.value: 'Tell your governor that Blathers and Duff is here, will you?' said the stouter man, smoothing down his hair, and laying a pair of handcuffs on the table.  'Oh!  Good-evening, master.  Can I have a word or two with you in private, if you please?'
children.prevalue: Tell your governor that Blathers and Duff is here will you said the stouter man smoothing down his hair and laying a pair of handcuffs on the table Oh Good evening master Can I have a word or two with you in private if you please

children.name: Paragraph_9
children.value: This was addressed to Mr. Losberne, who now made his appearance; that gentleman, motioning Brittles to retire, brought in the two ladies, and shut the door.
children.prevalue: This was addressed to Mr Losberne who now made his appearance that gentleman motioning Brittles to retire brought in the two ladies and shut the door

children.name: Paragraph_10
children.value: 'This is the lady of the house,' said Mr. Losberne, motioning towards Mrs. Maylie.
children.prevalue: This is the lady of the house said Mr Losberne motioning towards Mrs Maylie

children.name: Paragraph_11
children.value: Mr. Blathers made a bow.  Being desired to sit down, he put his hat on the floor, and taking a chair, motioned to Duff to do the same.  The latter gentleman, who did not appear quite so much accustomed to good society, or quite so much at his ease in it--one of the two--seated himself, after undergoing several muscular affections of the limbs, and the head of his stick into his mouth, with some embarrassment.
children.prevalue: Mr Blathers made a bow Being desired to sit down he put his hat on the floor and taking a chair motioned to Duff to do the same The latter gentleman who did not appear quite so much accustomed to good society or quite so much at his ease in it one of the two seated himself after undergoing several muscular affections of the limbs and the head of his stick into his mouth with some embarrassment

children.name: Paragraph_12
children.value: 'Now, with regard to this here robbery, master,' said Blathers. 'What are the circumstances?'
children.prevalue: Now with regard to this here robbery master said Blathers What are the circumstances

children.name: Paragraph_13
children.value: Mr. Losberne, who appeared desirous of gaining time, recounted them at great length, and with much circumlocution.  Messrs. Blathers and Duff looked very knowing meanwhile, and occasionally exchanged a nod.
children.prevalue: Mr Losberne who appeared desirous of gaining time recounted them at great length and with much circumlocution Messrs Blathers and Duff looked very knowing meanwhile and occasionally exchanged a nod

children.name: Paragraph_14
children.value: 'I can't say, for certain, till I see the work, of course,' said Blathers; 'but my opinion at once is,--I don't mind committing myself to that extent,--that this wasn't done by a yokel; eh, Duff?'
children.prevalue: I can t say for certain till I see the work of course said Blathers but my opinion at once is I don t mind committing myself to that extent that this wasn t done by a yokel eh Duff

children.name: Paragraph_15
children.value: 'Certainly not,' replied Duff.
children.prevalue: Certainly not replied Duff

children.name: Paragraph_16
children.value: 'And, translating the word yokel for the benefit of the ladies, I apprehend your meaning to be, that this attempt was not made by a countryman?' said Mr. Losberne, with a smile.
children.prevalue: And translating the word yokel for the benefit of the ladies I apprehend your meaning to be that this attempt was not made by a countryman said Mr Losberne with a smile

children.name: Paragraph_17
children.value: 'That's it, master,' replied Blathers.  'This is all about the robbery, is it?'
children.prevalue: That s it master replied Blathers This is all about the robbery is it

children.name: Paragraph_18
children.value: 'All,' replied the doctor.
children.prevalue: All replied the doctor

children.name: Paragraph_19
children.value: 'Now, what is this, about this here boy that the servants are a-talking on?' said Blathers.
children.prevalue: Now what is this about this here boy that the servants are a talking on said Blathers

children.name: Paragraph_20
children.value: 'Nothing at all,' replied the doctor.  'One of the frightened servants chose to take it into his head, that he had something to do with this attempt to break into the house; but it's nonsense: sheer absurdity.'
children.prevalue: Nothing at all replied the doctor One of the frightened servants chose to take it into his head that he had something to do with this attempt to break into the house but it s nonsense sheer absurdity

children.name: Paragraph_21
children.value: 'Wery easy disposed of, if it is,' remarked Duff.
children.prevalue: Wery easy disposed of if it is remarked Duff

children.name: Paragraph_22
children.value: 'What he says is quite correct,' observed Blathers, nodding his head in a confirmatory way, and playing carelessly with the handcuffs, as if they were a pair of castanets.  'Who is the boy? What account does he give of himself?  Where did he come from? He didn't drop out of the clouds, did he, master?'
children.prevalue: What he says is quite correct observed Blathers nodding his head in a confirmatory way and playing carelessly with the handcuffs as if they were a pair of castanets Who is the boy What account does he give of himself Where did he come from He didn t drop out of the clouds did he master

children.name: Paragraph_23
children.value: 'Of course not,' replied the doctor, with a nervous glance at the two ladies.  'I know his whole history: but we can talk about that presently.  You would like, first, to see the place where the thieves made their attempt, I suppose?'
children.prevalue: Of course not replied the doctor with a nervous glance at the two ladies I know his whole history but we can talk about that presently You would like first to see the place where the thieves made their attempt I suppose

children.name: Paragraph_24
children.value: 'Certainly,' rejoined Mr. Blathers.  'We had better inspect the premises first, and examine the servants afterwards. That's the usual way of doing business.'
children.prevalue: Certainly rejoined Mr Blathers We had better inspect the premises first and examine the servants afterwards That s the usual way of doing business

children.name: Paragraph_25
children.value: Lights were then procured; and Messrs. Blathers and Duff, attended by the native constable, Brittles, Giles, and everybody else in short, went into the little room at the end of the passage and looked out at the window; and afterwards went round by way of the lawn, and looked in at the window; and after that, had a candle handed out to inspect the shutter with; and after that, a lantern to trace the footsteps with; and after that, a pitchfork to poke the bushes with.  This done, amidst the breathless interest of all beholders, they came in again; and Mr. Giles and Brittles were put through a melodramatic representation of their share in the previous night's adventures: which they performed some six times over: contradicting each other, in not more than one important respect, the first time, and in not more than a dozen the last.  This consummation being arrived at, Blathers and Duff cleared the room, and held a long council together, compared with which, for secrecy and solemnity, a consultation of great doctors on the knottiest point in medicine, would be mere child's play.
children.prevalue: Lights were then procured and Messrs Blathers and Duff attended by the native constable Brittles Giles and everybody else in short went into the little room at the end of the passage and looked out at the window and afterwards went round by way of the lawn and looked in at the window and after that had a candle handed out to inspect the shutter with and after that a lantern to trace the footsteps with and after that a pitchfork to poke the bushes with This done amidst the breathless interest of all beholders they came in again and Mr Giles and Brittles were put through a melodramatic representation of their share in the previous night s adventures which they performed some six times over contradicting each other in not more than one important respect the first time and in not more than a dozen the last This consummation being arrived at Blathers and Duff cleared the room and held a long council together compared with which for secrecy and solemnity a consultation of great doctors on the knottiest point in medicine would be mere child s play

children.name: Paragraph_26
children.value: Meanwhile, the doctor walked up and down the next room in a very uneasy state; and Mrs. Maylie and Rose looked on, with anxious faces.
children.prevalue: Meanwhile the doctor walked up and down the next room in a very uneasy state and Mrs Maylie and Rose looked on with anxious faces

children.name: Paragraph_27
children.value: 'Upon my word,' he said, making a halt, after a great number of very rapid turns, 'I hardly know what to do.'
children.prevalue: Upon my word he said making a halt after a great number of very rapid turns I hardly know what to do

children.name: Paragraph_28
children.value: 'Surely,' said Rose, 'the poor child's story, faithfully repeated to these men, will be sufficient to exonerate him.'
children.prevalue: Surely said Rose the poor child s story faithfully repeated to these men will be sufficient to exonerate him

children.name: Paragraph_29
children.value: 'I doubt it, my dear young lady,' said the doctor, shaking his head. 'I don't think it would exonerate him, either with them, or with legal functionaries of a higher grade.  What is he, after all, they would say?  A runaway.  Judged by mere worldly considerations and probabilities, his story is a very doubtful one.'
children.prevalue: I doubt it my dear young lady said the doctor shaking his head I don t think it would exonerate him either with them or with legal functionaries of a higher grade What is he after all they would say A runaway Judged by mere worldly considerations and probabilities his story is a very doubtful one

children.name: Paragraph_30
children.value: 'You believe it, surely?' interrupted Rose.
children.prevalue: You believe it surely interrupted Rose

children.name: Paragraph_31
children.value: 'I believe it, strange as it is; and perhaps I may be an old fool for doing so,' rejoined the doctor; 'but I don't think it is exactly the tale for a practical police-officer, nevertheless.'
children.prevalue: I believe it strange as it is and perhaps I may be an old fool for doing so rejoined the doctor but I don t think it is exactly the tale for a practical police officer nevertheless

children.name: Paragraph_32
children.value: 'Why not?' demanded Rose.
children.prevalue: Why not demanded Rose

children.name: Paragraph_33
children.value: 'Because, my pretty cross-examiner,' replied the doctor: 'because, viewed with their eyes, there are many ugly points about it; he can only prove the parts that look ill, and none of those that look well. Confound the fellows, they will have the why and the wherefore, and will take nothing for granted.  On his own showing, you see, he has been the companion of thieves for some time past; he has been carried to a police-officer, on a charge of picking a gentleman's pocket; he has been taken away, forcibly, from that gentleman's house, to a place which he cannot describe or point out, and of the situation of which he has not the remotest idea.  He is brought down to Chertsey, by men who seem to have taken a violent fancy to him, whether he will or no; and is put through a window to rob a house; and then, just at the very moment when he is going to alarm the inmates, and so do the very thing that would set him all to rights, there rushes into the way, a blundering dog of a half-bred butler, and shoots him! As if on purpose to prevent his doing any good for himself! Don't you see all this?'
children.prevalue: Because my pretty cross examiner replied the doctor because viewed with their eyes there are many ugly points about it he can only prove the parts that look ill and none of those that look well Confound the fellows they will have the why and the wherefore and will take nothing for granted On his own showing you see he has been the companion of thieves for some time past he has been carried to a police officer on a charge of picking a gentleman s pocket he has been taken away forcibly from that gentleman s house to a place which he cannot describe or point out and of the situation of which he has not the remotest idea He is brought down to Chertsey by men who seem to have taken a violent fancy to him whether he will or no and is put through a window to rob a house and then just at the very moment when he is going to alarm the inmates and so do the very thing that would set him all to rights there rushes into the way a blundering dog of a half bred butler and shoots him As if on purpose to prevent his doing any good for himself Don t you see all this

children.name: Paragraph_34
children.value: 'I see it, of course,' replied Rose, smiling at the doctor's impetuosity; 'but still I do not see anything in it, to criminate the poor child.'
children.prevalue: I see it of course replied Rose smiling at the doctor s impetuosity but still I do not see anything in it to criminate the poor child

children.name: Paragraph_35
children.value: 'No,' replied the doctor; 'of course not!  Bless the bright eyes of your sex!  They never see, whether for good or bad, more than one side of any question; and that is, always, the one which first presents itself to them.'
children.prevalue: No replied the doctor of course not Bless the bright eyes of your sex They never see whether for good or bad more than one side of any question and that is always the one which first presents itself to them

children.name: Paragraph_36
children.value: Having given vent to this result of experience, the doctor put his hands into his pockets, and walked up and down the room with even greater rapidity than before.
children.prevalue: Having given vent to this result of experience the doctor put his hands into his pockets and walked up and down the room with even greater rapidity than before

children.name: Paragraph_37
children.value: 'The more I think of it,' said the doctor, 'the more I see that it will occasion endless trouble and difficulty if we put these men in possession of the boy's real story.  I am certain it will not be believed; and even if they can do nothing to him in the end, still the dragging it forward, and giving publicity to all the doubts that will be cast upon it, must interfere, materially, with your benevolent plan of rescuing him from misery.'
children.prevalue: The more I think of it said the doctor the more I see that it will occasion endless trouble and difficulty if we put these men in possession of the boy s real story I am certain it will not be believed and even if they can do nothing to him in the end still the dragging it forward and giving publicity to all the doubts that will be cast upon it must interfere materially with your benevolent plan of rescuing him from misery

children.name: Paragraph_38
children.value: 'Oh! what is to be done?' cried Rose.  'Dear, dear! why did they send for these people?'
children.prevalue: Oh what is to be done cried Rose Dear dear why did they send for these people

children.name: Paragraph_39
children.value: 'Why, indeed!' exclaimed Mrs. Maylie.  'I would not have had them here, for the world.'
children.prevalue: Why indeed exclaimed Mrs Maylie I would not have had them here for the world

children.name: Paragraph_40
children.value: 'All I know is,' said Mr. Losberne, at last:  sitting down with a kind of desperate calmness, 'that we must try and carry it off with a bold face.  The object is a good one, and that must be our excuse.  The boy has strong symptoms of fever upon him, and is in no condition to be talked to any more; that's one comfort.  We must make the best of it; and if bad be the best, it is no fault of ours.  Come in!'
children.prevalue: All I know is said Mr Losberne at last sitting down with a kind of desperate calmness that we must try and carry it off with a bold face The object is a good one and that must be our excuse The boy has strong symptoms of fever upon him and is in no condition to be talked to any more that s one comfort We must make the best of it and if bad be the best it is no fault of ours Come in

children.name: Paragraph_41
children.value: 'Well, master,' said Blathers, entering the room followed by his colleague, and making the door fast, before he said any more. 'This warn't a put-up thing.'
children.prevalue: Well master said Blathers entering the room followed by his colleague and making the door fast before he said any more This warn t a put up thing

children.name: Paragraph_42
children.value: 'And what the devil's a put-up thing?' demanded the doctor, impatiently.
children.prevalue: And what the devil s a put up thing demanded the doctor impatiently

children.name: Paragraph_43
children.value: 'We call it a put-up robbery, ladies,' said Blathers, turning to them, as if he pitied their ignorance, but had a contempt for the doctor's, 'when the servants is in it.'
children.prevalue: We call it a put up robbery ladies said Blathers turning to them as if he pitied their ignorance but had a contempt for the doctor s when the servants is in it

children.name: Paragraph_44
children.value: 'Nobody suspected them, in this case,' said Mrs. Maylie.
children.prevalue: Nobody suspected them in this case said Mrs Maylie

children.name: Paragraph_45
children.value: 'Wery likely not, ma'am,' replied Blathers; 'but they might have been in it, for all that.'
children.prevalue: Wery likely not ma am replied Blathers but they might have been in it for all that

children.name: Paragraph_46
children.value: 'More likely on that wery account,' said Duff.
children.prevalue: More likely on that wery account said Duff

children.name: Paragraph_47
children.value: 'We find it was a town hand,' said Blathers, continuing his report; 'for the style of work is first-rate.'
children.prevalue: We find it was a town hand said Blathers continuing his report for the style of work is first rate

children.name: Paragraph_48
children.value: 'Wery pretty indeed it is,' remarked Duff, in an undertone.
children.prevalue: Wery pretty indeed it is remarked Duff in an undertone

children.name: Paragraph_49
children.value: 'There was two of 'em in it,' continued Blathers; 'and they had a boy with 'em; that's plain from the size of the window.  That's all to be said at present.  We'll see this lad that you've got upstairs at once, if you please.'
children.prevalue: There was two of em in it continued Blathers and they had a boy with em that s plain from the size of the window That s all to be said at present We ll see this lad that you ve got upstairs at once if you please

children.name: Paragraph_50
children.value: 'Perhaps they will take something to drink first, Mrs. Maylie?' said the doctor: his face brightening, as if some new thought had occurred to him.
children.prevalue: Perhaps they will take something to drink first Mrs Maylie said the doctor his face brightening as if some new thought had occurred to him

children.name: Paragraph_51
children.value: 'Oh! to be sure!' exclaimed Rose, eagerly.  'You shall have it immediately, if you will.'
children.prevalue: Oh to be sure exclaimed Rose eagerly You shall have it immediately if you will

children.name: Paragraph_52
children.value: 'Why, thank you, miss!' said Blathers, drawing his coat-sleeve across his mouth; 'it's dry work, this sort of duty.  Anythink that's handy, miss; don't put yourself out of the way, on our accounts.'
children.prevalue: Why thank you miss said Blathers drawing his coat sleeve across his mouth it s dry work this sort of duty Anythink that s handy miss don t put yourself out of the way on our accounts

children.name: Paragraph_53
children.value: 'What shall it be?' asked the doctor, following the young lady to the sideboard.
children.prevalue: What shall it be asked the doctor following the young lady to the sideboard

children.name: Paragraph_54
children.value: 'A little drop of spirits, master, if it's all the same,' replied Blathers.  'It's a cold ride from London, ma'am; and I always find that spirits comes home warmer to the feelings.'
children.prevalue: A little drop of spirits master if it s all the same replied Blathers It s a cold ride from London ma am and I always find that spirits comes home warmer to the feelings

children.name: Paragraph_55
children.value: This interesting communication was addressed to Mrs. Maylie, who received it very graciously.  While it was being conveyed to her, the doctor slipped out of the room.
children.prevalue: This interesting communication was addressed to Mrs Maylie who received it very graciously While it was being conveyed to her the doctor slipped out of the room

children.name: Paragraph_56
children.value: 'Ah!' said Mr. Blathers:  not holding his wine-glass by the stem, but grasping the bottom between the thumb and forefinger of his left hand: and placing it in front of his chest; 'I have seen a good many pieces of business like this, in my time, ladies.'
children.prevalue: Ah said Mr Blathers not holding his wine glass by the stem but grasping the bottom between the thumb and forefinger of his left hand and placing it in front of his chest I have seen a good many pieces of business like this in my time ladies

children.name: Paragraph_57
children.value: 'That crack down in the back lane at Edmonton, Blathers,' said Mr. Duff, assisting his colleague's memory.
children.prevalue: That crack down in the back lane at Edmonton Blathers said Mr Duff assisting his colleague s memory

children.name: Paragraph_58
children.value: 'That was something in this way, warn't it?' rejoined Mr. Blathers; 'that was done by Conkey Chickweed, that was.'
children.prevalue: That was something in this way warn t it rejoined Mr Blathers that was done by Conkey Chickweed that was

children.name: Paragraph_59
children.value: 'You always gave that to him' replied Duff.  'It was the Family Pet, I tell you.  Conkey hadn't any more to do with it than I had.'
children.prevalue: You always gave that to him replied Duff It was the Family Pet I tell you Conkey hadn t any more to do with it than I had

children.name: Paragraph_60
children.value: 'Get out!' retorted Mr. Blathers; 'I know better.  Do you mind that time when Conkey was robbed of his money, though?  What a start that was!  Better than any novel-book I ever see!'
children.prevalue: Get out retorted Mr Blathers I know better Do you mind that time when Conkey was robbed of his money though What a start that was Better than any novel book I ever see

children.name: Paragraph_61
children.value: 'What was that?' inquired Rose:  anxious to encourage any symptoms of good-humour in the unwelcome visitors.
children.prevalue: What was that inquired Rose anxious to encourage any symptoms of good humour in the unwelcome visitors

children.name: Paragraph_62
children.value: 'It was a robbery, miss, that hardly anybody would have been down upon,' said Blathers.  'This here Conkey Chickweed--'
children.prevalue: It was a robbery miss that hardly anybody would have been down upon said Blathers This here Conkey Chickweed

children.name: Paragraph_63
children.value: 'Conkey means Nosey, ma'am,' interposed Duff.
children.prevalue: Conkey means Nosey ma am interposed Duff

children.name: Paragraph_64
children.value: 'Of course the lady knows that, don't she?' demanded Mr. Blathers. 'Always interrupting, you are, partner!  This here Conkey Chickweed, miss, kept a public-house over Battlebridge way, and he had a cellar, where a good many young lords went to see cock-fighting, and badger-drawing, and that; and a wery intellectual manner the sports was conducted in, for I've seen 'em off'en.  He warn't one of the family, at that time; and one night he was robbed of three hundred and twenty-seven guineas in a canvas bag, that was stole out of his bedroom in the dead of night, by a tall man with a black patch over his eye, who had concealed himself under the bed, and after committing the robbery, jumped slap out of window:  which was only a story high. He was wery quick about it.  But Conkey was quick, too; for he fired a blunderbuss arter him, and roused the neighbourhood. They set up a hue-and-cry, directly, and when they came to look about 'em, found that Conkey had hit the robber; for there was traces of blood, all the way to some palings a good distance off; and there they lost 'em.  However, he had made off with the blunt; and, consequently, the name of Mr. Chickweed, licensed witler, appeared in the Gazette among the other bankrupts; and all manner of benefits and subscriptions, and I don't know what all, was got up for the poor man, who was in a wery low state of mind about his loss, and went up and down the streets, for three or four days, a pulling his hair off in such a desperate manner that many people was afraid he might be going to make away with himself. One day he came up to the office, all in a hurry, and had a private interview with the magistrate, who, after a deal of talk, rings the bell, and orders Jem Spyers in (Jem was a active officer), and tells him to go and assist Mr. Chickweed in apprehending the man as robbed his house. I see him, Spyers, said Chickweed, pass my house yesterday morning, Why didn't you up, and collar him! says Spyers.  I was so struck all of a heap, that you might have fractured my skull with a toothpick, says the poor man; but we're sure to have him; for between ten and eleven o'clock at night he passed again.  Spyers no sooner heard this, than he put some clean linen and a comb, in his pocket, in case he should have to stop a day or two; and away he goes, and sets himself down at one of the public-house windows behind the little red curtain, with his hat on, all ready to bolt out, at a moment's notice. He was smoking his pipe here, late at night, when all of a sudden Chickweed roars out, Here he is! Stop thief!  Murder!  Jem Spyers dashes out; and there he sees Chickweed, a-tearing down the street full cry.  Away goes Spyers; on goes Chickweed; round turns the people; everybody roars out, Thieves! and Chickweed himself keeps on shouting, all the time, like mad.  Spyers loses sight of him a minute as he turns a corner; shoots round; sees a little crowd; dives in; Which is the man? D--me! says Chickweed, I've lost him again!  It was a remarkable occurrence, but he warn't to be seen nowhere, so they went back to the public-house. Next morning, Spyers took his old place, and looked out, from behind the curtain, for a tall man with a black patch over his eye, till his own two eyes ached again.  At last, he couldn't help shutting 'em, to ease 'em a minute; and the very moment he did so, he hears Chickweed a-roaring out, Here he is!  Off he starts once more, with Chickweed half-way down the street ahead of him; and after twice as long a run as the yesterday's one, the man's lost again!  This was done, once or twice more, till one-half the neighbours gave out that Mr. Chickweed had been robbed by the devil, who was playing tricks with him arterwards; and the other half, that poor Mr. Chickweed had gone mad with grief.'

children.name: Paragraph_65
children.value: 'What did Jem Spyers say?' inquired the doctor; who had returned to the room shortly after the commencement of the story.
children.prevalue: What did Jem Spyers say inquired the doctor who had returned to the room shortly after the commencement of the story

children.name: Paragraph_66
children.value: 'Jem Spyers,' resumed the officer, 'for a long time said nothing at all, and listened to everything without seeming to, which showed he understood his business.  But, one morning, he walked into the bar, and taking out his snuffbox, says Chickweed, I've found out who done this here robbery.  Have you? said Chickweed.  Oh, my dear Spyers, only let me have wengeance, and I shall die contented!  Oh, my dear Spyers, where is the villain!  Come! said Spyers, offering him a pinch of snuff, none of that gammon!  You did it yourself.  So he had; and a good bit of money he had made by it, too; and nobody would never have found it out, if he hadn't been so precious anxious to keep up appearances!' said Mr. Blathers, putting down his wine-glass, and clinking the handcuffs together.
