children.name: Paragraph_1
children.value: IN WHICH THE READER MAY PERCEIVE A CONTRAST, NOT UNCOMMON IN MATRIMONIAL CASES
children.prevalue: IN WHICH THE READER MAY PERCEIVE A CONTRAST NOT UNCOMMON IN MATRIMONIAL CASES

children.name: Paragraph_2
children.value: Mr. Bumble sat in the workhouse parlour, with his eyes moodily fixed on the cheerless grate, whence, as it was summer time, no brighter gleam proceeded, than the reflection of certain sickly rays of the sun, which were sent back from its cold and shining surface.  A paper fly-cage dangled from the ceiling, to which he occasionally raised his eyes in gloomy thought; and, as the heedless insects hovered round the gaudy net-work, Mr. Bumble would heave a deep sigh, while a more gloomy shadow overspread his countenance.  Mr. Bumble was meditating; it might be that the insects brought to mind, some painful passage in his own past life.
children.prevalue: Mr Bumble sat in the workhouse parlour with his eyes moodily fixed on the cheerless grate whence as it was summer time no brighter gleam proceeded than the reflection of certain sickly rays of the sun which were sent back from its cold and shining surface A paper fly cage dangled from the ceiling to which he occasionally raised his eyes in gloomy thought and as the heedless insects hovered round the gaudy net work Mr Bumble would heave a deep sigh while a more gloomy shadow overspread his countenance Mr Bumble was meditating it might be that the insects brought to mind some painful passage in his own past life

children.name: Paragraph_3
children.value: Nor was Mr. Bumble's gloom the only thing calculated to awaken a pleasing melancholy in the bosom of a spectator. There were not wanting other appearances, and those closely connected with his own person, which announced that a great change had taken place in the position of his affairs.  The laced coat, and the cocked hat; where were they?  He still wore knee-breeches, and dark cotton stockings on his nether limbs; but they were not the breeches.  The coat was wide-skirted; and in that respect like the coat, but, oh how different!  The mighty cocked hat was replaced by a modest round one.  Mr. Bumble was no longer a beadle.
children.prevalue: Nor was Mr Bumble s gloom the only thing calculated to awaken a pleasing melancholy in the bosom of a spectator There were not wanting other appearances and those closely connected with his own person which announced that a great change had taken place in the position of his affairs The laced coat and the cocked hat where were they He still wore knee breeches and dark cotton stockings on his nether limbs but they were not the breeches The coat was wide skirted and in that respect like the coat but oh how different The mighty cocked hat was replaced by a modest round one Mr Bumble was no longer a beadle

children.name: Paragraph_4
children.value: There are some promotions in life, which, independent of the more substantial rewards they offer, require peculiar value and dignity from the coats and waistcoats connected with them.  A field-marshal has his uniform; a bishop his silk apron; a counsellor his silk gown; a beadle his cocked hat.  Strip the bishop of his apron, or the beadle of his hat and lace; what are they?  Men.  Mere men.  Dignity, and even holiness too, sometimes, are more questions of coat and waistcoat than some people imagine.
children.prevalue: There are some promotions in life which independent of the more substantial rewards they offer require peculiar value and dignity from the coats and waistcoats connected with them A field marshal has his uniform a bishop his silk apron a counsellor his silk gown a beadle his cocked hat Strip the bishop of his apron or the beadle of his hat and lace what are they Men Mere men Dignity and even holiness too sometimes are more questions of coat and waistcoat than some people imagine

children.name: Paragraph_5
children.value: Mr. Bumble had married Mrs. Corney, and was master of the workhouse. Another beadle had come into power.  On him the cocked hat, gold-laced coat, and staff, had all three descended.
children.prevalue: Mr Bumble had married Mrs Corney and was master of the workhouse Another beadle had come into power On him the cocked hat gold laced coat and staff had all three descended

children.name: Paragraph_6
children.value: 'And to-morrow two months it was done!' said Mr. Bumble, with a sigh. 'It seems a age.'
children.prevalue: And to morrow two months it was done said Mr Bumble with a sigh It seems a age

children.name: Paragraph_7

children.prevalue: Mr Bumble might have meant that he had concentrated a whole existence of happiness into the short space of eight weeks but the sigh there was a vast deal of meaning in the sigh

children.name: Paragraph_8
children.value: 'I sold myself,' said Mr. Bumble, pursuing the same train of relection, 'for six teaspoons, a pair of sugar-tongs, and a milk-pot; with a small quantity of second-hand furniture, and twenty pound in money.  I went very reasonable.  Cheap, dirt cheap!'
children.prevalue: I sold myself said Mr Bumble pursuing the same train of relection for six teaspoons a pair of sugar tongs and a milk pot with a small quantity of second hand furniture and twenty pound in money I went very reasonable Cheap dirt cheap

children.prevalue: Cheap cried a shrill voice in Mr Bumble s ear you would have been dear at any price and dear enough I paid for you Lord above knows that

children.name: Paragraph_10
children.value: Mr. Bumble turned, and encountered the face of his interesting consort, who, imperfectly comprehending the few words she had overheard of his complaint, had hazarded the foregoing remark at a venture.
children.prevalue: Mr Bumble turned and encountered the face of his interesting consort who imperfectly comprehending the few words she had overheard of his complaint had hazarded the foregoing remark at a venture

The matter of fact, is, that the matron was in no way overpowered by Mr. Bumble's scowl, but, on the contrary, treated it with great disdain, and even raised a laugh thereat, which sounded as though it were genuine.

children.name: Paragraph_15
children.value: On hearing this most unexpected sound, Mr. Bumble looked, first incredulous, and afterwards amazed.  He then relapsed into his former state; nor did he rouse himself until his attention was again awakened by the voice of his partner.
children.prevalue: On hearing this most unexpected sound Mr Bumble looked first incredulous and afterwards amazed He then relapsed into his former state nor did he rouse himself until his attention was again awakened by the voice of his partner

children.prevalue: Are you going to sit snoring there all day inquired Mrs Bumble

children.name: Paragraph_17
children.value: 'I am going to sit here, as long as I think proper, ma'am,' rejoined Mr. Bumble; 'and although I was not snoring, I shall snore, gape, sneeze, laugh, or cry, as the humour strikes me; such being my prerogative.'
children.prevalue: I am going to sit here as long as I think proper ma am rejoined Mr Bumble and although I was not snoring I shall snore gape sneeze laugh or cry as the humour strikes me such being my prerogative

children.prevalue: Your prerogative sneered Mrs Bumble with ineffable contempt

children.name: Paragraph_22
children.value: Mrs. Bumble, seeing at a glance, that the decisive moment had now arrived, and that a blow struck for the mastership on one side or other, must necessarily be final and conclusive, no sooner heard this allusion to the dead and gone, than she dropped into a chair, and with a loud scream that Mr. Bumble was a hard-hearted brute, fell into a paroxysm of tears.

children.name: Paragraph_23
children.value: But, tears were not the things to find their way to Mr. Bumble's soul; his heart was waterproof.  Like washable beaver hats that improve with rain, his nerves were rendered stouter and more vigorous, by showers of tears, which, being tokens of weakness, and so far tacit admissions of his own power, pleased and exalted him.  He eyed his good lady with looks of great satisfaction, and begged, in an encouraging manner, that she should cry her hardest:  the exercise being looked upon, by the faculty, as strongly conducive to health.

children.name: Paragraph_24
children.value: 'It opens the lungs, washes the countenance, exercises the eyes, and softens down the temper,' said Mr. Bumble.  'So cry away.'

children.value: As he discharged himself of this pleasantry, Mr. Bumble took his hat from a peg, and putting it on, rather rakishly, on one side, as a man might, who felt he had asserted his superiority in a becoming manner, thrust his hands into his pockets, and sauntered towards the door, with much ease and waggishness depicted in his whole appearance.

children.name: Paragraph_26
children.value: Now, Mrs. Corney that was, had tried the tears, because they were less troublesome than a manual assault; but, she was quite prepared to make trial of the latter mode of proceeding, as Mr. Bumble was not long in discovering.

children.name: Paragraph_27
children.value: The first proof he experienced of the fact, was conveyed in a hollow sound, immediately succeeded by the sudden flying off of his hat to the opposite end of the room.  This preliminary proceeding laying bare his head, the expert lady, clasping him tightly round the throat with one hand, inflicted a shower of blows (dealt with singular vigour and dexterity) upon it with the other.  This done, she created a little variety by scratching his face, and tearing his hair; and, having, by this time, inflicted as much punishment as she deemed necessary for the offence, she pushed him over a chair, which was luckily well situated for the purpose:  and defied him to talk about his prerogative again, if he dared.

children.name: Paragraph_33
children.value: Mr. Bumble was fairly taken by surprise, and fairly beaten.  He had a decided propensity for bullying:  derived no inconsiderable pleasure from the exercise of petty cruelty; and, consequently, was (it is needless to say) a coward.  This is by no means a disparagement to his character; for many official personages, who are held in high respect and admiration, are the victims of similar infirmities.  The remark is made, indeed, rather in his favour than otherwise, and with a view of impressing the reader with a just sense of his qualifications for office.

children.value: But, the measure of his degradation was not yet full.  After making a tour of the house, and thinking, for the first time, that the poor-laws really were too hard on people; and that men who ran away from their wives, leaving them chargeable to the parish, ought, in justice to be visited with no punishment at all, but rather rewarded as meritorious individuals who had suffered much; Mr. Bumble came to a room where some of the female paupers were usually employed in washing the parish linen:  when the sound of voices in conversation, now proceeded.

children.prevalue: Hem said Mr Bumble summoning up all his native dignity These women at least shall continue to respect the prerogative Hallo hallo there What do you mean by this noise you hussies

children.name: Paragraph_36
children.value: With these words, Mr. Bumble opened the door, and walked in with a very fierce and angry manner:  which was at once exchanged for a most humiliated and cowering air, as his eyes unexpectedly rested on the form of his lady wife.
children.prevalue: With these words Mr Bumble opened the door and walked in with a very fierce and angry manner which was at once exchanged for a most humiliated and cowering air as his eyes unexpectedly rested on the form of his lady wife

children.name: Paragraph_37
children.value: 'My dear,' said Mr. Bumble, 'I didn't know you were here.'
children.prevalue: My dear said Mr Bumble I didn t know you were here

children.name: Paragraph_38
children.value: 'Didn't know I was here!' repeated Mrs. Bumble.  'What do you do here?'
children.prevalue: Didn t know I was here repeated Mrs Bumble What do you do here

children.name: Paragraph_39
children.value: 'I thought they were talking rather too much to be doing their work properly, my dear,' replied Mr. Bumble:  glancing distractedly at a couple of old women at the wash-tub, who were comparing notes of admiration at the workhouse-master's humility.
children.prevalue: I thought they were talking rather too much to be doing their work properly my dear replied Mr Bumble glancing distractedly at a couple of old women at the wash tub who were comparing notes of admiration at the workhouse master s humility

children.name: Paragraph_40
children.value: 'You thought they were talking too much?' said Mrs. Bumble. 'What business is it of yours?'
children.prevalue: You thought they were talking too much said Mrs Bumble What business is it of yours

children.name: Paragraph_41
children.value: 'Why, my dear--' urged Mr. Bumble submissively.
children.prevalue: Why my dear urged Mr Bumble submissively

children.name: Paragraph_42
children.value: 'What business is it of yours?' demanded Mrs. Bumble, again.
children.prevalue: What business is it of yours demanded Mrs Bumble again

children.name: Paragraph_43
children.value: 'It's very true, you're matron here, my dear,' submitted Mr. Bumble; 'but I thought you mightn't be in the way just then.'
children.prevalue: It s very true you re matron here my dear submitted Mr Bumble but I thought you mightn t be in the way just then

children.name: Paragraph_44
children.value: 'I'll tell you what, Mr. Bumble,' returned his lady.  'We don't want any of your interference.  You're a great deal too fond of poking your nose into things that don't concern you, making everybody in the house laugh, the moment your back is turned, and making yourself look like a fool every hour in the day.  Be off; come!'
children.prevalue: I ll tell you what Mr Bumble returned his lady We don t want any of your interference You re a great deal too fond of poking your nose into things that don t concern you making everybody in the house laugh the moment your back is turned and making yourself look like a fool every hour in the day Be off come

children.name: Paragraph_45
children.value: Mr. Bumble, seeing with excruciating feelings, the delight of the two old paupers, who were tittering together most rapturously, hesitated for an instant.  Mrs. Bumble, whose patience brooked no delay, caught up a bowl of soap-suds, and motioning him towards the door, ordered him instantly to depart, on pain of receiving the contents upon his portly person.
children.prevalue: Mr Bumble seeing with excruciating feelings the delight of the two old paupers who were tittering together most rapturously hesitated for an instant Mrs Bumble whose patience brooked no delay caught up a bowl of soap suds and motioning him towards the door ordered him instantly to depart on pain of receiving the contents upon his portly person

children.name: Paragraph_46
children.value: What could Mr. Bumble do?  He looked dejectedly round, and slunk away; and, as he reached the door, the titterings of the paupers broke into a shrill chuckle of irrepressible delight.  It wanted but this.  He was degraded in their eyes; he had lost caste and station before the very paupers; he had fallen from all the height and pomp of beadleship, to the lowest depth of the most snubbed hen-peckery.
children.prevalue: What could Mr Bumble do He looked dejectedly round and slunk away and as he reached the door the titterings of the paupers broke into a shrill chuckle of irrepressible delight It wanted but this He was degraded in their eyes he had lost caste and station before the very paupers he had fallen from all the height and pomp of beadleship to the lowest depth of the most snubbed hen peckery

children.name: Paragraph_47
children.value: 'All in two months!' said Mr. Bumble, filled with dismal thoughts. 'Two months!  No more than two months ago, I was not only my own master, but everybody else's, so far as the porochial workhouse was concerned, and now!--'
children.prevalue: All in two months said Mr Bumble filled with dismal thoughts Two months No more than two months ago I was not only my own master but everybody else s so far as the porochial workhouse was concerned and now

children.name: Paragraph_48
children.value: It was too much.  Mr. Bumble boxed the ears of the boy who opened the gate for him (for he had reached the portal in his reverie); and walked, distractedly, into the street.
children.prevalue: It was too much Mr Bumble boxed the ears of the boy who opened the gate for him for he had reached the portal in his reverie and walked distractedly into the street

children.name: Paragraph_49
children.value: He walked up one street, and down another, until exercise had abated the first passion of his grief; and then the revulsion of feeling made him thirsty.  He passed a great many public-houses; but, at length paused before one in a by-way, whose parlour, as he gathered from a hasty peep over the blinds, was deserted, save by one solitary customer.  It began to rain, heavily, at the moment.  This determined him.  Mr. Bumble stepped in; and ordering something to drink, as he passed the bar, entered the apartment into which he had looked from the street.
children.prevalue: He walked up one street and down another until exercise had abated the first passion of his grief and then the revulsion of feeling made him thirsty He passed a great many public houses but at length paused before one in a by way whose parlour as he gathered from a hasty peep over the blinds was deserted save by one solitary customer It began to rain heavily at the moment This determined him Mr Bumble stepped in and ordering something to drink as he passed the bar entered the apartment into which he had looked from the street

children.name: Paragraph_50
children.value: The man who was seated there, was tall and dark, and wore a large cloak.  He had the air of a stranger; and seemed, by a certain haggardness in his look, as well as by the dusty soils on his dress, to have travelled some distance.  He eyed Bumble askance, as he entered, but scarcely deigned to nod his head in acknowledgment of his salutation.
children.prevalue: The man who was seated there was tall and dark and wore a large cloak He had the air of a stranger and seemed by a certain haggardness in his look as well as by the dusty soils on his dress to have travelled some distance He eyed Bumble askance as he entered but scarcely deigned to nod his head in acknowledgment of his salutation

children.name: Paragraph_51
children.value: Mr. Bumble had quite dignity enough for two; supposing even that the stranger had been more familiar:  so he drank his gin-and-water in silence, and read the paper with great show of pomp and circumstance.
children.prevalue: Mr Bumble had quite dignity enough for two supposing even that the stranger had been more familiar so he drank his gin and water in silence and read the paper with great show of pomp and circumstance

children.name: Paragraph_52
children.value: It so happened, however: as it will happen very often, when men fall into company under such circumstances:  that Mr. Bumble felt, every now and then, a powerful inducement, which he could not resist, to steal a look at the stranger:  and that whenever he did so, he withdrew his eyes, in some confusion, to find that the stranger was at that moment stealing a look at him.  Mr. Bumble's awkwardness was enhanced by the very remarkable expression of the stranger's eye, which was keen and bright, but shadowed by a scowl of distrust and suspicion, unlike anything he had ever observed before, and repulsive to behold.
children.prevalue: It so happened however as it will happen very often when men fall into company under such circumstances that Mr Bumble felt every now and then a powerful inducement which he could not resist to steal a look at the stranger and that whenever he did so he withdrew his eyes in some confusion to find that the stranger was at that moment stealing a look at him Mr Bumble s awkwardness was enhanced by the very remarkable expression of the stranger s eye which was keen and bright but shadowed by a scowl of distrust and suspicion unlike anything he had ever observed before and repulsive to behold

children.name: Paragraph_53
children.value: When they had encountered each other's glance several times in this way, the stranger, in a harsh, deep voice, broke silence.
children.prevalue: When they had encountered each other s glance several times in this way the stranger in a harsh deep voice broke silence

children.name: Paragraph_54
children.value: 'Were you looking for me,' he said, 'when you peered in at the window?'
children.prevalue: Were you looking for me he said when you peered in at the window

children.name: Paragraph_55
children.value: 'Not that I am aware of, unless you're Mr.--'  Here Mr. Bumble stopped short; for he was curious to know the stranger's name, and thought in his impatience, he might supply the blank.
children.prevalue: Not that I am aware of unless you re Mr Here Mr Bumble stopped short for he was curious to know the stranger s name and thought in his impatience he might supply the blank

children.name: Paragraph_56
children.value: 'I see you were not,' said the stranger; an expression of quiet sarcasm playing about his mouth; 'or you have known my name.  You don't know it.  I would recommend you not to ask for it.'
children.prevalue: I see you were not said the stranger an expression of quiet sarcasm playing about his mouth or you have known my name You don t know it I would recommend you not to ask for it

children.name: Paragraph_57
children.value: 'I meant no harm, young man,' observed Mr. Bumble, majestically.
children.prevalue: I meant no harm young man observed Mr Bumble majestically

children.name: Paragraph_58
children.value: 'And have done none,' said the stranger.
children.prevalue: And have done none said the stranger

children.name: Paragraph_59
children.value: Another silence succeeded this short dialogue:  which was again broken by the stranger.
children.prevalue: Another silence succeeded this short dialogue which was again broken by the stranger

children.name: Paragraph_60
children.value: 'I have seen you before, I think?' said he.  'You were differently dressed at that time, and I only passed you in the street, but I should know you again.  You were beadle here, once; were you not?'
children.prevalue: I have seen you before I think said he You were differently dressed at that time and I only passed you in the street but I should know you again You were beadle here once were you not

children.name: Paragraph_61
children.value: 'I was,' said Mr. Bumble, in some surprise; 'porochial beadle.'
children.prevalue: I was said Mr Bumble in some surprise porochial beadle

children.name: Paragraph_62
children.value: 'Just so,' rejoined the other, nodding his head.  'It was in that character I saw you.  What are you now?'
children.prevalue: Just so rejoined the other nodding his head It was in that character I saw you What are you now

children.name: Paragraph_63
children.value: 'Master of the workhouse,' rejoined Mr. Bumble, slowly and impressively, to check any undue familiarity the stranger might otherwise assume.  'Master of the workhouse, young man!'
children.prevalue: Master of the workhouse rejoined Mr Bumble slowly and impressively to check any undue familiarity the stranger might otherwise assume Master of the workhouse young man

children.name: Paragraph_64
children.value: 'You have the same eye to your own interest, that you always had, I doubt not?' resumed the stranger, looking keenly into Mr. Bumble's eyes, as he raised them in astonishment at the question.
children.prevalue: You have the same eye to your own interest that you always had I doubt not resumed the stranger looking keenly into Mr Bumble s eyes as he raised them in astonishment at the question

children.name: Paragraph_65
children.value: 'Don't scruple to answer freely, man.  I know you pretty well, you see.'
children.prevalue: Don t scruple to answer freely man I know you pretty well you see

children.name: Paragraph_66
children.value: 'I suppose, a married man,' replied Mr. Bumble, shading his eyes with his hand, and surveying the stranger, from head to foot, in evident perplexity, 'is not more averse to turning an honest penny when he can, than a single one.  Porochial officers are not so well paid that they can afford to refuse any little extra fee, when it comes to them in a civil and proper manner.'
children.prevalue: I suppose a married man replied Mr Bumble shading his eyes with his hand and surveying the stranger from head to foot in evident perplexity is not more averse to turning an honest penny when he can than a single one Porochial officers are not so well paid that they can afford to refuse any little extra fee when it comes to them in a civil and proper manner

children.name: Paragraph_67
children.value: The stranger smiled, and nodded his head again: as much to say, he had not mistaken his man; then rang the bell.
children.prevalue: The stranger smiled and nodded his head again as much to say he had not mistaken his man then rang the bell

children.name: Paragraph_68
children.value: 'Fill this glass again,' he said, handing Mr. Bumble's empty tumbler to the landlord.  'Let it be strong and hot.  You like it so, I suppose?'
children.prevalue: Fill this glass again he said handing Mr Bumble s empty tumbler to the landlord Let it be strong and hot You like it so I suppose

children.name: Paragraph_69
children.value: 'Not too strong,' replied Mr. Bumble, with a delicate cough.
children.prevalue: Not too strong replied Mr Bumble with a delicate cough

children.name: Paragraph_70
children.value: 'You understand what that means, landlord!' said the stranger, drily.
children.prevalue: You understand what that means landlord said the stranger drily

children.name: Paragraph_71
children.value: The host smiled, disappeared, and shortly afterwards returned with a steaming jorum: of which, the first gulp brought the water into Mr. Bumble's eyes.
children.prevalue: The host smiled disappeared and shortly afterwards returned with a steaming jorum of which the first gulp brought the water into Mr Bumble s eyes

children.name: Paragraph_72
children.value: 'Now listen to me,' said the stranger, after closing the door and window.  'I came down to this place, to-day, to find you out; and, by one of those chances which the devil throws in the way of his friends sometimes, you walked into the very room I was sitting in, while you were uppermost in my mind.  I want some information from you.  I don't ask you to give it for nothing, slight as it is.  Put up that, to begin with.'
children.prevalue: Now listen to me said the stranger after closing the door and window I came down to this place to day to find you out and by one of those chances which the devil throws in the way of his friends sometimes you walked into the very room I was sitting in while you were uppermost in my mind I want some information from you I don t ask you to give it for nothing slight as it is Put up that to begin with

children.name: Paragraph_73
children.value: As he spoke, he pushed a couple of sovereigns across the table to his companion, carefully, as though unwilling that the chinking of money should be heard without.  When Mr. Bumble had scrupulously examined the coins, to see that they were genuine, and had put them up, with much satisfaction, in his waistcoat-pocket, he went on:
children.prevalue: As he spoke he pushed a couple of sovereigns across the table to his companion carefully as though unwilling that the chinking of money should be heard without When Mr Bumble had scrupulously examined the coins to see that they were genuine and had put them up with much satisfaction in his waistcoat pocket he went on

children.name: Paragraph_74
children.value: 'Carry your memory back--let me see--twelve years, last winter.'
children.prevalue: Carry your memory back let me see twelve years last winter

children.name: Paragraph_75
children.value: 'It's a long time,' said Mr. Bumble.  'Very good.  I've done it.'
children.prevalue: It s a long time said Mr Bumble Very good I ve done it

children.name: Paragraph_76
children.value: 'The scene, the workhouse.'
children.prevalue: The scene the workhouse

children.name: Paragraph_77
children.value: 'Good!'
children.prevalue: Good

children.name: Paragraph_78
children.value: 'And the time, night.'
children.prevalue: And the time night

children.name: Paragraph_79
children.value: 'Yes.'
children.prevalue: Yes

children.name: Paragraph_80
children.value: 'And the place, the crazy hole, wherever it was, in which miserable drabs brought forth the life and health so often denied to themselves--gave birth to puling children for the parish to rear; and hid their shame, rot 'em in the grave!'
children.prevalue: And the place the crazy hole wherever it was in which miserable drabs brought forth the life and health so often denied to themselves gave birth to puling children for the parish to rear and hid their shame rot em in the grave

children.name: Paragraph_81
children.value: 'The lying-in room, I suppose?' said Mr. Bumble, not quite following the stranger's excited description.
children.prevalue: The lying in room I suppose said Mr Bumble not quite following the stranger s excited description

children.name: Paragraph_82
children.value: 'Yes,' said the stranger.  'A boy was born there.'
children.prevalue: Yes said the stranger A boy was born there

children.name: Paragraph_83
children.value: 'A many boys,' observed Mr. Bumble, shaking his head, despondingly.
children.prevalue: A many boys observed Mr Bumble shaking his head despondingly

children.name: Paragraph_84
children.value: 'A murrain on the young devils!' cried the stranger; 'I speak of one; a meek-looking, pale-faced boy, who was apprenticed down here, to a coffin-maker--I wish he had made his coffin, and screwed his body in it--and who afterwards ran away to London, as it was supposed.
children.prevalue: A murrain on the young devils cried the stranger I speak of one a meek looking pale faced boy who was apprenticed down here to a coffin maker I wish he had made his coffin and screwed his body in it and who afterwards ran away to London as it was supposed

children.name: Paragraph_85
children.value: 'Why, you mean Oliver!  Young Twist!' said Mr. Bumble; 'I remember him, of course.  There wasn't a obstinater young rascal--'
children.prevalue: Why you mean Oliver Young Twist said Mr Bumble I remember him of course There wasn t a obstinater young rascal

children.name: Paragraph_86
children.value: 'It's not of him I want to hear; I've heard enough of him,' said the stranger, stopping Mr. Bumble in the outset of a tirade on the subject of poor Oliver's vices.  'It's of a woman; the hag that nursed his mother.  Where is she?'
children.prevalue: It s not of him I want to hear I ve heard enough of him said the stranger stopping Mr Bumble in the outset of a tirade on the subject of poor Oliver s vices It s of a woman the hag that nursed his mother Where is she

children.name: Paragraph_87
children.value: 'Where is she?' said Mr. Bumble, whom the gin-and-water had rendered facetious.  'It would be hard to tell.  There's no midwifery there, whichever place she's gone to; so I suppose she's out of employment, anyway.'
children.prevalue: Where is she said Mr Bumble whom the gin and water had rendered facetious It would be hard to tell There s no midwifery there whichever place she s gone to so I suppose she s out of employment anyway

children.name: Paragraph_88
children.value: 'What do you mean?' demanded the stranger, sternly.
children.prevalue: What do you mean demanded the stranger sternly

children.name: Paragraph_89
children.value: 'That she died last winter,' rejoined Mr. Bumble.
children.prevalue: That she died last winter rejoined Mr Bumble

children.name: Paragraph_90
children.value: The man looked fixedly at him when he had given this information, and although he did not withdraw his eyes for some time afterwards, his gaze gradually became vacant and abstracted, and he seemed lost in thought.  For some time, he appeared doubtful whether he ought to be relieved or disappointed by the intelligence; but at length he breathed more freely; and withdrawing his eyes, observed that it was no great matter. With that he rose, as if to depart.
children.prevalue: The man looked fixedly at him when he had given this information and although he did not withdraw his eyes for some time afterwards his gaze gradually became vacant and abstracted and he seemed lost in thought For some time he appeared doubtful whether he ought to be relieved or disappointed by the intelligence but at length he breathed more freely and withdrawing his eyes observed that it was no great matter With that he rose as if to depart

children.name: Paragraph_91
children.value: But Mr. Bumble was cunning enough; and he at once saw that an opportunity was opened, for the lucrative disposal of some secret in the possession of his better half.  He well remembered the night of old Sally's death, which the occurrences of that day had given him good reason to recollect, as the occasion on which he had proposed to Mrs. Corney; and although that lady had never confided to him the disclosure of which she had been the solitary witness, he had heard enough to know that it related to something that had occurred in the old woman's attendance, as workhouse nurse, upon the young mother of Oliver Twist. Hastily calling this circumstance to mind, he informed the stranger, with an air of mystery, that one woman had been closeted with the old harridan shortly before she died; and that she could, as he had reason to believe, throw some light on the subject of his inquiry.
children.prevalue: But Mr Bumble was cunning enough and he at once saw that an opportunity was opened for the lucrative disposal of some secret in the possession of his better half He well remembered the night of old Sally s death which the occurrences of that day had given him good reason to recollect as the occasion on which he had proposed to Mrs Corney and although that lady had never confided to him the disclosure of which she had been the solitary witness he had heard enough to know that it related to something that had occurred in the old woman s attendance as workhouse nurse upon the young mother of Oliver Twist Hastily calling this circumstance to mind he informed the stranger with an air of mystery that one woman had been closeted with the old harridan shortly before she died and that she could as he had reason to believe throw some light on the subject of his inquiry

children.name: Paragraph_92
children.value: 'How can I find her?' said the stranger, thrown off his guard; and plainly showing that all his fears (whatever they were) were aroused afresh by the intelligence.
children.prevalue: How can I find her said the stranger thrown off his guard and plainly showing that all his fears whatever they were were aroused afresh by the intelligence

children.name: Paragraph_93
children.value: 'Only through me,' rejoined Mr. Bumble.
children.prevalue: Only through me rejoined Mr Bumble

children.name: Paragraph_94
children.value: 'When?' cried the stranger, hastily.
children.prevalue: When cried the stranger hastily

children.name: Paragraph_95
children.value: 'To-morrow,' rejoined Bumble.
children.prevalue: To morrow rejoined Bumble

children.name: Paragraph_96
children.value: 'At nine in the evening,' said the stranger, producing a scrap of paper, and writing down upon it, an obscure address by the water-side, in characters that betrayed his agitation; 'at nine in the evening, bring her to me there.  I needn't tell you to be secret.  It's your interest.'
children.prevalue: At nine in the evening said the stranger producing a scrap of paper and writing down upon it an obscure address by the water side in characters that betrayed his agitation at nine in the evening bring her to me there I needn t tell you to be secret It s your interest

children.name: Paragraph_97
children.value: With these words, he led the way to the door, after stopping to pay for the liquor that had been drunk.  Shortly remarking that their roads were different, he departed, without more ceremony than an emphatic repetition of the hour of appointment for the following night.
children.prevalue: With these words he led the way to the door after stopping to pay for the liquor that had been drunk Shortly remarking that their roads were different he departed without more ceremony than an emphatic repetition of the hour of appointment for the following night

children.name: Paragraph_98
children.value: On glancing at the address, the parochial functionary observed that it contained no name.  The stranger had not gone far, so he made after him to ask it.
children.prevalue: On glancing at the address the parochial functionary observed that it contained no name The stranger had not gone far so he made after him to ask it

children.name: Paragraph_99
children.value: 'What do you want?' cried the man, turning quickly round, as Bumble touched him on the arm.  'Following me?'
children.prevalue: What do you want cried the man turning quickly round as Bumble touched him on the arm Following me

children.name: Paragraph_100
children.value: 'Only to ask a question,' said the other, pointing to the scrap of paper.  'What name am I to ask for?'
children.prevalue: Only to ask a question said the other pointing to the scrap of paper What name am I to ask for

children.name: Paragraph_101
children.value: 'Monks!' rejoined the man; and strode hastily, away.
children.prevalue: Monks rejoined the man and strode hastily away

children.name: Paragraph_1
children.value: CONTAINING AN ACCOUNT OF WHAT PASSED BETWEEN MR. AND MRS. BUMBLE, AND MR. MONKS, AT THEIR NOCTURNAL INTERVIEW
children.prevalue: CONTAINING AN ACCOUNT OF WHAT PASSED BETWEEN MR AND MRS BUMBLE AND MR MONKS AT THEIR NOCTURNAL INTERVIEW

children.name: Paragraph_2
children.value: It was a dull, close, overcast summer evening.  The clouds, which had been threatening all day, spread out in a dense and sluggish mass of vapour, already yielded large drops of rain, and seemed to presage a violent thunder-storm, when Mr. and Mrs. Bumble, turning out of the main street of the town, directed their course towards a scattered little colony of ruinous houses, distant from it some mile and a-half, or thereabouts, and erected on a low unwholesome swamp, bordering upon the river.
children.prevalue: It was a dull close overcast summer evening The clouds which had been threatening all day spread out in a dense and sluggish mass of vapour already yielded large drops of rain and seemed to presage a violent thunder storm when Mr and Mrs Bumble turning out of the main street of the town directed their course towards a scattered little colony of ruinous houses distant from it some mile and a half or thereabouts and erected on a low unwholesome swamp bordering upon the river

children.name: Paragraph_3
children.value: They were both wrapped in old and shabby outer garments, which might, perhaps, serve the double purpose of protecting their persons from the rain, and sheltering them from observation.  The husband carried a lantern, from which, however, no light yet shone; and trudged on, a few paces in front, as though--the way being dirty--to give his wife the benefit of treading in his heavy footprints.  They went on, in profound silence; every now and then, Mr. Bumble relaxed his pace, and turned his head as if to make sure that his helpmate was following; then, discovering that she was close at his heels, he mended his rate of walking, and proceeded, at a considerable increase of speed, towards their place of destination.
children.prevalue: They were both wrapped in old and shabby outer garments which might perhaps serve the double purpose of protecting their persons from the rain and sheltering them from observation The husband carried a lantern from which however no light yet shone and trudged on a few paces in front as though the way being dirty to give his wife the benefit of treading in his heavy footprints They went on in profound silence every now and then Mr Bumble relaxed his pace and turned his head as if to make sure that his helpmate was following then discovering that she was close at his heels he mended his rate of walking and proceeded at a considerable increase of speed towards their place of destination

children.name: Paragraph_4
children.value: This was far from being a place of doubtful character; for it had long been known as the residence of none but low ruffians, who, under various pretences of living by their labour, subsisted chiefly on plunder and crime.  It was a collection of mere hovels:  some, hastily built with loose bricks: others, of old worm-eaten ship-timber: jumbled together without any attempt at order or arrangement, and planted, for the most part, within a few feet of the river's bank.  A few leaky boats drawn up on the mud, and made fast to the dwarf wall which skirted it:  and here and there an oar or coil of rope:  appeared, at first, to indicate that the inhabitants of these miserable cottages pursued some avocation on the river; but a glance at the shattered and useless condition of the articles thus displayed, would have led a passer-by, without much difficulty, to the conjecture that they were disposed there, rather for the preservation of appearances, than with any view to their being actually employed.
children.prevalue: This was far from being a place of doubtful character for it had long been known as the residence of none but low ruffians who under various pretences of living by their labour subsisted chiefly on plunder and crime It was a collection of mere hovels some hastily built with loose bricks others of old worm eaten ship timber jumbled together without any attempt at order or arrangement and planted for the most part within a few feet of the river s bank A few leaky boats drawn up on the mud and made fast to the dwarf wall which skirted it and here and there an oar or coil of rope appeared at first to indicate that the inhabitants of these miserable cottages pursued some avocation on the river but a glance at the shattered and useless condition of the articles thus displayed would have led a passer by without much difficulty to the conjecture that they were disposed there rather for the preservation of appearances than with any view to their being actually employed

children.name: Paragraph_5
children.value: In the heart of this cluster of huts; and skirting the river, which its upper stories overhung; stood a large building, formerly used as a manufactory of some kind.  It had, in its day, probably furnished employment to the inhabitants of the surrounding tenements.  But it had long since gone to ruin.  The rat, the worm, and the action of the damp, had weakened and rotted the piles on which it stood; and a considerable portion of the building had already sunk down into the water; while the remainder, tottering and bending over the dark stream, seemed to wait a favourable opportunity of following its old companion, and involving itself in the same fate.
children.prevalue: In the heart of this cluster of huts and skirting the river which its upper stories overhung stood a large building formerly used as a manufactory of some kind It had in its day probably furnished employment to the inhabitants of the surrounding tenements But it had long since gone to ruin The rat the worm and the action of the damp had weakened and rotted the piles on which it stood and a considerable portion of the building had already sunk down into the water while the remainder tottering and bending over the dark stream seemed to wait a favourable opportunity of following its old companion and involving itself in the same fate

children.name: Paragraph_6
children.value: It was before this ruinous building that the worthy couple paused, as the first peal of distant thunder reverberated in the air, and the rain commenced pouring violently down.
children.prevalue: It was before this ruinous building that the worthy couple paused as the first peal of distant thunder reverberated in the air and the rain commenced pouring violently down

children.name: Paragraph_7
children.value: 'The place should be somewhere here,' said Bumble, consulting a scrap of paper he held in his hand.
children.prevalue: The place should be somewhere here said Bumble consulting a scrap of paper he held in his hand

children.name: Paragraph_8
children.value: 'Halloa there!' cried a voice from above.
children.prevalue: Halloa there cried a voice from above

children.name: Paragraph_9
children.value: Following the sound, Mr. Bumble raised his head and descried a man looking out of a door, breast-high, on the second story.
children.prevalue: Following the sound Mr Bumble raised his head and descried a man looking out of a door breast high on the second story

children.name: Paragraph_10
children.value: 'Stand still, a minute,' cried the voice; 'I'll be with you directly.' With which the head disappeared, and the door closed.
children.prevalue: Stand still a minute cried the voice I ll be with you directly With which the head disappeared and the door closed

children.name: Paragraph_11
children.value: 'Is that the man?' asked Mr. Bumble's good lady.
children.prevalue: Is that the man asked Mr Bumble s good lady

children.name: Paragraph_12
children.value: Mr. Bumble nodded in the affirmative.
children.prevalue: Mr Bumble nodded in the affirmative

children.name: Paragraph_13
children.value: 'Then, mind what I told you,' said the matron: 'and be careful to say as little as you can, or you'll betray us at once.'
children.prevalue: Then mind what I told you said the matron and be careful to say as little as you can or you ll betray us at once

children.name: Paragraph_14
children.value: Mr. Bumble, who had eyed the building with very rueful looks, was apparently about to express some doubts relative to the advisability of proceeding any further with the enterprise just then, when he was prevented by the appearance of Monks: who opened a small door, near which they stood, and beckoned them inwards.
children.prevalue: Mr Bumble who had eyed the building with very rueful looks was apparently about to express some doubts relative to the advisability of proceeding any further with the enterprise just then when he was prevented by the appearance of Monks who opened a small door near which they stood and beckoned them inwards

children.name: Paragraph_15
children.value: 'Come in!' he cried impatiently, stamping his foot upon the ground. 'Don't keep me here!'
children.prevalue: Come in he cried impatiently stamping his foot upon the ground Don t keep me here

children.name: Paragraph_16
children.value: The woman, who had hesitated at first, walked boldly in, without any other invitation.  Mr. Bumble, who was ashamed or afraid to lag behind, followed:  obviously very ill at ease and with scarcely any of that remarkable dignity which was usually his chief characteristic.
children.prevalue: The woman who had hesitated at first walked boldly in without any other invitation Mr Bumble who was ashamed or afraid to lag behind followed obviously very ill at ease and with scarcely any of that remarkable dignity which was usually his chief characteristic

children.name: Paragraph_17
children.value: 'What the devil made you stand lingering there, in the wet?' said Monks, turning round, and addressing Bumble, after he had bolted the door behind them.
children.prevalue: What the devil made you stand lingering there in the wet said Monks turning round and addressing Bumble after he had bolted the door behind them

children.name: Paragraph_18
children.value: 'We--we were only cooling ourselves,' stammered Bumble, looking apprehensively about him.
children.prevalue: We we were only cooling ourselves stammered Bumble looking apprehensively about him

children.name: Paragraph_19
children.value: 'Cooling yourselves!' retorted Monks.  'Not all the rain that ever fell, or ever will fall, will put as much of hell's fire out, as a man can carry about with him.  You won't cool yourself so easily; don't think it!'
children.prevalue: Cooling yourselves retorted Monks Not all the rain that ever fell or ever will fall will put as much of hell s fire out as a man can carry about with him You won t cool yourself so easily don t think it

children.name: Paragraph_20
children.value: With this agreeable speech, Monks turned short upon the matron, and bent his gaze upon her, till even she, who was not easily cowed, was fain to withdraw her eyes, and turn them towards the ground.
children.prevalue: With this agreeable speech Monks turned short upon the matron and bent his gaze upon her till even she who was not easily cowed was fain to withdraw her eyes and turn them towards the ground

children.name: Paragraph_21
children.value: 'This is the woman, is it?' demanded Monks.
children.prevalue: This is the woman is it demanded Monks

children.name: Paragraph_22
children.value: 'Hem!  That is the woman,' replied Mr. Bumble, mindful of his wife's caution.
children.prevalue: Hem That is the woman replied Mr Bumble mindful of his wife s caution

children.name: Paragraph_23
children.value: 'You think women never can keep secrets, I suppose?' said the matron, interposing, and returning, as she spoke, the searching look of Monks.
children.prevalue: You think women never can keep secrets I suppose said the matron interposing and returning as she spoke the searching look of Monks

children.name: Paragraph_24
children.value: 'I know they will always keep one till it's found out,' said Monks.
children.prevalue: I know they will always keep one till it s found out said Monks

children.name: Paragraph_25
children.value: 'And what may that be?' asked the matron.
children.prevalue: And what may that be asked the matron

children.name: Paragraph_26
children.value: 'The loss of their own good name,' replied Monks.  'So, by the same rule, if a woman's a party to a secret that might hang or transport her, I'm not afraid of her telling it to anybody; not I!  Do you understand, mistress?'
children.prevalue: The loss of their own good name replied Monks So by the same rule if a woman s a party to a secret that might hang or transport her I m not afraid of her telling it to anybody not I Do you understand mistress

children.name: Paragraph_27
children.value: 'No,' rejoined the matron, slightly colouring as she spoke.
children.prevalue: No rejoined the matron slightly colouring as she spoke

children.name: Paragraph_28
children.value: 'Of course you don't!' said Monks.  'How should you?'
children.prevalue: Of course you don t said Monks How should you

children.name: Paragraph_29
children.value: Bestowing something half-way between a smile and a frown upon his two companions, and again beckoning them to follow him, the man hastened across the apartment, which was of considerable extent, but low in the roof.  He was preparing to ascend a steep staircase, or rather ladder, leading to another floor of warehouses above:  when a bright flash of lightning streamed down the aperture, and a peal of thunder followed, which shook the crazy building to its centre.
children.prevalue: Bestowing something half way between a smile and a frown upon his two companions and again beckoning them to follow him the man hastened across the apartment which was of considerable extent but low in the roof He was preparing to ascend a steep staircase or rather ladder leading to another floor of warehouses above when a bright flash of lightning streamed down the aperture and a peal of thunder followed which shook the crazy building to its centre

children.name: Paragraph_30
children.value: 'Hear it!' he cried, shrinking back.  'Hear it!  Rolling and crashing on as if it echoed through a thousand caverns where the devils were hiding from it.  I hate the sound!'
children.prevalue: Hear it he cried shrinking back Hear it Rolling and crashing on as if it echoed through a thousand caverns where the devils were hiding from it I hate the sound

children.name: Paragraph_31
children.value: He remained silent for a few moments; and then, removing his hands suddenly from his face, showed, to the unspeakable discomposure of Mr. Bumble, that it was much distorted and discoloured.
children.prevalue: He remained silent for a few moments and then removing his hands suddenly from his face showed to the unspeakable discomposure of Mr Bumble that it was much distorted and discoloured

children.name: Paragraph_32
children.value: 'These fits come over me, now and then,' said Monks, observing his alarm; 'and thunder sometimes brings them on. Don't mind me now; it's all over for this once.'
children.prevalue: These fits come over me now and then said Monks observing his alarm and thunder sometimes brings them on Don t mind me now it s all over for this once

children.name: Paragraph_33
children.value: Thus speaking, he led the way up the ladder; and hastily closing the window-shutter of the room into which it led, lowered a lantern which hung at the end of a rope and pulley passed through one of the heavy beams in the ceiling:  and which cast a dim light upon an old table and three chairs that were placed beneath it.
children.prevalue: Thus speaking he led the way up the ladder and hastily closing the window shutter of the room into which it led lowered a lantern which hung at the end of a rope and pulley passed through one of the heavy beams in the ceiling and which cast a dim light upon an old table and three chairs that were placed beneath it

children.name: Paragraph_34
children.value: 'Now,' said Monks, when they had all three seated themselves, 'the sooner we come to our business, the better for all.  The woman know what it is, does she?'
children.prevalue: Now said Monks when they had all three seated themselves the sooner we come to our business the better for all The woman know what it is does she

children.name: Paragraph_35
children.value: The question was addressed to Bumble; but his wife anticipated the reply, by intimating that she was perfectly acquainted with it.
children.prevalue: The question was addressed to Bumble but his wife anticipated the reply by intimating that she was perfectly acquainted with it

children.name: Paragraph_36
children.value: 'He is right in saying that you were with this hag the night she died; and that she told you something--'
children.prevalue: He is right in saying that you were with this hag the night she died and that she told you something

children.name: Paragraph_37
children.value: 'About the mother of the boy you named,' replied the matron interrupting him.  'Yes.'
children.prevalue: About the mother of the boy you named replied the matron interrupting him Yes

children.name: Paragraph_38
children.value: 'The first question is, of what nature was her communication?' said Monks.
children.prevalue: The first question is of what nature was her communication said Monks

children.name: Paragraph_39
children.value: 'That's the second,' observed the woman with much deliberation. 'The first is, what may the communication be worth?'
children.prevalue: That s the second observed the woman with much deliberation The first is what may the communication be worth

children.name: Paragraph_40
children.value: 'Who the devil can tell that, without knowing of what kind it is?' asked Monks.
children.prevalue: Who the devil can tell that without knowing of what kind it is asked Monks

children.name: Paragraph_41
children.value: 'Nobody better than you, I am persuaded,' answered Mrs. Bumble: who did not want for spirit, as her yoke-fellow could abundantly testify.
children.prevalue: Nobody better than you I am persuaded answered Mrs Bumble who did not want for spirit as her yoke fellow could abundantly testify

children.name: Paragraph_42
children.value: 'Humph!' said Monks significantly, and with a look of eager inquiry; 'there may be money's worth to get, eh?'
children.prevalue: Humph said Monks significantly and with a look of eager inquiry there may be money s worth to get eh

children.name: Paragraph_43
children.value: 'Perhaps there may,' was the composed reply.
children.prevalue: Perhaps there may was the composed reply

children.name: Paragraph_44
children.value: 'Something that was taken from her,' said Monks.  'Something that she wore.  Something that--'
children.prevalue: Something that was taken from her said Monks Something that she wore Something that

children.name: Paragraph_45
children.value: 'You had better bid,' interrupted Mrs. Bumble.  'I have heard enough, already, to assure me that you are the man I ought to talk to.'
children.prevalue: You had better bid interrupted Mrs Bumble I have heard enough already to assure me that you are the man I ought to talk to

children.name: Paragraph_46
children.value: Mr. Bumble, who had not yet been admitted by his better half into any greater share of the secret than he had originally possessed, listened to this dialogue with outstretched neck and distended eyes:  which he directed towards his wife and Monks, by turns, in undisguised astonishment; increased, if possible, when the latter sternly demanded, what sum was required for the disclosure.
children.prevalue: Mr Bumble who had not yet been admitted by his better half into any greater share of the secret than he had originally possessed listened to this dialogue with outstretched neck and distended eyes which he directed towards his wife and Monks by turns in undisguised astonishment increased if possible when the latter sternly demanded what sum was required for the disclosure

children.name: Paragraph_47
children.value: 'What's it worth to you?' asked the woman, as collectedly as before.
children.prevalue: What s it worth to you asked the woman as collectedly as before

children.name: Paragraph_48
children.value: 'It may be nothing; it may be twenty pounds,' replied Monks. 'Speak out, and let me know which.'
children.prevalue: It may be nothing it may be twenty pounds replied Monks Speak out and let me know which

children.name: Paragraph_49
children.value: 'Add five pounds to the sum you have named; give me five-and-twenty pounds in gold,' said the woman; 'and I'll tell you all I know.  Not before.'
children.prevalue: Add five pounds to the sum you have named give me five and twenty pounds in gold said the woman and I ll tell you all I know Not before

children.name: Paragraph_50
children.value: 'Five-and-twenty pounds!' exclaimed Monks, drawing back.
children.prevalue: Five and twenty pounds exclaimed Monks drawing back

children.name: Paragraph_51
children.value: 'I spoke as plainly as I could,' replied Mrs. Bumble.  'It's not a large sum, either.'
children.prevalue: I spoke as plainly as I could replied Mrs Bumble It s not a large sum either

children.name: Paragraph_52
children.value: 'Not a large sum for a paltry secret, that may be nothing when it's told!' cried Monks impatiently; 'and which has been lying dead for twelve years past or more!'
children.prevalue: Not a large sum for a paltry secret that may be nothing when it s told cried Monks impatiently and which has been lying dead for twelve years past or more

children.name: Paragraph_53
children.value: 'Such matters keep well, and, like good wine, often double their value in course of time,' answered the matron, still preserving the resolute indifference she had assumed.  'As to lying dead, there are those who will lie dead for twelve thousand years to come, or twelve million, for anything you or I know, who will tell strange tales at last!'
children.prevalue: Such matters keep well and like good wine often double their value in course of time answered the matron still preserving the resolute indifference she had assumed As to lying dead there are those who will lie dead for twelve thousand years to come or twelve million for anything you or I know who will tell strange tales at last

children.name: Paragraph_54
children.value: 'What if I pay it for nothing?' asked Monks, hesitating.
children.prevalue: What if I pay it for nothing asked Monks hesitating

children.name: Paragraph_55
children.value: 'You can easily take it away again,' replied the matron. 'I am but a woman; alone here; and unprotected.'
children.prevalue: You can easily take it away again replied the matron I am but a woman alone here and unprotected

children.name: Paragraph_56
children.value: 'Not alone, my dear, nor unprotected, neither,' submitted Mr. Bumble, in a voice tremulous with fear: 'I am here, my dear. And besides,' said Mr. Bumble, his teeth chattering as he spoke, 'Mr. Monks is too much of a gentleman to attempt any violence on porochial persons.  Mr. Monks is aware that I am not a young man, my dear, and also that I am a little run to seed, as I may say; bu he has heerd:  I say I have no doubt Mr. Monks has heerd, my dear:  that I am a very determined officer, with very uncommon strength, if I'm once roused.  I only want a little rousing; that's all.'
children.prevalue: Not alone my dear nor unprotected neither submitted Mr Bumble in a voice tremulous with fear I am here my dear And besides said Mr Bumble his teeth chattering as he spoke Mr Monks is too much of a gentleman to attempt any violence on porochial persons Mr Monks is aware that I am not a young man my dear and also that I am a little run to seed as I may say bu he has heerd I say I have no doubt Mr Monks has heerd my dear that I am a very determined officer with very uncommon strength if I m once roused I only want a little rousing that s all

children.name: Paragraph_57
children.value: As Mr. Bumble spoke, he made a melancholy feint of grasping his lantern with fierce determination; and plainly showed, by the alarmed expression of every feature, that he did want a little rousing, and not a little, prior to making any very warlike demonstration: unless, indeed, against paupers, or other person or persons trained down for the purpose.
children.prevalue: As Mr Bumble spoke he made a melancholy feint of grasping his lantern with fierce determination and plainly showed by the alarmed expression of every feature that he did want a little rousing and not a little prior to making any very warlike demonstration unless indeed against paupers or other person or persons trained down for the purpose

children.name: Paragraph_58
children.value: 'You are a fool,' said Mrs. Bumble, in reply; 'and had better hold your tongue.'
children.prevalue: You are a fool said Mrs Bumble in reply and had better hold your tongue

children.name: Paragraph_59
children.value: 'He had better have cut it out, before he came, if he can't speak in a lower tone,' said Monks, grimly.  'So!  He's your husband, eh?'
children.prevalue: He had better have cut it out before he came if he can t speak in a lower tone said Monks grimly So He s your husband eh

children.name: Paragraph_60
children.value: 'He my husband!' tittered the matron, parrying the question.
children.prevalue: He my husband tittered the matron parrying the question

children.name: Paragraph_61
children.value: 'I thought as much, when you came in,' rejoined Monks, marking the angry glance which the lady darted at her spouse as she spoke.  'So much the better; I have less hesitation in dealing with two people, when I find that there's only one will between them.  I'm in earnest. See here!'
children.prevalue: I thought as much when you came in rejoined Monks marking the angry glance which the lady darted at her spouse as she spoke So much the better I have less hesitation in dealing with two people when I find that there s only one will between them I m in earnest See here

children.name: Paragraph_62
children.value: He thrust his hand into a side-pocket; and producing a canvas bag, told out twenty-five sovereigns on the table, and pushed them over to the woman.
children.prevalue: He thrust his hand into a side pocket and producing a canvas bag told out twenty five sovereigns on the table and pushed them over to the woman

children.name: Paragraph_63
children.value: 'Now,' he said, 'gather them up; and when this cursed peal of thunder, which I feel is coming up to break over the house-top, is gone, let's hear your story.'
children.prevalue: Now he said gather them up and when this cursed peal of thunder which I feel is coming up to break over the house top is gone let s hear your story

children.name: Paragraph_64
children.value: The thunder, which seemed in fact much nearer, and to shiver and break almost over their heads, having subsided, Monks, raising his face from the table, bent forward to listen to what the woman should say.  The faces of the three nearly touched, as the two men leant over the small table in their eagerness to hear, and the woman also leant forward to render her whisper audible.  The sickly rays of the suspended lantern falling directly upon them, aggravated the paleness and anxiety of their countenances: which, encircled by the deepest gloom and darkness, looked ghastly in the extreme.
children.prevalue: The thunder which seemed in fact much nearer and to shiver and break almost over their heads having subsided Monks raising his face from the table bent forward to listen to what the woman should say The faces of the three nearly touched as the two men leant over the small table in their eagerness to hear and the woman also leant forward to render her whisper audible The sickly rays of the suspended lantern falling directly upon them aggravated the paleness and anxiety of their countenances which encircled by the deepest gloom and darkness looked ghastly in the extreme

children.name: Paragraph_65
children.value: 'When this woman, that we called old Sally, died,' the matron began, 'she and I were alone.'
children.prevalue: When this woman that we called old Sally died the matron began she and I were alone

children.name: Paragraph_66
children.value: 'Was there no one by?' asked Monks, in the same hollow whisper; 'No sick wretch or idiot in some other bed?  No one who could hear, and might, by possibility, understand?'
children.prevalue: Was there no one by asked Monks in the same hollow whisper No sick wretch or idiot in some other bed No one who could hear and might by possibility understand

children.name: Paragraph_67
children.value: 'Not a soul,' replied the woman; 'we were alone.  I stood alone beside the body when death came over it.'
children.prevalue: Not a soul replied the woman we were alone I stood alone beside the body when death came over it

children.name: Paragraph_68
children.value: 'Good,' said Monks, regarding her attentively.  'Go on.'
children.prevalue: Good said Monks regarding her attentively Go on

children.name: Paragraph_69
children.value: 'She spoke of a young creature,' resumed the matron, 'who had brought a child into the world some years before; not merely in the same room, but in the same bed, in which she then lay dying.'
children.prevalue: She spoke of a young creature resumed the matron who had brought a child into the world some years before not merely in the same room but in the same bed in which she then lay dying

children.name: Paragraph_70
children.value: 'Ay?' said Monks, with quivering lip, and glancing over his shoulder, 'Blood!  How things come about!'
children.prevalue: Ay said Monks with quivering lip and glancing over his shoulder Blood How things come about

children.name: Paragraph_71
children.value: 'The child was the one you named to him last night,' said the matron, nodding carelessly towards her husband; 'the mother this nurse had robbed.'
children.prevalue: The child was the one you named to him last night said the matron nodding carelessly towards her husband the mother this nurse had robbed

children.name: Paragraph_72
children.value: 'In life?' asked Monks.
children.prevalue: In life asked Monks

children.name: Paragraph_73
children.value: 'In death,' replied the woman, with something like a shudder. 'She stole from the corpse, when it had hardly turned to one, that which the dead mother had prayed her, with her last breath, to keep for the infant's sake.'
children.prevalue: In death replied the woman with something like a shudder She stole from the corpse when it had hardly turned to one that which the dead mother had prayed her with her last breath to keep for the infant s sake

children.name: Paragraph_74
children.value: 'She sold it,' cried Monks, with desperate eagerness; 'did she sell it? Where?  When?  To whom?  How long before?'
children.prevalue: She sold it cried Monks with desperate eagerness did she sell it Where When To whom How long before

children.name: Paragraph_75
children.value: 'As she told me, with great difficulty, that she had done this,' said the matron, 'she fell back and died.'
children.prevalue: As she told me with great difficulty that she had done this said the matron she fell back and died

children.name: Paragraph_76
children.value: 'Without saying more?' cried Monks, in a voice which, from its very suppression, seemed only the more furious.  'It's a lie! I'll not be played with.  She said more.  I'll tear the life out of you both, but I'll know what it was.'
children.prevalue: Without saying more cried Monks in a voice which from its very suppression seemed only the more furious It s a lie I ll not be played with She said more I ll tear the life out of you both but I ll know what it was

children.name: Paragraph_77
children.value: 'She didn't utter another word,' said the woman, to all appearance unmoved (as Mr. Bumble was very far from being) by the strange man's violence; 'but she clutched my gown, violently, with one hand, which was partly closed; and when I saw that she was dead, and so removed the hand by force, I found it clasped a scrap of dirty paper.'
children.prevalue: She didn t utter another word said the woman to all appearance unmoved as Mr Bumble was very far from being by the strange man s violence but she clutched my gown violently with one hand which was partly closed and when I saw that she was dead and so removed the hand by force I found it clasped a scrap of dirty paper

children.name: Paragraph_78
children.value: 'Which contained--' interposed Monks, stretching forward.
children.prevalue: Which contained interposed Monks stretching forward

children.name: Paragraph_79
children.value: 'Nothing,' replied the woman; 'it was a pawnbroker's duplicate.'
children.prevalue: Nothing replied the woman it was a pawnbroker s duplicate

children.name: Paragraph_80
children.value: 'For what?' demanded Monks.
children.prevalue: For what demanded Monks

children.name: Paragraph_81
children.value: 'In good time I'll tell you.' said the woman.  'I judge that she had kept the trinket, for some time, in the hope of turning it to better account; and then had pawned it; and had saved or scraped together money to pay the pawnbroker's interest year by year, and prevent its running out; so that if anything came of it, it could still be redeemed.  Nothing had come of it; and, as I tell you, she died with the scrap of paper, all worn and tattered, in her hand.  The time was out in two days; I thought something might one day come of it too; and so redeemed the pledge.'
children.prevalue: In good time I ll tell you said the woman I judge that she had kept the trinket for some time in the hope of turning it to better account and then had pawned it and had saved or scraped together money to pay the pawnbroker s interest year by year and prevent its running out so that if anything came of it it could still be redeemed Nothing had come of it and as I tell you she died with the scrap of paper all worn and tattered in her hand The time was out in two days I thought something might one day come of it too and so redeemed the pledge

children.name: Paragraph_82
children.value: 'Where is it now?' asked Monks quickly.
children.prevalue: Where is it now asked Monks quickly

children.name: Paragraph_83
children.value: 'There,' replied the woman.  And, as if glad to be relieved of it, she hastily threw upon the table a small kid bag scarcely large enough for a French watch, which Monks pouncing upon, tore open with trembling hands.  It contained a little gold locket: in which were two locks of hair, and a plain gold wedding-ring.
children.prevalue: There replied the woman And as if glad to be relieved of it she hastily threw upon the table a small kid bag scarcely large enough for a French watch which Monks pouncing upon tore open with trembling hands It contained a little gold locket in which were two locks of hair and a plain gold wedding ring

children.name: Paragraph_84
children.value: 'It has the word Agnes engraved on the inside,' said the woman.
children.prevalue: It has the word Agnes engraved on the inside said the woman

children.name: Paragraph_85
children.value: 'There is a blank left for the surname; and then follows the date; which is within a year before the child was born.  I found out that.'
children.prevalue: There is a blank left for the surname and then follows the date which is within a year before the child was born I found out that

children.name: Paragraph_86
children.value: 'And this is all?' said Monks, after a close and eager scrutiny of the contents of the little packet.
children.prevalue: And this is all said Monks after a close and eager scrutiny of the contents of the little packet

children.name: Paragraph_87
children.value: 'All,' replied the woman.
children.prevalue: All replied the woman

children.name: Paragraph_88
children.value: Mr. Bumble drew a long breath, as if he were glad to find that the story was over, and no mention made of taking the five-and-twenty pounds back again; and now he took courage to wipe the perspiration which had been trickling over his nose, unchecked, during the whole of the previous dialogue.
children.prevalue: Mr Bumble drew a long breath as if he were glad to find that the story was over and no mention made of taking the five and twenty pounds back again and now he took courage to wipe the perspiration which had been trickling over his nose unchecked during the whole of the previous dialogue

children.name: Paragraph_89
children.value: 'I know nothing of the story, beyond what I can guess at,' said his wife addressing Monks, after a short silence; 'and I want to know nothing; for it's safer not.  But I may ask you two questions, may I?'
children.prevalue: I know nothing of the story beyond what I can guess at said his wife addressing Monks after a short silence and I want to know nothing for it s safer not But I may ask you two questions may I

children.name: Paragraph_90
children.value: 'You may ask,' said Monks, with some show of surprise; 'but whether I answer or not is another question.'
children.prevalue: You may ask said Monks with some show of surprise but whether I answer or not is another question

children.name: Paragraph_91
children.value: '--Which makes three,' observed Mr. Bumble, essaying a stroke of facetiousness.
children.prevalue: Which makes three observed Mr Bumble essaying a stroke of facetiousness

children.name: Paragraph_92
children.value: 'Is that what you expected to get from me?' demanded the matron.
children.prevalue: Is that what you expected to get from me demanded the matron

children.name: Paragraph_93
children.value: 'It is,' replied Monks.  'The other question?'
children.prevalue: It is replied Monks The other question

children.name: Paragraph_94
children.value: 'What do you propose to do with it?  Can it be used against me?'
children.prevalue: What do you propose to do with it Can it be used against me

children.name: Paragraph_95
children.value: 'Never,' rejoined Monks; 'nor against me either.  See here!  But don't move a step forward, or your life is not worth a bulrush.'
children.prevalue: Never rejoined Monks nor against me either See here But don t move a step forward or your life is not worth a bulrush

children.name: Paragraph_96
children.value: With these words, he suddenly wheeled the table aside, and pulling an iron ring in the boarding, threw back a large trap-door which opened close at Mr. Bumble's feet, and caused that gentleman to retire several paces backward, with great precipitation.
children.prevalue: With these words he suddenly wheeled the table aside and pulling an iron ring in the boarding threw back a large trap door which opened close at Mr Bumble s feet and caused that gentleman to retire several paces backward with great precipitation

children.name: Paragraph_97
children.value: 'Look down,' said Monks, lowering the lantern into the gulf. 'Don't fear me.  I could have let you down, quietly enough, when you were seated over it, if that had been my game.'
children.prevalue: Look down said Monks lowering the lantern into the gulf Don t fear me I could have let you down quietly enough when you were seated over it if that had been my game

children.name: Paragraph_98
children.value: Thus encouraged, the matron drew near to the brink; and even Mr. Bumble himself, impelled by curiousity, ventured to do the same. The turbid water, swollen by the heavy rain, was rushing rapidly on below; and all other sounds were lost in the noise of its plashing and eddying against the green and slimy piles.  There had once been a water-mill beneath; the tide foaming and chafing round the few rotten stakes, and fragments of machinery that yet remained, seemed to dart onward, with a new impulse, when freed from the obstacles which had unavailingly attempted to stem its headlong course.
children.prevalue: Thus encouraged the matron drew near to the brink and even Mr Bumble himself impelled by curiousity ventured to do the same The turbid water swollen by the heavy rain was rushing rapidly on below and all other sounds were lost in the noise of its plashing and eddying against the green and slimy piles There had once been a water mill beneath the tide foaming and chafing round the few rotten stakes and fragments of machinery that yet remained seemed to dart onward with a new impulse when freed from the obstacles which had unavailingly attempted to stem its headlong course

children.name: Paragraph_99
children.value: 'If you flung a man's body down there, where would it be to-morrow morning?' said Monks, swinging the lantern to and fro in the dark well.
children.prevalue: If you flung a man s body down there where would it be to morrow morning said Monks swinging the lantern to and fro in the dark well

children.name: Paragraph_100
children.value: 'Twelve miles down the river, and cut to pieces besides,' replied Bumble, recoiling at the thought.
children.prevalue: Twelve miles down the river and cut to pieces besides replied Bumble recoiling at the thought

children.name: Paragraph_101
children.value: Monks drew the little packet from his breast, where he had hurriedly thrust it; and tying it to a leaden weight, which had formed a part of some pulley, and was lying on the floor, dropped it into the stream. It fell straight, and true as a die; clove the water with a scarcely audible splash; and was gone.
