children.name: Paragraph_3
children.value: It was a very dark night.  The day had been unfavourable, and at that hour and place there were few people stirring. Such as there were, hurried quickly past:  very possibly without seeing, but certainly without noticing, either the woman, or the man who kept her in view. Their appearance was not calculated to attract the importunate regards of such of London's destitute population, as chanced to take their way over the bridge that night in search of some cold arch or doorless hovel wherein to lay their heads; they stood there in silence:  neither speaking nor spoken to, by any one who passed.
children.prevalue: It was a very dark night The day had been unfavourable and at that hour and place there were few people stirring Such as there were hurried quickly past very possibly without seeing but certainly without noticing either the woman or the man who kept her in view Their appearance was not calculated to attract the importunate regards of such of London s destitute population as chanced to take their way over the bridge that night in search of some cold arch or doorless hovel wherein to lay their heads they stood there in silence neither speaking nor spoken to by any one who passed

children.name: Paragraph_4
children.value: A mist hung over the river, deepening the red glare of the fires that burnt upon the small craft moored off the different wharfs, and rendering darker and more indistinct the murky buildings on the banks. The old smoke-stained storehouses on either side, rose heavy and dull from the dense mass of roofs and gables, and frowned sternly upon water too black to reflect even their lumbering shapes. The tower of old Saint Saviour's Church, and the spire of Saint Magnus, so long the giant-warders of the ancient bridge, were visible in the gloom; but the forest of shipping below bridge, and the thickly scattered spires of churches above, were nearly all hidden from sight.
children.prevalue: A mist hung over the river deepening the red glare of the fires that burnt upon the small craft moored off the different wharfs and rendering darker and more indistinct the murky buildings on the banks The old smoke stained storehouses on either side rose heavy and dull from the dense mass of roofs and gables and frowned sternly upon water too black to reflect even their lumbering shapes The tower of old Saint Saviour s Church and the spire of Saint Magnus so long the giant warders of the ancient bridge were visible in the gloom but the forest of shipping below bridge and the thickly scattered spires of churches above were nearly all hidden from sight

children.name: Paragraph_5
children.value: The girl had taken a few restless turns to and fro--closely watched meanwhile by her hidden observer--when the heavy bell of St. Paul's tolled for the death of another day.  Midnight had come upon the crowded city.  The palace, the night-cellar, the jail, the madhouse: the chambers of birth and death, of health and sickness, the rigid face of the corpse and the calm sleep of the child:  midnight was upon them all.
children.prevalue: The girl had taken a few restless turns to and fro closely watched meanwhile by her hidden observer when the heavy bell of St Paul s tolled for the death of another day Midnight had come upon the crowded city The palace the night cellar the jail the madhouse the chambers of birth and death of health and sickness the rigid face of the corpse and the calm sleep of the child midnight was upon them all

children.name: Paragraph_6
children.value: The hour had not struck two minutes, when a young lady, accompanied by a grey-haired gentleman, alighted from a hackney-carriage within a short distance of the bridge, and, having dismissed the vehicle, walked straight towards it.  They had scarcely set foot upon its pavement, when the girl started, and immediately made towards them.
children.prevalue: The hour had not struck two minutes when a young lady accompanied by a grey haired gentleman alighted from a hackney carriage within a short distance of the bridge and having dismissed the vehicle walked straight towards it They had scarcely set foot upon its pavement when the girl started and immediately made towards them

children.name: Paragraph_7
children.value: They walked onward, looking about them with the air of persons who entertained some very slight expectation which had little chance of being realised, when they were suddenly joined by this new associate. They halted with an exclamation of surprise, but suppressed it immediately; for a man in the garments of a countryman came close up--brushed against them, indeed--at that precise moment.
children.prevalue: They walked onward looking about them with the air of persons who entertained some very slight expectation which had little chance of being realised when they were suddenly joined by this new associate They halted with an exclamation of surprise but suppressed it immediately for a man in the garments of a countryman came close up brushed against them indeed at that precise moment

children.name: Paragraph_8
children.value: 'Not here,' said Nancy hurriedly, 'I am afraid to speak to you here. Come away--out of the public road--down the steps yonder!'
children.prevalue: Not here said Nancy hurriedly I am afraid to speak to you here Come away out of the public road down the steps yonder

children.name: Paragraph_9
children.value: As she uttered these words, and indicated, with her hand, the direction in which she wished them to proceed, the countryman looked round, and roughly asking what they took up the whole pavement for, passed on.
children.prevalue: As she uttered these words and indicated with her hand the direction in which she wished them to proceed the countryman looked round and roughly asking what they took up the whole pavement for passed on

children.name: Paragraph_10
children.value: The steps to which the girl had pointed, were those which, on the Surrey bank, and on the same side of the bridge as Saint Saviour's Church, form a landing-stairs from the river.  To this spot, the man bearing the appearance of a countryman, hastened unobserved; and after a moment's survey of the place, he began to descend.
children.prevalue: The steps to which the girl had pointed were those which on the Surrey bank and on the same side of the bridge as Saint Saviour s Church form a landing stairs from the river To this spot the man bearing the appearance of a countryman hastened unobserved and after a moment s survey of the place he began to descend

children.name: Paragraph_11
children.value: These stairs are a part of the bridge; they consist of three flights. Just below the end of the second, going down, the stone wall on the left terminates in an ornamental pilaster facing towards the Thames. At this point the lower steps widen:  so that a person turning that angle of the wall, is necessarily unseen by any others on the stairs who chance to be above him, if only a step. The countryman looked hastily round, when he reached this point; and as there seemed no better place of concealment, and, the tide being out, there was plenty of room, he slipped aside, with his back to the pilaster, and there waited:  pretty certain that they would come no lower, and that even if he could not hear what was said, he could follow them again, with safety.
children.prevalue: These stairs are a part of the bridge they consist of three flights Just below the end of the second going down the stone wall on the left terminates in an ornamental pilaster facing towards the Thames At this point the lower steps widen so that a person turning that angle of the wall is necessarily unseen by any others on the stairs who chance to be above him if only a step The countryman looked hastily round when he reached this point and as there seemed no better place of concealment and the tide being out there was plenty of room he slipped aside with his back to the pilaster and there waited pretty certain that they would come no lower and that even if he could not hear what was said he could follow them again with safety

children.name: Paragraph_12
children.value: So tardily stole the time in this lonely place, and so eager was the spy to penetrate the motives of an interview so different from what he had been led to expect, that he more than once gave the matter up for lost, and persuaded himself, either that they had stopped far above, or had resorted to some entirely different spot to hold their mysterious conversation.  He was on the point of emerging from his hiding-place, and regaining the road above, when he heard the sound of footsteps, and directly afterwards of voices almost close at his ear.
children.prevalue: So tardily stole the time in this lonely place and so eager was the spy to penetrate the motives of an interview so different from what he had been led to expect that he more than once gave the matter up for lost and persuaded himself either that they had stopped far above or had resorted to some entirely different spot to hold their mysterious conversation He was on the point of emerging from his hiding place and regaining the road above when he heard the sound of footsteps and directly afterwards of voices almost close at his ear

children.name: Paragraph_13
children.value: He drew himself straight upright against the wall, and, scarcely breathing, listened attentively.
children.prevalue: He drew himself straight upright against the wall and scarcely breathing listened attentively

children.name: Paragraph_14
children.value: 'This is far enough,' said a voice, which was evidently that of the gentleman.  'I will not suffer the young lady to go any farther.  Many people would have distrusted you too much to have come even so far, but you see I am willing to humour you.'
children.prevalue: This is far enough said a voice which was evidently that of the gentleman I will not suffer the young lady to go any farther Many people would have distrusted you too much to have come even so far but you see I am willing to humour you

children.name: Paragraph_15
children.value: 'To humour me!' cried the voice of the girl whom he had followed. 'You're considerate, indeed, sir.  To humour me!  Well, well, it's no matter.'
children.prevalue: To humour me cried the voice of the girl whom he had followed You re considerate indeed sir To humour me Well well it s no matter

children.name: Paragraph_16
children.value: 'Why, for what,' said the gentleman in a kinder tone, 'for what purpose can you have brought us to this strange place?  Why not have let me speak to you, above there, where it is light, and there is something stirring, instead of bringing us to this dark and dismal hole?'
children.prevalue: Why for what said the gentleman in a kinder tone for what purpose can you have brought us to this strange place Why not have let me speak to you above there where it is light and there is something stirring instead of bringing us to this dark and dismal hole

children.name: Paragraph_17
children.value: 'I told you before,' replied Nancy, 'that I was afraid to speak to you there.  I don't know why it is,' said the girl, shuddering, 'but I have such a fear and dread upon me to-night that I can hardly stand.'
children.prevalue: I told you before replied Nancy that I was afraid to speak to you there I don t know why it is said the girl shuddering but I have such a fear and dread upon me to night that I can hardly stand

children.name: Paragraph_18
children.value: 'A fear of what?' asked the gentleman, who seemed to pity her.
children.prevalue: A fear of what asked the gentleman who seemed to pity her

children.name: Paragraph_19
children.value: 'I scarcely know of what,' replied the girl.  'I wish I did. Horrible thoughts of death, and shrouds with blood upon them, and a fear that has made me burn as if I was on fire, have been upon me all day.  I was reading a book to-night, to wile the time away, and the same things came into the print.'
children.prevalue: I scarcely know of what replied the girl I wish I did Horrible thoughts of death and shrouds with blood upon them and a fear that has made me burn as if I was on fire have been upon me all day I was reading a book to night to wile the time away and the same things came into the print

children.name: Paragraph_20
children.value: 'Imagination,' said the gentleman, soothing her.
children.prevalue: Imagination said the gentleman soothing her

children.name: Paragraph_21
children.value: 'No imagination,' replied the girl in a hoarse voice. 'I'll swear I saw coffin written in every page of the book in large black letters,--aye, and they carried one close to me, in the streets to-night.'
children.prevalue: No imagination replied the girl in a hoarse voice I ll swear I saw coffin written in every page of the book in large black letters aye and they carried one close to me in the streets to night

children.name: Paragraph_22
children.value: 'There is nothing unusual in that,' said the gentleman. 'They have passed me often.'
children.prevalue: There is nothing unusual in that said the gentleman They have passed me often

children.name: Paragraph_23
children.value: 'Real ones,' rejoined the girl.  'This was not.'
children.prevalue: Real ones rejoined the girl This was not

children.name: Paragraph_24
children.value: There was something so uncommon in her manner, that the flesh of the concealed listener crept as he heard the girl utter these words, and the blood chilled within him.  He had never experienced a greater relief than in hearing the sweet voice of the young lady as she begged her to be calm, and not allow herself to become the prey of such fearful fancies.
children.prevalue: There was something so uncommon in her manner that the flesh of the concealed listener crept as he heard the girl utter these words and the blood chilled within him He had never experienced a greater relief than in hearing the sweet voice of the young lady as she begged her to be calm and not allow herself to become the prey of such fearful fancies

children.name: Paragraph_25
children.value: 'Speak to her kindly,' said the young lady to her companion. 'Poor creature!  She seems to need it.'
children.prevalue: Speak to her kindly said the young lady to her companion Poor creature She seems to need it

children.name: Paragraph_26
children.value: 'Your haughty religious people would have held their heads up to see me as I am to-night, and preached of flames and vengeance,' cried the girl.  'Oh, dear lady, why ar'n't those who claim to be God's own folks as gentle and as kind to us poor wretches as you, who, having youth, and beauty, and all that they have lost, might be a little proud instead of so much humbler?'
children.prevalue: Your haughty religious people would have held their heads up to see me as I am to night and preached of flames and vengeance cried the girl Oh dear lady why ar n t those who claim to be God s own folks as gentle and as kind to us poor wretches as you who having youth and beauty and all that they have lost might be a little proud instead of so much humbler

children.name: Paragraph_27
children.value: 'Ah!' said the gentleman.  'A Turk turns his face, after washing it well, to the East, when he says his prayers; these good people, after giving their faces such a rub against the World as to take the smiles off, turn with no less regularity, to the darkest side of Heaven. Between the Mussulman and the Pharisee, commend me to the first!'
children.prevalue: Ah said the gentleman A Turk turns his face after washing it well to the East when he says his prayers these good people after giving their faces such a rub against the World as to take the smiles off turn with no less regularity to the darkest side of Heaven Between the Mussulman and the Pharisee commend me to the first

children.name: Paragraph_28
children.value: These words appeared to be addressed to the young lady, and were perhaps uttered with the view of affording Nancy time to recover herself.  The gentleman, shortly afterwards, addressed himself to her.
children.prevalue: These words appeared to be addressed to the young lady and were perhaps uttered with the view of affording Nancy time to recover herself The gentleman shortly afterwards addressed himself to her

children.prevalue: You were not here last Sunday night he said

children.prevalue: I couldn t come replied Nancy I was kept by force

children.name: Paragraph_31

children.name: Paragraph_32
children.value: 'Him that I told the young lady of before.'
children.prevalue: Him that I told the young lady of before

children.name: Paragraph_33
children.value: 'You were not suspected of holding any communication with anybody on the subject which has brought us here to-night, I hope?' asked the old gentleman.
children.prevalue: You were not suspected of holding any communication with anybody on the subject which has brought us here to night I hope asked the old gentleman

children.name: Paragraph_34
children.value: 'No,' replied the girl, shaking her head.  'It's not very easy for me to leave him unless he knows why; I couldn't give him a drink of laudanum before I came away.'

children.prevalue: Did he awake before you returned inquired the gentleman

children.prevalue: No and neither he nor any of them suspect me

children.name: Paragraph_37
children.value: 'Good,' said the gentleman.  'Now listen to me.'
children.prevalue: Good said the gentleman Now listen to me

children.value: 'I am ready,' replied the girl, as he paused for a moment.
children.prevalue: I am ready replied the girl as he paused for a moment

children.name: Paragraph_39
children.value: 'This young lady,' the gentleman began, 'has communicated to me, and to some other friends who can be safely trusted, what you told her nearly a fortnight since.  I confess to you that I had doubts, at first, whether you were to be implicitly relied upon, but now I firmly believe you are.'
children.prevalue: This young lady the gentleman began has communicated to me and to some other friends who can be safely trusted what you told her nearly a fortnight since I confess to you that I had doubts at first whether you were to be implicitly relied upon but now I firmly believe you are

children.prevalue: I am said the girl earnestly

children.name: Paragraph_41
children.value: 'I repeat that I firmly believe it.  To prove to you that I am disposed to trust you, I tell you without reserve, that we propose to extort the secret, whatever it may be, from the fear of this man Monks.  But if--if--' said the gentleman, 'he cannot be secured, or, if secured, cannot be acted upon as we wish, you must deliver up the Jew.'

children.prevalue: Fagin cried the girl recoiling

children.prevalue: That man must be delivered up by you said the gentleman

children.name: Paragraph_44

children.prevalue: I will not do it I will never do it replied the girl Devil that he is and worse than devil as he has been to me I will never do that

children.name: Paragraph_45
children.value: 'You will not?' said the gentleman, who seemed fully prepared for this answer.
children.prevalue: You will not said the gentleman who seemed fully prepared for this answer

children.name: Paragraph_46
children.value: 'Never!' returned the girl.
children.prevalue: Never returned the girl

children.name: Paragraph_47
children.value: 'Tell me why?'
children.prevalue: Tell me why

children.name: Paragraph_48
children.value: 'For one reason,' rejoined the girl firmly, 'for one reason, that the lady knows and will stand by me in, I know she will, for I have her promise:  and for this other reason, besides, that, bad life as he has led, I have led a bad life too; there are many of us who have kept the same courses together, and I'll not turn upon them, who might--any of them--have turned upon me, but didn't, bad as they are.'
children.prevalue: For one reason rejoined the girl firmly for one reason that the lady knows and will stand by me in I know she will for I have her promise and for this other reason besides that bad life as he has led I have led a bad life too there are many of us who have kept the same courses together and I ll not turn upon them who might any of them have turned upon me but didn t bad as they are

children.name: Paragraph_49
children.value: 'Then,' said the gentleman, quickly, as if this had been the point he had been aiming to attain; 'put Monks into my hands, and leave him to me to deal with.'
children.prevalue: Then said the gentleman quickly as if this had been the point he had been aiming to attain put Monks into my hands and leave him to me to deal with

children.name: Paragraph_50
children.value: 'What if he turns against the others?'
children.prevalue: What if he turns against the others

children.name: Paragraph_51
children.value: 'I promise you that in that case, if the truth is forced from him, there the matter will rest; there must be circumstances in Oliver's little history which it would be painful to drag before the public eye, and if the truth is once elicited, they shall go scot free.'
children.prevalue: I promise you that in that case if the truth is forced from him there the matter will rest there must be circumstances in Oliver s little history which it would be painful to drag before the public eye and if the truth is once elicited they shall go scot free

children.name: Paragraph_52
children.value: 'And if it is not?' suggested the girl.
children.prevalue: And if it is not suggested the girl

children.name: Paragraph_53
children.value: 'Then,' pursued the gentleman, 'this Fagin shall not be brought to justice without your consent.  In such a case I could show you reasons, I think, which would induce you to yield it.'
children.prevalue: Then pursued the gentleman this Fagin shall not be brought to justice without your consent In such a case I could show you reasons I think which would induce you to yield it

children.name: Paragraph_54
children.value: 'Have I the lady's promise for that?' asked the girl.
children.prevalue: Have I the lady s promise for that asked the girl

children.name: Paragraph_55
children.value: 'You have,' replied Rose.  'My true and faithful pledge.'
children.prevalue: You have replied Rose My true and faithful pledge

children.name: Paragraph_56
children.value: 'Monks would never learn how you knew what you do?' said the girl, after a short pause.
children.prevalue: Monks would never learn how you knew what you do said the girl after a short pause

children.name: Paragraph_57

children.prevalue: Never replied the gentleman The intelligence should be brought to bear upon him that he could never even guess

children.name: Paragraph_58
children.value: 'I have been a liar, and among liars from a little child,' said the girl after another interval of silence, 'but I will take your words.'
children.prevalue: I have been a liar and among liars from a little child said the girl after another interval of silence but I will take your words

children.name: Paragraph_59
children.value: After receiving an assurance from both, that she might safely do so, she proceeded in a voice so low that it was often difficult for the listener to discover even the purport of what she said, to describe, by name and situation, the public-house whence she had been followed that night.  From the manner in which she occasionally paused, it appeared as if the gentleman were making some hasty notes of the information she communicated.  When she had thoroughly explained the localities of the place, the best position from which to watch it without exciting observation, and the night and hour on which Monks was most in the habit of frequenting it, she seemed to consider for a few moments, for the purpose of recalling his features and appearances more forcibly to her recollection.

children.name: Paragraph_60
children.value: 'He is tall,' said the girl, 'and a strongly made man, but not stout; he has a lurking walk; and as he walks, constantly looks over his shoulder, first on one side, and then on the other. Don't forget that, for his eyes are sunk in his head so much deeper than any other man's, that you might almost tell him by that alone.  His face is dark, like his hair and eyes; and, although he can't be more than six or eight and twenty, withered and haggard. His lips are often discoloured and disfigured with the marks of teeth; for he has desperate fits, and sometimes even bites his hands and covers them with wounds--why did you start?' said the girl, stopping suddenly.
children.prevalue: He is tall said the girl and a strongly made man but not stout he has a lurking walk and as he walks constantly looks over his shoulder first on one side and then on the other Don t forget that for his eyes are sunk in his head so much deeper than any other man s that you might almost tell him by that alone His face is dark like his hair and eyes and although he can t be more than six or eight and twenty withered and haggard His lips are often discoloured and disfigured with the marks of teeth for he has desperate fits and sometimes even bites his hands and covers them with wounds why did you start said the girl stopping suddenly

children.name: Paragraph_61
children.value: The gentleman replied, in a hurried manner, that he was not conscious of having done so, and begged her to proceed.
children.prevalue: The gentleman replied in a hurried manner that he was not conscious of having done so and begged her to proceed

children.name: Paragraph_62
children.value: 'Part of this,' said the girl, 'I have drawn out from other people at the house I tell you of, for I have only seen him twice, and both times he was covered up in a large cloak.  I think that's all I can give you to know him by.  Stay though,' she added.  'Upon his throat:  so high that you can see a part of it below his neckerchief when he turns his face:  there is--'
children.prevalue: Part of this said the girl I have drawn out from other people at the house I tell you of for I have only seen him twice and both times he was covered up in a large cloak I think that s all I can give you to know him by Stay though she added Upon his throat so high that you can see a part of it below his neckerchief when he turns his face there is

children.name: Paragraph_63
children.value: 'A broad red mark, like a burn or scald?' cried the gentleman.
children.prevalue: A broad red mark like a burn or scald cried the gentleman

children.name: Paragraph_64

children.prevalue: How s this said the girl You know him

children.name: Paragraph_65
children.value: The young lady uttered a cry of surprise, and for a few moments they were so still that the listener could distinctly hear them breathe.
children.prevalue: The young lady uttered a cry of surprise and for a few moments they were so still that the listener could distinctly hear them breathe

children.name: Paragraph_66
children.value: 'I think I do,' said the gentleman, breaking silence.  'I should by your description.  We shall see.  Many people are singularly like each other.  It may not be the same.'
children.prevalue: I think I do said the gentleman breaking silence I should by your description We shall see Many people are singularly like each other It may not be the same

children.name: Paragraph_67
children.value: As he expressed himself to this effect, with assumed carelessness, he took a step or two nearer the concealed spy, as the latter could tell from the distinctness with which he heard him mutter, 'It must be he!'
children.prevalue: As he expressed himself to this effect with assumed carelessness he took a step or two nearer the concealed spy as the latter could tell from the distinctness with which he heard him mutter It must be he

children.name: Paragraph_68
children.value: 'Now,' he said, returning:  so it seemed by the sound:  to the spot where he had stood before, 'you have given us most valuable assistance, young woman, and I wish you to be the better for it. What can I do to serve you?'
children.prevalue: Now he said returning so it seemed by the sound to the spot where he had stood before you have given us most valuable assistance young woman and I wish you to be the better for it What can I do to serve you

children.name: Paragraph_69
children.value: 'Nothing,' replied Nancy.
children.prevalue: Nothing replied Nancy

children.name: Paragraph_70
children.value: 'You will not persist in saying that,' rejoined the gentleman, with a voice and emphasis of kindness that might have touched a much harder and more obdurate heart. 'Think now.  Tell me.'
children.prevalue: You will not persist in saying that rejoined the gentleman with a voice and emphasis of kindness that might have touched a much harder and more obdurate heart Think now Tell me

children.name: Paragraph_71
children.value: 'Nothing, sir,' rejoined the girl, weeping.  'You can do nothing to help me.  I am past all hope, indeed.'
children.prevalue: Nothing sir rejoined the girl weeping You can do nothing to help me I am past all hope indeed

children.name: Paragraph_72
children.value: 'You put yourself beyond its pale,' said the gentleman. 'The past has been a dreary waste with you, of youthful energies mis-spent, and such priceless treasures lavished, as the Creator bestows but once and never grants again, but, for the future, you may hope. I do not say that it is in our power to offer you peace of heart and mind, for that must come as you seek it; but a quiet asylum, either in England, or, if you fear to remain here, in some foreign country, it is not only within the compass of our ability but our most anxious wish to secure you. Before the dawn of morning, before this river wakes to the first glimpse of day-light, you shall be placed as entirely beyond the reach of your former associates, and leave as utter an absence of all trace behind you, as if you were to disappear from the earth this moment.  Come!  I would not have you go back to exchange one word with any old companion, or take one look at any old haunt, or breathe the very air which is pestilence and death to you.  Quit them all, while there is time and opportunity!'
children.prevalue: You put yourself beyond its pale said the gentleman The past has been a dreary waste with you of youthful energies mis spent and such priceless treasures lavished as the Creator bestows but once and never grants again but for the future you may hope I do not say that it is in our power to offer you peace of heart and mind for that must come as you seek it but a quiet asylum either in England or if you fear to remain here in some foreign country it is not only within the compass of our ability but our most anxious wish to secure you Before the dawn of morning before this river wakes to the first glimpse of day light you shall be placed as entirely beyond the reach of your former associates and leave as utter an absence of all trace behind you as if you were to disappear from the earth this moment Come I would not have you go back to exchange one word with any old companion or take one look at any old haunt or breathe the very air which is pestilence and death to you Quit them all while there is time and opportunity

children.name: Paragraph_73
children.value: 'She will be persuaded now,' cried the young lady.  'She hesitates, I am sure.'
children.prevalue: She will be persuaded now cried the young lady She hesitates I am sure

children.name: Paragraph_74
children.value: 'I fear not, my dear,' said the gentleman.
children.prevalue: I fear not my dear said the gentleman

children.name: Paragraph_75
children.value: 'No sir, I do not,' replied the girl, after a short struggle.  'I am chained to my old life.  I loathe and hate it now, but I cannot leave it.  I must have gone too far to turn back,--and yet I don't know, for if you had spoken to me so, some time ago, I should have laughed it off.  But,' she said, looking hastily round, 'this fear comes over me again.  I must go home.'
children.prevalue: No sir I do not replied the girl after a short struggle I am chained to my old life I loathe and hate it now but I cannot leave it I must have gone too far to turn back and yet I don t know for if you had spoken to me so some time ago I should have laughed it off But she said looking hastily round this fear comes over me again I must go home

children.name: Paragraph_76
children.value: 'Home!' repeated the young lady, with great stress upon the word.
children.prevalue: Home repeated the young lady with great stress upon the word

children.name: Paragraph_77
children.value: 'Home, lady,' rejoined the girl.  'To such a home as I have raised for myself with the work of my whole life.  Let us part. I shall be watched or seen.  Go!  Go!  If I have done you any service all I ask is, that you leave me, and let me go my way alone.'
children.prevalue: Home lady rejoined the girl To such a home as I have raised for myself with the work of my whole life Let us part I shall be watched or seen Go Go If I have done you any service all I ask is that you leave me and let me go my way alone

children.name: Paragraph_78
children.value: 'It is useless,' said the gentleman, with a sigh.  'We compromise her safety, perhaps, by staying here.  We may have detained her longer than she expected already.'
children.prevalue: It is useless said the gentleman with a sigh We compromise her safety perhaps by staying here We may have detained her longer than she expected already

children.name: Paragraph_79
children.value: 'Yes, yes,' urged the girl. 'You have.'
children.prevalue: Yes yes urged the girl You have

children.name: Paragraph_80
children.value: 'What,' cried the young lady, 'can be the end of this poor creature's life!'
children.prevalue: What cried the young lady can be the end of this poor creature s life

children.name: Paragraph_81
children.value: 'What!' repeated the girl.  'Look before you, lady.  Look at that dark water.  How many times do you read of such as I who spring into the tide, and leave no living thing, to care for, or bewail them.  It may be years hence, or it may be only months, but I shall come to that at last.'
children.prevalue: What repeated the girl Look before you lady Look at that dark water How many times do you read of such as I who spring into the tide and leave no living thing to care for or bewail them It may be years hence or it may be only months but I shall come to that at last

children.name: Paragraph_82
children.value: 'Do not speak thus, pray,' returned the young lady, sobbing.
children.prevalue: Do not speak thus pray returned the young lady sobbing

children.name: Paragraph_83
children.value: 'It will never reach your ears, dear lady, and God forbid such horrors should!' replied the girl.  'Good-night, good-night!'
children.prevalue: It will never reach your ears dear lady and God forbid such horrors should replied the girl Good night good night

children.name: Paragraph_84
children.value: The gentleman turned away.
children.prevalue: The gentleman turned away

children.name: Paragraph_85
children.value: 'This purse,' cried the young lady.  'Take it for my sake, that you may have some resource in an hour of need and trouble.'
children.prevalue: This purse cried the young lady Take it for my sake that you may have some resource in an hour of need and trouble

children.name: Paragraph_86
children.value: 'No!' replied the girl.  'I have not done this for money.  Let me have that to think of.  And yet--give me something that you have worn:  I should like to have something--no, no, not a ring--your gloves or handkerchief--anything that I can keep, as having belonged to you, sweet lady.  There.  Bless you!  God bless you. Good-night, good-night!'

children.name: Paragraph_87
children.value: The violent agitation of the girl, and the apprehension of some discovery which would subject her to ill-usage and violence, seemed to determine the gentleman to leave her, as she requested.
children.prevalue: The violent agitation of the girl and the apprehension of some discovery which would subject her to ill usage and violence seemed to determine the gentleman to leave her as she requested

children.name: Paragraph_88
children.value: The sound of retreating footsteps were audible and the voices ceased.
children.prevalue: The sound of retreating footsteps were audible and the voices ceased

children.name: Paragraph_89
children.value: The two figures of the young lady and her companion soon afterwards appeared upon the bridge.  They stopped at the summit of the stairs.
children.prevalue: The two figures of the young lady and her companion soon afterwards appeared upon the bridge They stopped at the summit of the stairs

children.name: Paragraph_90
children.value: 'Hark!' cried the young lady, listening.  'Did she call!  I thought I heard her voice.'
children.prevalue: Hark cried the young lady listening Did she call I thought I heard her voice

children.name: Paragraph_91
children.value: 'No, my love,' replied Mr. Brownlow, looking sadly back. 'She has not moved, and will not till we are gone.'
children.prevalue: No my love replied Mr Brownlow looking sadly back She has not moved and will not till we are gone

children.name: Paragraph_92
children.value: Rose Maylie lingered, but the old gentleman drew her arm through his, and led her, with gentle force, away.  As they disappeared, the girl sunk down nearly at her full length upon one of the stone stairs, and vented the anguish of her heart in bitter tears.
children.prevalue: Rose Maylie lingered but the old gentleman drew her arm through his and led her with gentle force away As they disappeared the girl sunk down nearly at her full length upon one of the stone stairs and vented the anguish of her heart in bitter tears

children.name: Paragraph_93
children.value: After a time she arose, and with feeble and tottering steps ascended the street.  The astonished listener remained motionless on his post for some minutes afterwards, and having ascertained, with many cautious glances round him, that he was again alone, crept slowly from his hiding-place, and returned, stealthily and in the shade of the wall, in the same manner as he had descended.

children.name: Paragraph_94
children.value: Peeping out, more than once, when he reached the top, to make sure that he was unobserved, Noah Claypole darted away at his utmost speed, and made for the Jew's house as fast as his legs would carry him.

children.name: Paragraph_1
children.value: FATAL CONSEQUENCES
children.prevalue: FATAL CONSEQUENCES

children.name: Paragraph_2
children.value: It was nearly two hours before day-break; that time which in the autumn of the year, may be truly called the dead of night; when the streets are silent and deserted; when even sounds appear to slumber, and profligacy and riot have staggered home to dream; it was at this still and silent hour, that Fagin sat watching in his old lair, with face so distorted and pale, and eyes so red and blood-shot, that he looked less like a man, than like some hideous phantom, moist from the grave, and worried by an evil spirit.
children.prevalue: It was nearly two hours before day break that time which in the autumn of the year may be truly called the dead of night when the streets are silent and deserted when even sounds appear to slumber and profligacy and riot have staggered home to dream it was at this still and silent hour that Fagin sat watching in his old lair with face so distorted and pale and eyes so red and blood shot that he looked less like a man than like some hideous phantom moist from the grave and worried by an evil spirit

children.name: Paragraph_3
children.value: He sat crouching over a cold hearth, wrapped in an old torn coverlet, with his face turned towards a wasting candle that stood upon a table by his side.  His right hand was raised to his lips, and as, absorbed in thought, he hit his long black nails, he disclosed among his toothless gums a few such fangs as should have been a dog's or rat's.
children.prevalue: He sat crouching over a cold hearth wrapped in an old torn coverlet with his face turned towards a wasting candle that stood upon a table by his side His right hand was raised to his lips and as absorbed in thought he hit his long black nails he disclosed among his toothless gums a few such fangs as should have been a dog s or rat s

children.name: Paragraph_4
children.value: Stretched upon a mattress on the floor, lay Noah Claypole, fast asleep. Towards him the old man sometimes directed his eyes for an instant, and then brought them back again to the candle; which with a long-burnt wick drooping almost double, and hot grease falling down in clots upon the table, plainly showed that his thoughts were busy elsewhere.
children.prevalue: Stretched upon a mattress on the floor lay Noah Claypole fast asleep Towards him the old man sometimes directed his eyes for an instant and then brought them back again to the candle which with a long burnt wick drooping almost double and hot grease falling down in clots upon the table plainly showed that his thoughts were busy elsewhere

children.name: Paragraph_5
children.value: Indeed they were.  Mortification at the overthrow of his notable scheme; hatred of the girl who had dared to palter with strangers; and utter distrust of the sincerity of her refusal to yield him up; bitter disappointment at the loss of his revenge on Sikes; the fear of detection, and ruin, and death; and a fierce and deadly rage kindled by all; these were the passionate considerations which, following close upon each other with rapid and ceaseless whirl, shot through the brain of Fagin, as every evil thought and blackest purpose lay working at his heart.
children.prevalue: Indeed they were Mortification at the overthrow of his notable scheme hatred of the girl who had dared to palter with strangers and utter distrust of the sincerity of her refusal to yield him up bitter disappointment at the loss of his revenge on Sikes the fear of detection and ruin and death and a fierce and deadly rage kindled by all these were the passionate considerations which following close upon each other with rapid and ceaseless whirl shot through the brain of Fagin as every evil thought and blackest purpose lay working at his heart

children.name: Paragraph_6
children.value: He sat without changing his attitude in the least, or appearing to take the smallest heed of time, until his quick ear seemed to be attracted by a footstep in the street.
children.prevalue: He sat without changing his attitude in the least or appearing to take the smallest heed of time until his quick ear seemed to be attracted by a footstep in the street

children.name: Paragraph_7
children.value: 'At last,' he muttered, wiping his dry and fevered mouth. 'At last!'
children.prevalue: At last he muttered wiping his dry and fevered mouth At last

children.name: Paragraph_8
children.value: The bell rang gently as he spoke.  He crept upstairs to the door, and presently returned accompanied by a man muffled to the chin, who carried a bundle under one arm. Sitting down and throwing back his outer coat, the man displayed the burly frame of Sikes.
children.prevalue: The bell rang gently as he spoke He crept upstairs to the door and presently returned accompanied by a man muffled to the chin who carried a bundle under one arm Sitting down and throwing back his outer coat the man displayed the burly frame of Sikes

children.name: Paragraph_9
children.value: 'There!' he said, laying the bundle on the table.  'Take care of that, and do the most you can with it.  It's been trouble enough to get; I thought I should have been here, three hours ago.'
children.prevalue: There he said laying the bundle on the table Take care of that and do the most you can with it It s been trouble enough to get I thought I should have been here three hours ago

children.name: Paragraph_10
children.value: Fagin laid his hand upon the bundle, and locking it in the cupboard, sat down again without speaking.  But he did not take his eyes off the robber, for an instant, during this action; and now that they sat over against each other, face to face, he looked fixedly at him, with his lips quivering so violently, and his face so altered by the emotions which had mastered him, that the housebreaker involuntarily drew back his chair, and surveyed him with a look of real affright.
children.prevalue: Fagin laid his hand upon the bundle and locking it in the cupboard sat down again without speaking But he did not take his eyes off the robber for an instant during this action and now that they sat over against each other face to face he looked fixedly at him with his lips quivering so violently and his face so altered by the emotions which had mastered him that the housebreaker involuntarily drew back his chair and surveyed him with a look of real affright

children.name: Paragraph_11
children.value: 'Wot now?' cried Sikes.  'Wot do you look at a man so for?'
children.prevalue: Wot now cried Sikes Wot do you look at a man so for

children.name: Paragraph_12
children.value: Fagin raised his right hand, and shook his trembling forefinger in the air; but his passion was so great, that the power of speech was for the moment gone.
children.prevalue: Fagin raised his right hand and shook his trembling forefinger in the air but his passion was so great that the power of speech was for the moment gone

children.name: Paragraph_13

children.prevalue: Damme said Sikes feeling in his breast with a look of alarm He s gone mad I must look to myself here

children.value: 'No, no,' rejoined Fagin, finding his voice.  'It's not--you're not the person, Bill.  I've no--no fault to find with you.'
children.prevalue: No no rejoined Fagin finding his voice It s not you re not the person Bill I ve no no fault to find with you

children.name: Paragraph_15
children.value: 'Oh, you haven't, haven't you?' said Sikes, looking sternly at him, and ostentatiously passing a pistol into a more convenient pocket.  'That's lucky--for one of us.  Which one that is, don't matter.'
children.prevalue: Oh you haven t haven t you said Sikes looking sternly at him and ostentatiously passing a pistol into a more convenient pocket That s lucky for one of us Which one that is don t matter

children.name: Paragraph_16

children.prevalue: I ve got that to tell you Bill said Fagin drawing his chair nearer will make you worse than me

children.value: 'Aye?' returned the robber with an incredulous air.  'Tell away! Look sharp, or Nance will think I'm lost.'
children.prevalue: Aye returned the robber with an incredulous air Tell away Look sharp or Nance will think I m lost

children.prevalue: Sikes looked with an aspect of great perplexity into the Jew s face and reading no satisfactory explanation of the riddle there clenched his coat collar in his huge hand and shook him soundly

children.name: Paragraph_20
children.value: 'Speak, will you!' he said; 'or if you don't, it shall be for want of breath.  Open your mouth and say wot you've got to say in plain words. Out with it, you thundering old cur, out with it!'

children.prevalue: Suppose that lad that s laying there Fagin began

children.name: Paragraph_23
children.value: 'Suppose that lad,' pursued Fagin, 'was to peach--to blow upon us all--first seeking out the right folks for the purpose, and then having a meeting with 'em in the street to paint our likenesses, describe every mark that they might know us by, and the crib where we might be most easily taken.  Suppose he was to do all this, and besides to blow upon a plant we've all been in, more or less--of his own fancy; not grabbed, trapped, tried, earwigged by the parson and brought to it on bread and water,--but of his own fancy; to please his own taste; stealing out at nights to find those most interested against us, and peaching to them.  Do you hear me?' cried the Jew, his eyes flashing with rage.  'Suppose he did all this, what then?'

children.value: 'What then!' replied Sikes; with a tremendous oath.  'If he was left alive till I came, I'd grind his skull under the iron heel of my boot into as many grains as there are hairs upon his head.'

children.prevalue: What if I did it cried Fagin almost in a yell I that knows so much and could hang so many besides myself

children.name: Paragraph_26
children.value: 'I don't know,' replied Sikes, clenching his teeth and turning white at the mere suggestion.  'I'd do something in the jail that 'ud get me put in irons; and if I was tried along with you, I'd fall upon you with them in the open court, and beat your brains out afore the people. I should have such strength,' muttered the robber, poising his brawny arm, 'that I could smash your head as if a loaded waggon had gone over it.'

children.value: 'If it was Charley, or the Dodger, or Bet, or--'
children.prevalue: If it was Charley or the Dodger or Bet or

children.value: Fagin looked hard at the robber; and, motioning him to be silent, stooped over the bed upon the floor, and shook the sleeper to rouse him.  Sikes leant forward in his chair:  looking on with his hands upon his knees, as if wondering much what all this questioning and preparation was to end in.

children.value: 'Bolter, Bolter!  Poor lad!' said Fagin, looking up with an expression of devilish anticipation, and speaking slowly and with marked emphasis. 'He's tired--tired with watching for her so long,--watching for her, Bill.'
children.prevalue: Bolter Bolter Poor lad said Fagin looking up with an expression of devilish anticipation and speaking slowly and with marked emphasis He s tired tired with watching for her so long watching for her Bill

children.name: Paragraph_34
children.value: Fagin made no answer, but bending over the sleeper again, hauled him into a sitting posture.  When his assumed name had been repeated several times, Noah rubbed his eyes, and, giving a heavy yawn, looked sleepily about him.

children.prevalue: That about Nancy said Fagin clutching Sikes by the wrist as if to prevent his leaving the house before he had heard enough You followed her

children.name: Paragraph_38

children.prevalue: Yes

children.name: Paragraph_39

children.prevalue: To London Bridge

children.name: Paragraph_40
children.value: 'Yes.'
children.prevalue: Yes

children.prevalue: Where she met two people

children.prevalue: So she did

children.name: Paragraph_43
children.value: 'A gentleman and a lady that she had gone to of her own accord before, who asked her to give up all her pals, and Monks first, which she did--and to describe him, which she did--and to tell her what house it was that we meet at, and go to, which she did--and where it could be best watched from, which she did--and what time the people went there, which she did.  She did all this.  She told it all every word without a threat, without a murmur--she did--did she not?' cried Fagin, half mad with fury.
children.prevalue: A gentleman and a lady that she had gone to of her own accord before who asked her to give up all her pals and Monks first which she did and to describe him which she did and to tell her what house it was that we meet at and go to which she did and where it could be best watched from which she did and what time the people went there which she did She did all this She told it all every word without a threat without a murmur she did did she not cried Fagin half mad with fury

children.value: 'All right,' replied Noah, scratching his head.  'That's just what it was!'
children.prevalue: All right replied Noah scratching his head That s just what it was

children.prevalue: About last Sunday replied Noah considering Why I told yer that before

children.prevalue: Again Tell it again cried Fagin tightening his grasp on Sikes and brandishing his other hand aloft as the foam flew from his lips

children.name: Paragraph_48
children.value: 'They asked her,' said Noah, who, as he grew more wakeful, seemed to have a dawning perception who Sikes was, 'they asked her why she didn't come, last Sunday, as she promised.  She said she couldn't.'
children.prevalue: They asked her said Noah who as he grew more wakeful seemed to have a dawning perception who Sikes was they asked her why she didn t come last Sunday as she promised She said she couldn t

children.name: Paragraph_49
children.value: 'Why--why?  Tell him that.'

children.name: Paragraph_50
children.value: 'Because she was forcibly kept at home by Bill, the man she had told them of before,' replied Noah.
children.prevalue: Because she was forcibly kept at home by Bill the man she had told them of before replied Noah

children.name: Paragraph_51
children.value: 'What more of him?' cried Fagin.  'What more of the man she had told them of before?  Tell him that, tell him that.'
children.prevalue: What more of him cried Fagin What more of the man she had told them of before Tell him that tell him that

children.name: Paragraph_52
children.value: 'Why, that she couldn't very easily get out of doors unless he knew where she was going to,' said Noah; 'and so the first time she went to see the lady, she--ha! ha! ha! it made me laugh when she said it, that it did--she gave him a drink of laudanum.'

children.prevalue: Bill Bill cried Fagin following him hastily A word Only a word

children.name: Paragraph_58

children.name: Paragraph_60
children.value: 'You won't be--too--violent, Bill?'
children.prevalue: You won t be too violent Bill

children.name: Paragraph_61
children.value: The day was breaking, and there was light enough for the men to see each other's faces.  They exchanged one brief glance; there was a fire in the eyes of both, which could not be mistaken.
children.prevalue: The day was breaking and there was light enough for the men to see each other s faces They exchanged one brief glance there was a fire in the eyes of both which could not be mistaken

children.name: Paragraph_62
children.value: 'I mean,' said Fagin, showing that he felt all disguise was now useless, 'not too violent for safety.  Be crafty, Bill, and not too bold.'
children.prevalue: I mean said Fagin showing that he felt all disguise was now useless not too violent for safety Be crafty Bill and not too bold

children.name: Paragraph_64
children.value: Without one pause, or moment's consideration; without once turning his head to the right or left, or raising his eyes to the sky, or lowering them to the ground, but looking straight before him with savage resolution:  his teeth so tightly compressed that the strained jaw seemed starting through his skin; the robber held on his headlong course, nor muttered a word, nor relaxed a muscle, until he reached his own door.  He opened it, softly, with a key; strode lightly up the stairs; and entering his own room, double-locked the door, and lifting a heavy table against it, drew back the curtain of the bed.

children.name: Paragraph_65
children.value: The girl was lying, half-dressed, upon it.  He had roused her from her sleep, for she raised herself with a hurried and startled look.
children.prevalue: The girl was lying half dressed upon it He had roused her from her sleep for she raised herself with a hurried and startled look

children.name: Paragraph_66
children.value: 'Get up!' said the man.
children.prevalue: Get up said the man

children.name: Paragraph_67
children.value: 'It is you, Bill!' said the girl, with an expression of pleasure at his return.
children.prevalue: It is you Bill said the girl with an expression of pleasure at his return

children.name: Paragraph_68
children.value: 'It is,' was the reply.  'Get up.'
children.prevalue: It is was the reply Get up

children.name: Paragraph_69
children.value: There was a candle burning, but the man hastily drew it from the candlestick, and hurled it under the grate.  Seeing the faint light of early day without, the girl rose to undraw the curtain.
children.prevalue: There was a candle burning but the man hastily drew it from the candlestick and hurled it under the grate Seeing the faint light of early day without the girl rose to undraw the curtain

children.name: Paragraph_70
children.value: 'Let it be,' said Sikes, thrusting his hand before her. 'There's enough light for wot I've got to do.'

children.name: Paragraph_71
children.value: 'Bill,' said the girl, in the low voice of alarm, 'why do you look like that at me!'
children.prevalue: Bill said the girl in the low voice of alarm why do you look like that at me

children.name: Paragraph_72
children.value: The robber sat regarding her, for a few seconds, with dilated nostrils and heaving breast; and then, grasping her by the head and throat, dragged her into the middle of the room, and looking once towards the door, placed his heavy hand upon her mouth.
children.prevalue: The robber sat regarding her for a few seconds with dilated nostrils and heaving breast and then grasping her by the head and throat dragged her into the middle of the room and looking once towards the door placed his heavy hand upon her mouth

children.name: Paragraph_73
children.value: 'Bill, Bill!' gasped the girl, wrestling with the strength of mortal fear,--'I--I won't scream or cry--not once--hear me--speak to me--tell me what I have done!'
children.prevalue: Bill Bill gasped the girl wrestling with the strength of mortal fear I I won t scream or cry not once hear me speak to me tell me what I have done

children.name: Paragraph_74
children.value: 'You know, you she devil!' returned the robber, suppressing his breath. 'You were watched to-night; every word you said was heard.'
children.prevalue: You know you she devil returned the robber suppressing his breath You were watched to night every word you said was heard

children.name: Paragraph_75
children.value: 'Then spare my life for the love of Heaven, as I spared yours,' rejoined the girl, clinging to him.  'Bill, dear Bill, you cannot have the heart to kill me.  Oh! think of all I have given up, only this one night, for you.  You shall have time to think, and save yourself this crime; I will not loose my hold, you cannot throw me off.  Bill, Bill, for dear God's sake, for your own, for mine, stop before you spill my blood!  I have been true to you, upon my guilty soul I have!'

children.name: Paragraph_76
children.value: The man struggled violently, to release his arms; but those of the girl were clasped round his, and tear her as he would, he could not tear them away.
children.prevalue: The man struggled violently to release his arms but those of the girl were clasped round his and tear her as he would he could not tear them away

children.name: Paragraph_77
children.value: 'Bill,' cried the girl, striving to lay her head upon his breast, 'the gentleman and that dear lady, told me to-night of a home in some foreign country where I could end my days in solitude and peace.  Let me see them again, and beg them, on my knees, to show the same mercy and goodness to you; and let us both leave this dreadful place, and far apart lead better lives, and forget how we have lived, except in prayers, and never see each other more. It is never too late to repent. They told me so--I feel it now--but we must have time--a little, little time!'

children.name: Paragraph_78
children.value: The housebreaker freed one arm, and grasped his pistol. The certainty of immediate detection if he fired, flashed across his mind even in the midst of his fury; and he beat it twice with all the force he could summon, upon the upturned face that almost touched his own.
children.prevalue: The housebreaker freed one arm and grasped his pistol The certainty of immediate detection if he fired flashed across his mind even in the midst of his fury and he beat it twice with all the force he could summon upon the upturned face that almost touched his own

children.name: Paragraph_79
children.value: She staggered and fell:  nearly blinded with the blood that rained down from a deep gash in her forehead; but raising herself, with difficulty, on her knees, drew from her bosom a white handkerchief--Rose Maylie's own--and holding it up, in her folded hands, as high towards Heaven as her feeble strength would allow, breathed one prayer for mercy to her Maker.

children.name: Paragraph_80
children.value: It was a ghastly figure to look upon.  The murderer staggering backward to the wall, and shutting out the sight with his hand, seized a heavy club and struck her down.
children.prevalue: It was a ghastly figure to look upon The murderer staggering backward to the wall and shutting out the sight with his hand seized a heavy club and struck her down

children.name: Paragraph_1
children.value: THE FLIGHT OF SIKES
children.prevalue: THE FLIGHT OF SIKES

children.name: Paragraph_2
children.value: Of all bad deeds that, under cover of the darkness, had been committed within wide London's bounds since night hung over it, that was the worst.  Of all the horrors that rose with an ill scent upon the morning air, that was the foulest and most cruel.
children.prevalue: Of all bad deeds that under cover of the darkness had been committed within wide London s bounds since night hung over it that was the worst Of all the horrors that rose with an ill scent upon the morning air that was the foulest and most cruel

children.name: Paragraph_3
children.value: The sun--the bright sun, that brings back, not light alone, but new life, and hope, and freshness to man--burst upon the crowded city in clear and radiant glory.  Through costly-coloured glass and paper-mended window, through cathedral dome and rotten crevice, it shed its equal ray.  It lighted up the room where the murdered woman lay. It did.  He tried to shut it out, but it would stream in.  If the sight had been a ghastly one in the dull morning, what was it, now, in all that brilliant light!
children.prevalue: The sun the bright sun that brings back not light alone but new life and hope and freshness to man burst upon the crowded city in clear and radiant glory Through costly coloured glass and paper mended window through cathedral dome and rotten crevice it shed its equal ray It lighted up the room where the murdered woman lay It did He tried to shut it out but it would stream in If the sight had been a ghastly one in the dull morning what was it now in all that brilliant light

children.name: Paragraph_4
children.value: He had not moved; he had been afraid to stir.  There had been a moan and motion of the hand; and, with terror added to rage, he had struck and struck again.  Once he threw a rug over it; but it was worse to fancy the eyes, and imagine them moving towards him, than to see them glaring upward, as if watching the reflection of the pool of gore that quivered and danced in the sunlight on the ceiling.  He had plucked it off again.  And there was the body--mere flesh and blood, no more--but such flesh, and so much blood!
children.prevalue: He had not moved he had been afraid to stir There had been a moan and motion of the hand and with terror added to rage he had struck and struck again Once he threw a rug over it but it was worse to fancy the eyes and imagine them moving towards him than to see them glaring upward as if watching the reflection of the pool of gore that quivered and danced in the sunlight on the ceiling He had plucked it off again And there was the body mere flesh and blood no more but such flesh and so much blood

children.name: Paragraph_5
children.value: He struck a light, kindled a fire, and thrust the club into it. There was hair upon the end, which blazed and shrunk into a light cinder, and, caught by the air, whirled up the chimney.  Even that frightened him, sturdy as he was; but he held the weapon till it broke, and then piled it on the coals to burn away, and smoulder into ashes.  He washed himself, and rubbed his clothes; there were spots that would not be removed, but he cut the pieces out, and burnt them.  How those stains were dispersed about the room!  The very feet of the dog were bloody.

children.name: Paragraph_6
children.value: All this time he had, never once, turned his back upon the corpse; no, not for a moment.  Such preparations completed, he moved, backward, towards the door:  dragging the dog with him, lest he should soil his feet anew and carry out new evidence of the crime into the streets. He shut the door softly, locked it, took the key, and left the house.
children.prevalue: All this time he had never once turned his back upon the corpse no not for a moment Such preparations completed he moved backward towards the door dragging the dog with him lest he should soil his feet anew and carry out new evidence of the crime into the streets He shut the door softly locked it took the key and left the house

children.name: Paragraph_7
children.value: He crossed over, and glanced up at the window, to be sure that nothing was visible from the outside.  There was the curtain still drawn, which she would have opened to admit the light she never saw again.  It lay nearly under there.  He knew that.  God, how the sun poured down upon the very spot!
children.prevalue: He crossed over and glanced up at the window to be sure that nothing was visible from the outside There was the curtain still drawn which she would have opened to admit the light she never saw again It lay nearly under there He knew that God how the sun poured down upon the very spot

children.name: Paragraph_8
children.value: The glance was instantaneous.  It was a relief to have got free of the room.  He whistled on the dog, and walked rapidly away.
children.prevalue: The glance was instantaneous It was a relief to have got free of the room He whistled on the dog and walked rapidly away

children.name: Paragraph_9
children.value: He went through Islington; strode up the hill at Highgate on which stands the stone in honour of Whittington; turned down to Highgate Hill, unsteady of purpose, and uncertain where to go; struck off to the right again, almost as soon as he began to descend it; and taking the foot-path across the fields, skirted Caen Wood, and so came on Hampstead Heath.  Traversing the hollow by the Vale of Heath, he mounted the opposite bank, and crossing the road which joins the villages of Hampstead and Highgate, made along the remaining portion of the heath to the fields at North End, in one of which he laid himself down under a hedge, and slept.

children.name: Paragraph_10
children.value: Soon he was up again, and away,--not far into the country, but back towards London by the high-road--then back again--then over another part of the same ground as he already traversed--then wandering up and down in fields, and lying on ditches' brinks to rest, and starting up to make for some other spot, and do the same, and ramble on again.
children.prevalue: Soon he was up again and away not far into the country but back towards London by the high road then back again then over another part of the same ground as he already traversed then wandering up and down in fields and lying on ditches brinks to rest and starting up to make for some other spot and do the same and ramble on again

children.name: Paragraph_11
children.value: Where could he go, that was near and not too public, to get some meat and drink?  Hendon.  That was a good place, not far off, and out of most people's way.  Thither he directed his steps,--running sometimes, and sometimes, with a strange perversity, loitering at a snail's pace, or stopping altogether and idly breaking the hedges with a stick.  But when he got there, all the people he met--the very children at the doors--seemed to view him with suspicion.  Back he turned again, without the courage to purchase bit or drop, though he had tasted no food for many hours; and once more he lingered on the Heath, uncertain where to go.
children.prevalue: Where could he go that was near and not too public to get some meat and drink Hendon That was a good place not far off and out of most people s way Thither he directed his steps running sometimes and sometimes with a strange perversity loitering at a snail s pace or stopping altogether and idly breaking the hedges with a stick But when he got there all the people he met the very children at the doors seemed to view him with suspicion Back he turned again without the courage to purchase bit or drop though he had tasted no food for many hours and once more he lingered on the Heath uncertain where to go

children.name: Paragraph_12
children.value: He wandered over miles and miles of ground, and still came back to the old place.  Morning and noon had passed, and the day was on the wane, and still he rambled to and fro, and up and down, and round and round, and still lingered about the same spot.  At last he got away, and shaped his course for Hatfield.
children.prevalue: He wandered over miles and miles of ground and still came back to the old place Morning and noon had passed and the day was on the wane and still he rambled to and fro and up and down and round and round and still lingered about the same spot At last he got away and shaped his course for Hatfield

children.name: Paragraph_13
children.value: It was nine o'clock at night, when the man, quite tired out, and the dog, limping and lame from the unaccustomed exercise, turned down the hill by the church of the quiet village, and plodding along the little street, crept into a small public-house, whose scanty light had guided them to the spot.  There was a fire in the tap-room, and some country-labourers were drinking before it.

children.name: Paragraph_14

children.name: Paragraph_15

children.name: Paragraph_16
children.value: There was nothing to attract attention, or excite alarm in this. The robber, after paying his reckoning, sat silent and unnoticed in his corner, and had almost dropped asleep, when he was half wakened by the noisy entrance of a new comer.

children.name: Paragraph_17
children.value: This was an antic fellow, half pedlar and half mountebank, who travelled about the country on foot to vend hones, strops, razors, washballs, harness-paste, medicine for dogs and horses, cheap perfumery, cosmetics, and such-like wares, which he carried in a case slung to his back.  His entrance was the signal for various homely jokes with the countrymen, which slackened not until he had made his supper, and opened his box of treasures, when he ingeniously contrived to unite business with amusement.

children.name: Paragraph_18
children.value: 'And what be that stoof?  Good to eat, Harry?' asked a grinning countryman, pointing to some composition-cakes in one corner.
children.prevalue: And what be that stoof Good to eat Harry asked a grinning countryman pointing to some composition cakes in one corner

children.name: Paragraph_19
children.value: 'This,' said the fellow, producing one, 'this is the infallible and invaluable composition for removing all sorts of stain, rust, dirt, mildew, spick, speck, spot, or spatter, from silk, satin, linen, cambric, cloth, crape, stuff, carpet, merino, muslin, bombazeen, or woollen stuff.  Wine-stains, fruit-stains, beer-stains, water-stains, paint-stains, pitch-stains, any stains, all come out at one rub with the infallible and invaluable composition.  If a lady stains her honour, she has only need to swallow one cake and she's cured at once--for it's poison.  If a gentleman wants to prove this, he has only need to bolt one little square, and he has put it beyond question--for it's quite as satisfactory as a pistol-bullet, and a great deal nastier in the flavour, consequently the more credit in taking it.  One penny a square.  With all these virtues, one penny a square!'

children.name: Paragraph_20
children.value: There were two buyers directly, and more of the listeners plainly hesitated.  The vendor observing this, increased in loquacity.

children.name: Paragraph_21
children.value: 'It's all bought up as fast as it can be made,' said the fellow. 'There are fourteen water-mills, six steam-engines, and a galvanic battery, always a-working upon it, and they can't make it fast enough, though the men work so hard that they die off, and the widows is pensioned directly, with twenty pound a-year for each of the children, and a premium of fifty for twins.  One penny a square!  Two half-pence is all the same, and four farthings is received with joy.  One penny a square! Wine-stains, fruit-stains, beer-stains, water-stains, paint-stains, pitch-stains, mud-stains, blood-stains!  Here is a stain upon the hat of a gentleman in company, that I'll take clean out, before he can order me a pint of ale.'

He almost knew what was to come; but he crossed over, and listened.

children.name: Paragraph_38
children.value: Sikes remained standing in the street, apparently unmoved by what he had just heard, and agitated by no stronger feeling than a doubt where to go.  At length he went back again, and took the road which leads from Hatfield to St. Albans.
